Sharjah (إِمَارَة ٱلشَّارِقَة ar) is one of the seven emirate of the United Arab Emirates.

[[Bob Sebra]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, American baseball players, Cincinnati Reds players, Disease-related deaths in Florida, Milwaukee Brewers players, Montreal Expos players, People from Ridgewood, New Jersey, Philadelphia Phillies players, Sportspeople from New Jersey, Texas Rangers players

Robert Bush Sebra (December 11, 1961 – July 22, 2020) was an American professional baseball player. He played as a pitcher. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1985 to 1990, for the Texas Rangers, Montreal Expos, Philadelphia Phillies, Cincinnati Reds and Milwaukee Brewers. He threw and batted right-handed. He was born in Ridgewood, New Jersey.

On July 22, 2020, Sebra died from multiple organ failure in Miami, Florida. He was 58.

[[Madang big-eyed tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The Madang big-eyed tree frog  (Nyctimystes disruptus)  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  It also used to be called Richard's big-eyed tree frog.  Scientists have seen it in mountain ranges in central and eastern New Guinea, though they think it could live in other places as well.  They found it 1500 to 2000 meters above sea level.

Scientists say this frog looks a lot like the Papua big-eyed tree frog but with more webbing on its feet and clearer lines on its lower eyelids.  This frog has short, broken lines on its lower eyelids.  This frog has pupils in its eyes that go up and down and open side to side.  It can be many different colors.  Scientists have found frogs that are brown with white spots, gray with purple marks and green with brown markings on the back.  The adult male frog is about 7.4 cm long and the adult female is about 8.0 cm long.

For a while, scientists thought another group of frogs, Nyctimystes oktediensis, was a separate species, but other scientists say these frogs are also Madang big-eyed tree frogs.

In the local Kaironk language, this frog is called kwyos and gepgep.

[[Al-Hasakah Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Syria

Al-Hasakah Governorate (Muḥāfaẓat al-Ḥasakah, Parêzgeha Hesîçe, Huparkiyo d'Ḥasake, also known as Gozarto) is one of the fourteen governorates of Syria. Its capital is Al-Hasakah.

Quneitra Governorate (مُحافظة القنيطرة ar) is one of the fourteen governorates of Syria. Its capital is Quneitra.

Richmond County is a county in the U.S. state of North Carolina. In 2010, 46,639 people lived there. Its county seat is Rockingham.

[[Aidlingen]]

[[Giuoco Piano]]

CATEGORIES: Chess openings

The Giuoco Piano (Italian for quiet game) is a chess opening deriving from the Italian Game and beginning with the moves:

The Giuoco Piano is one of the oldest recorded chess openings. It is also known as the Italian Opening. It can lead to such variations as the Giuoco Pianissimo or the Evans Gambit.

[[Fayette, Mississippi]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Mississippi, County seats in Mississippi

Fayette is a city in Jefferson County, Mississippi, United States. The population was 1,614 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Jefferson County.

[[Brandon, Mississippi]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Mississippi, County seats in Mississippi

Brandon is a city in Rankin County, Mississippi, United States. The population was 21,705 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Rankin County. Brandon is part of the Jackson Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[111 West 57th Street]]

CATEGORIES: Skyscrapers in New York City, Buildings and structures in Manhattan

111 West 57th Street, also known as the Steinway Tower, is a building developed by JDS Development Group and Property Markets Group in Midtown Manhattan, New York City. It is a 84 story building 1,428 feet (438 meter) tall. It is located on 57th Street near Sixth Avenue.

This tower will be one of the tallest buildings in the United States after it is finished. It will be the thinnest building in the world with a width-to-height ratio of about 1:24. The north side of the building rises straight to the top. The south side of the building contains some step-backs near the top.

Construction began in early 2014. The building's roof was done in April 2019. It will open by 2021.

[[Louis L'Amour]]

CATEGORIES: Writers from North Dakota, American science fiction writers, Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients, Writers from Los Angeles, California, Deaths from lung cancer, Congressional Gold Medal recipients, Cancer deaths in California, 20th-century American novelists, 1988 deaths, 1908 births

Louis Dearborn L'Amour (ˈ; March 22, 1908 – June 10, 1988) was an American novelist and short-story writer. His books contains primarily focused onn Western novels (though he called his work "frontier stories"); however, he also wrote historical fiction (The Walking Drum), science fiction (Haunted Mesa), non-fiction (Frontier), as well as poetry and short-story collections. he published not more than a hundred stories and also he was given the Golden Plate Award of the American Academy of Achievement in 1979. after his death, his wife Katie and his children Beau and Angelique still using his name.

[[Jos Bax]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch footballers, People from Eindhoven, Sportspeople from North Brabant

Jos Bax (29 March 1946 – July 2020) was a Dutch professional footballer. He played as a goalkeeper for RPC, Eindhoven, Helmond Sport, VVV, Overpelt and VOS. His career lasted from 1965 to 1976.

Bax died in July 2020, aged 74.

[[Zacharias Chaliabalias]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Greek footballers

Zacharias Chaliabalias (Ζαχαρίας Χαλιαμπάλιας; 8 March 1946 – 22 July 2020) was a Greek international footballer. He spent his entire career with Iraklis playing as a centre-back from 1964 to 1975. He also played for the national team between 1968 to 1972.

Chaliabalias was born in Thessaloniki, Greece. He died in Thessaloniki on 22 July 2020, aged 74.

[[Dino De Poli]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Italian lawyers, Italian politicians

Dino De Poli (24 August 1929 – 22 July 2020) was an  Italian lawyer and politician. De Poli was born in Treviso, Italy. De Poli was elected to a single term as a member of the Chamber of Deputies in 1968, representing Christian Democracy. 

He later was one of the founding leaders of the Cassamarca Foundation from 1992 to 2018. 

De Poli died on 22 July 2020, aged 90.

[[Alexander Gusev (ice hockey)]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Russian ice hockey players, Soviet Olympic gold medalists, Sportspeople from Moscow

Alexander Vladimirovich Gusev (Александр Владимирович Гусев; 21 January 1947 – 22 July 2020) was a Russian Soviet ice hockey player. He participated at the 1976 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, where the Soviet team won the gold  medal. He was born in Moscow.

Vladimirovich Gusev died on 22 July 2020, aged 73. 

[[Carlton Haselrig]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Pittsburgh Steelers players, New York Jets players, American professional wrestlers, Mixed martial artists, Sportspeople from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, People from Johnstown, Pennsylvania

Carlton Lee Haselrig (January 22, 1966 – July 22, 2020) was an American heavyweight wrestler and NFL player. Haselrig wrestled for University of Pittsburgh at Johnstown. Haselrig then moved on to professional football, where he played five seasons in the NFL. He played for the Pittsburgh Steelers and the New York Jets. Haselrig was born in Johnstown, Pennsylvania.

Haselrig died on July 22, 2020 in Johnstown, aged 54.

[[Roland Desné]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, French philosophers, French historians

Roland Desné (24 April 1931 – 9 July 2020) was a French writer, philosopher, and historian. In the 1960's, he worked with Pierre Abraham to publish Histoire litteraire de la France published in 12 volumes by Éditions sociales.

Desné became involved with study and research for the Supreme Council of the Scottish Rite. In 1989, he helped organize the celebration of the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution.

Desné died in Paris on 9 July 2020 at the age of 89.

[[Tom Mitchell (Irish politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Irish politicians

Thomas James Mitchell (29 July 1931 – July 2020) was an Irish republican. He was active in the Irish Republican Army. While in jail he was twice elected as a Member of the United Kingdom Parliament, but was disqualified and his elections were not counted.

Mitchell died in July 2020, shortly before his 89th birthday.

[[Stanley Robinson]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, 2020 deaths, African-American basketball players, Sportspeople from Birmingham, Alabama

Stanley Earl Robinson (July 14, 1988 – July 21, 2020) was an American professional basketball player. He last played for the Español de Talca of the Liga Nacional de Básquetbol de Chile. He was born in Birmingham, Alabama. From 2011 to 2012, he played for Iowa Energy. Robinson played college basketball with the Connecticut Huskies.

Robinson died on July 21, 2020, a week after his 32nd birthday, at his home in Birmingham.

[[Chito Soganub]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s births, 2020 deaths, Crime victims, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Filipino people, Roman Catholic priests

Fr. Teresito "Chito" Suganob (1960/1961 – July 22, 2020) was a Filipino Roman Catholic priest. 

He became well known after he was taken hostage by ISIL-linked Maute group militants during the earlier period of the Battle of Marawi in May 2017. Suganob along with a Dansalan College teacher who was also taken hostage escaped early morning of September 17, 2017 from their captors and were found by the military who rescued them near the Bato Ali mosque. 

Suganob was from Lambunao, Iloilo.

Suganob died from cardiac arrest on July 22, 2020 at the age of 59.

[[Vivienne Westwood]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, British fashion designers, British activists, British businesspeople, People from Cheshire

Dame Vivienne Isabel Westwood GBR (née Swire; born 8 April 1941) is a British fashion designer, political activist and businesswoman. She is known for bringing modern punk and new wave fashions into the mainstream. Westwood was born in Tintwistle, Cheshire.

[[Defence Colony]]

Defence colony is the part of newly formed district SOUTH EAST DELHI. It is one of the three tehsils of south east district. areas like Lajpat nagar, Kotla mubarakpur, ,New friends colony, moolchand,Jangpura, South extension 1,2,3 , etc.... are part of this tehsil.

[[Sarita Vihar]]

Sarita vihar is the part of South East district of NCT DELHI. It is one of the three tehsils of south east delhi. Areas like Badarpur, Jaitpur, Shaheen bagh, Jamia nagar, madanpur khadar , Jasola,etc... are part of the tehsil.

[[Ralph Liguori]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, American racecar drivers, NASCAR drivers, Sportspeople from New York City

Ralph Liguori (October 10, 1926 – July 22, 2020) was an American racing driver. He was born in New York City.

He competed in the USAC Championship Car series from 1957 to 1971 making 61 starts. His best finish was 2nd place at the Indiana State Fairgrounds Speedway in 1970.  

Liguori competed in 76 NASCAR Grand National Series races in his career. He had 30 Top 10 and 5 Top 5 finishes in his career.

Liguori died on July 22, 2020 at the age of 93.

[[Ragaa Al Geddawy]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Egypt, Egyptian movie actors, Egyptian television actors, Models

Ragaa Al Geddawy (رجاء الجداوي; 6 September 1934 – 5 July 2020) was an Egyptian actress and model. Her career lasted for sixty years. She was born in Ismailia, Egypt. Her best known roles were as Amna's friend in the Academy Award-nominated movie The Nightingale's Prayer (1959) and as Samiha's friend in A Rumor of Love (1960).

Al Geddawy died on July 5, 2020 at a hospital in Ismailia from COVID-19, aged 85.

[[Nawaf Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Emirs of Kuwait, Current national leaders

Sheikh Nawaf Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah (الشيخ نواف الأحمد الجابر الصباح Nawaf al-Ahmad al-Jābir as-Sabāh, born 25 June 1937) is the Emir of Kuwait following the death of Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber on 29 September 2020. He was the Deputy Commander of the Military of Kuwait. 

He is a half-brother of the Emir of Kuwait, Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah. 

Nawaf was nominated as Crown Prince on 7 February 2006 against the tradition of the Al-Sabah family.

[[Nadja West]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, American physicians, American generals, Scientists from Washington, D.C.

Nadja Yudith West (née Grammer; March 20, 1961) is a retired United States Army lieutenant general. She was the 44th U.S. Army Surgeon General and former Commanding General of the U.S. Army Medical Command. West was born in Washington, D.C..

West, a physician, was the first black Army Surgeon General, and was the first black female active-duty major general and the first black female major general in Army Medicine. 

West is also the first Army black female lieutenant general. She is the highest ranking woman to have graduated from the United States Military Academy.

[[Nadja Tiller]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, Austrian movie actors, Austrian television actors, Austrian stage actors, Models, Actors from Vienna

Nadja Tiller (born March 16, 1929) is an Austrian actress. She was one of the most popular Austrian actresses and was well known during the 1950s and 1960s. She was born in Vienna.

Her best known roles were Ich suche Dich (1955) and Rosemary (1958). She won the Miss Austria competition in 1949.

[[Ichiyo Shimizu]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Japanese sportspeople, Sportswomen, People from Tokyo, Living people

Ichiyo Shimizu (清水市代, Shimizu Ichiyo, born January 9, 1969) is a Japanese women's professional shogi player ranked 7-dan. She became the first women's professional to be promoted to the rank of women's 6-dan and obtain 40 women titles. She is also the second women's professional to win 600 official games.

[[John Schneider]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, American country singers, American guitarists, American country musicians, Actors from New York, Screenwriters from New York, Movie producers from New York, Movie directors from New York, Singers from New York, Musicians from New York, People from Mount Kisco, New York

[[The Dukes of Hazzard]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 television series debuts, 1985 television series endings, American comedy television series, English-language television programs

The Dukes of Hazzard is an American action-comedy television series that was aired on CBS from January 26, 1979 to February 8, 1985. The show aired for 147 episodes spanning seven seasons.

The show is about two young male cousins, Bo and Luke Duke, who live in Georgia and are on probation for moonshine-running. The young men and their friends and their female cousin Daisy Duke, and other family escape many times from corrupt law officers Boss Hogg and Sheriff Rosco P. Coltrane.

The series was inspired by the 1975 movie Moonrunners. The show was the plot for a movie of the same title in 2005.

The show starred Tom Wopat as Luke, John Schneider as Bo, Catherine Bach as Daisy, Denver Pyle as Jesse, Ben Jones as Cooter, James Best as Sheriff Rosco P. Coltrane, and Sorrell Booke as Boss Jefferson Davis "J.D." Hogg with Sonny Shroyer as Deputy Sheriff Enos.

[[Christopher Mayer]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2011 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Christopher Mayer (born George Charles Mayer III; February 21, 1954 – July 23, 2011), also known as Chip Mayer, was an American actor. He was best known for playing Vance Duke on The Dukes of Hazzard for 19 episodes during season 5.

Mayer was found dead in his Los Angeles home in Sherman Oaks on July 23, 2011 at the age of 57.

[[Sonny Shroyer]]

Otis Burt "Sonny" Shroyer, Jr. (born August 28, 1935) is an American actor and singer. He is known for his role as Deputy Sheriff Enos Strate in the television series The Dukes of Hazzard. He also starred in a short-lived spin-off called Enos. He was born in Valdosta, Georgia.

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American playwrights, American essayists, United States representatives from Georgia, Politicians from North Carolina, Actors from North Carolina, Writers from North Carolina, Actors from Georgia (U.S. state), Writers from Georgia (U.S. state), US Democratic Party politicians

Jones was also in the United States House of Representatives from January 3, 1989 to January 3, 1993 as a Democrat.

Forreston is an unincorporated community in Ellis County, Texas, United States. It lies on U.S. Route 77 eight miles south of the county seat of Waxahachie. The population was 238 in 2008, but Forreston is not listed in the 2010 census.

[[Tom Wopat]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American people convicted of assault, Actors from Wisconsin, Singers from Wisconsin

Thomas Steven Wopat (born September 9, 1951) is an American actor and singer. He is known for his role as Lucas K. "Luke" Duke on the long-running television action/comedy series The Dukes of Hazzard. He had a small role as U.S. Marshal Gil Tatum in Django Unchained (2012). 

Wopat was arrested on August 2, 2017 on indecent assault and battery (felony) and drug (misdemeanor) charges in Waltham, Massachusetts. Wopat assaulted a woman after grabbing her buttocks and continued touching her in that area. 

On July 20, 2018, Wopat pleaded guilty to two counts of "annoying and accosting a person of the opposite sex" and was sentenced to one year of probation.

[[The Trial of the Chicago 7]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 movies, American crime drama movies, Netflix movies, Movies set in Chicago, Illinois, Movies shot in Chicago, Illinois, Movies based on real life events

The Trial of the Chicago 7 is an upcoming American crime drama movie written and directed by Aaron Sorkin. The movie stars Sacha Baron Cohen, Eddie Redmayne, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II, Jeremy Strong, Mark Rylance, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Kelvin Harrison Jr., Frank Langella, William Hurt, and Michael Keaton.

The movie is about the Chicago Seven, a group of anti-Vietnam War protesters charged with conspiracy in 1968. The movie was filmed in Chicago and New Jersey.

It was originally going to be release by Paramount Pictures. The rights to the movie were sold to Netflix due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Netflix will digitally release The Trial of the Chicago 7 on October 16, 2020.

[[Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial]]

CATEGORIES: Martin Luther King Jr., Buildings and structures in Washington, D.C.

The Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial is in West Potomac Park next to the National Mall in Washington, D.C., United States. 

It covers 4 and includes the Stone of Hope, a granite statue of Civil Rights Movement leader Martin Luther King. The inspiration for the memorial design is a line from King's "I Have A Dream" speech: "Out of the mountain of despair, a stone of hope."  

The memorial opened to the public on August 22, 2011, after more than twenty years of planning, fund-raising, and construction.

[[Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial]]

CATEGORIES: Franklin D. Roosevelt, Buildings and structures in Washington, D.C.

The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial is a presidential memorial in Washington D.C., dedicated to the memory of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the 32nd President of the United States. The memorial is the second of two that have been constructed in Washington to honor that president.

It was dedicated on May 2, 1997 by President Bill Clinton. The monument, spread over 7.5 near the southwest side of the Tidal Basin along the Cherry Tree Walk in West Potomac Park. 

The memorial honors the 12 years of the history of the United States through four outdoor rooms, one for each of FDR's terms of office. 

[[Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial]]

CATEGORIES: Dwight D. Eisenhower, Buildings and structures in Washington, D.C.

The Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial is a United States presidential memorial honoring Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in Europe during World War II and the 34th President of the United States. 

On October 25, 1999, the United States Congress created the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission, and charged it with creating "...an appropriate permanent memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower". 

An early design by architect Frank Gehry was controversial. After several years of hearings and several design changes by Gehry, final design approvals were given in 2015.

After more than a decade and a half of planning and controversy, Congress approved $150 million to the memorial in 2017 and on November 2, dignitaries held a groundbreaking ceremony at the four-acre site in Washington DC. 

The dedication was scheduled for May 8, 2020, the 75th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day, now postponed to September 17, 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

[[Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force]]

CATEGORIES: World War II, Dwight D. Eisenhower

Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force (SHAEF; ˈ SHAYF) was the headquarters of the Commander of Allied forces in north west Europe, from late 1943 until the end of World War II. 

U.S. General Dwight D. Eisenhower was the commander in SHAEF throughout its existence. The position itself is similar to that of Supreme Allied Commander Europe and Atlantic, but they are different titles.

[[David Cliche]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian businesspeople, Environmentalists, Deaths from brain cancer, Politicians from Quebec, Cancer deaths in Canada

David Cliche (July 10, 1952 – July 19, 2020) was a Canadian politician. He represented Vimont in the National Assembly of Quebec from 1994 to 2002. He was a member of the Parti Québécois. After leaving politics, he became an environmental businessman. Cliche was born in Saint-Joseph-de-Beauce, Quebec.

Cliche died of brain cancer on July 19, 2020 at his home in Saint-Étienne-de-Bolton, Quebec, aged 68.

[[Duško Popov]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 1981 deaths, Spies, Serbian people, Autobiographers

Dušan "Duško" Popov GBR (Душан "Душко" Попов; 10 July 1912 – 10 August 1981) was a Serbian triple spy agent. He worked as part of the MI6 and Abwehr during World War II, and passed off disinformation to Germany as part of the Double-Cross System and working also as agent for the Yugoslav government-in-exile in London.

Popov was known for his lifestyle and attracted women during his missions, including the French actress Simone Simon. 

Popov is believed to be one of Ian Fleming's primary inspirations for the character of James Bond.

[[Jeffrey Katzenberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Disney people, American chief executives, Democrats (United States), Movie producers from New York City

Jeffrey Katzenberg (ˈ; born December 21, 1950) is an American movie producer and media businessman. He was born in New York City. He was chairman of Walt Disney Studios from 1984 to 1994. He also co-founded DreamWorks Animation. In 2018, he founded the short-form media app Quibi.

He is a well known Democratic donor because he has donated to the political campaigns of Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama, Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren.

[[Stuart Wheeler]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stomach cancer, British activists, Businesspeople from London

John Stuart Wheeler (30 January 1935 – 23 July 2020) was a British financier and political activist.  He made his fortune as the founder of the spread betting firm IG Index in 1974. He was best known for his political activism, being a major donor to the Conservative Party and treasurer of the UK Independence Party from 2011 to 2014. He was born in London.

In June 2020, Wheeler announced that he had stomach cancer with only "six months to live". He died a month later on 23 July 2020 at his home in Chilham, Kent from the disease, aged 85.

[[University of Delhi]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in India, New Delhi, 1920s establishments in India, 1922 establishments

The University of Delhi, or Delhi University (DU), is a  public central university in the capital of India, New Delhi. It was founded in 1922. 

Internationally, the University of Delhi was ranked 474 in the QS World University Rankings of 2020. The same rankings ranked it 67 in Asia in 2020 and 42 among BRICS nations in 2019. It was ranked 601-800 in the world by the Times Higher Education World University Rankings of 2020.

[[Flora (mythology)]]

CATEGORIES: Roman gods and goddesses

Flora is the goddess of flowers and spring in Roman mythology.

The name Flōra descends from Proto-Italic *flōsā ('goddess of flowers'), itself a derivation from Proto-Italic *flōs ('flower'; cf. Latin flōs, flōris 'blossom, flower'). It is cognate with the Oscan goddess of flowers Fluusa, demonstrating that the cult was known more widely among Italic peoples. The name ultimately derives from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleh₃ōs ('blossoming').

Her festival, the Floralia, was held between April 28 and May 3 and symbolized the renewal of the cycle of life, drinking, and flowers. The festival was first instituted in 240 B.C.E, and on the advice of the Sibylline books, she was also given a temple in 238 B.C.E. At the festival, with the men decked in flowers, and the women wearing normally forbidden gay costumes, five days of farces and mimes were enacted – ithyphallic, and including nudity when called for – followed by a sixth day of the hunting of goats and hares. On May 23 another (rose) festival was held in her honor.

Flora's Greek equivalent is Chloris, who was a nymph. Flora is married to Favonius, the wind god also known as Zephyr, and her companion was Hercules.

Flora achieved more prominence in the neo-pagan revival of Antiquity among Renaissance humanists than she had ever enjoyed in ancient Rome.

[[Morobe big-eyed tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The Morobe big-eyed tree frog  (Nyctimystes trachydermis) is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  It lives in the mountains in the southeastern peninsula.  Scientists found it between 1280 and 2480 meters above sea level.

Scientists say this is one of the largest frogs in the genus Nyctimystes.  The male frog can grow to 8.8 cm long and scientists are not sure how large the female can be.  It has rough skin on its back and brown eyes.

[[Alexiares and Anicetus]]

CATEGORIES: Sibling duos, Twelve Olympians

Alexiares and Anicetus (Ἀλεξιάρης Alexiarês and Ανικητος Anikêtos) are minor deities in Greek Mythology. They are the immortal twin sons of Heracles, the greatest of the Greek heroes and the strongest mortal to live. Their mother was Hebe, the goddess of youth the server of Ambrosia and nectar to the other Olympian gods. Along with their father Heracles, they were the guardians of Mount Olympus, and the pair may have been regarded as the gatekeepers of Olympus, a role which was often assigned to their immortal father. Additionally, they were responsible for the protection and fortification of towns and citadels, they were also the gods of defense and sports. They were born after Hercules's mortal death and ascent to Olympus, where he gained immortality and married the goddess Hebe. Callimachus makes a reference to Hebe receiving assistance from her sister during the birth of her sons, Eiliethyia the goddess of midwives and childbirth. Their names mean "he who wards off war" and "the unconquerable one" respectively.

The twins were worshipped the most in Thebes and Rhodes, their powers were said to be youth and sports. Little is known about them besides a mention of their birth in the Bibliotheca: "Heracles achieved immortality, and when Hera’s enmity changed to friendship, he married her daughter Hebe, who bore him twin sons Alexiares and Anicetus."

[[Rockingham County, North Carolina]]

[[Watauga County, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: 1840s establishments in North Carolina, 1849 establishments in the United States, North Carolina counties

Watauga County is a county in the U.S. state of North Carolina. In 2010, 51,079 people lived there. Its county seat is Boone.

[[Keith Sonnier]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, American sculptors, Artists from New York, People from Louisiana

Keith Sonnier (July 31, 1941 – July 18, 2020) was an American postminimalist sculptor, performance artist, video and light artist. Sonnier was one of the first artists to use light in sculpture in the 1960s. Sonnier was a part of the Process Art movement. He was born in Mamou, Louisiana.

Sonnier died in Southampton, New York, on 18 July 2020 from colon cancer at the age of 78.

[[Bruce G. Blair]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, American educators, American political writers, American political activists, Researchers, Writers from Iowa, Writers from New Jersey, Writers from Illinois

Bruce G. Blair (November 16, 1947 – July 19, 2020) was an American nuclear security expert and a research scholar. He worked at the Program on Science and Global Security at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. His works focused on technical and policy steps on the path toward the elimination of nuclear weapons. He was co-founder of Global Zero.

Blair was born in Creston, Iowa. He died on July 19, 2020 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania from a stroke, aged 72.

[[Hümmel]]

Hümmel is a municipality in the district of Ahrweiler, in Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany.

[[Doug Rogers (judoka)]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian Olympic silver medalists, Judoka, People from Nova Scotia

Alfred Harold Douglas "Doug" Rogers (January 26, 1941 – July 20, 2020) was a Canadian Olympic competitor in judo. He was the first Canadian to win an Olympic medal in the sport.  He was an honoured member in the Canadian Sports Hall of Fame. He won a silver medal at the 1964 Summer Olympics and gold medals at two Pan American Games, in 1965 and 1967. He was born in Truro, Nova Scotia.

Rogers died on July 20, 2020 in Vancouver, aged 79.

[[John Blake (American football)]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, College football coaches, American football coaches, Sportspeople from Illinois, People from Rockford, Illinois

John Patrick Blake (March 6, 1961 – July 23, 2020) was an American football coach and player. He was the head football coach at the University of Oklahoma from 1996 to 1998.  Blake was also the defensive line coach of the Buffalo Bills. He also cocahed at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, from 2007 until 2010. Blake was born in Rockford, Illinois.

Blake died on July 23, 2020 at the age of 59 from a heart attack while walking in Tulsa, Oklahoma.

[[José Said]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Peruvian businesspeople, Chilean businesspeople

José Said (17 April 1930 – 23 July 2020) was a Peruvian-born Chilean businessman. He was the founder and CEO of Parque Arauco S.A.. It is one of the largest real estate developers and operators of shopping malls in both Chile and Argentina. Said was born in Arequipa, Peru.

Said died on 23 July 2020 in Santiago de Chile, aged 90.

[[Mahendra Yadav]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth missing, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians, Indian criminals

Mahendra Yadav (died July 5, 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a member of the Indian National Congress. He was an MLA from Delhi's Palam constituency from 1988 to 2003.  He was convicted in a 1984 anti-Sikh riots case and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.

Yadav died on 5 July 2020 from COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic. He had tested positive for the infection on June 26, 2020.

Nozay is a commune of 4,150 people (2017). It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Loire-Atlantique department in western France.

[[Swedish sj-sound]]

CATEGORIES: Swedish language, Linguistics

The Swedish sj-sound is represented by  in the IPA. It is most commonly spelled with Sj. Sk is the next most iconic spelling, but only occurs before e, i, y, ä, or ö. The spelling xj only occurs in the place name Växjö vɛːkɧœː. X is a combination of K and S, so Xj is basically "Ksj."

[[Wasting Light]]

CATEGORIES: 2011 albums, Grammy Award-winning albums, Rock albums

Wasting Light is the seventh studio album by American rock band Foo Fighters. It was released on April 12, 2011 on Roswell and RCA Records. It was the first Foo Fighters album with guitarist Pat Smear playing on it since The Colour and the Shape (1997) as a member. He did play on Echoes, Silence, Patience & Grace (2007) as a guest.

When making the album, the band did not want to use digital recording as they wanted to sound how they did in their first albums. The album was made in the garage of Dave Grohl, the lead singer and guitarist of the band. The house was in Encino, California. The album was made on only analog equipment. It was produced by Butch Vig. Vig had worked with Grohl in 1991 and 1992 to produce Nirvana's album Nevermind. The band spent three weeks making sure they could play the songs well before recording, as no mistakes can be fixed after recording on analog equipment. There were also guests who played on the album, such as Bob Mould, Krist Novoselic, Jessy Greene, Rami Jaffee and Fee Waybill.

Six singles were released from the album. The most successful was Rope, which went straight to number one on Billboard's Rock Songs chart. It was only the second ever single to go straight to number one on this chart. Wasting Light went straight to number one on the albums charts of twelve countries. Critics said mainly good things about the album, mainly about the production and songwriting. In 2012, Wasting Light won four Grammy Awards, including Best Rock Album.

[[Ross Dallow]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, New Zealand politicians, Police officers

Ross Philip Dallow NZL (4 December 1937 – 20 July 2020) was a senior member of the New Zealand Police. He was a very important person in improved race relations in Auckland. He was also an Auckland local politician serving as a member of the Auckland Council from 2010 to 2016.

Dallow died on 20 July 2020, aged 82.

[[François Amoudruz]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths

François Amoudruz (7 September 1926 – 21 July 2020) was a member of the French Resistance during World War II. He was born in Albertville, France. 

[[Mike Adams (columnist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, American political writers, American political commentators, American conservatives, American educators, Writers from Mississippi, Writers from Missouri, Writers from Texas

Mike S. Adams (October 30, 1964 – July 23, 2020) was an American conservative political columnist and writer. He was a professor at University of North Carolina Wilmington. He was born in Columbus, Mississippi. 

Adams' first book, Welcome to the Ivory Tower of Babel, was published in 2004. Later that year, Adams joined the faculty of Summit Ministries and taught why abortion was bad and defending First Amendment rights on college campuses. 

His third book Letters to a Young Progressive: How to Avoid Wasting Your Life Protesting Things You Don’t Understand was published by Regnery in 2013.

On July 23, 2020, Adams was found dead at his Wilmington, North Carolina at the age of 55.

[[Lavon, Texas]]

Lavon (l lə) is a city in Collin County, Texas, United States. The population was 2,219 at the 2010 census. 

[[Jean Brankart]]

CATEGORIES: Belgian cyclists, 1930 births, 2020 deaths

Jean Brankart (12 July 1930 – 23 July 2020) was a Belgian professional road bicycle racer. He was active from 1953 to 1960. In 1955, Brankart finished the 1955 Tour de France in second place, winning two stages. Brankart was born in Momalle, Belgium.

Brankart died on 23 July 2020, aged 90.

[[Éric de Cromières]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, French businesspeople, French sportspeople, Cancer deaths in France

Éric de Cromières (20 November 1953 – 23 July 2020) was a French sporting executive and manager for Michelin. He then worked as a sales manager and general manager until he retired from the company on 31 March 2015 after having served on the executive committee starting in 2005.

In 2006, de Cromières became a member of the board of directors of ASM Clermont Auvergne. In 2012, René Fontès chose him to be his replacement as Director of the rugby union club, and de Cromières began his term in 2013.

de Cromières died on 23 July 2020 of cancer at the age of 66.

[[Sérgio Ricardo]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian movie directors, Composers, Brazilian writers, People from São Paulo, Deaths from heart failure, Brazilian musicians, Pianists

João Lutfi (18 June 1932 – 23 July 2020), most commonly known as Sérgio Ricardo, was a Brazilian movie director and composer. He directed five movies between 1964 and 1974. He was born in Marília, São Paulo. He composed the score for Black God, White Devil (1964). In 1974, Ricardo directed The Night of the Scarecrow.

Ricardo died on 23 July 2020, aged 88, of heart failure in Rio de Janeiro.

[[Goldcrest]]

CATEGORIES: Passeriformes

The goldcrest (Regulus regulus) is a tiny passerine bird in the kinglet family. Its colourful golden crest feathers gives rise to its popular name. The scientific name, R. regulus, means king or knight. 

There are several subspecies. The bird has a very large distribution range: much of the Palearctic and the islands of Macaronesia and Iceland. Birds from the north and east of its breeding range migrate to winter further south.

The goldcrest breeds in coniferous woodland and in gardens, It builds its compact, three-layered nest on a tree branch. Ten to twelve eggs are incubated by the female alone. The chicks are fed by both parents, and second broods are common. 

This little bird is always on the move as it searches for insects to eat. In winter it is often found with flocks of tits. It may be killed by birds of prey or carry parasites, but its large range and population means it is doing quite well. It is not a  conservation concern.

[[Susan Silo]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, American voice actors, American television actors, American video game actors, American stage actors, American movie actors, Actors from New York City, Singers from New York City

Susan Silo (born July 27, 1942) is an American actress and singer. She is known for her work in voice over roles. She was born in New York City. 

Her famous roles are Wuya the Witch in Xiaolin Showdown, Dr Karbunkle in Biker Mice from Mars, White Queen on Pryde of the X-Men, multiple voices on What A Cartoon, Sue on Pac-Man and Tess on Zazoo U. 

She also played the roles of Mama Mousekewitz in Fievel's American Tails and Petaluma in The Smurfs.

[[The Night of the Scarecrow]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 drama movies, Brazilian movies

The Night of the Scarecrow (A Noite do Espantalho) is a 1974 Brazilian drama movie directed by Sérgio Ricardo and starring Geraldo Azevedo, Fátima Batista, Ana Lúcia Castro, Emmanuel Cavalcanti, Geórgia Maria.

[[Incubation]]

CATEGORIES: Birds, Reptiles, Animal husbandry

Incubation or brooding, is when oviparous (egg-laying) animals sit on their  eggs to hatch them. It also refers to the development of the embryo in the egg under good environmental conditions. 

Since birds are warm-blooded, they sit on the eggs to keep them warm. Reptiles and invertebrates are cold-blooded, and so need to keep their eggs in warm places. Sometimes even birds need the help of the Sun.

Many factors may be vital to the incubation. In some reptiles for example, no fixed temperature is necessary. However, the actual temperature determines the sex ratio of the offspring. In birds, by contrast, the sex of offspring is genetically determined, but a constant and particular temperature may be necessary for successful incubation.

In poultry, the act of sitting on eggs to incubate them is called 'brooding'. The action or tendency to sit on a clutch of eggs is also called broodiness.

Saffron is a yellowish orange color.

[[Ádria Santos]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, Blind people, Brazilian Paralympic bronze medalists, Paralympic gold medalists, Paralympic silver medalists, Sprinters

Ádria Santos (born 11 August 1974) is a former Brazilian Paralympic sprinter. She competed in category T11 events at six consecutive Paralympics from 1988 to 2008 and won at least one medal on each occasion. She was a final torch bearer at the 2016 Summer Paralympics opening ceremony.

She won Gold medals at the 1992 Summer Paralympics in the 100 meters, the 2000 Summer Paralympics in the 100 meters, and 200 meters, and 2004 Summer Paralympics in the 100 meters.

[[Maria Ligorio]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births

Maria Ligorio (born 25 June 1970 San Michele Salentino) is an Italian Paralympic athlete. She won a silver medal at the 2000 Summer Paralympic Games, in the 200 meters, and bronze medals at the 1996 Summer Paralympic Games, in the 400 meters and 200 meters. 

[[Sabrina Bulleri]]

Sabrina Bulleri (7 January 1959 - 18 April 2000, Ghezzano) was an Italian Paralympic athlete.

She won bronze medals at the 1984 Summer Paralympics, in the 4x400 meters, and 100 meters. She won gold medals at the 1988 Summer Paralympic Games in the 4x100 meters, 200 meters, and 100 meters. She won a bronze medal at the 4x200 meters.

[[Death-grip syndrome]]

CATEGORIES: Human sexuality

Death-grip syndrome means being unable to ejaculate when having sex because of aggressive masturbation.

[[Milena Balsamo]]

Milena Balsamo (born 26 January 1961 Bologna) was an Italian Paralympic athlete. She won a bronze medal at the 1984 Summer Paralympics, in the 4x400 meters, and silver medal at the 100 meters. She won a gold medal at the 1988 Summer Paralympic Games in the 4x100 meters, and bronze medal at the 4x200 meters.

For her sporting merits, she was awarded the Collare d'oro for sporting merit in 2015 by the Italian National Olympic Committee.

[[Agnese Grigio]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Italian sportspeople

Agnese Grigio (born 12 January 1963 Albignasego) was an Italian Paralympic athlete. She won a silver medal at the 1984 Summer Paralympics, in the Pentathlon, and bronze medal in the 800 meters. In 2014, she was awarded the Silver lion by the Veneto regional, Italian National Olympic Committee.

[[Emanuela Grigio]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Italian sportspeople

Emanuela Grigio (born 7 October 1964 Albignasego) is a former partially sighted Italian Paralympic athlete. She won a silver medal at the 1984 Summer Paralympics, in the 800 meters, and bronze medal in the 400 meters.

[[Angry white male]]

CATEGORIES: American culture, Conservatism, Men

"Angry white male" is an insult for white men holding conservative or right-wing views. The term is often used when talking about the politics of the United States.

The term mostly refers to a group which emerged in the early 1990s. They reacted to what they thought were injustices by the "affirmative action" quotas in the workplace. Such people are not necessarily Nazis or extremists.

[[Class traitor]]

CATEGORIES: Socialism, Marxism

A class traitor is someone who is thought to be working against the interests of the particular social class. The term is often used by socialists to describe members of the proletariat class who work for the bourgeoisie. Some examples of those who are seen as class traitors are: soldiers, police officers, strikebreakers, and those who help keep things the way things are right now, instead of working for change. However, some people think that anyone, including the bourgeois, can become class traitors.

The motives behind becoming a traitor to one's class can include: survival (taking up whatever wage is available), the belief that the person is of a higher class and so has political views that work against the working class, the pressure to follow rules and laws, or disagreeing with the view that society is divided up into classes that are fighting each other.

Karl Kautsky, a Marxist philosopher, first used the term. 

[[Copaganda]]

CATEGORIES: Law

Copaganda is when the media show police officers in a good way, and do not show the bad actions that they do. The word is a portmanteau of cop and propaganda, and is used by Black Lives Matter activists. Showing police in a good way is not thought to be true for many working class, indigenous, brown, and black people.

Since the George Floyd protests, the term has been used more to criticize the media.

[[Rajnath Singh]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, Hindus, Indian politicians, Bharatiya Janata Party politicians, Indian Hindus

Rajnath Singh (born 10 July 1951) is an Indian politician. He is the current Defence Minister since 2019. He is the former Home Minister of India in 2014-2019. He was the President of Bharatiya Janata Party twice from 2005 to 2009 and 2013 to 2014. He was also Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh from 2000 to 2002. He was a cabinet minister in Atal Bihari Vajpayee's Government.

[[Bruce Nestande]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Minneapolis, Minnesota, Politicians from California, US Republican Party politicians

Bruce Kenneth Nestande (January 28, 1938 – July 9, 2020) was an American politician. He was a Republican California State Assemblyman between 1973 to 1980. He was also an Orange County Supervisor. Nestande was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

Nestande died on July 9, 2020 in Newport Beach, California at the age of 82.

[[Mary Miller (actress)]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from Norfolk, English movie actors, English television actors, American stage actors, 1933 births, 2020 deaths

Mary Elizabeth Miller (27 December 1929 – 11 July 2020) was an English television and stage actress. She was a founding member of the National Theatre Company in 1963. Miller was born in Norfolk, England. In 1965, she played Diana Gibbs in "Other People's Lives", an instalment of the popular BBC Television police drama Dixon of Dock Green. She was given the role of Maggie Hobson in a 3 part BBC production of  Hobson's Choice.

Miller died on 11 July 2020, at the age of 90.

[[Mason Gaffney]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, American economists, Writers from New York, Writers from California

Merrill Mason Gaffney (October 18, 1923 – July 16, 2020) was an American economist. He was a major critic of Neoclassical economics from a Georgist point of view. After serving in the southwest Pacific during World War II. Gaffney was Professor of Economics at the University of California, Riverside beginning in 1976. He was born in New York.

Gaffney died on July 16, 2020 in Riverside, California at the age of 96.

[[People's National Assembly]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Algeria, National lower houses

The People's National Assembly (al-Majlis al-Sha'abi al-Watani) is the lower house of the Algerian Parliament. It is made of 462 members directly elected by the population. Of the 462 seats, 8 are reserved for Algerians living abroad. 

Members of the People's National Assembly are directly elected through proportional representation in multiple-member districts and serve terms lasting five years at a time. 

The minimum age required for election into the APN is 28.

[[Council of the Nation]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Algeria, National upper houses

The Council of the Nation  (majlis al'umma) is the upper house of the Algerian Parliament. It is made of 144 members, 2/3 of which are elected indirectly and 1/3 of which are appointed by the president.

Abdelkader Bensalah was elected as President of the Council of the Nation on July 2, 2002, re-elected on January 11, 2007 and January 10, 2008.

Zohra Drif was elected as Vice-president of the Council of the Nation on September 10, 2002, re-elected on March 7, 2007 and March 8, 2008.

[[Moussa Benhamadi]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Algeria, Algerian politicians, Researchers

Moussa Benhamadi (4 January 1953 – 17 July 2020) was an Algerian politician and researcher. He was a member of the National Liberation Front (FLN). He was born in Ras El Oued, Algeria. From 2008 to 2010, he was CEO of Algérie Télécom. From 2002 to 2007, he was a member of the People's National Assembly.

Benhamadi died on 17 July 2020 in Bordj Bou Arréridj, Algeria from COVID-19 at the age of 67.

[[Andrzej Strzelecki]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Polish movie actors, Polish television actors, Polish stage actors, Polish voice actors, Polish screenwriters, Polish comedians, Polish theatre directors, Polish educators, Writers from Warsaw

Andrzej Tadeusz Strzelecki (4 February 1952 – 17 July 2020), was a Polish actor, satirist, theatre director and screenwriter. He was the rector of the Aleksander Zelwerowicz National Academy of Dramatic Art in Warsaw in the years 2008 to 2016. He was born in Warsaw. His best known roles were in Klan, Battle of Warsaw 1920 and Barwy szczęścia.

Strzelecki died in Warsaw on 17 July 2020 from lung cancer, aged 68.

[[Franciszek Ziejka]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Polish historians, Polish educators

Franciszek Ziejka (3 October 1940 – 19 July 2020) was a Polish scholar and historian. His works focused in Polish literature. He was born in Radłów, Poland. Ziejka became a member of the Polish Academy of Learning in 1997 in Kraków. He was also a member of the Polish Academy of Sciences and the Polish PEN International Club.

Ziejka died on 19 July 2020 in Krakow, Poland at the age of 79.

[[Margaret McIver]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Australian Olympians, Equestrians, Sportspeople from Victoria (Australia)

Margaret Elizabeth McIver (7 August 1933 – 21 July 2020) was an Australian equestrian, dressage coach and judge. She was born in Gordon, Australia.

McIver was the first Australian to represent her country in dressage when she competed at the Los Angeles 1984 Olympics in the individual event. 

IcIver was an honorary life member of Equestrian Australia. 

In January 2000, she was awarded the Australian Sports Medal as the first Australian to compete at the Olympics in dressage.

She died on 21 July 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Charles Dewachtere]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian Olympians, People from Ghent

Charles Paul Dewachtere (22 December 1927 – 22 July 2020) was a Belgian long-distance runner. He competed in the marathon at the 1952 Summer Olympics. 

In 1951 he became Belgian champion in a race over 35 km, between Waregem and Ghent. He was born in Ghent, Belgium.

[[Lunatic]]

CATEGORIES: Law

Lunatic is an old term that was used to refer to a person with a mental illness, or a mental disability. The term goes back to the Latin word lunaticus, which means ' of the moon', or moonstruck. It was also used in English law until about 1930, when it was  replaced by "person of unsound mind". Starting 1959, English law speaks about "mental illness".

[[Luzius Wildhaber]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss politicians, Judges, European Union politicians

Luzius Wildhaber (18 January 1937 – 22 July 2020) was a Swiss judge. He was born in Basel. He was the first President of the European Court of Human Rights. Wildhaber was elected on 24 July 1998, and was in the office from 1 November 1998 to 18 January 2007.

Wildhaber died on 22 July 2020, aged 83.

[[Bernard Ładysz]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Polish singers, Polish movie actors, Polish television actors, Polish stage actors, Polish writers

Bernard Ładysz (24 July 1922 – 25 July 2020) was a Polish opera singer and actor.  His recordings include Lucia di Lammermoor (with Maria Callas) and The Devils of Loudon (with Tatiana Troyanos). He was born in Wilno, then Poland.

His best known roles were in The Doll (1968), Ziemia obiecana (1974), The Quack (1982), Pierścień i róża (1986) and Ogniem i mieczem (1999).

Ładysz died on 25 July 2020 in Warsaw, one day after his 98th birthday.

[[Emmanuel Farhi]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, 2020 deaths, French economists, French educators

Emmanuel Farhi (September 8, 1978 – July 23, 2020) was a French economist. He was a professor of economics at Harvard University. His research focused on macroeconomics and finance. He was a member of the French Economic Analysis Council to the French Prime Minister from 2010 to 2012.

Farhi died on July 23, 2020 at the age of 41.

[[Alan Garner (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, English footballers, Sportspeople from London

Alan Henry Garner (2 February 1951 – 23 July 2020) was an English professional footballer. He was best known as a player for Watford.

Garner only made two league appearances before moving on to Luton Town in 1971. Garner played 88 times in the league and helped Luton to promotion in 1973–74. 

At Watford, Garner became a key player, appearing 200 times in the league during his five years at Vicarage Road. His career later focused into non-League football with Barnet.

[[Tomas Joson III]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Filipino politicians, Filipino businesspeople, Filipino lawyers

Tomas Noriel Joson III (May 10, 1948 – July 23, 2020) was a Filipino politician, businessman and lawyer. He was a Governor of Nueva Ecija for one term from 1992 to 1995, and was re-elected for another three terms from 1998 to 2007. Joson was born in Santo Domingo, Nueva Ecija.

In 2019, Joson was found guilty of three counts of graft and sentenced to between six and ten years' imprisonment for each count. Joson was acquitted in 2020.

Joson died on July 23, 2020 at the age of 72.

[[Paolo Sassone-Corsi]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Italian biologists, Researchers, People from Naples

Paolo Sassone-Corsi (8 June 1956 – 23 July 2020) was an Italian researcher and molecular biologist. He was born in Naples, Italy. Sassone-Corsi's work largely focused on the implementation of molecular approaches for cell signaling, circadian rhythm, epigenetics, and the plasticity of the genome.

Sassone-Corsi died on 23 July 2020 in Irvine, California at the age of 64.

[[Azimzhan Askarov]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1951 births, Political activists, Journalists, Human rights activists, Kyrgyzstani people, Deaths from pneumonia, CPJ International Press Freedom Award winners

Azimzhan Askarov (Azimjon Asqarov, Азимжон Асқаров; 17 May 1951 – 25 July 2020) was an Uzbek Kyrgyzstani political activist. He founded the group Vozduh in 2002 to investigate police brutality. During the 2010 ethnic clashes.

[[Aleksandr Ivanitsky]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths by drowning, Soviet Olympic gold medalists, Wrestlers

Aleksandr Vladimirovich Ivanitsky (Александр Владимирович Иваницкий; 8 October 1937 – 22 July 2020) was a Soviet wrestler and Olympic champion in Freestyle wrestling. He won a gold medal at the 1964 Summer Olympics.

Ivanitsky died on 22 July 2020 from a possible drowning, aged 82.

[[Dominic Sonic]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, French singers

[[Jerry Taft]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, American meteorologists, Television personalities from Chicago

Jerry Taft (March 14, 1943 – July 23, 2020) was an American meteorologist and weather presenter. He was chief meteorologist for WLS-TV in Chicago. He worked for 34 years with WLS, and for 42 years as a broadcast meteorologist in the Chicago area. He retired in January 2018.

Taft died on July 23, 2020 in Chicago, aged 77.

[[Paulette Wilson]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, British activists

Paulette Wilson (1956 – 23 July 2020) was a British immigrant rights activist. She fought her own deportation to Jamaica and brought media attention to the human rights violations of the Windrush scandal. Under the terms of the British Nationality Act 1948, Wilson had arrived in England as citizens of the British Empire. 

In 2015, Wilson received notification from the government that she was an illegal immigrant and was required to leave the UK. Her housing and health care benefits were stopped. She became homeless and was denied the right to seek work. 

By 2017, Wilson was facing deportation. She had not returned to Jamaica for 50 years, but was arrested twice, detained in Yarl's Wood Detention Centre and then sent to the deportation centre at Heathrow Airport in October 2017. 

The Refugee and Migrant Centre of Wolverhampton persuaded her MP, Emma Reynolds, to stop the deportation at the last minute to allow Wilson more time to appeal to the Home Office. In 2018, she was officially granted leave to remain.

Wilson died on 23 July 2020 in Wolverhampton, West Midlands, England at the age of 64.

[[Ice Hockey Federation of the Republic of Azerbaijan]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 establishments in Azerbaijan, Ice hockey, Sport in Azerbaijan

The Ice Hockey Federation of the Republic of Azerbaijan is the Azerbaijani national ice hockey federation.

[[Zheng Shouren]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese scientists, Chinese engineers

Zheng Shouren (郑守仁; January 30, 1940 – July 24, 2020) was a Chinese engineer. He was the chief designer of the Three Gorges Dam. He had been a key person in the planning and design of the Yangtze River Basin for a long time. He had published more than 60 papers and 4 books. He was a member of the Communist Party of China.

[[Dick Bond (Kansas politician)]]

CATEGORIES: Kansas Republicans, State legislators of the United States, 1935 births, 2020 deaths, American lawyers, Businesspeople from Kansas, Politicians from Kansas

Richard Lee Bond  (September 18, 1935 – July 23, 2020) was an American banker, lawyer and Republican politician. He was born in Kansas City, Kansas. He was a member of the Kansas State Senate from 1987 to 2000. He was president of the senate between 1996 and 2000.

Bond died on July 23, 2020 in Overland Park, Kansas at the age of 84.

[[Rene Carpenter]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, American columnists, American feminist writers, American television personalities, Writers from Iowa

Rene Carpenter (April 12, 1928spndJuly 24, 2020) was an American newspaper columnist and television personality. She was the wife of Scott Carpenter, one of the Mercury Seven astronauts. She was part of the Astronaut Wives Club and was its last living member. She was born in Clinton, Iowa.

In 1968, she campaigned for Robert Kennedy. She had a syndicated women's page column, "A Woman, Still", and from 1972 to 1976, a television presenter, first with Everywoman, and then with Nine in the Morning. She worked for Committee for National Health Insurance.

Carpenter died on July 24, 2020, at a hospital in Denver from congestive heart failure, aged 92.  She was the last surviving member of the Astronaut Wives Club, after Annie Glenn died two months earlier.

[[Roberto Draghetti]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Rome, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors, Italian voice actors, Actors from Rome

Roberto Draghetti (24 August 1960 – 24 July 2020) was an Italian actor. He was born in Rome. He was known for being the official dubber of actors Jamie Foxx, Terry Crews and Idris Elba. He dubbed the voice of Maurice in the Madagascar franchise and Eddy in Ed, Edd n Eddy.

Draghetti died on 24 July 2020 after having suffered a heart attack. He was 59.

[[Dubbing (filmmaking)]]

CATEGORIES: Voice actors

Dubbing, mixing or re-recording, is a post-production process used in filmmaking and video production in which more recordings are lip-synced and "mixed" with original production sound to create the finished soundtrack.

These are often used to translate movies, television shows and video games into different languages using different voice actors.

[[Azerbaijan Futsal Premier League]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 establishments in Azerbaijan, Futsal, Sport in Azerbaijan

Azerbaijan Futsal Premier League is the premier futsal league in Azerbaijan.  It was founded in 1994. Organized by Association of Football Federations of Azerbaijan and is played under UEFA  rules, currently consists of 8 teams.

[[David Hagen]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from motor neurone disease, Scottish footballers

David James Hagen (5 May 1973 – 24 July 2020) was a Scottish professional footballer. He was born in Edinburgh, Scotland. Hagen began his career with Rangers, where he played 20 competitive games, before moving to Hearts.

Hagen joined Peterhead in 2004. This was to be his last senior club, before he joined junior side Bo'ness United in 2006, where he played for a year before retiring.

In July 2018, it was reported that Hagen was suffering from motor neuron disease. He died of the illness on 24 July 2020.

[[Ben Jipcho]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, Kenyan people, Olympic gold medalists, Competitors in athletics

Benjamin Wabura Jipcho (1 March 1943 – 24 July 2020) was a Kenyan track and field athlete. He won the silver medal in the 3000 metres steeplechase at the 1972 Summer Olympics. He was born in Mount Elgon District, Western Province in Kenya.

Jipcho died on 24 July 2020 from prostate cancer at a hospital in Eldoret, Kenya, aged 77.

[[Nejib Ben Khalfallah]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, 2020 deaths, Choreographers, Dancers, People from Tunis

Nejib Ben Khalfallah (نجيب بن خلف الله) (1967 – 24 July 2020) was a Tunisian dancer and choreographer. He was born in Tunis, Tunisia. From 1993 to 2020, he directed and staged choreographic shows. His best known works were Mnema (2012), Jardin d'amour (2014), Thala mon amour (2016), and Fausse couche (2017).

Khalfallah died on 24 July 2020 in Tunis.

[[National Assembly (Angola)]]

CATEGORIES: Angola, National legislatures

The National Assembly (Assembleia Nacional) is the legislative branch of the government of Angola. The National Assembly is a unicameral body. It is made up with 220 members: 130 members elected by representation and 90 members elected by provincial districts.

[[Kundi Paihama]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Angolan people, African politicians

Kundi Paihama (9 December 1944 – 24 July 2020) was an Angolan politician. He was Angola's Minister of Defense from 2002 to 2010. He was also a member of the National Assembly between 2018 to 2020. 

Paihama died in a private hospital in Luanda, Angola on 24 July 2020, aged 75.

[[Lotty Rosenfeld]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Chilean artists, People from Santiago

Carlota Eugenia Rosenfeld Villarreal (20 June 1943 – 24 July 2020), known as Lotty Rosenfeld, was a Chile artist. She was born in Santiago, Chile. She was active during the late 1970s during the time of the Chilean military coup d'etat. She carried out public art interventions in urban areas. She would use traffic signs in order to challenge viewers to rethink notions of public space and political agency. Her work has been seen in many countries throughout Latin America, and Internationally in places such as Europe, Japan, and Australia.

Rosenfeld died on 24 July 2020 in Santiago from lung cancer, aged 77.

[[Paul Van Roy]]

CATEGORIES: 1930s births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Belgian journalists, Belgian sportspeople, Basketball players

Paul Van Roy (1931/1932 – July 2020) was a Belgian basketball player and journalist. He was born in Niel, Belgium. He played for the Belgium men's national basketball team. He scored 75 points in 1 match.

Van Roy was for over 50 years a local news and sport journalist and correspondent for Gazet van Antwerpen. He wrote articles for the news agency until his death.

Van Roy died in July 2020, aged 88, from pancreatic cancer. His death was announced on 24 July 2020.

[[John Bingham, 7th Earl of Lucan]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Unexplained deaths, People declared dead in absentia, Missing people, Businesspeople from London

Richard John Bingham, 7th Earl of Lucan (born 18 December 1934 – disappeared 8 November 1974, declared dead 3 February 2016), commonly known as Lord Lucan, was a British peer. He disappeared after being suspected of murder.

[[Jan Verroken]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian mayors, Centenarians, Christelijke Volkspartij politicians, Flemish people, Former MEPs, MEPs for Belgium, People from East Flanders

Jan Verroken (30 January 1917 – 24 July 2020) was a Belgian politician. He was born in Melden, Belgium. He was a member of the Christelijke Volkspartij. He was a member of the Chamber of Representatives from 1950 to 1981. Verroken was a member of the European Parliament from 1979 to 1984. He was Mayor of Oudenaarde from 1983 to 1988.

Verroken died on 24 July 2020 in Mechelen, Belgium at the age of 103.

[[Victor Brandt]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American video game actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California

Victor Brandt (born September 19, 1942) is an American actor. Brandt was born in Los Angeles, California. He is known for being the voice of Master Pakku in Avatar: The Last Airbender, as Rupert Thorne in The Batman, and as General Crozier in Metalocalypse.

[[Elsevier]]

CATEGORIES: 19th century establishments in the Netherlands, 1880 establishments in Europe, Publishing companies, Companies of the Netherlands, Amsterdam

Elsevier is a Dutch publishing and analytics company specialized in scientific, medical and technical contents. It belongs to RELX Group.

[[Azerbaijan men's national basketball team]]

CATEGORIES: Azerbaijan national basketball team, Basketball in Azerbaijan, 1991 establishments in Azerbaijan

The Azerbaijan national basketball team (Azərbaycan milli baskebol komandası) is the national basketball team of Azerbaijan. The team is controlled by the Azerbaijan Basketball Federation. 

Azerbaijan has been a FIBA member since 1991, although they have not fielded a senior national team in any competition in over five years.

[[Ladies in Love]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 movies, 1930s comedy movies, 1930s romance movies, American romantic comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Edward H. Griffith

Ladies in Love is a 1936 American romantic comedy movie directed by Edward H. Griffith and based on the play of the same name by Leslie Bush-Fekete. It stars Janet Gaynor, Constance Bennett, Loretta Young, Simone Simon, Don Ameche, Paul Lukas, Tyrone Power, Virginia Field and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Manic Frustration]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 albums

Manic Frustration is the fifth studio album by American rock band Trouble. It was recorded in 1991 and released on 16 June 1992. The album had faster music than the albums they made before. Their older albums were slower and more like doom metal.

[[Trouble (band)]]

CATEGORIES: American rock bands, Musical groups from Illinois, 1970s establishments in Illinois, 1979 establishments in the United States

Trouble is an American rock band. They were started in 1979 in Aurora, Illinois. They are thought to be one of the main bands that started doom metal. They used sounds from British rock bands Black Sabbath and Judas Priest, as well as psychadelic rock bands from the 1970s. The main members of the band have been Eric Wagner (singer), Rick Wartell and Bruce Franklin (guitarists), and Jeff Olson (drums).

[[Hurricane Hanna (2020)]]

CATEGORIES: Hurricanes in Texas, Hurricanes in Mexico, 2020 in the United States, July 2020 events, August 2020 events

Hurricane Hanna was an Atlantic tropical cyclone. The storm threatened northern Mexico and south-central Texas.

Hanna struck Texas as a borderline Category 1/Category 2 hurricane on Saturday, July 25, 2020.

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Luxembourg

Neunhausen (Néngsen) is a former commune in Luxembourg. It was part of the canton of Wiltz.

On 1 January 2012, the commune was merged with Heiderscheid to form the commune of Esch-sur-Sûre.

[[Medernach]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Luxembourg

Medernach (Miedernach) is a former commune in Luxembourg. It was part of the canton of Diekirch.

On 1 January 2012, the commune was merged with Ermsdorf to form the new commune of Vallée de l'Ernz.

[[Heinerscheid]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Luxembourg

Heinerscheid (Hengescht) is a former commune in northern Luxembourg. It was part of the canton of Clervaux.

On 1 January 2012, the commune was merged with Munshausen to form the commune of Clervaux.

[[Vallée de l'Ernz]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 establishments in Europe, Communes in Luxembourg

Vallée de l'Ernz (Ärenzdall) is a commune in Luxembourg. It is part of the canton of Diekirch. It was created on 1 January 2012 from the former communes of Ermsdorf and Medernach.

As of 2019, 2,641 people live here.

[[Boevange-sur-Attert]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Luxembourg

Boevange-sur-Attert (Béiwen-Atert, Böwingen/Attert) is a former commune in Luxembourg. It was part of the canton of Mersch.

On 1 January 2018, the commune was merged with Tuntange to form the new commune of Helperknapp.

[[Helperknapp]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 establishments in Europe, Communes in Luxembourg

Helperknapp is a commune in Luxembourg. It is part of the canton of Mersch. It was created on 1 January 2018 from the former communes of Boevange-sur-Attert and Tuntange.

As of 2019, 4,241 people live here.

[[Litochoro]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Greece

Litochoro (Λιτόχωρο, Litóchoro; Katharevousa: Λιτόχωρον) is a town in the southern part of Greece.

[[Massader]]

CATEGORIES: Palestine

Massader of Palestine is the arm of the Palestinian Investment Fund for Development of Natural Resources and Infrastructure Projects. The company plays an important role in developing large-scale strategic projects that aim to develop and use Palestinian natural resources (hydrocarbon resources and renewable resources) and provide various sources of national energy sources, in addition to developing the basic infrastructure for the electricity sector, all with the aim of establishing a firm foundation for an independent Palestinian state. 

The company aims to develop the natural resources of Palestinian oil and gas, develop productive infrastructure for the electricity and water sectors, contribute to achieving economic independence in the energy and water sectors, reduce the level of dependence on imported supplies, contribute to enabling the development of heavy industries such as cement and steel.

[[When Ambrose Dared Walrus]]

CATEGORIES: 1915 movies, Silent movies, Short movies

When Ambrose Dared Walrus is a 1915 silent short film directed by Walter Wright.

The film was produced by the Keystone Film Company under the working title Fire Insurance Story. It was distributed by Mutual Film. It was released in the United States on July 12, 1915.

[[Nyctimystes cryptochrysos]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes cryptochrysos  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea. It lives on Fergusson Island between 900 and 1500 meters above sea level.  Scientists think it might also live in the D'Entrecasteaux Islands.

The adult male frog is 4.8 to 5.1 cm long and the adult female frog is 6.1 to 6.5 cm long.  Most of its back is a mixture of light brown and dark brown in color.  This frog has up-and-down lines on its lower eyelids and gold coloring on its legs and middle.

The scientific name of this species chryptochrysos comes from the Greek kryptos for "hidden" and chrysos for "gold," meaning the gold color on the middle of this frog's body.

[[The Freeze-Out]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 movies, 1920s western movies, American western movies, American silent movies, Movies directed by John Ford

The Freeze-Out is a 1921 American western movie directed by John  Ford and starring Harry Carey, Helen Ferguson, Joe Harris, Charles Le Moyne. It was distributed by Universal Pictures and is a lost movie.

[[22 Short Films About Springfield]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons (season 7) episodes, 1996 television episodes, Internet memes, Television episodes written by David X. Cohen

"22 Short Films About Springfield" is the 21st episode of the 7th season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on television on April 14, 1996. The episode is divided into 22 parts. Each part is a different story that shows how life is for the people in Springfield.

The name of the episode is based on the movie Thirty Two Short Films About Glenn Gould. The episode's story is based on the ending of a season 4 episode named "The Front". Many parts of the episode reference the film Pulp Fiction. A scene from the episode became an internet meme after two decades of when the episode was first shown on television.

[[Boško Marinko]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Serbian sportspeople, Wrestlers, Olympians

Boško Marinko (11 August 1939 – 18 July 2020) was a Serbian wrestler. He competed in the 1968 Summer Olympics and 1972 Summer Olympics.

Marinko died on 18 July 2020, aged 81.

[[Nina Andreyeva]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, People from Saint Petersburg, Russian chemists, Russian communists, Critics

Nina Aleksandrovna Andreyeva (Нина Александровна Андреева, 12 October 1938 – 24 July 2020) was a Russian chemist, teacher, author, political activist, and social critic. She criticized General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev and his closest supporters for not being true communists.

Andreyeva died in St. Petersburg, Russia on 24 July 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Flor Isava Fonseca]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Venezuelan writers, Journalists

Flor Isava Fonseca (20 May 1921 – 25 July 2020)  was a Venezuelan sportswoman, journalist and writer. She was the vice president of the Venezuelan Red Cross.

In 1981, Isava-Fonseca and Finnish Pirjo Häggman were the first women to be elected to the International Olympic Committee. She was the first woman to be on the executive board in 1990.

Fonseca died on 25 July 2020, aged 99.

[[José Mentor]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian politicians, Brazilian lawyers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil

José Mentor Guilherme de Mello Netto (30 September 1948 – 25 July 2020), better known simply as José Mentor, was a Brazilian lawyer and politician. He was a Federal Deputy from 2003 to 2019. Mentor was a member of the Workers' Party.

Mentor died on 25 July 2020 in São Paulo from COVID-19, aged 71.

[[Maurice Petty]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Engineers from North Carolina, NASCAR, Businesspeople from North Carolina, Sportspeople from North Carolina

Maurice Petty (March 27, 1939spndJuly 25, 2020) was an American NASCAR crew chief and engine builder. He worked for Petty Enterprises, of which he was part owner.  He was added into the International Motorsports Hall of Fame in 2011.  He was honored into the NASCAR Hall of Fame in 2014. He was the first engine builder to be honored in that Hall. Petty was born in Randolph County, North Carolina. Petty was the younger brother of Richard Petty.

Petty died on the morning of July 25, 2020, at the age of 81.

[[Luciano Fabio Stirati]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Italian politicians

Luciano Fabio Stirati (15 December 1922 – 25 July 2020) was an Italian politician. Stirati was born in Gubbio, Italy. He represented the Italian Socialist Party for two nonconsecutive terms. He was a member of the Senate, from 1963 to 1968, and from 1972 to 1976. 

Stirati died on 25 July 2020 at a hospital in the Province of Perugia at the age of 97.

[[Order of Queen Maria Luisa]]

CATEGORIES: Order of Noble Ladies of Queen Maria Luisa

The Order of Queen Maria Luisa  or "Royal Order of Noble Ladies of Queen Maria Luisa" was an Order created by King King Carlos IV of Spain by ryal decree in Aprile 21 1792, at the request of his dominating wife, Queen Maria Luisa, to reward noble women who distinguished themselves for their services and talents. As such, it was established as an honour reserved only for women. The "Grand Mistress" of the order was the wife and thus the queen consort of Spain. The "Grand Mistress" would decide which woman would become a member of the order. It is one of about four orders reserved for women. Others include the Order of Saint Elisabeth (Bavaria) as well as the Order of Saint Catherine (Russia) and the Order of the Starry Cross (Holy Roman Empire)

[[John Tucker Must Die]]

CATEGORIES: 2006 romance movies, 2006 comedy movies, 2000s romantic comedy movies, 2000s teen comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, American teen comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies

John Tucker Must Die is a 2006 American teen romantic comedy movie directed by Betty Thomas. The movie is about a trio of girls who plot to break the heart of manipulative basketball star John Tucker after they learn he has been secretly dating all three and pledging each is "the one". They recruit cute wallflower Kate in their scheme to publicly humiliate the main male lead. The movie made $68 million worldwide. It stars Jesse Metcalfe, Brittany Snow, Ashanti, Sophia Bush, Arielle Kebbel, Penn Badgley, Jenny McCarthy and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Nyctimystes dux]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes dux  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists have only seen it near Yuwong Village on the Huon Peninsula.  Different scientists disagree about whether this frog should be in the genus Litoria or Nyctimystes.

This frog has red eyes and pads, called nuptual pads, on its front feet.

Some scientists think that Nyctimystes dux is a separate species.  Other scientists think it is the same species as Litoria graminea.

[[Application layer gateway]]

CATEGORIES: Computer networking

An application layer gateway is a special firewall which does stateful packet inspection. Some protocols such as TFTP use ports chosen at random. An application layer gateway can strengthen such a system by only allowing communication on ports which are used by one of the sessions. Note that this setup is different from a proxy firewall (also called application layer firewall). Such a firewall will also look at the payload data being transmitted.

[[MacOS Big Sur]]

CATEGORIES: MacOS

macOS Big Sur (version 11.0) is the seventeenth major version of macOS, Apple Inc.'s desktop operating system for Macintosh computers. It is the successor to macOS Catalina. macOS Big Sur was announced at WWDC 2020 on June 3, 2020.

[[NGC 4589]]

CATEGORIES: Elliptical galaxies

NGC 4589 is an elliptical galaxy in the Draco constellation. It is about 108 million light-years away from Earth.
