[[Malaysian Investment Development Authority]]

CATEGORIES: Malaysia

The Malaysian Industry Development Authority (MIDA) is the main government agency for improving the manufacturing and services sector in Malaysia and is listed under the Malaysia Industrial Development Authority Act. The authority assists companies that intend to invest in the industrial and services sector and facilitate the implementation of its projects. It includes the wide range of services that MIDA provides, in addition to providing information on investment opportunities, as well as facilitating companies looking for joint venture partners.

[[Nyctimystes eucavatus]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes eucavatus  is a tree frog from eastern Papua New Guinea.  Scientists found it between 800 and 1200 meters above sea level in the eastern mountains.

This frog lays eggs that are about 2.2 mm long.

[[Hamilton, Georgia]]

Hamilton is a city in the U.S. state of Georgia. It is the county seat of Harris County.

[[Ingrian language]]

CATEGORIES: Finnic languages, Languages of Russia

Ingrian, also called Izhorian, is a Finnic language spoken in Ingria, Russia. It is almost extinct, as it only has about 142 native speakers left. Most of these are elderly. This has happened because many people who speak Finnish moved there, meaning most people in Ingria now speak Finnish.

[[Ancenis]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Loire-Atlantique, Subprefectures in France

[[Sonni Hönscheid]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, German sportspeople, Surfers

Sonja "Sonni" Hönscheid (born 27 May 1981) is a German professional surfer. She is a three time champion in stand up paddling (SUP), and a twelve times German champion in surfing. She won the 2019 International Canoe Federation (ICF) Stand Up Paddling championship.

She won the Molokai 2 Oahu Paddleboard World Championships, in 2014, 2015 and 2016. She won the 2019 Carolina Cup.

[[Ancenis-Saint-Géréon]]

Ancenis-Saint-Géréon is a commune of 10,802 people (2017). It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Loire-Atlantique department in western France. It was created on 1 January 2019 from the former communes of Ancenis (the seat) and Saint-Géréon.

[[Cahit Sıtkı Tarancı]]

Cahit Sıtkı Tarancı (4 October 1910 Diyarbakır - 12 October 1956 Vienna) Turkish poet, writer and interpreter. He was the one of the important poet on Turkish Poetry on Republic era.

[[Ali Sami Yen]]

CATEGORIES: 1888 births, 1951 deaths, Turkish footballers, Turkish football managers, People from Istanbul

Ali Sami Yen (20 May 1888 – 29 July 1951) was a Turkish football player, coach and manager. He was the founder and first president of Galatasaray S.K.

When he was a student at Galatasaray High School, he and his colleagues decided to start a football club. On October 1905, they started Galatasaray S.K. and he became founding member number 1.

[[New and Renewable Energy Authority]]

CATEGORIES: Egypt, Renewable energy

New and Renewable Energy Authority (NREA) is the government institution which is responsible for the promotion and development of renewable energy projects which include solar and wind energy in Egypt. The main role of the authority is providing research and development for new and renewable energy projects. NREA is affiliated with many energy projects which includes Zafarana wind farm the first wind farm in Egypt and Africa, Jabal al-Zeit wind farm, Benban solar park and others.

Recently, The Authority worked in a project (The Migratory Soaring Birds (MSB)) to protect the migrating birds with the ministry of environment. In 2020 the project awarded the International Energy Prize for saving millions of birds from death by colliding with wind turbines in Jabal al-Zeit wind farm north of Hurghada. 

[[Dumat Al-Jandal Wind Farm]]

CATEGORIES: Wind farms

Dumat Al-Jandal Wind Farm is the first wind farm in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, located in Dumat Al-Jandal in the Al-Jouf region, northwest of Saudi Arabia, about 1046 km north of the capital Riyadh. The cost of the Dumat Al-Jandal wind power plant is $ 500 million, and after the construction works are completed, the station will be able to generate sustainable energy sufficient for about 70,000 housing units. The "Dumat Al-Jandal" project was chosen as the first wind energy project in Saudi Arabia, after studies showed a strong mixture of wind capabilities at the project site, so that the expected average production for the wind station is about 1.4 Terawatts.

The project was granted based on the standard cost of electricity, which equals 2.3 cents per kilowatt hour, which was a new record for a project of this kind in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Dumat Al-Jandal wind farm will provide electric power according to a 20-year energy purchase agreement with the Saudi Energy Purchase Company, a subsidiary of the Saudi Electricity Company, the agency responsible for generating and distributing energy in Saudi Arabia.

[[Arizona (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 movies, 1930s romance movies, 1930s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by George B. Seitz

Arizona is a 1931 American romantic drama movie directed by George B. Seitz and was based on the play of the same name by Augustus Thomas. It stars John Wayne, Laura Le Plante, June Clyde, Forrest Stanley, Nina Quartero, Susan Fleming and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Two brothers islands]]

CATEGORIES: Seas of the Indian Ocean

Al-Akhawayn Islands which means The two brothers island (Arabic: جزيرة الأخوين) sometimes called " The older brother and the younger brother islands" are one of the Red Sea islands. “Al-Akhawain” are located between Safaga and Al-Qusair, and it is one of the best coral and shark gatherings, and one of the best diving areas.

That islands were mentioned by the French marine scientist "Jacques Cousteau" in his book The Silent World, due to the nature of island which a unique scene of coral reefs and crystal clear waters, in addition to the wreckage of two sunken ships, Numidia and Aida, which made these two islands an attractive place for fans of underwater photography.

The waters around the island Characterized by the presence of whale shark (locally called "Bahloul") which is human friendly and facilitating taking photos with the divers.

The Red Sea Reserves Sector has issued guidelines to deal with the whale shark, including warnings against trying to touch, ride or chase the whale shark, as well as trying to change its movement path to allow the whale shark to move and act naturally, maintain a distance of at least 3 meters in-front of it , 4 meters behind it. the Red Sea Reserves prohibited also the use of a flash photography that annoys the shark.

[[Zkara]]

CATEGORIES: Arab people

The Zkara (in Arabic : الذكرة or الزكرة, in Berber : ⵡⵜⵎⵏ Utamen, in English : The Masculines) are an arab-speaker Zenati Berber tribe established in the northeast region of Morocco, in the eastern region, 25 km southwest of Oujda, in the Mestferki commune, not far from the closed border between Morocco and Algeria.This name is not exclusive to them.

Aubrey David Nicholas Jasper de Grey (born 20 April 1963) is an English author. He is the Chief Science Officer of the SENS Research Foundation and VP of New Technology Discovery at AgeX Therapeutics, Inc.

[[Guy Lutgen]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian mayors, Parti social-chrétien politicians, People from Luxembourg (Belgium), Walloon politicians

Guy Lutgen (19 April 1936 – 26 July 2020) was a Belgian politician. He was a member of Christian Social Party. He was the Minister of Agriculture from 1988 to 1999. He was a Senator  between 1977 to 1995. Lutgen was Mayor of Bastogne (1976–2000).

Lutgen died on 26 July 2020, aged 84.

[[Francisco Frutos]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish politicians

Francisco "Paco" Frutos Gras (6 September 1939 – 26 July 2020) was a Spanish politician. From 1998 until 2009, he was the Secretary-General of the Communist Party of Spain (PCE). He was born in Calella, Spain.

He died on 26 July 2020, aged 80.

[[Edmund Ansin]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, American billionaires, Businesspeople from Massachusetts

Edmund N. Ansin (March 9, 1936 – July 26, 2020) was an American billionaire. He was co-founder of Sunbeam Television. Ansin was born in Worcester, Massachusetts. In March 2014, his net worth was $1.4 billion.

Ansin died on July 26, 2020 in Miami Beach, Florida at the age of 84.

[[Summerfest]]

CATEGORIES: Milwaukee, Wisconsin

Summerfest is an annual music festival held in downtown Milwaukee, Wisconsin. It was first held in 1968. Summerfest is located at Henry Maier Festival Park. Summerfest has about 800,000 people come each year. It calls itself "The World's Largest Music Festival". The title was verified by the Guinness World Records in 1999.

[[Eddie Shack]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Boston Bruins players, Buffalo Sabres players, Canadian ice hockey left wingers, Canadian ice hockey right wingers, Deaths from throat cancer, Ice hockey people from Ontario, Los Angeles Kings players, New York Rangers players, Pittsburgh Penguins players, Stanley Cup champions, Toronto Maple Leafs players

Edward Steven Phillip Shack (February 11, 1937 – July 25, 2020), also known by his nicknames "The Entertainer" and "The Nose", was a Canadian professional ice hockey player. He played for six National Hockey League (NHL) teams from 1959 to 1975. He spent eight and a half seasons of his career with the Toronto Maple Leafs, with whom he won the Stanley Cup in 1962, 1963, 1964, and 1967.

He also played for the New York Rangers, Boston Bruins, Los Angeles Kings, Buffalo Sabres and the Pittsburgh Penguins. Shack was born in Greater Sudbury, Ontario.

Shack died on July 25, 2020 from throat cancer at a hospital in Toronto at the age of 83.

[[Janell Smith]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, American Olympians, American track and field athletes, Sportspeople from Texas

Linda Janell Carson (nee Smith, May 3, 1947 – July 25, 2020) was an American sprinter. She competed in the women's 400 metres at the 1964 Summer Olympics. She was born in Killeen, Texas.

Smith died of cancer on July 25, 2020 at the age of 73.

[[Noel Jenke]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from surgical complications, Minnesota Vikings players, Atlanta Falcons players, Green Bay Packers players, American football linebackers, Sportspeople from Minneapolis, Minnesota

Noel Charles Jenke (December 17, 1946 – July 23, 2020) was an American football linebacker in the National Football League (NFL). He played for three different teams during the 1971 through 1974 seasons. The teams were the Minnesota Vikings, Atlanta Falcons and the Green Bay Packers. Before playing professional football, Jenke was a minor league baseball player in the Boston Red Sox organization. 

Jenke was born in Owatonna, Minnesota. He died on July 23, 2020 from surgery-related problems in Minneapolis at the age of 73.

[[Wouter Snijders]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch academics, Dutch jurists, Judges, People from Hilversum

Wouter Snijders (26 May 1928 – 21 July 2020) was a Dutch judge and legal scholar. He was justice on the Supreme Court of the Netherlands between 1970 and 1986 and was vice president from 1986 to 1998. He was born in Hilversum, Netherlands.

Snijders died on 21 July 2020 in The Hague, aged 92.

[[Supreme Court of the Netherlands]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of the Netherlands, National supreme courts

The Supreme Court of the Netherlands (Hoge Raad der Nederlanden ˈɦoːɣə raːt dɛr ˈneːdərlɑndə(n) or simply Hoge Raad), officially the High Council of the Netherlands, is the final court of appeal in civil, criminal and tax cases in the Netherlands. It was created on 1 October 1838 and is located in The Hague.

The Supreme Court is made up of 36 judges: a president, six vice presidents, twenty-five justices (raadsheren, literally "Lords of the Council") and four justices extraordinary (buitengewone dienst). 

All judges are appointed for life, until they retire.

[[Ejike Obumneme Aghanya]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Nigerian military people

Ejike Ebenezer Obumneme Aghanya (27 November 1932 – 3 July 2020) was a Nigerian military officer and electrical engineer. He was in the Nigerian Army and the Biafran Armed Forces, retiring as a Colonel. 

He was accused of being part of the 1966 Nigerian coup d'état. He was arrested and imprisoned without trial until the outbreak of the Nigerian Civil War where he worked in key jobs in the Biafran Armed Forces. He was the head of the Biafran Agency for Research and Production (RAP). 

Later he was the Chief of Staff of the Biafran Organisation of Freedom Fighters (BOFF) which was the guerrilla warfare and special operations arm of the Biafran Armed Forces. 

He also was Battalion Commander, 44th Electrical and Mechanical Engineer Battalion Biafran Army and later Brigade Commander of the 58th Brigade of 12th Infantry Division Biafran Army during the war.

Aghanya died on 3 July 2020 in Atlanta, Georgia at the age of 87.

[[Nagindas Sanghavi]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, Centenarians, Indian writers, Indian educators, Columnists, Political writers

Nagindas Sanghavi (10 March 1920 ― 12 July 2020) was an Indian political professor, author and columnist. His works were written in English, Hindi and Gujarati. He received Padma Shri, India's fourth highest civilian honour in 2019.

Sanghavi started his teaching career at Bhavan's College, Andheri in 1951. He later moved to Ruparel College, Mahim and Mithibai College, Vile Parle teaching political science. He retired in 1980.

Sanghavi died on 12 July 2020 at the age of 100.

[[Chaumes-en-Retz]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Loire-Atlantique

Chaumes-en-Retz is a commune of 6,759 people (2017). It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Loire-Atlantique department in western France.  The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 from the former communes of Arthon-en-Retz (the seat) and Chéméré.

[[Divatte-sur-Loire]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Loire-Atlantique

Divatte-sur-Loire (Diwazh-Liger) is a commune of 6,844 people (2017). It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Loire-Atlantique department in western France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 from the former communes of La Chapelle-Basse-Mer (the seat) and Barbechat.

[[Vallons-de-l'Erdre]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 establishments in France, Communes in Loire-Atlantique

Vallons-de-l'Erdre is a commune of 6,556 people (2017). It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Loire-Atlantique department in western France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2018 from the former communes of Saint-Mars-la-Jaille (the seat), Bonnœuvre, Freigné (part of the department of Maine-et-Loire before 2018), Maumusson, Saint-Sulpice-des-Landes and Vritz.

[[Loireauxence]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Loire-Atlantique

Loireauxence is a commune of 7,522 people (2017). It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Loire-Atlantique department in western France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 from the former communes of Varades (the seat), Belligné, La Chapelle-Saint-Sauveur and La Rouxière.

[[Kaironk big-eyed tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The Kaironk big-eyed tree frog (Nyctimystes foricula)  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.

The adult male frog is 4.0 cm long and the adult female is 5.0 cm long.  This frog is bright green and sometimes has white spots.  It has a white or yellow belly.  The veins in its eyes are gold in color.  It lives in forests near small streams where the water flows quickly. Scientists found it between 1000 and 2000 meters above sea level.

In the local Kaironk language, this frog is called gojmay.

[[Smile (Katy Perry album)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 albums, Katy Perry albums, Pop albums

Smile is the sixth studio album by American recording artist Katy Perry.  It will be released on August 28, 2020.  It was originally planned for released on August 14, but Perry announced that production delays pushed the album back two weeks.

The previously-released singles "Never Really Over" and "Harleys in Hawaii" are included on the album.

[[Northern New Guinea tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The Northern New Guinea tree frog (Nytimystes gramineus) is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.

This is a canopy-dwelling frog, meaning it lives high in the branches of the trees where the leaves grow.  For a while, scientists thought Litoria dux was a different species, but some scientists now think Litoria dux is part of Litoria graminea.

[[Bart on the Road]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons (season 7) episodes, 1996 television episodes

"Bart on the Road" is the 20th episode of the 7th season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on television on March 31, 1996. In the episode, Bart gets a fake driver's license and takes his friends to Knoxville, Tennessee. However, Bart's car gets destroyed and Homer must use a courier to get Bart and his friends back to Springfield. 

The episode makes references to the movie Naked Lunch, singer Andy Williams, and the Look magazine.

[[List of George Polk Award winners]]

CATEGORIES: American journalists, Journalism awards

The George Polk Awards in Journalism are prizes given every year by Long Island University in New York.

[[Historic counties of Wales]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Wales

The thirteen historic counties of Wales have been used for many purposes for hundreds of years. Today, the counties are different, and there are now 22 principal areas instead. Some of the names of the old counties are used in the principal areas. The historic counties can also be called "ancient counties".

[[Katyń (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 drama movies, Polish movies, World War II movies, Movies directed by Andrzej Wajda

Katyń is a 2007 Polish movie about the 1940 Katyn massacre. It was directed by Andrzej Wajda.

[[Magda Kósáné Kovács]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Former MEPs, Politicians from Budapest

Magda Kósáné Kovács (November 4, 1940 – July 27, 2020) was a Hungarian politician. He was a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the Hungarian Socialist Party, part of the Party of European Socialists from 2004 to 2009. She joined Democratic Coalition in 2011.

Kósáné Kovács died in Budapest on July 27, 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Primal Scream]]

CATEGORIES: Scottish musical groups

Primal Scream are a Scottish rock band originally formed in 1982 in Glasgow by Bobby Gillespie (vocals) and Jim Beattie. 

The band's current band members are Gillespie, Andrew Innes (guitar), Martin Duffy (keyboards), Simone Butler (bass), and Darrin Mooney (drums). 

Primal Scream had been performing live from 1982 to 1984, but their career did not take off until Gillespie left his position as drummer of The Jesus and Mary Chain. 

The band were a key part of the mid-1980s indie pop scene. They later made psychedelic and garage rock music, before using a dance music element to their sound with their 1991 album Screamadelica. Their latest album Chaosmosis was released on 18 March 2016.

[[William Hill (Hong Kong athlete)]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Male athletes, Olympians, Sprinters

William Hill (11 June 1945 – 27 July 2020) was a Hong Kong sprinter. He competed in the men's 200 and 400 metres at the 1964 Summer Olympics.

Hill died on 27 July 2020, aged 75.

[[Chris Needs]]

CATEGORIES: 1950s births, 2020 deaths, BBC people, Welsh entertainers, Radio personalities, Deaths from cardiovascular disease

Christopher Needs, MBE (12 March 1954 – 26 July 2020) was a Welsh radio broadcaster. Needs was best known as a regular evening and daytime presenter on BBC Radio Wales. He was born in Cwmafan, Neath Port Talbot.

Needs died on 26 July 2020 from heart disease, aged 66.

[[Alain Cacheux]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, French politicians, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Alain Cacheux (November 15, 1947 – July 26, 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the National Assembly of France from 1997 to 2002 and again from 2007 to 2012.  He represented the Nord department. He was a member of the Socialiste, radical, citoyen et divers gauche.

Cacheux died of a heart attack on July 26, 2020 at the age of 72.

[[Rafael Barraza Sánchez]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, Mexican people

Rafael Barraza Sánchez (24 October 1928 – 26 July 2020) was a Mexican Roman Catholic bishop. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1951. He was titular bishop of Drivastum and as auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Durango, Mexico, from 1979 to 1981. He then was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Mazatlán, Mexico, from 1981 to 2005.

Barraza Sánchez died on 26 July 2020, aged 91.

[[Jim Abbott (Canadian politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Toronto

The Honourable James Abbott, CAN (August 18, 1942 – July 26, 2020) was a Canadian politician. He was a Conservative member of the House of Commons of Canada. Abbott was a member of the Reform Party from 1993 to 2000 and a member of the Canadian Alliance from 2000 to 2004.  

Before retiring, Abbott was the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for International Cooperation (Canada). On October 15, 2007, he was sworn in as a member of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada.

Abbott died on July 26, 2020, at the age of 77.

[[Kansai Yamamoto]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from acute myeloid leukemia, Japanese businesspeople, Fashion designers

Kansai Yamamoto (8 February 1944 – 21 July 2020) was a Japanese fashion designer. He was well known during the 1970s and 1980s.

In 1971, he opened his own company, Yamamoto Kansai Company, Ltd., Tokyo. His first collection debuted the same year in London and the United States at Hess's Department Store in Allentown, Pennsylvania.

Kansai became well known for creating stage costumes for David Bowie, mainly during his Ziggy Stardust Tour.

Yamamoto died on 21 July 2020 from acute myeloid leukemia at the age of 76.

[[Brad Watson]]

CATEGORIES: Writers from Mississippi, American novelists, Writers from Wyoming, American educators, 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure

Wilton Brad Watson (July 24, 1955spndJuly 8, 2020) was an American author and academic. He was a professor at the University of Wyoming until his death. Watson published four books, two novels and two collections of short stories. He was born in Meridian, Mississippi. Watson's 2002 novel The Heaven of Mercury was a finalist for the National Book Award. In 2013, Watson received the Award in Letters from The American Academy of Arts and Letters.

Watson died on July 8, 2020, at his home in Laramie, Wyoming from heart failure, aged 64.  

[[W. C. Handy]]

CATEGORIES: 1873 births, 1958 deaths, Deaths from bronchopneumonia, American composers, American educators, American songwriters, American blues musicians, Musicians from Alabama, Writers from Alabama, People from Florence, Alabama

William Christopher Handy (November 16, 1873 – March 28, 1958) was an American composer and musician who referred to himself as the Father of the Blues. Handy was one of the most important songwriters in the United States. He was known as one of the first singers to publish music American blues music.

[[To Each His Own (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies directed by Mitchell Leisen

To Each His Own is a 1946 American drama romance movie directed by Mitchell Leisen and starring Olivia de Havilland. The screenplay was written by Charles Brackett and Jacques Théry. The movie is about a young woman who gives birth to a child out of wedlock and has to give him up.

De Havilland won the Academy Award for Best Actress. Brackett was nominated for Best Writing, Original Story. The title song became a hit.

[[Confirm or Deny]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 movies, 1940s war movies, 1940s drama movies, American drama movies, World War II movies, Movies directed by Fritz Lang, Movies directed by Archie Mayo

Confirm or Deny is a 1941 American World War II drama movie directed by Archie Mayo and Fritz Lang (uncredited). It stars Don Ameche, Joan Bennett, Roddy McDowall, Raymond Walburn, John Loder, Arthur Shields, Queenie Leonard and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal]]

CATEGORIES: Political scandals

The 1Malaysia Development Berhad scandal is a political scandal that is taking place in Malaysia. In 2015, Prime Minister Najib Razak was accused of sending over 2672000000 Malaysian ringgit (about US$700000000) from 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a government-run company that was made to develop the country's economy, to his own bank accounts. Many Malaysians called for Najib to resign because they did not want a corrupt prime minister. In 2018, Najib was defeated in an election by Mahathir Mohamad.

A Malaysian politician, Anwar Ibrahim, has asked questions about the true purpose of 1MDB. He told Parliament that the company "has no business address and no appointed auditor" to check the company's finances.  According to records, 1MDB has nearly RM 42 billion (US$11.73 billion) in debt.

[[The Girl Who Knew Too Much (1963 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 movies, Italian movies, Movies set in Rome

The Girl Who Knew Too Much (La ragazza che sapeva troppo) is a 1963 Italian giallo movie. It was directed by Italian filmmaker Mario Bava. The movie stars John Saxon as Dr. Marcello Bassi and Letícia Román as Nora Davis.. 

The plot is about a young woman named Nora, who travels to Rome and  witnesses a murder. The police and Dr. Bassi don't believe her since a corpse can't be found. Several more murders follow, tied to a decade-long string of killings of victims chosen in alphabetical order.

[[Letícia Román]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors, Italian voice actors, Actors from Rome

Letícia Román (born 12 August 1941) is an Italian actress. She was born in Rome. Román had her first leading role in the movie  The Girl Who Knew Too Much (1963). She also starred in Russ Meyer's Fanny Hill.

[[Prakash Ambedkar]]

CATEGORIES: Indian politicians, Ambedkarites, Indian lawyers

Prakash Yashwant Ambedkar (born 10 May 1954), also known as Adv. Balasaheb Ambedkar, is an Indian politician, lawyer and social activist. He became Member of Parliament of India (MP) three times, two times in Lok Sabha and one time in Rajya Sabha. He is the grandson of Babasaheb Ambedkar, the father of the Indian constitution. He is the founder and the president of political party called the Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi.

[[Unistʼotʼen Camp]]

The Unistʼotʼen Camp (pronounced OO-nis-TAH-den) is a camp built on the territory of the Unist'otʼen clan of the Wetʼsuwetʼen Nation. It is in northern British Columbia, Canada. It is located at the point where several planned energy pipelines will pass, as a means to block the crossing of Wetʼsuwetʼen territory by pipeline-related industries. It is at the point where several planned energy pipelines will pass.

The camp is 1200 by road from Vancouver, BC and about 130 from the town of Smithers, BC.

The Wetʼsuwetʼen have built a checkpoint some 20 east of the camp on the Morice River Forest Services Road. At this point, visitors must have permission to enter the territory. They have banned construction workers and equipment from coming in. In 2019, the Coastal GasLink Pipeline went to court to enforce the permission granted by the Wetʼsuwetʼen and other First Nations band councils to build in the area. A court decision in 2020 gave an injunction against the Unisʼtotʼen clan and its supporters. In February 2020, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) took down the blockades and checkpoints. After the RCMP's actions, there have been protests across Canada supporting the Wetʼsuwetʼen.

[[Angela Spook]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, German entertainers, People from Düsseldorf

Angelika Tampier known under the name Angela Spook (14 March 1954 – 20 July 2020) was a German witch and street performer. She became known as "Hexe von der Kö" (translated: "Witch of the Kö") for her public appearance on Düsseldorf's Königsallee for 25 years in a witch costume.

Spook died on 20 July 2020 from an illness, aged 66.

[[Ortillon]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Aube

Ortillon is a commune of the Aube département in the north-central part of France.

[[Kumkum (actress)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Indian movie actors, Indian television actors, Indian stage actors, People from Bihar

Kumkum (born Zaibunnissa; 22 April 1934 – 28 July 2020) was an Indian actress. She was born in Hussainabad, Sheikhpura district, Bihar. From 1954 to 1973, she appeared in 115 movies. Her best known roles were in Ganga Maiyya Tohe Piyari Chadhaibo, Mr. X in Bombay and Gunah Aur Kanoon.

Kumkum died on 28 July 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Israfil Alam]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Bangladesh, Bangladeshi politicians, Bangladeshi Muslims

Israfil Alam (13 March 1966 – 27 July 2020) was a Bangladesh Awami League politician. He was a member of the Jatiya Sangsad from 2009 until his death. He was born in Naogaon, Pakistan.

Alam died on 27 July 2020 at a hospital in Dhaka from COVID-19, aged 54.

[[Muhammad Asad Malik]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Field hockey players, Pakistani people, Olympic gold medalists, Olympic silver medalists, Road accident deaths

Muhammad Asad Malik (October 30, 1941 – July 27, 2020) was a Pakistani field hockey player. He won a silver medal at the 1964 Summer Olympics, a gold medal at the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City, and a silver medal at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich.

Malik was killed in a car crash on July 27, 2020, at the age of 78.

[[Ronald L. Schwary]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from multiple system atrophy, American movie producers, American movie directors, Businesspeople from Oregon

Ronald Louis Schwary (May 23, 1944 – July 2, 2020) was an American producer and director. He was known for producing Ordinary People (for which he won an Academy Award for Best Picture), Sabrina, Havana and Random Hearts. He was born in The Dalles, Oregon.

Schwary died July 2, 2020 in Hollywood, California from multiple system atrophy at the age of 76.

[[Frank A. Howard]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, State legislators of the United States, American police officers, Politicians from Louisiana, US Republican Party politicians

Frank "Frankie" A. Howard (December 1, 1938 – July 27, 2020) was an American law enforcement officer and politician. He was a member of the Louisiana House of Representatives from 2008 to 2020. Howard was born in Hornbeck, Louisiana. He was a member of the Republican Party. From 1976 to 2000, he was the sheriff of Vernon Parish, Louisiana.

Howard died from problems caused by COVID-19 on July 27, 2020 in Baton Rouge, Louisiana at the age of 81.

[[Hornbeck, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Louisiana

Hornbeck is a town in Vernon Parish, Louisiana, United States. The population was 480 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Fort Polk South Micropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Gianrico Tedeschi]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, Italian centenarians, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian voice actors, Italian stage actors, Actors from Milan

Gianrico Tedeschi (20 April 1920 – 27 July 2020) was an Italian actor. He was born in Milan, Italy. His career lasted between 1943 to 2013. He appeared in over 100 movies and television shows. His best known roles were in Susanna Whipped Cream, Il merlo maschio and in Dr. Jekyll Likes Them Hot.

In April 2020, Tedeschi celebrated his 100th birthday. He died three months later on 27 July 2020 at his home in Pettenasco, Italy from congestive heart failure.

[[Bent Fabric]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Pianists, Danish composers

Bent Fabricius-Bjerre (7 December 1924 – 28 July 2020), better known internationally as Bent Fabric, was a Danish pianist and composer. He was born in Frederiksberg, Denmark. His career lasted from 1950 until his death.

He started a jazz ensemble after World War II and founded a label, Metronome Records, in 1950. However, he is best known for his 1961 instrumental "Omkring et flygel" (literally, "Around a Piano") which became a hit in Denmark.

Fabric died on 28 July 2020 in Copenhagen, aged 95.

[[Emily Howell Warner]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, American aviators, American educators, People from Denver, Colorado, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease

Emily Howell Warner (October 30, 1939 – July 3, 2020) was an American airline pilot. She the first woman captain of a scheduled US airline. She was born in Denver, Colorado.

In 1973, Warner was the first woman pilot to be hired by a scheduled US airline since Helen Richey was hired as a co-pilot in 1934. In 1976 Warner was the first woman to become a US airline captain.

[[Lennox Napier]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, British generals

Major-General Lennox Alexander Hawkins Napier GBR (28 June 1928 – 21 July 2020) was a British Army officer.

Napier was commissioned into the South Wales Borderers in 1946. He was honored with the Military Cross in December 1957 during the Malayan Emergency. He became commanding officer of the 1st Battalion South Wales Borderers in 1967 and commanding officer of the 1st Battalion Royal Regiment of Wales in 1969.

He was commander of the Berlin Infantry Brigade in 1974, Divisional Brigadier for the Prince of Wales' Division in 1976 and General Officer Commanding Wales in 1980 before retiring in 1983. 

He died on 21 July 2020 at the age of 92.

[[Orvilliers-Saint-Julien]]

Orvilliers-Saint-Julien is a commune of the Aube département in the north-central part of France.

[[Lluís Serrahima]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish singers, Writers from Barcelona

Lluís Serrahima i Villavecchia (19 August 1931 – 26 July 2020) was a Spanish singer-songwriter. He was born in Barcelona. He was known as the founder of the Nova Cançó, a music genre that became popular during the Francisco Franco regime. In the 1980s, he became vocal in the Generalitat de Catalunya. 

Serrahima died on 26 July 2020 in Barcelona, aged 88.

[[Terry Waters]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Australia, Australian rules footballers, Sportspeople from Victoria (Australia)

Terry Waters (14 December 1943 – 28 July 2020) was an Australian rules footballer. He played with Collingwood in the Victorian Football League (VFL).

At first, he played for the Victorian Football Association (VFA) club Dandenong. Waters won the Copeland Trophy for being Collingwood's Best and Fairest player in 1966, was their leading goalkicker in 1963 and 1964.

Waters was appointed captain of Collingwood in 1970. 

Waters died on 28 July 2020 from cancer at the age of 76.

[[Maurizio Calvesi (art historian)]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Italian historians, Italian educators, Italian essayists, Writers from Rome

Maurizio Calvesi (18 September 1927 – 24 July 2020) was an Italian art critic, historian and essayist. He was born in Rome. He was a professor at the Sapienza University of Rome. He was also a member of Accademia dei Lincei. He wrote about art history during the Renaissance and Baroque.

Calvesi died on 24 July 2020 in Rome, aged 92.

[[Mona Simpson]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, American novelists, Writers from Wisconsin, People from Green Bay, Wisconsin, Steve Jobs, Living people

Mona Simpson (Jandali; June 14, 1957) is an American novelist and the former wife of Richard Appel. She has written six novels. Studied English at the University of California, Berkeley. She also took Languages and Literature at Bard College. She won a Whiting Award for her first novel, Anywhere but Here (1986). It was a popular success and later adapted as a film by the same name and was released in 1999. 

She wrote a sequel, The Lost Father (1992). Critical recognition has included the Chicago Tribune Heartland Prize. She also made the shortlist for the PEN/Faulkner Award for her novel Off Keck Road (2000). 

Simpson is the younger sister of the late Apple Inc. co-founder Steve Jobs. Simpson was born after her parents had married. She did not meet Jobs, who was placed for adoption after he was born, until she was 25 years old. 

Simpson was born in Green Bay, Wisconsin.

[[Lodovico Meneghetti]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Italian architects, Italian educators, Urban planners, People from Novara

Lodovico Meneghetti (2 June 1926 – 19 July 2020) was an Italian architect, urban planner and educator. He was born in Novara, Italy. He was known for his works with Vittorio Gregotti and Giotto Stoppino. He worked for the National Urban Planning Institute in Milan. From 1956 to 1960, he was the urban planner of the Municipality of Novara. Beginning in 1970, he worked at the Polytechnic University of Milan.

Meneghetti died on 19 July 2020 in Milan at the age of 94.

[[The Factory]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in New York City, Andy Warhol

The Factory was Andy Warhol's New York City studio, which had three different locations between 1962 and 1984. 

The original Factory was on the fifth floor at 231 East 47th Street, in Midtown Manhattan. The rent was one hundred dollars per year. Warhol left in 1967 when the building was scheduled to be torn down to make way for an apartment building. 

He then relocated his studio to the sixth floor of the Decker Building at 33 Union Square West near the corner of East 16th Street, where he was shot in 1968 by Valerie Solanas. 

The Factory was revamped and remained there until 1973. It moved to 860 Broadway at the north end of Union Square. Although this space was much larger, not much filmmaking took place there. 

In 1984 Warhol moved his remaining business, no longer including filming, to 22 East 33rd Street, a conventional office building. 

Many Warhol movies, including those made at the Factory, were first (or later) shown at the New Andy Warhol Garrick Theatre or 55th Street Playhouse.

[[Highlands Ranch, Colorado]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Colorado

Highlands Ranch is a census-designated place (CDP) in Douglas County, Colorado, United States. The population was 96,713 at the 2010 census. It is located 12 south of Denver.

[[Campbell's Soup Cans]]

CATEGORIES: Andy Warhol, Pop art

Campbell's Soup Cans, which is sometimes referred to as 32 Campbell's Soup Cans, is a work of art produced between November 1961 and March or April 1962 by Andy Warhol. It is made up of thirty-two canvases, each measuring 20 in height × 16. Each are of a painting of a Campbell's Soup can—one of each of the canned soup versions the company offered at the time. It is one of the most important art pieces of pop art in the United States.

[[Marilyn Diptych]]

CATEGORIES: Andy Warhol

The Marilyn Diptych (1962) is a silkscreen painting by American pop artist Andy Warhol. It shows Marilyn Monroe. The piece is one of the artist's most well known works. It is in the collection of the Tate.

The painting has one picture of Monroe but painted fifty times. Twenty-five of the Monroe paintings are colored in purple, yellow and green. The other half is the same picture but in black and white.

[[Citrus]]

CATEGORIES: Citrus

Citrus is a genus of flowering trees and shrubs in the rue family, Rutaceae. Plants in the genus produce citrus fruits. The genus Citrus is native to South Asia, East Asia, Southeast Asia, Melanesia, and Australia. For thousands of years, people in these areas grew citrus plants. Citrus reached Micronesia and Polynesia with the Austronesian expansion around 3000-1500 BCE. It reached the Middle East and Mediterranean around 1200 BCE, and then Europe.

Citrus fruits include oranges, lemons, grapefruits, limes, citrons, pomelos, and kumquats. See List of citrus fruits.

[[Philip de' Medici]]

CATEGORIES: 1577 births, 1582 deaths, Grand Princes of Tuscany, House of Medici, People from Florence, Heirs apparent who never acceded

Philip de' Medici (May 20, 1577 – March 29, 1582) was a Prince of the Grand Duchy o Tuscany, an hier tae the Tuscan throne from his birth till his death in 1582. He was named in honour of King Philip II of Spain. The birth was celebrated with great joy bi the court, because thus was secured the succession of the Grand Duchy for another generation and eliminated all the hopes o Bianca Cappello (his father's mistress, and later wife) He was known as Don Filippo. Upon his death, the title of Grand Prince went to his cousin Prince Ferdinando (future Grand Duke Ferdinando  I of Tuscany). His older sister Princess Maria was eventually a wife of the future King Henri IV of France. 

[[Cumae]]

CATEGORIES: Archaeological sites in Europe, Buildings and structures in Italy, Campania

Cumae was a Greek settlement in Italy. It was settled in 740 BC, and is the first Greek colony on the Italian mainland. The same group had founded Pithekoussai, on the island of Ischia, in 770 BC. Later they founded other cities, namely Dikaiarcheia (modern-day Pozzuoli, and Neapolis (Naples).

[[Wisdom of Solomon]]

The Book of Wisdom is a book of the Bible that is part of the Catholic and Orthodox Biblical canon, put forward by the Council of Carthage in 397 and confirmed by Catholic leaders at the Council of Trent in 1546. It was written by a Jew in Ancient Egypt in the 1st century BC and talks about the importance of learning wisdom, describes how foolish the life without wisdom is, shows how wisdom played a role in the life of Old Testament figures like Adam, Noah and Abraham, and shows how God's wisdom effected the history of the Israelites during events like the Exodus out of Egypt.

[[Book of Sirach]]

The Book of Sirach is a book of the Bible that is part of the Catholic and Orthodox biblical canon, put forward by the Council of Carthage in 397 and confirmed by Catholic leaders at the Council of Trent in the 16th century. It was written roughly in the year 180 BC in Jerusalem by a Jew named Ben Sira. Its main theme is that of wisdom.

[[Sool, Somalia]]

CATEGORIES: Regions, Somalia

Sool (Sool, سول) is an administrative region in the east part of Somaliland. Sool is mostly settled by the reer darawiish tribe. It lies between Nugal to the east, and Togdheer in the west.

[[Chamorro language]]

[[Darod]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in Africa, Somalia

Darod is the largest Somali tribe. Most of them live in Jubaland, in Puntland, Ogadenia and the Khatumo State.

[[Litoria hunti]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Litoria hunti is a tree frog from northern Papua New Guinea.  The New Guineans call it "Wowo." Scientists have only seen it in Utai, which is in Sanduan Province, but they think it lives in many other places on the island of New Guinea.

The adult male frog has pads on its feet called nuptual pads.  The adult male frog is 5.8 to 6.0 cm in length.  It is bright green on the back and sometimes has a white stripe from its jaw to its ear.  The climbing discs on its feet are white.  It has vomerine teeth in its upper jaw.

Scientists could hear this frog calling from the trees 5 to 8 meters above the ground, so they think it lays eggs in pools on the forest floor.  But they did not see the frogs doing this.

[[Welcome to Sky Valley]]

Welcome to Sky Valley, also known as just Sky Valley, is the third studio album by American rock band Kyuss. It was released on 28 June 1994 on Elektra and Chameleon Records.

[[A13 autoroute]]

CATEGORIES: Autoroutes in France

The A13 is an autoroute (motorway) in France. It goes between Paris and Caen. It also goes past Rouen and Le Harve. It is the oldest autoroute in France, as it first opened in 1946. It is used a lot by people going on holiday to the north coast of France. It is about 225 long.

[[Tadhg]]

CATEGORIES: Given names

Tadhg is an Irish masculine given name meaning "poet" or "philosopher". 

Tadhg was a very popular name when the Goidelic languages predominated. It was also the name of many Gaelic Irish kings from the 10th to the 16th centuries. 

[[A14 autoroute]]

CATEGORIES: Autoroutes in France

The A14 is a short autoroute (motorway) in France. It starts from the A13 and goes east towards Central Paris. The autoroute is about 21 long.

[[Batagay megaslump]]

CATEGORIES: Craters, Siberia

The Batagay megaslump  (also called the Batagaika crater) is a large pit in Siberia.  It is caused by the permafrost melting.  This megaslump began as a cut on the side of a hill.  It is the largest megaslump in the world. Scientists are interested in the Batagay because it has a natural record of past ecology.  Remains of extinct animals such as the prehistoric steppe bison and cave lion have been recovered.

[[Audemus jura nostra defendere]]

CATEGORIES: Alabama, Latin state mottos of the United States

Audemus jura nostra defendere is the state motto of Alabama. It means "We dare defend our rights".

[[Extreme Spots]]

CATEGORIES: SpongeBob SquarePants episodes, 2012 television episodes

"Extreme Spots" is the first part of the 9th season of SpongeBob SquarePants. It was first shown on television on July 21, 2012. In the episode, SpongeBob and Patrick try to join an extreme sports team. The episode guest stars Johnny Knoxville as Johnny Krill. 

The episode was a part of a television marathon called "The Super Spongy Square Games". The marathon was watched by 3.7 million people. This made the marathon the most watched kids program for the week it was shown. The episode was released on a DVD named Extreme Kah-Rah-Tay on January 15, 2013.

[[Sikeston, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri

Sikeston ˈ is a city located both in southern Scott County and northern New Madrid County, in the state of Missouri, United States. It is the principal city of the Sikeston Micropolitan Statistical Area, which consists of all of Scott County. It has a total population of 41,143.

[[Benton, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: County seats in Missouri, Cities in Missouri

Benton is a city in Scott County, Missouri, United States. The population was 863 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Scott County.

[[Middlebury College]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Vermont, 1800 establishments in the United States, Colleges and universities in Vermont

Middlebury College is a private liberal arts college in Middlebury, Vermont. It was founded in 1800 by Congregationalists. The college currently enrolls 2,526 undergraduates from all 50 states and 74 countries and offers 44 majors in the arts, humanities, literature, foreign languages, social sciences, and natural sciences.

The college is the first American institution of higher education to have granted a bachelor's degree to an African-American, graduating Alexander Twilight in the class of 1823. 

[[Chronic lymphocytic leukemia]]

CATEGORIES: Cancer

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). 

Early on there are typically no symptoms. Later non-painful lymph node swelling, feeling tired, fever, night sweats, or weight loss for no clear reason may occur.

Risk factors include having a family history of the disease.

[[Perence Shiri]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Zimbabwe politicians, Military people, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Zimbabwe

Perrance Shiri (born Bigboy Samson Chikerema on 11 January 1955  – 29 July 2020) Zimbabwean air officer and government official. He was Minister of Lands, Agriculture and Rural Resettlement  in the Cabinet of Zimbabwe from 1 December 2017 until his death in 2020. He was the commander of the Air Force of Zimbabwe and member of the Joint Operations Command.

Shiri was a cousin of former President Robert Mugabe. He called himself "Black Jesus".

Shiri died on 28 July 2020 from COVID-19 while hospitalized in Harare, aged 65.

[[Anilingus]]

CATEGORIES: Sexual acts

Anilingus (from the Latin anus + -lingus, from lingere, "to lick", variantly  spelled "analingus",) is the oral and anal sex act in which a person licks the anus of another by using the mouth, including lips, tongue, or teeth. It is also called anal–oral contact and anal–oral sex, and is additionally known by slang names.

Nicknames include: rimming, rim job, eating ass or tossing the salad.

[[Andy Haden]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from chronic lymphocytic leukemia, New Zealand rugby union players

Andrew Maxwell Haden (26 September 1950spnd29 July 2020) was a New Zealand rugby union player and All Black captain. He played at lock for Auckland and New Zealand from 1972 until 1985.  He also played club rugby in the United Kingdom and Italy. He was born in Wanganui, New Zealand.

In 2003, Haden announced that he was beginning chemotherapy for chronic lymphocytic leukaemia. He died on 29 July 2020 in Auckland, aged 69. 

[[Reese Schonfeld]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, American television producers, CNN people, Journalists from New Jersey, Businesspeople from Newark, New Jersey

Maurice Wolfe "Reese" Schonfeld (November 5, 1931 – July 28, 2020) was an American television journalist and executive. He was a co-founder of CNN in the early 1980s. He was president to the news network from 1980 to 1982. He went on to create the Food Network in the 1990s. Schonfeld was born in Newark, New Jersey.

Schonfeld died on July 28, 2020, at his home in Manhattan from Alzheimer's disease-related problems, aged 88.

[[Joseph Moingt]]

CATEGORIES: 1915 births, 2020 deaths, French centenarians, French theologians, Writers from Paris

Joseph Moingt (19 November 1915 – 28 July 2020) was a French jesuit. He was born in Salbris, France. He was known for working at the Institut Catholique de Paris. From 1970 to 1997, he was Director of the Recherches de science religieuse. In 2015, he turned 100.

Moingt died on 28 July 2020 in Paris, aged 104.

[[Raavi Kondala Rao]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Indian movie actors, Indian television actors, Indian stage actors, Playwrights, Indian journalists, Indian movie producers, Indian movie directors

Raavi Kondala Rao (11 February 1932 – 28 July 2020) was an Indian actor, playwright, theatre artist, journalist, editor, producer, director and writer. He appeared in Telugu movies and performed in over 600. He was born in Srikakulam, Andra Pradesh. Rao was known for his works in Ramudu Bheemudu, Preminchi Choodu and in Jeevitha Chakram.

Rao died from cardiac arrest on 28 July 2020 in Hyderabad, India at the age of 86.

[[Sound City Studios]]

CATEGORIES: Music, Buildings and structures in Los Angeles, California

Sound City Studios is a recording studio in Los Angeles, California. It first opened in 1969 in the Van Nuys neighborhood. Before this, it was a factory for the British musical instrument maker Vox. The studio became well known for having a unique sound, especially when drums are played in there. Because of this, many famous recording artists have recorded there. These include Johnny Cash, Nirvana, Fleetwood Mac, Metallica, and many others. Over one hundred albums recorded at Sound City were given gold and platinum certifications.

[[Gisèle Halimi]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, French lawyers, French politicians, Feminist writers, French essayists, Tunisian writers, Tunisian politicians, People from Tunis

Gisèle Halimi (born Zeiza Gisèle Élise Taïeb; 27 July 1927 – 28 July 2020) was a Tunisian-French lawyer, feminist, and essayist. She was born in Tunis. 

In 1971 she founded the feminist group Choisir ("To Choose"), to protect the women who had signed the Manifesto of the 343 admitting to having illegal abortions. 

In 1981 she was elected to the French National Assembly and was Deputy for Isère until 1984. Between 1985 and 1987 she was a French legate to UNESCO.

Halimi died at the age of 93 on 28 July 2020 in Paris.

[[Aleksandr Aksinin]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Russian sportspeople, Olympic gold medalists, Olympic bronze medalists, Sprinters, Male athletes, People from Saint Petersburg

Aleksandr Timofeyevich Aksinin (Александр Тимофеевич Аксинин, 4 November 1954 – 28 July 2020)) was a Soviet athlete. He won a gold medal winner of the 4 × 100m relay at the 1980 Summer Olympics. He also won a bronze medal at the 1976 Summer Olympics. Aksinin was born in Leningrad. 

Aksinin died on 28 July 2020, aged 65.

[[Destination Tokyo]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 movies, 1940s war movies, 1940s adventure movies, American adventure movies, World War II movies, Movies directed by Delmer Daves

Destination Tokyo is a 1943 American World War II adventure movie directed by Delmer Daves and starring Cary Grant, John Garfield, Alan Hale, Sr., Tom Tully, John Forsythe, John Ridgely, Dane Clark, Warner Anderson, Eleanor Parker, Faye Emerson. It was distributed by Warner Bros. and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1944.

[[Kina Kadreva]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Bulgarian writers, Children's writers

Kina Kadreva (27 September 1931 – 27 July 2020) was a Bulgarian author. She was best known for the children's book The Milk Tree from 1962, and Dragon under a down pillow from 1996. Kadreva was born in Burgas, Bulgaria.

Kadreva died on 27 July 2020 in Sofia, aged 88.

[[John Weeks (economist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, American economists, American educators, Writers from Austin, Texas

John Weeks (1941 – 26 July 2020) was an American economist. He was born in Austin, Texas. He was Professor Emeritus at the School of Oriental and African Studies of the University of London. His research interests were in theoretical and policy-applied macroeconomics and economic development. He published academic papers, books and policy reports in these areas. 

He died on 26 July 2020, aged 79.

[[Claudia Giannotti]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors

Claudia Giannotti (19 February 1937 – 26 July 2020) was an Italian actress. She was born in Campobasso, Italy. She was known for her role as Dr. Natoli in the 1969 comedy Il Prof. Dott. Guido Tersilli, primario della clinica Villa Celeste, convenzionata con le mutue.

Giannotti died on 26 July 2020 in Torino, Italy at the age of 83.

[[Giulio Maceratini]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, MEPs for Italy, Former MEPs, Politicians from Rome

Giulio Maceratini (13 February 1938 – 25 July 2020) was an Italian politician. He was born in Rome. He was a member of the European Parliament between 6 June 1988 to 1 October 1988.

Maceratini died on 25 July 2020 in Rome at the age of 82.

[[Jim Frick]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, Swedish sportspeople

Kjell ''Jim'' Erik Frick, (6 November 1951 – 25 July 2020) was a Swedish horse racer within harness racing. He was born in Rättvik, Sweden. After winning 5002 races he ended his career in 2010 after being thrown off the horse. 

In 1987, Frick represented Sweden in the World Driving Championship.

Between 2003 and 2007 he won 36 million (SEK) with 400 victories in the sport. On 21 February 2010, he won his 5000th victory in horse racing with the horse Sandro Mustang at Gävletravet.

Frick died on 25 July 2020 from prostate cancer at the age of 68.

[[Bernard Mohlalisi]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholics

Bernard Mohlalisi O.M.I. (March 16, 1933 – July 24, 2020) was the Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Maseru in Lesotho from 1990 to 2009. On June 30, 2009, his resignation due to age was accepted by Pope Benedict XVI. Mohlalisi was ordained as a priest on July 14, 1963.

Mohlalisi died on July 24, 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Claude-Gérard Marcus]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, French politicians

Claude-Gérard Marcus (24 August 1933 – 24 July 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the National Assembly from 1968 to 1997. He was born in Paris. He was a member of the Union of Democrats for the Republic.

Marcus died on 24 July 2020 in Paris, aged 86.

[[Claude Beausoleil]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Essayists, Canadian poets, Writers from Montreal

Claude Beausoleil (16 November 1948 – 24 July 2020) was a Canadian writer, poet, and essayist. He was born in Montreal. 

In 1991, Beausoleil won the Prix littéraires du Journal de Montréal for Une certain fin de siècle. He was also a finalist for the 1991 Governor General's Awards. He won the 1997 Prix Alain-Grandbois for Grand Hôtel des étrangers. La Blessure du silence won the Prix Louise-Labé in 2009, and Mystère Wilde won the Prix Heredia of the Académie française in 2015.

Beausoleil was a member of the Académie Mallarmé. His archives are kept in the Bibliothèque et Archives nationales du Québec.

Beausoleil died on 24 July 2020 in Montreal, aged 71.

[[Bonneville, Haute-Savoie]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Haute-Savoie, Subprefectures in France

Bonneville (bɔn.vil; Bônavela) is a commune in the Haute-Savoie department in the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region in south-eastern France.

[[Eulogius (Smirnov)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Russian Orthodox Christians

Eulogius (born Yuri Vasilyevich Smirnov; 13 January 1937 – 22 July 2020) was a Russian Orthodox prelate. He was the figure head at the Russian Orthodox Eparchy of Vladimir between 1990 and 2018.

Metropolitan Eulogius died on 22 July 2020, aged 83.

[[A15 autoroute]]

CATEGORIES: Autoroutes in France

The A15 is a short autoroute (motorway) in France. It goes through the suburbs of the northwest of Paris. It is about 21 long.

[[The Telebugs]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 television series debuts, 1987 television series endings, English-language television programs

The Telebugs is a cartoon from the 1980s about the adventures of three robots with televisions for heads.

[[Theodotion]]

CATEGORIES: Jewish people

Theodotion was a Greek-speaking Jewish scholar, who likely worked in Ephesus (a place in the west of modern-day Turkey), and translated the Hebrew Bible into Greek in roughly AD 150.

[[Qumran]]

CATEGORIES: Archaeological sites in Israel

Qumran is an archaeological site in the West Bank by the nation of Israel. It is best known as the settlement nearest to the Qumran Caves where the Dead Sea Scrolls were kept. The excavations were carried out by Roland de Vaux in the 1950s, though several later works at the site have since been carried out. The Biblical documents found at Qumran have been very useful to scholars of the Bible, Judaism and Christianity, as it allows them to understand the history of the Jewish community that lived there as well as the history of the Bible (such as which books were part of the canon or when certain books were written).

[[Squeezie]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, French YouTubers, People from Ile-de-France, Living people

Lucas Hauchard (born 27 January 1996), also known as Squeezie, is a French YouTuber. He is the most well-known French-speaking gamer with over 14 million subscribers and 7 billion views. He specialises in Let's Play commentaries and vlogs, and also works with Cyprien Iov on Bigorneaux & Coquillages, a channel with over 6 million subscribers as of October 2019.

[[Bojangles' Famous Chicken 'n Biscuits]]

CATEGORIES: American fast food restaurants, 1977 establishments in the United States

Bojangles' Famous Chicken 'n Biscuits is a chain of fast food restaurants. They serve Cajun-style chicken and biscuits. It was founded in 1977 by Jack Fulk and Richard Thomas.

[[Thin Ice (1937 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 movies, 1930s comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Sidney Lanfield

Thin Ice is a 1937 American romantic comedy movie directed by Sidney Lanfield and starring Sonja Henie, Tyrone Power, Arthur Treacher, Raymond Walburn, Joan Davis. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1938.

[[Pinkel]]

CATEGORIES: Sausage, German food

Pinkel is a type of sausage that is common in the north of Germany.  It does not only contain meat, but also has non-meat ingredients. Its exact composition varies, but it is usually made of bacon, groats of oats or barley, beef suet, pig lard, onions, salt, pepper and other spices. It is the kind of sausage that is usually served cooked, with some form of cabbage. 

Mostly during the winter months, it may also be used in Eintopf. Pinkel is a smoked sausage. It is eaten mainly in northwest Germany, especially the region around Oldenburg, Bremen and Osnabrück as well as in East Frisia and Friesland. 

[[Statue of Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar, Japan]]

CATEGORIES: Statues, Japan, B. R. Ambedkar

The Statue of Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar at the Koyasan University in Wakayama

Prefecture, Japan, is a public monument of Babasaheb Ambedkar. Ambedkar (1891-1956) was an Indian polymath, Dalit leader, human and civil rights activist, the architect of the Indian constitution and the founding father of republic of India. The statue was unveiled on 10 September 2015 by then Maharashtra's Chief

Minister Devendra Fadnavis. The statue of a foreign person has been set up for the first time in Wakayama. The statue's height is 10.5 feet (3.2 m). It was established on the celebration of 1,200th year of foundation of Koyasan and the 125th birth anniversary of B. R. Ambedkar. It was established at a cost of ₹ 22.25 lakhs.

[[Additions to Esther]]

CATEGORIES: Septuagint, Old Testament

Additions to Esther refer to several additional chapters to the Book of Esther found in the Septuagint. They are distributed among the conventional Book of Esther and are found in Catholic and Orthodox Bibles but generally not in ones used by Protestants. Some of the additions are: Mordechai's dream, his later interpretation of the dream in light of what happened to him in real life and details of the decree against the Jews.

[[Georgian Orthodox Church]]

CATEGORIES: Christian denominations, Eastern Christian denominations, Eastern Orthodox Church, Georgia (country), Tbilisi

Orthodox Church of Georgia is an autocephalous (meaning independent) Eastern Orthodox Church in full communion with the other churches of Eastern Orthodoxy. It is Georgia's main religious institution, and a majority of Georgian people are members. The Orthodox Church of Georgia is one of the oldest churches in the world. Its claim to be apostolic means it can be traced back to the original disciples of Jesus. Its doctrine is similar to that of Eastern Orthodoxy, with only some differences. The church is the most trusted institution in Georgia. According to a 2013 survey 95% respondents had a positive opinion of its work.

[[Molecular gastronomy]]

CATEGORIES: Food and drink, Science

Molecular gastronomy is a type of science that studies the chemical reactions in food during cooking.

[[Nyctimystes intercastellus]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes intercastellus  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists found it on three of the D'Entrecasteaux Islands: Fergusson Island, Normanby Island, and Goodenough Island.

This frog is 3.9 to 5.1 cm long.  Scientists say it has more webbing on its feet than other tree frogs.

[[Carnoy]]

Carnoy is a former commune. It is found in the region Hauts-de-France in the Somme department in the north of France. On 1 January 2019, it was merged into the new commune of Carnoy-Mametz.

Trois-Rivières is a commune. It is found in the region Hauts-de-France in the Somme department in the north of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2019 and consists of the former communes of Pierrepont-sur-Avre (the seat), Contoire and Hargicourt.

[[Intercontinental Cup (football)]]

CATEGORIES: Football

The Intercontinental Cup was an international football competition. It was approved by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA) and the Confederación Sudamericana de Fútbol (CONMEBOL). Teams from these confederations played against each other. It was usually the winners of the UEFA Champions League against the South American Copa Libertadores winners. It ran from 1960 to 2004. The FIFA Club World Cup replaced it. These cups ran at the same time from 2000 to 2004. The Intercontinal Cup was also known as European/South American Cup, or the Toyota Cup from 1980 to 2004. This was because they had an agreement with the car maker Toyota. 

Between 1960 and 1979, the competition was two matches between the same teams. There was a playoff if the teams were level until 1968. After this date, there were penalty kicks instead. During the 1970s, the European teams were unsure about playing due to events in the 1969 final. Some European Cup-winning teams did not play. From 1980, the competition was a single match. The teams played in Japan. The sponsor was the multinational car maker Toyota. It gave a second trophy called the Toyota Cup. The organisation of the competition was then done by the Japan Football Association. UEFA and CONMEBOL continued to approve of the tournament.

The first winner of the cup was Spanish team Real Madrid. They beat Peñarol of Uruguay in 1960. The last winner was Portuguese team Porto. They beat Colombian team Once Caldas in a penalty shoot-out in 2004. The competition ended in 2004. It merged with the FIFA Club World Cup in 2005.

[[Simbang big-eyed tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The Simbang big-eyed tree frog (Nyctimystes obsoletus)  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists found it on the Huon Peninsula.

This frog's ear is hard to see when it is alive.  The ear is easier to see when it is dead and preserved.

[[Ditat Deus]]

Ditat Deus is the state motto of Arizona. It is featured on the state's seal. It means "God enriches" in Latin.

[[Eintopf]]

CATEGORIES: Soups

Eintopf is a traditional recipe in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland. At the base it is a vegetable soup to which other ingredients, usually meat or sausages are added. It is commonly eaten during the winter months. An eintopf should be a complete meal. 

[[North to the Future]]

North to the Future is the state motto of :Alaska. It was adopted in 1967.

[[Vouziers]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Ardennes, Subprefectures in France

Vouziers (vu.zje) is a commune of the Ardennes department in northern France.

Vouziers is known for being the burial place of the pioneer First World War fighter pilot , after whom the Stade Roland Garros in Paris (the location of the French Open tennis tournament) is named. Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk (the first president of Czechoslovakia) fought at Vouziers with the Czechoslovak Legion in France; there is a monument to the legion, and the president's name given to the city lycee (high school). The cellist and conductor Jean Witkowski was born in Vouziers on 23 May 1895.

The town was also known for the solar eclipse of August 11, 1999. It hosted a major observation event. Because of its closeness to the Belgian border, it was gridlocked by visiting Belgian cars on the morning of the eclipse.

[[Adamswiller]]

[[Stephanie Murphy]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, American Protestants, US Democratic Party politicians, United States representatives from Florida, Living people

Stephanie Murphy (born Đặng Thị Ngọc Dung; September 16, 1978) is an American politician from Florida. She has represented Florida's 7th congressional district since 2017. Murphy is the first Vietnamese-American woman to serve in Congress. She is a Democrat.

Murphy is a Protestant.

[[Arameans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups

Arameans, also known as Syriacs are a predominantly Syriac Christian ethnic group whose origins remain in what is today Iraq, Turkey and Syria and fled to Western Europe, North America and the Caucasus due persecution over the past centuries. The Arameans speak Aramaic which once was the language of the whole Middle East.

Their culture has survived for thousands of years despite efforts by their Arab, Turkish and Kurdish neighbors to demolish it: it remains a strong influence on their way of life. 

Today there are about 3-5 million Arameans worldwide with the majority living in the diaspora.

[[Somen Mitra]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Indian politicians

Somendra Nath Mitra (31 December 1941 – 30 July 2020), popularly known as Somen Mitra, was an Indian politician. He was a member of the 15th Lok Sabha, elected from the Diamond Harbour constituency in West Bengal state in 2009. He was a member of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly from Sealdah from 1972 to 2006. He was the president of the state unit of the Indian National Congress. 

In July 2008, he left the Indian National Congress and formed a new party, named, Pragatisheel Indira Congress. He was born in Katorah, India.

Mitra died on 30 July 2020 at a hospital in Kolkata, India from cardiac arrest caused by multiple organ failure, aged 78.

[[John McNamara (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Baseball players from California, Boston Red Sox managers, Cincinnati Reds managers, Sportspeople from Sacramento, California

John Francis McNamara (June 4, 1932 – July 28, 2020) was an American professional baseball manager, coach and player. He was born in Sacramento, California.

After spending over 15 years in the minor leagues as a player and player-manager, McNamara helmed six Major League Baseball (MLB) teams for all or parts of 19 seasons between 1969 and 1996. He directed the 1986 Boston Red Sox to the American League pennant.

He also managed the Oakland Athletics, San Diego Padres, Cincinnati Reds, California Angels, and Cleveland Indians. He coached the Athletics, the San Francisco Giants, and the Angels.

McNamara died on July 28, 2020, at his home in Brentwood, Tennessee at the age of 88.

[[David Ramsay (Ontario politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Sydney, Politicians from Ontario

David James Ramsay (April 23, 1948 – July 29, 2020) was an Australian-born Canadian politician. He was elected as a New Democratic member of the Legislative Assembly of Ontario in 1985. He retired in 2011. Ramsay was born in Sydney. He was a member of the New Democrat and later switched parties to Liberal.

Ramsay died on July 29, 2020 at his home in Belle Vallée, Ontario at the age of 72.

[[Oz Griebel]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths in the United States, American lawyers, Politicians from Connecticut, Businesspeople from Connecticut, Independent politicians in the United States

Richard Nelson "Oz" Griebel (June 21, 1949 – July 29, 2020) was an American banker, lawyer, and political candidate. He ran as a Republican primary candidate in the 2010 Connecticut gubernatorial election, and as an independent in the 2018 gubernatorial election.

On July 21, 2020, Griebel was hit by a car while jogging in Pennsylvania. He died from problems caused by his injuries on July 29 at the age of 71.

[[Mike Gillespie (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung disease, Deaths from stroke, College basketball coaches, Sportspeople from Los Angeles, California

Michael James Gillespie (May 7, 1940 – July 29, 2020) was an American college baseball coach.  He was the head coach at UC Irvine and head coach at USC from 1987 to 2006.  He led USC to the 1998 College World Series championship. He was born in Los Angeles, California.

Gillespie died on July 29, 2020, in Irvine, California from problems caused by lung disease and a stroke, aged 80.

[[Anatoli Fedyukin]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Soviet Olympic gold medalists, Soviet Olympic silver medalists

Anatoli Viktorovich Fedyukin (Анатолий Викторович Федюкин; January 26, 1952 – July 29, 2020) was a Soviet/Russian handball player. He competed in the 1976 Summer Olympics and in the 1980 Summer Olympics. He was born in Voronezh, Soviet Union. 

Fedyukin died on July 29, 2020 in Moscow at the age of 69.

[[Malik B.]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, 2020 deaths, American rap musicians from Pennsylvania, American hip hop musicians, Musicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Singers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Malik Abdul Basit (November 14, 1972 – July 29, 2020), who performed under the name Malik B., was an American rapper and singer. He was a founding member of the Roots. He appeared on the first four albums released by the Roots. He returned as a featured artist for some later albums. 

He released one EP, entitled Psychological, on emcee Haak Blast's publishing company Future Blast Publishing. He also released two studio albums, Street Assault (2005) and Unpredictable (2015) with Mr. Green. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Basit died on July 29, 2020 at the age of 47.

[[Diana E. H. Russell]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, South African writers, Political activists, Feminist writers, Deaths from respiratory failure

Diana E. H. Russell (6 November 1938 – 28 July 2020) was a South African feminist writer and activist. B

For the past 45 years she was engaged in research on sexual violence against women and girls. She wrote many books and articles on rape, including marital rape, femicide, incest, misogynist murders of women, and pornography. 

For The Secret Trauma, she was co-recipient of the 1986 C. Wright Mills Award. She was also the recipient of the 2001 Humanist Heroine Award from the American Humanist Association. 

She was also an organizer of the First International Tribunal on Crimes against Women, in Brussels in March 1976.

[[Gerry Harris]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, People from Shropshire, English footballers

Gerald William Harris (8 October 1935 – 28 July 2020) was an English professional footballer. He spent the majority of his league career with Wolverhampton Wanderers, with whom he won two league championships and the FA Cup.

Harris died on July 28, 2020, at the age of 84.

[[The GTOs]]

CATEGORIES: Musical groups from Los Angeles, California

The GTOs (Girls Together Outrageously) were an all-girl group from the Los Angeles area, specifically the Sunset Strip scene. They were active for only two and a half years (1968–1970) with a single reunion in 1974, their only album, Permanent Damage, produced by Frank Zappa, was released in 1969.

[[R. Stephen Berry]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American educators, American chemists, Scientists from Denver, Colorado

R. Stephen Berry (April 9, 1931 – July 26, 2020) was an American professor of physical chemistry. He was the James Franck Distinguished Service Professor Emeritus at The University of Chicago. He was also Special Advisor for National Security to the Director, at Argonne National Laboratory. He was born in Denver, Colorado.

He died on July 26, 2020 in Chicago at the age of 89.

[[Ward Plummer]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, American physicists, American educators, Scientists from Oregon

E. Ward Plummer (October 30, 1940 – July 23, 2020) was an American physicist. His main works were in surface physics of metals.  Plummer was a Professor of Physics at Louisiana State University. He was born in Astoria, Oregon. In 2014, he was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Plummer died in Baton Rouge, Louisiana on July 23, 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Hugh Dane]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American video game actors, Actors from Phoenix, Arizona

Hugh Dane (October 21, 1942 – May 16, 2018) was an American actor. He was best known for playing Hank the security guard on the television sitcom The Office from 2005 to 2013. His career began in 1989. He was born in Phoenix, Arizona.

Dane died on May 16, 2018, at the age of 75 from pancreatic cancer in Los Angeles, aged 75.

[[Don Townsend]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, English footballers, People from Wiltshire, Crystal Palace F.C. players

Donald Edward Townsend (17 September 1930 – 30 July 2020) was an English footballer. He played as a left back in the Football League. He was the father of former Ireland international Andy Townsend. His career lasted from 1953 to 1965. He played for Trowbridge Town, Charlton Athletic and Crystal Palace.

Townsend was born in Swindon, England. He died in 30 July 2020, aged 89.

[[Bathsheba]]

CATEGORIES: Biblical people, Old Testament people, Religious leaders, Year of birth unknown, Year of death unknown

Bathsheba was the wife of Uriah the Hittite and later of David, according to the Hebrew Bible. She is most known for the biblical narrative in which she had an affair with King David, who had seen her bathing and lusted after her. This affair resulted in the birth of Solomon, who succeeded David as king, making her the Queen mother.

[[Cyprien Iov]]

Cyprien Iov (born 12 May 1989), also known as Monsieur Dream, is a is a French comedian, actor, dubber, and YouTuber.

As of October 2019, his YouTube channel had 13.3 million subscribers and over 2.3 billion views. 

[[Hard Hunted]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 action movies, 1990s adventure movies, American action movies, American adventure movies

Hard Hunted is a 1993 American action adventure movie directed by Andy Sidaris and starring Bruce Penhall, Geoffrey Moore, Cynthia Brimhall, Chu Chu Malave, Dona Speir, Roberta Vasquez, Becky Mullen. It was distributed by Malibu Bay Films.

[[Tyson Brummett]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths in the United States, Aviation deaths in the United States, American baseball players, Los Angeles Dodgers players, Philadelphia Phillies players, Toronto Blue Jays players

Tyson Colby Brummett (August 15, 1984spndJuly 3, 2020) was an American baseball player. He was born in Columbus, Mississippi. In 2012, he played as a pitcher in one Major League Baseball (MLB) game for the Philadelphia Phillies. He batted and threw right-handed and was mainly a starting pitcher.

Brummett was drafted by the Phillies in 2007. He played for five of their minor league affiliates until 2012, when the organization promoted him to the major leagues. He later signed for the Toronto Blue Jays and Los Angeles Dodgers.

On July 3, 2020, Brummett was piloting an airplane that crashed in the mountains north of Alpine, Utah. He died along with three passengers. He was 35.

Alpine is a city in Utah County, Utah, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 9,555.

[[Kiss the Boys Goodbye]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 movies, 1940s musical movies, American musical movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Victor Schertzinger

Kiss the Boys Goodbye is a 1941 American musical movie directed by Victor Schertzinger and was based on the play of the same name by Clare Boothe Luce. It stars Mary Martin, Don Ameche, Oscar Levant, Virginia Dale, Jerome Cowan and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Bigender]]

CATEGORIES: Gender

Bigender is a gender identity which can be literally translated as 'two genders' or 'double gender'. Bigender people experience exactly two gender identities, either simultaneously or varying between the two. These two gender identities could be male and female, but could also include non-binary identities.
