[[Nyctimystes latratus]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes latratus is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea. It lives between 500 and 1200 meters above sea level on Mount Dayman and near the Bai-u River.

This frog has gold eyes.  This frog is light brown or dark brown with a dull white belly.

The name of this frog is from the Latin word latros for "to bark."

[[Anna and the King of Siam (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by John Cromwell

Anna and the King of Siam is a 1946 American drama movie directed by John Cromwell and is an adaptation of the 1944 novel of the same name by Margaret Landon. It stars Irene Dunne, Rex Harrison, Linda Darnell and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It won for two Oscars in 1947.

[[National Assembly (Nigeria)]]

CATEGORIES: Nigeria

The National Assembly of the Federal Republic of Nigeria is a bicameral legislature. It is made up of a Senate with 109 members and a 360-memberHouse of Representatives. 

The body, modeled after the federal Congress of the United States, is supposed to make sure it has equal representation with 3 Senators to each 36 states. 

The National Assembly, like many other parts of the Nigerian federal government, is based in Abuja, in the FCT, Abuja.

[[Senate of Nigeria]]

CATEGORIES: Nigeria

The Senate is the upper chamber of Nigeria's bicameral legislature, the National Assembly of Nigeria. The National Assembly (popularly referred to as NASS) is the nation's highest legislature, whose power is to make laws. It is made up of 109 senators. 

The President of the Senate is the presiding officer of the Senate, whose chief function is to guide and regulate the proceedings in the Senate. The Senate President is third in the Nigerian presidential line of succession. 

[[House of Representatives (Nigeria)]]

CATEGORIES: Nigeria

The House of Representatives is the lower chamber of Nigeria's bicameral National Assembly. The Senate is the upper chamber.

The House of Representatives has 360 members who are elected in single-member constituencies using the plurality (or first-past-the-post) system. Members serve four-year terms. The Speaker of the Nigerian House of Representatives is the presiding officer of the house.

[[V.S. Ramachandran]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, Neuroscientists, Indian scientists

Vilayanur Subramanian Ramachandran, also called V.S. Ramachandran (born 1951) is an Indian scientist and educator.  He has written more than 180 scientific research papers.  He co-discovered the mirror neuron, a nerve cell that helps human beings understand other human beings' actions.  Richard Dawkins called him "the Marco Polo of Neuroscience." Time magazine called him one of the 100 most influential people in the world.

Ramachandran is the director of the Center for Brain and Cognition at the University of California, San Diego, distinguished professor in the Psychology Department and Neurosciences Program at the University of California, San Diego, and adjunct professor of biology at the Salk Institute.  He is an Honorary Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians.

[[Alex Fraser Bridge]]

CATEGORIES: Bridges in Canada, British Columbia

The Alex Fraser Bridge is a cable stayed bridge that used to have six lanes until a counterflow lane was added to help reduce traffic, during the morning and afternoon rush hour. It crosses the Fraser River that connects Richmond, British Columbia and New Westminster, British Columbia. 

[[Traditional pop]]

CATEGORIES: American music, American pop singers, Popular culture

Traditional pop, also called standard music, is a genre (or type) of Western popular music that was popular before the beginning of rock and roll in the middle of 1950s. The most popular and ever-lasting songs during this period of music are also known as pop standards or American standards.

[[Mars 2020]]

CATEGORIES: Mars

Mars 2020 is a Mars rover mission by NASA's Mars Exploration Program that includes the Perseverance rover and the Ingenuity helicopter drone.

It was launched on 30 July 2020 at 11:50 UTC, and landed in the Jezero crater on Mars on 18 February 2021.

It will investigate to see if living organisms have lived or is living on Mars and if people can live there.

[[Mark V. Meierhenry]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, American lawyers, Politicians from South Dakota, US Republican Party politicians

Mark V. Meierhenry (October 29, 1944 – July 29, 2020) was an American attorney and politician. He was the 26th Attorney General of South Dakota from 1979 to 1987. He was born in Gregory, South Dakota. He was a member of the Republican Party. 

Meierhenry died in Sioux Falls, South Dakota on July 29, 2020 at his home in Sioux Falls, South Dakota at the age of 75.

[[Sydney Lotterby]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, BAFTA Award winners, British television producers, British television directors

Sydney Warren Lotterby OBE (30 November 1926 – July 2020) was a British television producer and director. He started as a cameraman at the BBC and progressed to becoming technical manager. 

Shows he directed and produced were As Time Goes By, May to December, Last of the Summer Wine, Yes, Minister and Yes, Prime Minister, Ever Decreasing Circles, Brush Strokes, Open All Hours, The Old Boy Network, Butterflies, Ripping Yarns, Porridge, Going Straight,  Broaden Your Mind, the final series of Some Mothers Do 'Ave 'Em, The Liver Birds, Up Pompeii! and Sykes and A....

Lotterby died in July 2020 at the age of 93.

[[Bob Dearing]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, American educators, Politicians from Mississippi, Businesspeople from Mississippi, US Democratic Party politicians

Bob M. Dearing (January 26, 1935 – July 30, 2020) was an American politician, educator, and businessman. He was a Democratic member of the Mississippi Senate. He represented the 37th District from 1980 to 2011. In 2011, he was defeated by Republican Melanie Sojourner. He ran for the seat again in 2015, and defeated Sojourner. Dearing was born in Natchez, Mississippi.

Dearing died on July 30, 2020 in Natchez at the age of 85.

[[Maarten Biesheuvel]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, People from Schiedam, Writers from South Holland

Maarten Biesheuvel (23 May 1939 – 30 July 2020) was a Dutch writer. He made his literary debut in 1972 with the short story collection In de bovenkooi. He received the "Ferdinand Bordewijk Prijs" in 1984 for Reis door mijn kamer. In 2007 he received the P. C. Hooft Award. He was born in Schiedam, Netherlands.

Biesheuvel died on 30 July 2020 in Leiden, Netherlands at the age of 81.

[[Karen Berg]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Writers from New York City

Karen Berg (born Karen Mulnick; October 12, 1942 – July 30, 2020) was an American author. She was born in New York City. Berg was the founder of the Kabbalah Centre International. 

She wrote four books; God Wears Lipstick: Kabbalah for Women; Simple Light, Wisdom from a Woman's Heart; To Be Continued, Reincarnation and the Purpose of our Lives; and Finding the Light through the Darkness, Inspirational lessons rooted in the Bible and the Zohar.

Berg died on July 30, 2020 at the age of 77.

[[Ajip Rosidi]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Indonesian writers, Poets

Ajip Rosidi (31 January 1938 – 29 July 2020) was an Indonesian poet and short story writer. He had published 326 works in 22 different magazines. He was born in Majalengka, Dutch East Indies. His career began in 1953. 

Rosidi worked to preserve Sundanese culture as well as other cultures of Indonesia. He founded and led the research project and folklore Pantun Sundanese (PPP-FS), during the period 1970 to 1973. 

In 2000 he wrote Encyclopedia: Encyclopedia of Culture Sundanese. 

Rosidi died on 29 July 2020 in Magelang, Central Java at the age of 82.

[[Ayo Fasanmi]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Nigerian businesspeople, Nigerian politicians

Ayorinde Fasanmi (27 September 1925 – 29 July 2020) was a Nigerian pharmacist and politician. He was born in Iye Ekiti, Nigeria. 

He joined the Unity Party of Nigeria in 1978 and was a candidate in the Ondo State gubernatorial primary election but lost. 

In 1983, he was elected member of the Federal House of Representatives representing

Ondo North.

He later served as member of the Board of Directors of the Old Western Nigeria Housing Corporation.

[[Salko Bukvarević]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnia and Herzegovina politicians, Civil servants

Salko Bukvarević (20 April 1967 – 29 July 2020) was a Bosnian politician and soldier. He was the Minister for Veterans and Disabled Veterans between 2015 to 2020. In 1990, Bukvarević was one of the founders of the Party of Democratic Action. 

During the Yugoslav Wars he served in the Bosnian army and was one of the founders of the Patriotic League paramilitary unit. 

He was born in Gornje Hrasno, Kalesija, SRBH, SFRY. He died on 29 July 2020 in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina from COVID-19 at the age of 53.

Clinton County is a county in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 census, 75,382 people live here. The county seat is St. Johns. It was created in 1831.

[[Nicholas Micozzie]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, US Republican Party politicians

Nicholas Anthony "Nick" Micozzie (September 7, 1930 – July 28, 2020) was an American politician. He was a Republican member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives for the 163rd district from 1979 to 2014. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

Micozzie died on July 28, 2020 from problems caused by a fall at his home in Upper Darby Township, Pennsylvania at the age of 89.

[[Martin Konings]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Labour Party (Netherlands) politicians, People from 's-Hertogenbosch, Politicians from North Brabant

Martinus Johannes "Martin" Konings (15 March 1929 – 28 July 2020) was a Dutch Labour politician. He was a member of the House of Representatives between 1973 and 1986. He was born in 's-Hertogenbosch, Netherlands. 

Konings died on 28 July 2020 in Maastricht, Netherlands at the age of 91.

[[Angelo Carossino]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, MEPs for Italy, Former MEPs

Angelo Carossino (21 February 1929 – 28 July 2020) was an Italian politician. He was President of Liguria between 1975 to 1979. He was a MEP from 1979 to 1989. Before, he was Mayor of Savona between 1958 to 1967.

Carossino died on 28 July 2020, aged 91.

[[Jurjaan Koolen]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch Olympians, Dutch volleyball players, Sportspeople from North Holland

Jurjaan Christiaan Koolen (20 September 1938 – 23 June 2020) was a Dutch volleyball player. He competed in the men's tournament at the 1964 Summer Olympics. He was born in Monnickendam, Netherlands.

Koolen died on 23 June 2020, aged 81.

[[White tea]]

CATEGORIES: Tea

White tea may refer to one of several styles of tea which generally feature young or minimally processed leaves of the Camellia sinensis plant. 

Most definitions agree, however, that white tea is not rolled or oxidizedMay 2020, resulting in a flavor characterized as "lighter" than most green or traditional black teas.

It is harvested primarily in China, mostly in the Fujian province.

[[Jasmine tea]]

CATEGORIES: Tea

Jasmine tea (茉 or 香) is tea scented with the aroma of jasmine blossoms. Jasmine tea has green tea as the tea base; however, white tea and black tea are also used. The resulting flavour of jasmine tea is subtly sweet and highly fragrant.

[[Ginseng tea]]

CATEGORIES: Tea

Ginseng tea or insam-cha (인삼차 insam means ginseng and cha means tea in Korean) is a traditional Korean tea made with ginseng.

While it is called a tea, ginseng tea does not contain tea leaves. It is a herbal tea infusion made out of the ginseng plant's root.

[[Oolong]]

CATEGORIES: Tea

Oolong (pron; 烏龍 (wūlóng, "black dragon") is a traditional semi-oxidized Chinese tea (Camellia sinensis) produced through a process including withering the plant under strong sun. 

Oolong is especially popular in south China.

The creation of oolong tea involves repeating stages to achieve the desired amount of bruising and browning of leaves. Withering, rolling, shaping, and firing are similar to black tea.

[[Herbal tea]]

CATEGORIES: Tea

Herbal teas—less commonly called tisanes (UK and US t, US also t)—are beverages made from the infusion or decoction of herbs, spices, or other plant material in hot water. 

The term "herbal tea" is often used to show the difference between true teas (e.g., black, green, white, yellow, oolong) which are made from Camellia sinensis. 

[[Yellow tea]]

CATEGORIES: Tea

Yellow tea can refer to Chinese huángchá (黃茶) and Korean hwangcha (황차). is an increasingly rare and expensive variety of tea. The process for making yellow tea is similar to that of green but with an added step of encasing and steaming the tea.

[[The Black Forest Girl (1950 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 drama movies, 1950s romantic drama movies, German drama movies

The Black Forest Girl (Schwarzwaldmädel) is a 1950 German romantic drama movie directed by Hans Deppe and based on the 1917 play of the same name by Leon Jessel and August Neidhart. It stars Paul Hörbiger, Sonja Ziemann, Gretl Schörg, Rudolf Prack, Walter Müller, Ernst Waldow.

[[Carbon Cliff, Illinois]]

[[Hurricane Isaias]]

CATEGORIES: Hurricanes in North Carolina, Hurricanes in New England, Hurricanes in the Dominican Republic, Hurricanes in Florida, July 2020 events, August 2020 events

Hurricane Isaias was an Atlantic tropical cyclone in July and August 2020. The storm moved over the Leeward Islands, Hispaniola and the Bahamas. Isaias later threatened the East Coast of the United States from Florida to Maine.

Isaias first began on July 28 as Potential Tropical Cyclone Nine. It was upgraded to Tropical Storm Isaias on July 30.

Hurricane or tropical storm notices were put up from the Windward Islands to United States' East Coast. The storm made landfall at 03:10 UTC August 4 in North Carolina, moving up the East Coast and dissipating on August 5. 

[[Sharon, Kansas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Barber County, Kansas

Sharon is a city in Barber County, Kansas, United States. 158 people lived there at the 2010 census.

[[P. Lakshmi Narasu]]

CATEGORIES: Indian writers, Buddhists, Tamil people

Pokala Lakshmi Narasu (1861 – 14 July 1934), sometimes known as P. L. Narasu or P. Lakshmi Narasu, was an Indian scholar, author, social reformer and Buddhist philosopher. He was a professor of Physics.  His research papers have been published in science journals. He worked mainly on dynamics. 

[[Nyctimystes kuduki]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes kuduki  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  It lives on mountains with rainforests in Southern Highlands Province.

The adult male frog is 5.8 to 6.1 cm long, which is large for a frog in Nyctimystes.  It has yellow or gold veins on its lower eyelids.  The male frog sits on leaves over fast-flowing streams and sings for female frogs.  It has very small ears for a Nyctimystes frog.  It has very large, dark brown eyes.  It has two big groups of vomerine teeth in its upper jaw.  This frog has dark brown and light brown skin.  Some parts of its legs are yellow.  It has a dull white belly.  It has white spots on its back and eyelids.

Scientists named this frog after Max Kuduk, who worked for the World Wide Fund for Nature.

[[Grewia asiatica (phalsa or falsa)]]

CATEGORIES: Malvaceae

Grewia asiatica is a plant in the genus Grewia. It was first found in Varanasi, India and was taken by Buddhist scholars to other Asian countries and the rest of the world. Grewia celtidifolia was initially considered a mere variety of Phalsa, but is now recognized as a distinct species.

[[Joan Mari Torrealdai]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish writers, Spanish journalists, Political writers, European sociologists, Cancer deaths in Spain

Joan Mari Torrealdai Nabea (November 24, 1942 – July 31, 2020) was a Spanish writer, journalist and sociologist. He was a member of Euskaltzaindia (the Royal Academy of the Basque Language). He was born in Forua, Spain. 

In 2003, he was arrested and tortured by the Government of Spain in a campaign against the newspaper Euskaldunon Egunkaria. In 2007 he was appointed as a full member of the Royal Academy of the Basque Language. In 2011 he took charge of the Azkue Library of the Academy.

Torrealdai died on July 31, 2020 in Basque Country, Spain from cancer at the age of 77.

[[Mark Rocco]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, English professional wrestlers, Sportspeople from Manchester

Mark Hussey (11 May 1951 – 30 July 2020) was an English professional wrestler. He competed for Joint Promotions,  All Star Wrestling and the second BWF as Mark "Rollerball" Rocco and as the original masked Black Tiger in New Japan Pro Wrestling (NJPW) during the 1970s and '80s. 

He was known for appearing on ITV's World of Sport. He was born in Manchester, England.

Hussey died on 30 July 2020 at his home in Tenerife, Canary Islands at the age of 69.

[[Bill Mack (songwriter)]]

Bill Mack (June 4, 1932 – July 31, 2020) was an American country music singer-songwriter, and radio host. He was born in Fort Worth, Texas. He was known for his songs "Blue" and "Drinking Champagne". He was also known for hosting radio shows on WBAP and XM Radio.

[[Eusebio Leal]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Mexican historians, People from Havana

Eusebio Leal Spengler (11 September 1942 – 31 July 2020) was a Cuban-Mexican historian. He was born in Havana. He was director of the  restoration program of Old Havana and its historical center,  UNESCO World Heritage Site and was an honorary member of the National Assembly of People's Power. He was a well known historian of the city of Havana.

Leal died on 31 July 2020 in Havana from pancreatic cancer, aged 77.

[[Gilles Lapouge]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, French journalists

Gilles Lapouge (November 7, 1923 – July 31, 2020) was a French writer and journalist. He worked with the daily O Estado de S. Paulo. He won the 2007 Prix Femina Essai. He worked for many newspapers in Brazil and later worked for Le Monde when he moved back to France.

Lapouge died on July 31, 2020 at the age of 96.

[[Miodrag Živković (sculptor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Sculptors, Educators, People from Belgrade

Miodrag Živković (Serbian Cyrillic: Миодраг Живковић; (1928 — 31 July 2020) was a Serbian sculptor. He was most well known for his work on memorial statues throughout the Former Yugoslavia.

After working as an arts teaching instructor in Mladenovac and Novi Beograd, he was hired as an Assistant Professor at the Faculty of Applied Arts within the University of Arts in Belgrade, becoming Dean in 1974. He left the job in 1977. From 1977 to 1984 he was head of the Faculty's sculpture department. From 1991 to 1996 he was again Dean of the Faculty.

Živković died on 31 July 2020 in Belgrade, aged 92.

[[Le Chaudron infernal]]

CATEGORIES: 1903 movies, French horror movies, Silent movies

Le Chaudron infernal is a French silent trick movie made in 1903. It was directed by  Georges Méliès. In  Britain it was released as The Infernal Cauldron and in the United States as The Infernal Caldron and the Phantasmal Vapors. It was released by Méliès's Star Film Company and is numbered 499–500 in its catalogues.

[[Imogen]]

CATEGORIES: Given names

Imogen or Imogene is an English first name. The first recorded use of the name is under the English playwright William Shakespeare. It is chiefly used as a given name in several countries. They include Canada, the United States, Ireland, Australia and South Africa.

Imogen or Imogene was used on several celebrities, including Imogene Coca and Imogen Hassall.

[[Jagongan Jail]]

CATEGORIES: Indonesia

Jagongan Jail is an entrepreneurial training program for the fostered citizens of Malang First Class Correctional Institutions or also known as LAPAS Lowokwaru Malang. The fostered citizens are guided and trained to become professional in technical matters such as baristas, cafe servants and also capster (hair stylists).

[[Mike Gale]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, New Jersey Nets players, Portland Trail Blazers players, San Antonio Spurs players, Golden State Warriors players, Sportspeople from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Michael Eugene Gale (July 18, 1950 – July 31, 2020) was an American basketball player. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. 

Gale played in the National Basketball Association and American Basketball Association. He played for the Kentucky Colonels (1971–1974), the New York Nets (1974–1975), the San Antonio Spurs (1975–1980), the Portland Trail Blazers (1980–1981), and the Golden State Warriors (1981–1982).  

Gale died on July 31, 2020 at the age of 70.

[[Alex Dupont]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, French footballers, French football managers

Alex Dupont (30 June 1954 -  1 August 2020) was a French football manager and former player.

He coached Dunkerque, Charleville, Boulogne, Gueugnon, with whom he won the Coupe de la Ligue in 2000, Sedan, Laval, Amiens. 

He managed Brest beginning in 2009, when he took over Gérald Baticle.

He died on 1 August 2020.

[[Helena Žigon]]

CATEGORIES: Slovenian sportspeople, 1928 births, 2020 deaths

Helena Žigon (13 April 1928 – 30 July 2020) was a Slovenian long-distance runner between 1946 and 2014.

She was the oldest Slovenian runner who ran all Ljubljana Marathons. She ran the half marathon in Istrian on her 86th birthday.

Žigon died on 30 July 2020, aged 92.

[[Jorge Santibáñez Ceardi]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Mayors, Chilean politicians

Jorge Santibáñez Ceardi (1 March 1934 – 30 July 2020) was a Chilean politician and lawyer. He was a member of the Christian Democratic Party. He was a Deputy from 1965 to 1973. He was Mayor of Viña del Mar from 1994 to 1996. 

Santibáñez Ceardi died at the age of 86 on 30 July 2020.

[[Face transplant]]

CATEGORIES: Medical procedures

A face transplant is a medical procedure to replace all or part of a person's face using tissue from a donor. 

The world's first partial face transplant on a living human was carried out in France in 2005. The world's first full face transplant was completed in Spain in 2010. Turkey, France, the United States and Spain are seen as the leading countries in the research into the procedure.

[[Connie Culp]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2020 deaths, Infectious disease deaths in the United States, Organ transplant recipients, American crime victims, People from Ohio

Connie Culp (March 26, 1963 – July 30, 2020) was the first United States recipient of a partial face transplant. It was performed at the Cleveland Clinic in December 2008.

Culp was shot in the face by her husband Thomas G. "Tom" Culp in a failed murder–suicide in September 2004. The shotgun blast destroyed Culp's nose, cheeks, the roof of her mouth and an eye. She had over thirty surgeries. 

Culp died on July 30, 2020 at the Cleveland Clinic from problems caused by an infection, aged 57.

[[R. Toros]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, French sculptors

Toros Rasguélénian, real name of R. Toros (12 December 1934 – 29 July 2020) was a French sculptor.

He settled in Valence, then in Romans-sur-Isère, both in the Drôme region. He made a large amount of monuments in memory of the victims of the Armenian Genocide, of which his uncle was a victim. These monuments can be found in Valence, Aix-en-Provence, Marseille, and Saint-Étienne. 

He awarded the Trophée Toros to the best piece of Franco-Armenian literature published each year in Marseille.

R. Toros died on 29 July 2020 in Romans-sur-Isère at the age of 85.

[[Marcelo Elío Chávez]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Journalists, Bolivian politicians, Civil servants

Marcelo Elío Chavez (15 May 1966 – 27 July 2020) was a Bolivian politician and journalist. He was born in Oruro, Bolivia. He was a member of the Movement for Socialism. He was President of the Plurinational Legislative Assembly from 2014 to 2015.

Elío Chávez died in Oruro on 27 July 2020, aged 54.

[[Turning Point USA]]

CATEGORIES: Conservatism

Turning Point USA (TPUSA) is an American conservative nonprofit organization. 

TPUSA's related organizations include Turning Point News, the Turning Point Endowment, Turning Point Action, and Students for Trump. 

TPUSA's wants to "identify, educate, train and organize students to promote the principles of fiscal responsibility, free markets and limited government." 

[[Roger Williams (hepatologist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, British educators, British physicians

Roger Stanley Williams CBE FRCS FRCP FRCPE FRACP FMedSci (28 August 1931 – 26 July 2020) was a British professor of hepatology. He was Director of the Institute of Hepatology, London and Professor of Hepatology, King's College London. 

He was also Medical Director of the charity, the Foundation for Liver Research a UK registered charity (RCN 1134579) and was the lead person of the Lancet Commission into Liver Disease in the UK.

[[Janine Despinette]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, French literary critics

Janine Despinette (1926 – 24 July 2020) was a French researcher and critic of children's literature. She was born in Aix-les-Bains, France. She was known for creating the idea of "color literature" which says that illustrations have as much power to the reader as words and narrations.

Despinette died on 24 July 2020, aged 94.

[[East Frisia]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Lower Saxony, Regions of Germany

East Frisia is a region in Lower Saxony, Germany. In German it is called Ostfriesland. The area is near the coast, and also includes some of the East Frisian Islands. It is one of the regions where Low German is still widely spoken. About half of the population still speak Low German in everyday life.

The Gwich'in people are a group of people who live in Alaska and Canada, above the Arctic Circle.

[[Keiko Kato]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Japanese Go players, Sportswomen, Living people

Keiko Kato is a Japanese professional Go player at Nihon Ki-in. Her husband is also a professional Go player. She has several title match appearances since the 2000s.

[[2020 Atlantic hurricane season]]

CATEGORIES: Atlantic hurricane seasons, 2020 disasters

The 2020 Atlantic hurricane season was the most active Atlantic hurricane season ever recorded, breaking the record of 2005. The season had a record-breaking 12 storms that hit the U.S, with many making landfall in Louisiana. The season had had thirty-one tropical or subtropical cyclones, thirty named storms, fourteen hurricanes, and seven major hurricanes. It had over twenty tropical storms that broke formation date records. The season happened during the COVID-19 pandemic, making it harder to evacuate and give help to people who needed it. The season did not have a Category 5 hurricane, ending the 4-year streak of Category 5 hurricanes.

[[Majorana fermion]]

CATEGORIES: Physics

A Majorana fermion(m), also referred to as a Majorana particle, is a fermion that has the same properties as its antiparticle. Ettore Majorana, an Italian physicist, thought they would exist, in 1937.  Majorana disappeared in 1938, and the particles are named after him. As Majorana fermionns are thought to have the same properties as their antiparticles, they cannot have an electric charge. Today, atomic particles with an electric charge are called Dirac fermions. An example for Dirac fermions are electrons, and positrons; they have the same properties, but their electric charge is different. 

Neutrinos do not have an electric charge, and might be Majorana fermions, but their status is unclear

[[Tomoko Kato]]

Tomoko Kato is a Japanese professional Go player at Nihon Ki-in. Her mentor is Kazuko Sugiuchi (Sachiko Honda's sister).

[[Folklore (Taylor Swift album)]]

CATEGORIES: Taylor Swift, 2020 albums

Folklore (styled in lowercase) is the eighth studio album by American recording artist Taylor Swift.  It was released on July 24, 2020.  Swift released the album as a surprise when her Loverfest stadium tour was canceled due to the 2019–20 coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. She produced the album with her longtime collaborator Jack Antonoff, along with Aaron Dessner. It is Swift's first album with a Parental Advisory logo. It was released to all music streaming platforms.

Swift announced the album the day before its release.

On August 3, 2020, Billboard revealed that both folklore and its lead single, "cardigan", entered at the top of both the Billboard 200 album chart and Hot 100 singles chart. This marked Swift's sixth US number-one song and her seventh US number-one album. She became the first artist to have a song and album both debut at number one in the same week and is the only artist to have seven of her albums enter at number one. The songs "the 1" and "exile" featuring Bon Iver entered at numbers four and six of the Hot 100.

Nil sine numine is the state motto of Colorado. In Latin, it means Nothing without the Deity or Nothing without the divine will.

[[Numen]]

CATEGORIES: History of religion

Numen, pl. numina,  is a Latin term.  It is used  for "divinity", a "divine presence" or a "divine will." The Latin authors defined it as follows. Cicero writes of a "divine mind" (divina mens), a god "whose numen everything obeys," and a "divine power" (vis divina) "which pervades the lives of men." It causes the motions and cries of birds during augury. In his Aeneid, Virgil tells about the  how the one-eyed giant, Polyphemus, is blinded:  First, Odysseus and his men "ask for the assistance of the great numina" (magna precati numina). Reviewing public opinion of Augustus on the day of his funeral, the historian Tacitus reports that some thought "no honor was left to the gods" when he "established the cult of himself" (se ... coli vellet) "with temples and the effigies of numina" (effigie numinum). Pliny the younger in a letter to Paternus raves about the "power," the "dignity," and "the majesty;" in short, the "numen of history." Lucretius uses the expression numen mentis, or "bidding of the mind," where "bidding" is numen, not, however, the divine numen, unless the mind is to be considered divine, but as simply human will.

Since the early 20th century, numen has sometimes been treated in the history of religion as a pre-animistic phase. This is a belief system that comes from an earlier time. Sociologists also use the term Numen to refer to the idea of magical power coming from an object, particularly when writing about ideas in the western tradition. When used in this sense, numen means almost the same thing as mana. However, some authors only use the word mana for ideas about magic from Polynesia and Southeast Asia.

[[2020 Darfur attacks]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in Africa, 2020s murders in Africa, Darfur conflict, July 2020 events, Mass murder in 2020, Mass shootings in Africa, Mass shootings in the 2020s, Massacres in Africa

The 2020 Darfur attacks were three mass shootings. They occurred from 12-26 July 2020 in Darfur, Sudan, killing 89 people. They were part of the War in Darfur, which continued with major clashes in January 2021.

[[Olivia Jordan]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, American movie actors, American television actors, American television personalities, Democrats (United States), Boston University alumni, Models from Oklahoma, Actors from Tulsa, Oklahoma, Living people

August 2020

Olivia Jordan Thomas (born September 28, 1988) is an American model, actress, TV show host and beauty pageant titleholder from Oklahoma who won Miss USA 2015 and also finished 3rd in Miss Universe 2015. She was the first Oklahoman to be crowned Miss USA.

[[Amir Sarkhosh]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 births, Snooker players, Living people, Iranian sportspeople

Amir Sarkhosh (born May 30, 1991) is an Iranian snooker player.

Amir Sarkhosh won his first international position in Lebanon in 2013 and won a solo bronze and gold team in the West Asian championship, and has won three more in a team in 2013.

[[United States Marshals Service]]

CATEGORIES: 1789 establishments in the United States, Federal law enforcement agencies of the United States, Organizations based in the United States, United States Department of Justice, United States intelligence agencies

The U.S. Marshals Service does law enforcement for federal courts. It is mainly responsible for protecting court officers like judges in court buildings.

It is also responsible for finding fugitives, serving arrest warrants, and prisoner transport.

It is different from the FBI, which is responsible for things like counter-terrorism and going after organized crime, and which operates in multiple countries, not just the USA.

[[Chizu Kobayashi]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Japanese Go players, Sportswomen, Living people

Chizu Kobayashi is a Japanese professional Go player at Nihon Ki-in. She has several professional Go players in her relatives. Her brother is the president of Nihon Ki-in.

[[Fareway]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Iowa, 1938 establishments in the United States, Supermarkets of the United States

Fareway Stores is an American grocery company. Fareway is based in Boone, Iowa. It operates over 120 grocery stores in South Dakota, Nebraska, Minnesota, Iowa and Illinois. 

Fareway is a family-owned business in the Midwestern United States. Some stores open as early as 6am. Some remain open unti 11pm. All Fareway grocery stores are closed Sundays and major holidays.

Fareway was founded in 1938.

[[Winn-Dixie]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 establishments in Florida, Supermarkets of the United States, Jacksonville, Florida

Winn-Dixie is a supermarket chain. They have stores in Georgia, Louisiana, Arkansas, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida. The company once served Oklahoma, Texas, South Carolina, North Carolina and New Mexico. Now, they mainly serve the Southeastern United States.

The company is headquartered in Jacksonville, Florida. 

Winn-Dixie has its private label Chek for sodas. The sodas have over 20 different flavors.

Winn-Dixie was established in 1925. It is owned by Southeastern Grocers.

[[Ayumi Ishida]]

CATEGORIES: Japanese singers, j-pop, Japanese movie actors

Ayumi Ishida (いしだあゆみ) is a Japanese popular actress and singer. She was born on March 26, 1948 in Nagasaki, Japan.

Ishida has officially started as a singer in 1964. Then in December, 1968 her early recording "Blue Light Yokohama" (ja:ブルー・ライト・ヨコハマ) was made public by a songwriter Kyohei Tsutsumi (筒美京平). This single recording was her biggest hit, and nominated as a best vocal performance award in Japan. Thanks to its hit, she was introduced on a then NHK program "紅白歌合戦" in the same year and became popular throughout Japan.

Ishida also acted as actress on dramas on television, too. She appeared on many movies such as "男はつらいよ".

[[Terumi Koyama]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Sportswomen, Japanese Go players, People from Kanagawa Prefecture, Living people

Terumi Koyama (小山栄美) is a Japanese professional Go player at Nihon Ki-in. Her husband, son and father in law are also professional Go players. Her mentor is Masao Kato.

[[Joseph Kasa-Vubu]]

CATEGORIES: 1915 births, 1969 deaths, Presidents of the Democratic Republic of the Congo

Joseph Kasa-Vubu (circa 1917 – 24 March 1969) was a Congolese politician. He was the first President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (then Republic of the Congo) from 1960 to 1965.

[[One Tree Hill (TV show)]]

CATEGORIES: WB network shows, English-language television programs

One Tree Hill is an American TV drama. It aired from 2003 to 2012. It is about two half-brothers, Lucas and Nathan Scott, who live in the town of Tree Hill in North Carolina. They play on the school basketball team and have romantic relationships.

[[Wim Scherpenhuijsen Rom]]

CATEGORIES: Dutch businesspeople, Bankers, 1933 births, 2020 deaths

Willem Elmert “Wim” Scherpenhuijsen Rom (15 March 1933 – 31 July 2020) was a Dutch banker. He was co-founder of the ING Group.

Scherpenhuijsen Rom started working at NMB Bank in 1967. He was main person in the fusion between NMB Bank and Postbank in 1989. He became CEO of the ING Group in 1992. He was also highly involved in the merger of NMB Postbank Group and Nationale-Nederlanden in the early 1990s.

Scherpenhuijsen Rom died on 31 July 2020, aged 87.

[[Resurreccion Borra]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Filipino politicians

Resurreccion Borra (October 20, 1935 – August 1, 2020) was a Filipino public servant. He worked as a Career Executive Service Officer (CESO). He also was a commissioner and was the Acting Chairman of the Philippine Commission on Elections. During his term, he became known for forcing strict rules on impeachment.  He also tried to fight against bribery in mayoral races in Manila. He was also critical of the use of modern election machines in the Philippines. 

[[David Darcy]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Australian rules footballers, Sportspeople from Victoria (Australia)

David Darcy (11 August 1943spnd1 August 2020) was an Australian rules footballer. He played for Footscray in the Victorian Football League (VFL) during the 1960s. 

Darcy also played for and coached South Adelaide in the South Australian National Football League (SANFL). He started his career at half forward but in his second season moved to defence where he excelled.  

Darcy died on 1 August 2020, aged 76.

[[Julio Diamante]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish movie directors, Spanish screenwriters

Julio Diamante (27 December 1930 – 1 August 2020) was a Spanish movie director and screenwriter. He directed ten movies between 1959 and 1976. His 1965 movie El arte de vivir was entered into the 15th Berlin International Film Festival. He also directed Sex o no sex. Diamante was born in Cádiz, Spain.

Diamante died on 1 August 2020 in Madrid, aged 89.

[[Feri Horvat]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Slovenian politicians

Feri Horvat (ˈfɛ́ːri ˈxɔ́ːrʋat; 26 September 1941 – 1 August 2020) was a Slovenian manager and politician. He was one of the founders of the United List of Social Democrats. Between July and October 2004, he served as speaker of the Slovenian National Assembly.

[[Vitold Kreyer]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Soviet sportspeople, Triple jumpers, Olympic bronze medalists

Vitold Anatolievich Kreyer (Витольд Анатольевич Креер, 12 October 1932 – 1 August 2020) was a Russian  triple jumper. He competed in the 1956, 1960 and 1964 Olympics and won bronze medals in 1956 and 1960. He won the Soviet title in 1960 and 1961 but failed to reach the finals at the 1958 and 1962 European Championships.

[[Stan Mellor]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, English sportspeople

Stanley Thomas Edward Mellor GBR (10 April 1937 – 1 August 2020) was a National Hunt jockey and trainer. He was the first jockey to ride 1,000 winners and Champion Jockey three years in a row from 1960 to 1962.

Mellor died on 1 August 2020, aged 83.

[[Khosrow Sinai]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Iranian movie directors, Iranian screenwriters, Composers, Iranian educators, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Iran

Khosrow Sinai (خسرو سینایی, 19 January 1941 – 1 August 2020) was an Iranian movie director, screenwriter, music composer and scholar. He was born in Sari, Iran. He was known for his movie In the Alleys of Love.

Sinai died on 1 August 2020 in Tehran from COVID-19, aged 79.

[[Amar Singh (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians, Deaths from renal failure

Amar Singh (27 January 1956 – 1 August 2020) was an Indian politician. He was one of the leaders of the Samajwadi Party. He was a member of the Rajya Sabha from 2016 until his death. 

On August 1, 2020, at the age of 64, Singh died from kidney failure at a hospital in Singapore. 

[[Andre Ptaszynski]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, British television producers, Theatre producers

André Ptaszynski (7 May 1953 – 29 July 2020) was a British theatre producer. He was a president of The Society of London Theatre and was on the board of the Royal National Theatre from 2001 to 2010.  

He died on 29 July 2020 at the age of 67.

[[Bob McCurdy]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from anal cancer, American basketball players, Sportspeople from New York

Robert McCurdy (February 26, 1952spndJuly 29, 2020) was an American college basketball player. He played for the Richmond Spiders from 1973 to 1975. He began his collegiate career with the Virginia Cavaliers before transferring to Richmond. He was born in Deer Park, New York.

McCurdy died on July 29, 2020 from anal cancer in Connecticut, aged 68.

[[Deer Park, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in New York (state), Hamlets in New York

Deer Park is a hamlet and census-designated place (CDP) in the town of Babylon, Suffolk County, New York, United States. The population was 27,745 at the 2010 census.

[[Olive Ann Alcorn]]

CATEGORIES: American silent movie actors, Actors from Minnesota, American models, American dancers, Deaths from anal cancer, 1900 births, 1975 deaths

Olive Ann Alcorn (October 2, 1900 – January 8, 1972) was an American dancer, model, and silent movie actress of the 1910s and 1920s. She was known for the many nude photographs of her from the era than for her movie work.

[[Khalil Taha]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Lebanese people, Olympic bronze medalists, Wrestlers

Khalil Taha (13 July 1932 – 27 July 2020) was a Lebanese wrestler. At the 1951 Mediterranean Games in Alexandria Egypt, Taha won the silver medal in the 73 kg Greco-Roman wrestling.

At the 1952 Summer Olympics, he won the bronze medal in the men's Greco-Roman Welterweight category.

[[John Guinness]]

CATEGORIES: British businesspeople, 1935 births, 2020 deaths

Sir John Ralph Sidney Guinness CBE (23 December 1935 – 27 July 2020) was a British civil servant and businessman.

Guinness was a member of HM Diplomatic Service and had worked in the Cabinet Office and was Permanent Secretary of the Department of Energy. from 1991 to 1992 and Chairman of British Nuclear Fuels Ltd from 1992 to 1993.

He died on 27 July 2020.

[[Bill English (computer engineer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, American computer scientists, American engineers, People from Lexington, Kentucky, Scientists from Kentucky

William Kirk English (January 27, 1929 – July 26, 2020) was an American computer engineer. He was known for helping create the computer mouse while working for Douglas Engelbart at SRI International's Augmentation Research Center. He would later work for Xerox PARC and Sun Microsystems.

English died of respiratory failure in San Rafael, California on July 26, 2020, aged 91.

[[Wang Hai]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese generals, Aviators

Wang Hai (王海; 19 January 1926 – 2 August 2020) was a Chinese retired fighter pilot and general. He was a flying ace of the Korean War. He was Commander of the People's Liberation Army Air Force (PLAAF) from 1985 to 1992. He was awarded the rank of general (shang jiang) in 1988. He was born in Shandong, China.

Wang died on 2 August 2020 in Beijing, aged 94.

[[Judith Collins]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, Leaders of the Opposition (New Zealand)

Judith Anne Collins (born 24 February 1959) is a New Zealand politician. She has been the Leader of the New Zealand National Party and Leader of the Opposition since 14 July 2020. She has been the Member of Parliament (MP) for Papakura since 2002. He was a government minister under John Key and Bill English.

[[Todd Muller]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, Leaders of the Opposition (New Zealand)

Todd Michael Muller (ˈ; born 23 December 1968) is a New Zealand politician. He was the Leader of the New Zealand National Party and the Leader of the Opposition from 22 May to 14 July 2020. 

He entered Parliament at the 2014 general election as the MP for Bay of Plenty.

Muller resigned on 14 July 2020, stating, "I am not the best person to be Leader of the Opposition and Leader of the New Zealand National Party at this critical time for New Zealand" and that the role has had a negative impact on his health. At just 53 days, Muller is the shortest serving leader of any political party represented in Parliament in New Zealand's history.

[[Dirac fermion]]

CATEGORIES: Physics

In particle physics, a Dirac fermion is a particle that is different from its antiparticle. This is true for most particles. In the standard model of physics, each particle has its antiparticle. They are named for Paul Dirac, and can be modeled with the Dirac equation.

A Dirac fermion is equivalent to two Weyl fermions. The counterpart to a Dirac fermion is a Majorana fermion, a particle that must be its own antiparticle. Neutrinos are particles without an electric charge, they might be Majorana fermions.

Black Moon is a 1975 French West German horror movie directed by Louis Malle and starring Cathryn Harrison, Joe Dallesandro, Therese Giehse, and Alexandra Stewart.

[[Zhaksylyk Ushkempirov]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Kazakhstani sportspeople, Olympic gold medalists

Zhaksylyk Ushkempirov (6 May 1951 – 2 August 2020) was a light-flyweight Greco-Roman wrestler from Kazakhstan. He won an Olympic gold medal in 1980 and a world title in 1981.

Ushkempirov took up wrestling in 1969 and won the Soviet title in 1975 and 1980. 

[[Syed Iftikhar Ul Hassan]]

He was a member of the National Assembly from June 2013 to May 2018. He was a member of the Pakistan Muslim League (N). 

Hassan died on 2 August 2020 at the age of 78.

[[Kamal Rani Varun]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians

Kamal Rani Varun (3 May 1958 – 2 August 2020) was an Indian politician. She was member of Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly from 2017 to 2020. She was also a member of Eleventh and Twelfth Lok Sabha between 1996 to 1999. She was born in Lucknow. Varun was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

On 2 August 2020, Varun died at a hospital in Lucknow at the age of 62 from COVID-19.

[[José Vicente Anaya]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Mexican poets, Mexican journalists

José Vicente Anaya (22 January 1947 – 1 August 2020) was a Mexican writer, poet and cultural journalist. He was born in Chihuahua, Mexico. He wrote over thirty books and was part of the Infrarealism poetry movement in Mexico City. He also translated poems of Allen Ginsberg and Carl Sandburg.

Anaya died on 1 August 2020 in Mexico City, aged 73.

[[Male privilege]]

CATEGORIES: Feminism

Male privilege is the system of advantages or rights that men have because of their sex. 

Special privileges and status are granted to males in patriarchal societies.

Many men have responded to this by saying that they do not feel that they have been given any unearned advantages, such as in their struggles to find success in employment, education, or relationships. Supporters for men's rights and father's rights as well as anti-feminist men often accept that men's traditional roles are damaging to men.

[[Ted Yoho]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, United States representatives from Florida, Businesspeople from Florida, Businesspeople from Minneapolis, Minnesota, Politicians from Minneapolis, Minnesota, US Republican Party politicians

Theodore Scott Yoho ˈ (born April 13, 1955) is an American politician, veterinarian, and businessman. He was a member of the U.S. Representative from FL between 2013 to 2021. He is a member of the Republican Party.

In the 2012 Republican primary election for the district, Yoho beat long-term incumbent U.S. Congressman Cliff Stearns. In December 2019, Yoho announced that he would not run for re-election to Congress in 2020.

[[Roger Williams (American politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, United States representatives from Texas, Businesspeople from Texas, Businesspeople from Illinois, Politicians from Illinois, People from Evanston, Illinois, US Republican Party politicians

John Roger Williams (born September 13, 1949) is an American businessman and politician. He has been the U.S. Representative for Texas's 25th congressional district since 2013. He is a member of the Republican Party. He worked for Governor Rick Perry as Secretary of State of Texas from November 2004 to July 1, 2007.

With a net worth of $27.7 million, Williams is one of the wealthiest members of Congress.

[[Bill Battle]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, College football coaches, Sportspeople from Birmingham, Alabama, Sportspeople from Tennessee

William Raines Battle III (born December 8, 1941) is an American college athletics administrator and football coach.  He was the athletic director of the University of Alabama from 2013 to 2017. He was born in Birmingham, Alabama. He coached the Tennessee Volunteers between 1970 to 1976.

In August 2020, it was reported Battle was hospitalized for COVID-19.

[[Tino rangatiratanga]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of New Zealand

Tino rangatiratanga is a Māori language term that means "absolute sovereignty." Sovereignty means absolute power to rule something without someone else interfering. In this case, it refers to the ability of the Māori people (the indigenous people of New Zealand) to rule themselves and be recognized as the owners of the land. "Tino rangatiratanga" shows up in the Māori version of the Treaty of Waitangi, which they signed with the British in 1840. They were promised that they would have tino rangatiratanga forever in the treaty. However, this concept was not respected since the British colonizers took a lot of things from the Māori people. To this day, people in New Zealand do not agree on what "tino rangatiratanga" means or what kind of things it is supposed to cover.

[[Venae cavae]]

CATEGORIES: Blood vessels

The superior vena cava is the large vein which returns blood to the heart from the head, neck and both upper limbs. The inferior vena cava returns blood to the heart from the lower part of the body.

The return of blood via the vena cava can be compromised and cause disease. For example, in the superior vena cava syndrome, the symptoms that result from compression of the large vein that carries blood down to the heart.

[[Brick red]]

CATEGORIES: Shades of red

Brick Red is a Maroon-like color. Similar to the color of a brick

The name comes from its similarity to the color of a brick.

[[Saori Minami]]

CATEGORIES: japanese singers

Saori Minami (born Akemi Shinoyama, 篠山 明美) is a retired Japanese female popular singer. She was also called "Cynthia" as a nickname.  

[[Executive order]]

CATEGORIES: Law

An executive order or executive decree is a rule or order, or a law made by a head of state (president or monarch) who has this power given to him by the constitution of the country. The order tells ministries, agencies, the civil service and the military of a state the things that they must do.

Executive orders can be stopped by the courts in a process called judicial review. They may be stopped by the courts or the legislature if they are against laws or against the constitution. 

However, in countries where there is no real separation of powers and the head of state is actually a dictator, the executive order cannot be stopped by the courts or the legislature, which as a result have no powers and are controlled by him. In many cases, the head of state with dictatorial powers often rules the country by making executive orders rather than making laws in the legislature which he also controls.

Executive orders have a big effect on the internal affairs of the government and on the citizens. They decide how and to what degree legislation will be enforced. They also deal with emergencies and wars.

[[Naft Masjed Soleyman F.C.]]

Naft Masjed Soleyman Football Club (باشگاه فوتبال نفت مسجدسلیمان) is an Iranian LOR football club based in Masjed-Soleyman, Iran.

[[Two Guys from Milwaukee]]

[[Kunigami language]]

CATEGORIES: Ryukyuan languages, Languages of Asia, Japan

The Kunigami language (Kunigami: 山原言葉, Yanbaru kutūba) is an endangered Ryukyuan language spoken in the Kunigami area of Okinawa, Japan.

Japan calls it a dialect while most linguists put Kunigami as its own language within the Ryukyuan languages group.

Kunigami is somewhat understandable to people who speak the Okinawan language. However, Japanese speakers wouldn’t be able to understand Kunigami. There are also different dialects of Kunigami, such as the one on Okinoerabu.

[[Qui transtulit sustinet]]

CATEGORIES: Connecticut, Latin state mottos of the United States

Qui transtulit sustinet is the state motto of Connecticut. It means "He who transplanted sustains" in Latin.

[[Rumex spinosus]]

CATEGORIES: Caryophyllales

Lesser Jack (Rumex spinosus) is a Mediterrenean plant that grows annually, in which its large leaves usually have three spines.

[[Dirigo]]

CATEGORIES: Latin state mottos of the United States, Maine

In Latin, Dirigo means "I direct". This phrase is the state motto of Maine, by analogy of it appearing on the state's seal. 

[[United we stand, divided we fall]]

CATEGORIES: State mottos of the United States, Aesop's Fables

United we stand, divided we fall is a phrase that is used in many mottos and phrases, often used to inspire unity. It is also used in its short form "United we stand". Aesop made up the phrase (and possibly invented it) in his stories The Four Oxen and the Lion directly and in ":The Bundle of Sticks" indirectly. It is the state motto of Kentucky, adopted on December 30, 1792.

[[Gwichʼin language]]
