The Gwichʼin langauge (Dinju Zhuh Kʼyuu in Gwichʼin) is a language spoken by the Gwichʼin people in Canada and Alaska.

[[Nyctimystes myolae]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes myolae is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists found this frog near the village of Myola village, at 2000 meters above sea level.

This frog is brown in color.  Scientists say it is related to the common big-eyed tree frog, Nyctimystes narinosus.

[[Xoloitzcuintle]]

CATEGORIES: Dog breeds

The Xoloitzcuintle (

), or Xolo, also known as the Mexican hairless dog, is a breed of dog from Mexico. Most have no hair but some are born with hair (coated). The Xolo also has wrinkled skin. It is found in three sizes: toy, miniature, and standard. Its name is from the Nahuatl language, where it is called xōlōitzcuintli (singular) and xōlōitzcuintin (plural). The name comes from the god Xolotl and itzcuīntli, meaning dog in Nahuatl.

[[The Luck of the Irish (1948 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s comedy movies, 1940s fantasy movies, 1940s romance movies, American romantic comedy movies, American fantasy movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Henry Koster

The Luck of the Irish is a 1948 American romantic fantasy comedy movie directed by Henry Koster and starring Tyrone Power, Anne Baxter, Cecil Kellaway is his Oscar nominated role, Lee J. Cobb, Jayne Meadows. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Joseph Jerome Farris]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, Politicians from Birmingham, Alabama, US Democratic Party politicians

Joseph Jerome Farris (March 4, 1930 – July 23, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was the Senior United States Circuit Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit between 1979 until his death. Farris was nominated by President Jimmy Carter. Farris was born in Birmingham, Alabama. 

Farris died on July 23, 2020 in Seattle, Washington at the age of 90.

[[Junrey Balawing]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, 2020 deaths, People with dwarfism, Filipino people

Junrey Balawing (dʒ joon; dʒunˈrɪ bɐˈlawɪŋ; born June 12, 1993 – July 28, 2020) was a Filipino record holder at the Guinness World Records for the  world's shortest man alive measuring at 60.00 tall. The declaration came during Balawing's 18th birthday celebration. 

Guinness World Records official said Balawing broke the record of Khagendra Thapa Magar of Nepal, who was 0.67 tall.

[[Herbert Leuninger]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 deaths, 2020 deaths, German human rights activists, German theologians

Herbert Leuninger (8 September 1932 – 28 July 2020) was a German Catholic priest and theologian. He was a human rights activist for asylum in Germany. He was a co-founder of the organisation Pro Asyl, helping refugees, and a member of the board of the European Council on Refugees and Exiles. He was born in Cologne.

Leininger died after a short illness in Limburg on 28 July 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Juan Ramón]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine singers, Argentine movie actors, Deaths from pneumonia

Juan Ramón (born as Ellery Guy Rech; 13 January 1940 – 30 July 2020) was an Argentine singer and actor. He was born in Cañada de Gómez, Santa Fe. He was known for his Spanish dubbing of classic to pop French songs by Christophe such as "Aline". He also created the soundtrack for the 1970 French-Italian movie Road to Salina.

Ramón died of pneumonia-related problems in Buenos Aires on 30 July 2020, aged 80.

[[Parable]]

CATEGORIES: Parables, Metaphors, Literature

A parable is a short story in prose or verse. It teaches something. On the surface, it may be about animals or objects, but is just a metaphor for the real idea. Familiar are the parables of Jesus, where he explains an idea by telling a story. Familiar also are the parables of Aesop.

[[Robert Gnaizda]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American civil rights activists, American lawyers, Businesspeople from New York City, Businesspeople from Oakland, California

Robert Leslie Gnaizda (ɡ gə) (August 6, 1936 – July 11, 2020) was an American civil rights activist. He was the co-founder, General Counsel and Policy Director for the Greenlining Institute. He was born in New York City.

Gnaizda died of a heart attack on July 11, 2020 in San Francisco, aged 83.

[[Randal Kleiser]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, American movie directors, American television directors, Living people, American television producers, American movie producers, American screenwriters, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

John Randal Kleiser (born July 20, 1946) is an American movie and television director, producer and screenwriter. He is best known for directing the 1978 musical romantic-comedy movie Grease. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

[[Tom Pollock]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American lawyers, Movie producers from Los Angeles, California

Thomas Philip Pollock (April 10, 1943 – August 1, 2020) was an American movie producer and studio executive. He started his career as an entertainment lawyer. He was the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the American Film Institute.

He was an Adjunct Professor of Film at the University of California Santa Barbara. He was also co-owner of The Montecito Picture Company. Pollock was known for producing Hitchcock. He was born in Los Angeles.

Pollock died on August 1, 2020 from a heart attack in Los Angeles, aged 77.

[[Harold Scheraga]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, American biologists, American physicists, American educators, Scientists from New York City

Harold Scheraga (October 18, 1921 – August 1, 2020) was an American biophysicist. He was the George W. and Grace L. Todd Professor Emeritus in the chemistry department at Cornell University. He was a key person in protein biophysics and in the study of protein solvation and the hydrophobic effect as it relates to protein folding. He was born in New York City.

Scheraga died on August 1, 2020 in Ithaca, New York at the age of 98.

[[John Hume]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Former MEPs, MEPs for the United Kingdom, Northern Ireland politicians

PeaceJohn Hume KCSG (18 January 1937spnd3 August 2020) was an Irish politician. He was a founding member of the Social Democratic and Labour Party. He was co-recipient of the 1998 Nobel Peace Prize, with David Trimble.

He was the second leader of the Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP) from 1979 until 2001. He was a Member of the European Parliament and a Member of the United Kingdom Parliament, as well as a member of the Northern Ireland Assembly.

He was also a recipient of the Gandhi Peace Prize and the Martin Luther King Award. In 2012, Pope Benedict XVI made Hume a Knight Commander of the Papal Order of St. Gregory the Great.

He suffered from dementia. Hume died on 3 August 2020, at a nursing home in Derry at the age of 83.

[[American Pie (song)]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 songs, Pop songs

American Pie is an American popular song, written by a singer-songwriter Don McLean.

[[Mohammad Reza Navaei]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Wrestlers, Olympians, Sportspeople from Tehran

Mohammad Reza Navaei (محمدرضا نوايى, 1 December 1948 – 3 August 2020) was an Iranian lightweight freestyle wrestler. He won bronze medals at the 1973 World Wrestling Championships and 1974 Asian Games. He competed at the 1976 Summer Olympics. He was born in Tehran. 

Navaei died on 3 August 2020 in Tehran at the age of 71.

[[Saïd Amara]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Algerian football managers, Algerian footballers

Saïd Amara (11 March 1933 – 2 August 2020) was an Algerian football player and manager. He was born in Saïda. He played club football for MC Saïda, USM Bel-Abbès, Strasbourg, Béziers and Bordeaux. He also earned five caps for the Algerian national team between 1963 and 1964.

[[Bernard Cleary]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Quebec

Bernard Cleary (May 8, 1937 – July 27, 2020) was a Canadian politician. He was born in Mashteuiatsh, Quebec.

Cleary was first elected to the House of Commons of Canada in the 2004 Canadian federal election. He was the Bloc Québécois member of parliament for the riding of Louis-Saint-Laurent.

In 2006, he was defeated by Josée Verner from the Conservative Party of Canada.

He was the first person of Aboriginal descent to be elected in Quebec.

[[Bruno Dettori]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Italian politicians

Bruno Dettori (22 December 1941 – 2 August 2020) was an Italian politician. He was born in Sassari, Italy.

He began his political career in 1990 becoming a city councilor in Sassari under the Christian Democrats. He was elected senator at the end of the 2001 general election on 13 May 2001.  From 18 May 2006 to 7 May 2008 he  was part of the second Prodi government as Secretary for the Environment.

Dettori died on 2 August 2020, aged 78.

[[Keith Pontin]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Welsh footballers

Keith Pontin (14 June 1956 – 2 August 2020) was a Welsh professional footballer who played as a central defender.

Pontin began his career with Cardiff City. He made nearly 200 league appearances and earning two caps for the Welsh national team. He later played for Merthyr Tydfil and Barry Town.

At the age of 59, Pontin was diagnosed with dementia.

Pontin died on 2 August 2020, aged 64.

[[Bobby Prescott]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Panamanian sportspeople, Kansas City Athletics players

George Bertrand "Bobby" Prescott (March 27, 1931 – August 2, 2020) was a Panamanian professional baseball player. He was an outfielder, first baseman and third baseman. He had a 19-year career, from 1952–1970, in North American minor league baseball and a brief trial with the 1961 Kansas City Athletics of the Major Leagues. 

[[Leon Fleisher]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, American pianists, American conductors, American educators, Cancer deaths in the United States, Musicians from San Francisco

Leon Fleisher (July 23, 1928 – August 2, 2020) was an American pianist and conductor. He was one of the most renowned pianists and pedagogues in the world. He was born in San Francisco, California.

He taught at Peabody Conservatory of Music, the Curtis Institute of Music, and the Royal Conservatory of Music in Toronto. He co-founded and co-directed the Theater Chamber Players in 1968–2003, which was the first resident chamber ensemble of the Smithsonian Institution and of The Kennedy Center.

Fleisher died on August 2, 2020 from cancer under hospice care in Baltimore, Maryland, aged 92.

[[Katherine B. Hoffman]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2020 deaths, American chemists, American centenarians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Female scientists

Katherine "Kitty" Marie Blood Hoffman (August 1, 1914 – July 18, 2020) was an American chemist and academic administrator. When she retired from Florida State University, the chemistry department named a laboratory building in her honor. It was dedicated to her again in 2018.  Hoffman was awarded an honorary doctorate by Florida State University in 2007.

Hoffman died in Tallahassee Memorial HealthCare on 18 July 2020, aged 105 of COVID-19.

[[Wilmington insurrection of 1898]]

CATEGORIES: 1898 in the United States, African-American history

The Wilmington insurrection of 1898, also known as the Wilmington massacre of 1898 or the Wilmington coup of 1898, happened in Wilmington, North Carolina, on Thursday, November 10, 1898. 

It is seen as a turning point in post-Reconstruction North Carolina politics. It caused more intense racial segregation of African Americans throughout the South. It made it harder for African-Americans to vote. 

The event was caused after many white supremacists took over the Wilmington city government which was controlled by both white and black men and killed the black alderman. After the event, no black politician was in charge in Wilmington.

It has been called a race riot caused by blacks by white newspapers at the time. However, over time, with more facts publicized, the event has come to be seen as a coup d'état, the violent overthrow of a duly elected government, by a group of white supremacists. It is seen as the only coup in American history. 

The coup happens with 2,000 white men. They destroyed the property and businesses of black citizens built up since the Civil War, including the only black newspaper in the city, and killed about 60 to more than 300 people.

[[Rachel Dolezal]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, American civil rights activists, Businesspeople from Montana, American educators

Rachel Anne Dolezal (born November 12, 1977), also known as Nkechi Amare Diallo, is a self-proclaimed black American woman who was assigned white at birth. 

She is a former college instructor and National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) chapter president.

[[Billy Porter]]

CATEGORIES: Grammy Award winners, Drama Desk Award winners, Golden Globe Award winning actors, Emmy Award winning actors, 1969 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Singers from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, People with HIV/AIDS

Billy Porter (born September 21, 1969) is an American actor and singer.

Porter won the 2013 Best Actor in a Musical for his role as Lola in Kinky Boots at the 67th Tony Awards. 

In 2014 Porter won the Grammy Award for Best Musical Theater Album for Kinky Boots. He currently stars in the television series Pose for which he was nominated for a Golden Globe Award and won the 2019 Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series. 

In 2021, he confirmed he had been living with HIV for 14 years.

[[Viktor Saneyev]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Triple jumpers, Sportspeople from Georgia (country), Olympic gold medalists, Olympic silver medalists

Viktor Danilovich Saneyev (Georgia (country) ვიქტორ სანაევი born 3 October 1945) is a retired Georgian triple jumper. He competed internationally for the USSR and won four Olympic medals; three golds (1968, 1972 and 1976) and one silver (1980). He was born in Sukhumi, Georgian SSR.

[[Narumi Ohsawa]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Japanese Go players, People from Saitama Prefecture, Sportswomen, Living people

Narumi Ohsawa (大澤奈留美, sometimes written as Narumi Osawa) is a Japanese professional Go player at Nihon Ki-in. She was born at Saitama, Saitama in 1976.

[[Japanese Society for Rights of Authors, Composers and Publishers]]

CATEGORIES: Japanese music, Music industry, Organisations based in Japan, Cultural organizations, 1930s establishments in Japan, 1939 establishments

Japanese Society for Rights of Authors, Composers and Publishers is also called JASRAC in short. Its official name in Japan is 一般社団法人日本音楽著作権協会.

JASRAC was made in 1939. It is the only organization in Japan to manage and protect copyrights in Japan.

JASRAC can only manage copyrights inside Japan. As for outside Japan (for overseas), foreign organizations such as ASCAP, Muserk manage copyrights of origins of Japan instead, according to a separete agreement with these organizations. 129 foreign organizations have relation with JASRAC.

When people in Japan uses music, videos and books for business useage,  originally produced in outside Japan must pay proper money for their copyrights. For this purpose or business, JASRAC manage copyrights in turn by legal agreements with organizations overseas such as PRS for Music, ASCAP, BMI,  SESAC, HARRY FOX AGENCY and Muserk.

[[JASRAC]]

CATEGORIES:  music industry,  Japanese music

[[Abdul Hay Mosallam Zarara]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Palestinian people, Artists

Abdul Hay Mosallam Zarara (10 March 1933 – 1 August 2020) was a self-taught Palestinian artist. He was born in Al-Dawayima, near Al Khalil (Hebron), in Palestine.

Mosallam was known for recreating scenes from daily life in his lost Palestinian home. Mosallam also created documentation of the recent Palestinian struggle and liberation movements in the form of painted reliefs. 

Mosallam Zarara died on 1 August 2020 in Amman, Jordan at the age of 87.

[[Edina Müller]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, Living people, German Paralympic gold medalists, German Paralympic silver medalists, German wheelchair basketball players, Sportspeople from North Rhine-Westphalia

Edina Müller (born 28 June 1983) is a German wheelchair basketball player. She won a gold medal at the 2012 Summer Paralympics and silver medal at the 2016 Summer Paralympics.

She played several major tournaments like 2011 European Championship, 2012 Paralympic Games, and 2014 World Championships.

[[Sa. Kandasamy]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Indian movie directors, Indian writers

Sa. Kandasamy  (23 July 1940 – 31 July 2020) was an Indian novelist and filmmaker. He was born in Tamil Nadu. His 1968 novel Chayavanam was listed by the National Book Trust as a masterpiece in modern Indian Literature.

In 1998, Kandasamy was honored with the Sahitya Academy award for his novel Vicharanai Commission.

Kandasamy died on 31 July 2020 from a heart attack, aged 80.

[[Litoria nullicedens]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Litoria nullicedens is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists found this frog on the southwestern side of Mount Obree, at 550 meters above sea level.

This frog has green coloring on the inside of its mouth.  Scientists say it is related to the northern New Guinea tree frog, Litoria graminea.

[[Ua Mau ke Ea o ka ‘Āina i ka Pono]]

CATEGORIES: Hawaii, State mottos of the United States

Ua Mau ke Ea o ka ‘Āina i ka Pono is the state motto of :Hawaii. In :Hawaiian, it means "The life of the land is perpetuated in righteousness".

[[Cherokee language]]

CATEGORIES: Languages of the United States, Tonal languages, Oklahoma

The Cherokee language (ᏣᎳᎩ ᎦᏬᏂᎯᏍᏗ, Tsalagi Gawonihisdi) is an endangered language spoken by the Cherokee people.

[[Chess in Azerbaijan]]

CATEGORIES: Chess in Azerbaijan

Chess is one of the most popular sports in Azerbaijan, where it is organized by the Azerbaijan Chess Federation (ACF). On May 5, 2009 Azerbaijani president Ilham Aliyev, who is also the chairman of the National Olympic Committee, signed an executive order starting a state-supported chess development program, covering the years 2009–2014.

[[Gustaf Skarsgård]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Swedish movie actors, Swedish television actors, Swedish stage actors, Swedish voice actors, Actors from Stockholm, Living people

Gustaf Caspar Orm Skarsgård (born 12 November 1980) is a Swedish actor. He is best known outside Scandinavia for his role as Floki in the History Channel series Vikings as well as for his roles in the movies Evil (2003), The Way Back (2010) and Kon-Tiki (2012). He also played Karl Strand in the second season of the HBO series Westworld.

[[Bart's Friend Falls in Love]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons (season 3) episodes, 1992 television episodes

"Bart's Friend Falls in Love" is the 22nd episode of the 3rd season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on television on May 7, 1992. In the episode, Bart's friend Milhouse gets a girlfriend named Samantha Stanky. Bart gets jealous and tells Samantha's father about the relationship. Samantha's father sends her to a different school that only allows girls. While this happens, Homer tries to lose weight using a subliminal stimuli cassette tape. However, Homer is given a tape about using better vocabulary instead.

The beginning of the episode is a parody of the movie Raiders of the Lost Ark. The end of the episode is a parody of the movie Casablanca.

[[Darleen Carr]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, American television actors, American movie actors, American voice actors, American child actors, Deaths from brain cancer, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, Actors from Chicago, Singers from Chicago

Darleen Carr (December 12, 1950 – July 17, 2020) was an American actress, singer, and voice-over artist.  She has also been credited as Darlene Carr or Darleen Drake. She has two sisters, both actresses (Shannon Farnon and Charmian Carr).

[[Kita, Tokyo]]

CATEGORIES: Wards of Tokyo, 1947 establishments in Japan

Kita is one of the 23 special wards of Tokyo, Japan. The population was 285,321 in 2015.

On 15 March 1947, the ward of Kita was formed by combining the wards of Ōji and Takinogawa.

[[Kōtō]]

CATEGORIES: Wards of Tokyo, 1947 establishments in Japan

Kōtō is one of the 23 special wards of Tokyo, Japan. The population was 498,109 in 2015.

On 15 March 1947, the ward of Kōtō was formed by combining the wards of Fukagawa and Jōtō.

[[Sumida, Tokyo]]

CATEGORIES: Wards of Tokyo, 1947 establishments in Japan

Sumida is one of the 23 special wards of Tokyo, Japan. The population was 256,274 in 2015.

On 15 March 1947, the ward of Sumida was formed by combining the wards of Honjo and Mukojima.

[[Taitō]]

CATEGORIES: Wards of Tokyo, 1947 establishments in Japan

Taitō is one of the 23 special wards of Tokyo, Japan. The population was 190,873 in 2015.

On 15 March 1947, the ward of Taitō was formed by combining the wards of Asakusa and Shitaya.

[[Emil Ciocoiu]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Painters, Photographers, Romanian people

Emil Ciocoiu (13 September 1948 – 1 August 2020) was a Romanian painter and photographer.

In 1972, he won the Musée 2000 Prize in Luxembourg, and the City of Bucharest awarded him the scholarship of Theodor Aman in 1975.

From 1994 to 2000, Ciocoiu's works were displayed at the Salon des indépendants in Paris. In 1997, the European Parliament organized an exhibition of his paintings.

Ciocoiu died on 1 August 2020, aged 71.

[[Sean Martin (cartoonist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, American cartoonists, American illustrators, Naturalized citizens of Canada

Sean Stephane Martin (December 29, 1960 – August 3, 2020) was an American-Canadian cartoonist, illustrator, and graphic designer. He was best known for creating the long-running Doc and Raider comic strip which appeared in LGBT publications.

Martin died of pancreatic cancer on August 3, 2020 at the age of 59.

[[John Otto (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Texas, US Republican Party politicians

John Clifford Otto (1948 – August 1, 2020) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the Texas House of Representatives from District 18 from 2004 to 2017. He was born in Dayton, Texas.

Otto died on August 1, 2020 in Dayton, Texas at the age of 71.

[[Dayton, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Dayton is a city in Liberty County, Texas, United States. The population was 7,242 at the 2010 census.

[[Reni Santoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from New York City

Reni Santoni (April 21, 1939 – August 1, 2020) was an American actor. He was born in New York City. His career began in 1962 and he retired in 2012. 

He was known for his roles as Inspector "Chico" González in 1971's Dirty Harry, as prison official Ramon Herrera in Bad Boys (1983), and as Detective Tony Gonzales in the action movie Cobra (1986).

Santoni died on August 1, 2020 under hospice care in Los Angeles from cancer at the age of 81.

[[David L. Gunn]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Businesspeople from Boston, Massachusetts

David L. Gunn (born June 21, 1937) is an American transportation businessman. He was born in Boston, Massachusetts.

He was Director of Operations of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA) from 1975 to 1979, General Manager and Chief Operations Officer of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (SEPTA) from 1979 to 1984, President of the New York City Transit Authority from 1984 to 1990, the General Manager at WMATA (the Washington Metro) from 1991 to 1994, and Chief General Manager of the Toronto Transit Commission in Canada from 1995 to 1999.

In 2002, Gunn became president of Amtrak. He was fired in 2005.

[[Tim Wirth]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, United States senators from Colorado, United States representatives from Colorado, American environmentalists, Politicians from New Mexico, People from Santa Fe, New Mexico, US Democratic Party politicians

Timothy Endicott Wirth (born September 22, 1939) is an American politician and environmentalist. He was born in Santa Fe, New Mexico.

Wirth, a Democrat, was a member of the House from 1975 to 1987. He was elected to the Senate in 1986, serving one term there before retiring in 1993. 

He worked in the United States Department of Education for President Richard Nixon and was the first Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs for the United States Department of State for President Bill Clinton. 

He worked with Vice President Al Gore on global environmental and population issues, supporting the administration's views on global warming. 

From 1998 to 2013, he was the president of the United Nations Foundation.

[[Nicholas D'Agosto]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Omaha, Nebraska

Nicholas D'Agosto  (born April 17, 1980) is an American actor. He is known for being the lead of Final Destination 5. He starred in the Showtime series Masters of Sex and the Fox series Gotham.

[[Dehydrogenation]]

CATEGORIES: Hydrogen, Organic chemistry

Dehydrogenation is the chemical process where hydrogen is taken from an organic molecule. It is the reverse of hydrogenation.

[[Ryōko Tateishi]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, People from Nagasaki Prefecture, Japanese movie actors, Japanese stage actors, Japanese television actors, Deaths from lung cancer

Ryōko Tateishi was a Japanese stage, movie and television actress. She was from Nagasaki, the capital city of Nagasaki Prefecture. She appeared in many theatrical works directed by Yukio Ninagawa. She appeared in the Japanese television dramas Kinpachi-sensei, Kita no Kuni Kara, and Shimomachi Rocket.

In 1976, she joined the Engeki Shūdan En troupe. In 2015, she moved to Sis Company.

In 2004, she won an Individual Award in the 39th Kinokuniya Awards. Her final stage appearance was in a 2019 adaptation of Crime and Punishment.

In September 2019, she was diagnosed with lung cancer. A performance she planned to be in was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic in Japan. In June 2020, her health became worse. She died of lung cancer on 2 August 2020 in Tokyo Metropolis, aged 68.

[[Gregory Areshian]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Armenia, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American historians, Armenian writers, American archaeologists

Gregory Areshian (13 May 1949 – 2 August 2020) was an Armenian-American archeologist and historian. He was a professor at American University of Armenia. He was the co-director of the international team of archeologists that found the 5,500 years old shoe in and the oldest winery in Areni.

Areshian taught at 14 American universities and colleges including; the University of California, Los Angeles, University of California, Irvine, University of Chicago, University of Wisconsin, Platteville, and Amherst College. 

Areshian died on 2 August 2020 in Yerevan from COVID-19, aged 71.

[[Getúlio Teixeira Guimarães]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, Brazilian people, Deaths from cardiovascular disease

Dom Getúlio Teixeira Guimarães (17 October 1937 – 1 August 2020) was a Brazilian Roman Catholic prelate. He was born in Cipotânea, Minas Gerais. He became a priest in 1966 in Barbacena. In 1984, Pope John Paul II appointed him to be the Bishop of the Diocese of Cornélio Procópio. He retired in 2014.

Guimarães died on 1 August 2020 from heart disease-related problems in Cornélio Procópio, Paraná, aged 82.

[[Siddaramaiah]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Indian politicians

Siddaramaiah (born 12 August 1948) is an Indian politician. He was born in present-day Karnataka, India. He is a member of the Indian National Congress. He was the Chief Minister of Karnataka between 2013 to 2018.

[[Adhe Tapontsang]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Tibetan people, Political activists

Adhe Tapontsang (1932 – 3 August 2020) was a Tibetan resistance fighter of the Chushi Gangdruk. She spent 27 years in the Laogai before taking refuge in India. Tapontsang was born in Ghortsa, Xinlong County, Tibet. 

In 1958, Tapontsang was arrested and separated from her two children. She was subject to interrogation and internment in the Laogai for 27 years, eleven of them as a "free laborer". She was released in 1985.

Tapontsang died on 3 August 2020 in Dharamshala, India at the age of 92.

[[Jan Halvarsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish Olympians, Olympic silver medalists

Jan Ivar "Janne" Halvarsson (26 December 1942 – 5 May 2020) was a Swedish cross-country skier. He was born in Östersund, Sweden. He won a silver medal at the 1968 Winter Olympics.

Halvarsson died on 5 May 2020 in Hammerdal, Sweden, aged 77.

[[Leslie Randall (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, English voice actors

Leslie Randall (19 October 1924 – circa 2 August 2020) was an English actor. He was born in South Shields, County Durham. He was known for starring in Joan and Leslie, ITV's first home-grown situation comedy.  He also appeared in the 1963 movie version of Billy Liar where he played Danny Boon.

On 2 August 2020, it was announced that Randall had died at age 95.

[[Carol A. Timmons]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, American generals, People from Wilmington, Delaware

Carol A. Timmons (1958 – August 2, 2020) was an American military officer. He was the Adjutant General of the Delaware National Guard from February 1, 2017, until her retirement on March 2, 2019.

She was awarded the Legion of Merit, Bronze Star Medal, and others.

Timmons died on August 2, 2020 at the age of 62.

[[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]]

CATEGORIES: Hospitals in the United States

Saint Jude Children's Research Hospital is a pediatric treatment and research facility focused on children's catastrophic diseases. It help treat  leukemia and other cancers. The hospital costs about US$2.8 million a day to run, but patients are not charged for their care. 

It is located in Memphis, Tennessee. St. Jude was founded by entertainer Danny Thomas in 1962.

[[Vangapandu Prasada Rao]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Indian poets, Indian activists, Communists, Songwriters

Vangapandu Prasada Rao (Telugu: వంగపండు ప్రసాదరావు) (1943 – 4 August 2020) was an Indian poet, lyricist and actor. He was better known as "Vangapandu". He was born in Andhra Pradesh. A political writer, he was known for writing works that were pro-communism and held rallies about it. He also wrote revolutionary songs such as yantrametta nadustumdantee, Jajjenaka janare, eem pillado eldamostavaa and ooda nuv vellipoke.

Rao died on 4 August 2020 at the age of 77.

[[Ernesto Brambilla]]

CATEGORIES: Deaths from myocardial infarction, 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Italian racecar drivers, Sportspeople from Lombardy, People from Monza

Ernesto "Tino" Brambilla (31 January 1934 – 3 August 2020) was a Grand Prix motorcycle road racer. He was a professional race car driver. He was born in Monza. 

In 1959, he finished in 10th place in the 350cc Grand Prix motorcycle season. In 1961 he again finished in 10th place in the 350 class.

Brambilla entered in two Formula One Grands Prix, firstly in the 1963 Italian Grand Prix, which he failed to qualify. 

Brambilla died on 3 August 2020 in Monza from a heart attack, aged 86.

[[The Secret Life of Pets 2]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 comedy movies, 2019 animated movies, American comedy movies, American animated movies

The Secret Life of Pets 2 is a 2019 American 3D computer animated comedy movie produced by Illumination, directed by Chris Renaud. It was written by Brian Lynch.

It is the sequel to The Secret Life of Pets (2016).

The movie stars Patton Oswalt (who replaces Louis C.K.), Kevin Hart, Eric Stonestreet, Jenny Slate, Tiffany Haddish, Lake Bell, Nick Kroll, Dana Carvey, Ellie Kemper, Chris Renaud, Tara Strong, Michael Beattie, Hannibal Buress, Bobby Moynihan, and Harrison Ford.

The movie was theatrically released in the United States on June 7, 2019, by Universal Pictures. The movie received mixed reviews from critics.

[[Tiffany Haddish]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winning actors, 1979 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Writers from Los Angeles, California, Comedians from Los Angeles, California

Tiffany Sara Cornilia Haddish (born December 3, 1979) is an American actress, comedian, and author. She is known for her role as Nekeisha Williams on the NBC sitcom The Carmichael Show. 

[[Magnificent Obsession]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 movies, 1930s drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by John M. Stahl

Magnificent Obsession is a 1935 American drama movie directed by John M. Stahl and based on the 1929 novel of the same name by Lloyd C. Douglas. It stars Robert Taylor, Irene Dunne, Charles Butterworth, Betty Furness, Sara Haden, Beryl Mercer and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was remade in 1954.

[[Nick Kroll]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American television writers, American television producers, Screenwriters from New York, Comedians from New York, Actors from New York, People from Rye, New York

Nicholas Kroll (born June 5, 1978) is an American actor, comedian, writer, and producer. He is known for creating and starring in the Comedy Central series Kroll Show, The Oh, Hello Show, the FX comedy series The League, and starring in and co-creating in the animated Netflix series Big Mouth.

[[Irfaan Ali]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Living people, Current national leaders, Presidents of Guyana

Mohamed Irfaan Ali (born 25 April 1980) is a Guyanese politician. He is the 10th President of Guyana since 2020. He was a Member of Parliament and the Minister of Housing.

[[Mark Phillips (Guyana)]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1961 births, Prime Ministers of Guyana

Mark Phillips (born 1961) is a Guyanese politician and retired military officer. In August 2020, he became the 9th Prime Minister of Guyana. He was the chief of staff of the Guyana Defence Force from 2013 to 2016.

[[U.S. Route 491]]

CATEGORIES: U.S. Highways, New Mexico, Colorado, Utah

U.S. Route 491 is a U.S. Highway through Utah, Colorado, and New Mexico, from north to south. It was originally known as Devil's Highway or Route 666.

[[Azerbaijan Cup]]

CATEGORIES: Football in Azerbaijan, Football competitions, 1936 establishments, 1992 establishments, 1990s establishments in Azerbaijan

The Azerbaijan Cup is a major association football competition in Azerbaijan. In its original form, it started in 1936, when the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic was a republic of the Soviet Union and it was not disputed by Azerbaijani teams in the Soviet league pyramid.

Compared to cups in many other countries, Azerbaijan attracts considerably less public interest and even the cup final tickets are rarely sold out. Consequently, the Association of Football Federations of Azerbaijan has experimented with the cup in order to raise public interest for the cup.

[[Azerbaijan First Division]]

CATEGORIES: Football in Azerbaijan, Football leagues, 1992 establishments, 1990s establishments in Azerbaijan

The Azerbaijan First Division (Azərbaycan Birinci Divizionu) is the second highest professional division in Azerbaijani professional football. The division is run by AFFA.

[[Azerbaijani Footballer of the Year]]

CATEGORIES: Football in Azerbaijan, 1991 establishments, 1990s establishments in Azerbaijan, Azerbaijani awards

Azerbaijani Footballer of the Year is an yearly title awarded to the best Azerbaijani football (soccer) player of the year. The award has been given since 1991, and the winner is elected by authorized journalists from the leading Azerbaijani sport media. On the same occasion, an award is also given for Azerbaijani Football Goalkeeper of the Year since 2009. However, this award is not always given every year.

[[Annie's Song]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 songs, Pop songs

"Annie's Song" is a song recorded and written by singer/songwriter John Denver. It was his second number one song in the USA, staying that place for two weeks in July 1974. It also went to number one in the UK. 

"Annie's Song" was written as an poem to Denver's then-wife, Annie Denver (Annie Martel) of Sleepy Eye, Minnesota.

This song was written while Denver was riding a ski lift in Switzerland. He said, by the time he had finished the 10 minute ride, the song was finished. It also recall an image of hiking through a state park in nearby New Ulm, Minnesota, Denver might have become filled with wonder at the beauty around, and thinking about his wife. 

The song has since become a wedding standard and an expression of love for many people, due to its grand imagery and the fact it could appeal anyone (Annie is not mentioned by name in any part of the song). 

[[All Japan Student Go Federation]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 establishments in Asia, 1950s establishments in Japan, Board games, Culture, Non-profit organizations, Go organizations

All Japan Student Go Federation (全日本学生囲碁連盟) is a Japanese student Go organization for holding university Go championships. They have branches in each regions (Kanto, Kansai, Kyushu, Tohoku etc.).

[[Megumi Asaoka]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Japanese singers, People from Ōita Prefecture, Living people

Megumi Asaoka (麻丘めぐみ) is a Japanese female popular singer and actress. Asaoka was born on October 11, 1955 in Ohita, Japan and grew up in Osaka. She started as a model for photos of magazines and on TV commercials. In 1972 at age 16, she started as a singer and sung her first recording song "芽ばえ". Her biggest hit that she had ever made was a song "わたしの彼は左きき" in July, 1973. Many songs sung by Asaoka were written by a songwriter Kyohei Tsutsumi. 

She had been popular in 1970s. But in 1983 she made up her mind to start herself as an actress for movies and on television.

[[Tim Staffell]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, English rock singers, People from Ealing, Living people

Timothy John Staffell (born 24 February 1948) is an English rock singer, visual artist, model maker and designer. Together with Freddie Mercury and John Deacon, they formed the band Queen.

[[English Lutheran Church]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Lawrence, Kansas, National Register of Historic Places in Douglas County, Kansas

English Lutheran Church is a historic church at 1040 New Hampshire Street in Lawrence, Kansas. It was built in 1870, and it grew in 1900.  It was added to the National Register in 1995.

It is a two-story church. It is made of rusticated limestone on a limestone block base. It is about 46x78 in plan.

[[Douglas County Courthouse (Kansas)]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Lawrence, Kansas, National Register of Historic Places in Douglas County, Kansas

The Douglas County Courthouse in Lawrence, Kansas is a three-and-a-half-story stone courthouse. It was built in 1903.

It was designed by 19th-century architect John G. Haskell. Frederick C. Gunn, who was also an architect, helped. The style is Richardsonian Romanesque.29–30

[[Nyctimystes ocreptus]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes ocreptus is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scintists found it on Mount Albert Edward, 2600 meters above sea level. Some may also live on Mount Victoria or Mount Knutsford.

This frog has brown eyes.  The veins in its lower eyelid go in all directions, like a net.  This frog's skin is gold-green to gray-green in color.  Its belly is white with purple and brown marks.

Scientists say this frog is related to the common big-eyed tree frog, Nyctimystes narinosus.

The name of this frog is from the words "oculus in rete captus," which means "eye caught in a net."

[[A55 road (Great Britain)]]

CATEGORIES: Roads in the United Kingdom

The A55, also called the North Wales Expressway (Welsh: Gwibffordd Gogledd Cymru), is an important road in Great Britain. It goes between Chester, England and Holyhead, Wales. It goes along the north coast of Wales for most of its route. For most of the route, it is a dual carriageway. Many parts of the road act like a motorway. 

It is also part of the European route E22, which links to Amsterdam, Riga, and Moscow. The route once went between Bangor and Chester, but was extended to Holyhead in 2001. This links to the Republic of Ireland through the Port of Holyhead. In total, the road is 87 long.

[[Gazebo]]

CATEGORIES: architecture

A gazebo is a  pavilion structure. It is often built in a park, garden or large public area.

[[Disc golf]]

CATEGORIES: Golf

Disc golf is a flying disc sport in which players throw a disc at a target. It is played using rules similar to golf.

The game is played in about 40 countries. As of 2019, there are  active people in the PDGA worldwide.

[[2020 Beirut explosion]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 disasters in Asia, 2020s explosions in Asia, 2020s fires, 21st century in Lebanon, August 2020 events, Beirut, Building and structure fires in Asia, Explosions in 2020

Beirutnorth.jpg

On 4 August 2020, an explosion happened in the city of Beirut, the capital of Lebanon.

The blast happened at the Port of Beirut and left at least 215 people dead (with the total expected to go higher), at least 7,500 injured, and many more missing. The Governor of Beirut, Marwan Abboud, said over 300,000 people lost their homes.

It is said that the explosion may have been caused by 2,750 tonnes of ammonium nitrate. Ammonium nitrate is a chemical substance that can be used for fertilizer. It can also be used to make explosives. The government took the ammonium nitrate from a ship in the port of Damascus, the MV Rhosus. The MV Rhosus had been abandoned in the port, after the Lebanese government said it was no longer fit to travel by sea. The ammonium nitrate was then stored in the port, for at least six years. This may have been without the proper precautions. There are various regulations how ammonium nitrate should be stored, and handled.  In its pure form, ammonium nitrate does not burn; but it increases fires a great deal. It should therefore not be stored near flammable substances, and it should not be heated in a closed space. It is also very sensitive to temperature.

Before the big explosion, here seems to have been a fire in a part of the warehouse, where fireworks were stored. The ammonium nitrate was stored in the same building.

The explosion has been compared to three thousand tonnes of TNT.

Some countries offered medical aid, rescue teams and money to help deal with the aftermath of the disaster.

[[Orichalcum]]

CATEGORIES: Ancient Greece, Ancient Rome, Ancient history, Metals

Orichalcum or aurichalcum, ὀρείχαλκος is the name of a metal or two different metals.  Old writings from ancient Greece talk about orichalcum and the Romans made coins out of a metal they called orichalcum, but they might not have been the same metal.  People today are not sure exactly what it was.  Some scholars think orichalcum was the ancient Greek name for platinum.  Others think it was an alloy, or mixture, of copper and either gold, tin, or zinc.  Scientists examined Roman coins and found a mixture of copper and zinc.

[[Shirley Ann Grau]]

CATEGORIES: Pulitzer Prize winners, 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, American feminist writers, Writers from New Orleans, Louisiana

Shirley Ann Grau (July 8, 1929 – August 3, 2020) was an American writer.  She was born in New Orleans. Her work is set mainly in the Deep South and talks about issues of race and gender.

Her 1964 work The Keepers of the House was awarded the 1965 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. 

She was an important feminist writer who talked about abortion, death and misogyny.

Grau died on August 3, 2020 in Kenner, Louisiana from stroke-related problems at the age of 91.

[[Yard (land)]]

CATEGORIES: Gardens

A yard is an open space around a building. For instance, the space around a school is called a school yard. A yard is often used by humans and their pets. Yards with plants are called lawns.

[[Fatti maschi, parole femmine]]

CATEGORIES: State mottos of the United States, Italian language, Maryland

Fatti maschi, parole femmine is an Italian phrase literally meaning "deeds are males, words are females", but the actual institutional meaning is "strong deeds, gentle words". This phrase is the state motto of Maryland. 

[[Ontario Highway 404]]

CATEGORIES: Roads in Ontario

Ontario Highway 404 is a 400-series highway. It starts at Highway 401 in Toronto and ends at Woodbine Avenue in East Gwillimbury.

[[Mark Ormrod (historian)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, English historians

William Mark Ormrod, GBR, (1 November 1957–2 August 2020), known professionally as Mark Ormrod, was an English historian. His works focused on the English later Middle Ages. 

He worked at the University of York where he became Dean of the History Faculty and director of the Centre for Medieval Studies. He researched and published widely, including nine books and over 80 book chapters.

Ormrod died of bowel cancer on 2 August 2020 in York, aged 62.

[[Regional Representative Council]]

CATEGORIES: Indonesia

The Regional Representative Council (Dewan Perwakilan Daerah, DPD; alternatively translatable as the House of Regions or the House of Regional Representatives or the Senate of Indonesia), is one of two parliamentary chambers in Indonesia. 

With the Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat, (DPR), it makes up the Indonesian national legislative body, the Majelis Permusyawaratan Rakyat (MPR).

Under Indonesia's constitution, the authority of the DPD is limited to areas related to regional governments and can only propose and give advise on bills to the DPR.

[[People's Representative Council]]

CATEGORIES: Indonesia

The People's Treason Council of the Republic of Indonesia (Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat Republik Indonesia, DPR-RI) is one of two elected national legislative assemblies in Indonesia.

Together with the Regional Representative Council (Dewan Perwakilan Daerah, DPD), a second chamber with limited powers, it makes up a legislative body, the People's Consultative Assembly (Majelis Permusyawaratan Rakyat, MPR). 

The house has been controversial due to high levels of fraud and corruption.

[[People's Consultative Assembly]]

CATEGORIES: Indonesia

The People's Consultative Assembly of the Republic of Indonesia (Majelis Permusyawaratan Rakyat Republik Indonesia, MPR-RI) is the legislative branch in Indonesia's political system. It is made up of the members of the People's Representative Council (DPR) and the Regional Representative Council (DPD). 

Before 2004, and the amendments to the 1945 Constitution, the MPR was the highest governing body in Indonesia.

[[Dani Anwar]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia, Indonesian politicians

Dani Anwar (22 February 1968 – 3 August 2020) was an Indonesian PKS politician. He was a Senator from 2009 to 2014. He was also a member of the Jakarta Regional People's Representative Council from 2019 until his death. He was born in Jakarta.

Anwar died on 3 August 2020 in Jakarta from COVID-19, aged 52.

[[Ralf Metzenmacher]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, German painters

Ralf Metzenmacher (July 26, 1964 – August 3, 2020) was a German painter and designer. He was an expert Retro-Art, a mixture between art and product design. He was born in Aachen, Germany. Between 1991 and 2004 he worked as a designer for Puma. As director, towards the end of his time there he was responsible for the Footwear Europe and Accessories International division.

Metzenmacher died on August 3, 2020 at the age of 56.

[[Michael Peter Smith]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, American folk singers, American rock singers, Singer-songwriters from Chicago, Singers from New Jersey, Writers from New Jersey, People from Orange, New Jersey

Michael Peter Smith (September 7, 1941 – August 3, 2020) was an American singer-songwriter. He was known as "The greatest songwriter in the English language". He sang and composed from the 1960s.

He was best known for writing "The Dutchman", which was popularized by Steve Goodman.

He died from colon cancer on August 3, 2020 at the age of 78.

[[Ebrahim Alkazi]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Indian educators, Indian theatre directors

Ebrahim Alkazi (18 October 1925 – 4 August 2020) was an Indian theatre director and drama teacher. He was the Director of National School of Drama, New Delhi from 1962 to 1977. 

He directed over 50 plays, including famous productions of: Girish Karnad's Tughlaq, Mohan Rakesh's Ashadh Ka Ek Din, Dharamvir Bharati's Andha Yug and numerous Shakespeare and Greek plays.

[[Rajko Dujmić]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths, Croatian writers, Songwriters, Composers, Record producers

Rajko Dujmić (7 August 1954 – 4 August 2020) was a Croatian songwriter, composer and music producer. He was best known as a member of the pop group Novi fosili. He composed the winner entry of Eurovision Song Contest 1989, "Rock me".

He was in a car crash on 29 July 2020. Dujmić died six days later, on 4 August at the hospital, aged 65.

[[Dick Goddard]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American meteorologists, American cartoonists, American animal rights activists, Writers from Akron, Ohio

Richard D. "Dick" Goddard (February 24, 1931 – August 4, 2020) was an American television meteorologist, author, cartoonist, and animal activist. He was the evening meteorologist at WJW-TV. He held the Guinness World Record for longest career as a weather forecaster. Goddard was born in Akron, Ohio.

In June 2020, he tested positive for COVID-19. Goddard died on August 4, 2020 in Florida, at the age of 89.

[[Hu Ping]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese politicians

Hu Ping (1 July 1930 – 4 August 2020) was a Chinese politician. He was born in Jiaxing, Zhejiang. Hu was a member of the Chinese Communist Party. Hu was Governor of Fujian from 1983 to 1987. He was the Minister of Commerce from 1988 to 1993.

Hu died on 4 August 2020 in Beijing, aged 90.

[[Jiaxing]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in China

Jiaxing (嘉兴), alternately romanized as Kashing, is a prefecture-level city in northern Zhejiang province, China. At the 2010 census, its population was 4,501,657.

[[Willie Hunter (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Scottish footballers, Scottish football managers, Sportspeople from Edinburgh

William Hunter (14 February 1940 — 4 August 2020) was a Scottish football player and manager. Hunter spent most of his playing career with Motherwell.

He also played for the Detroit Cougars, Hibernian, Hellenic and Cape Town City. Hunter also represented both Scotland and the Scottish League. 

He was born in Edinburgh. Hunter died in August 2020, aged 80.

[[Eddie Ilarde]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Filipino politicians, Filipino entertainers

Edgardo "Eddie" U. Ilarde (August 25, 1934 – August 4, 2020) was a Filipino radio-television host and politician. He was born in Iriga, Camarines Sur. He was a member of the Liberal Party. He hosted Student Canteen. From 1965 to 1969, he was a member of the House of Representatives. In 1972, he was a member of the Senate.

Ilarde died on August 4, 2020 at a hospital in Makati, Philippines at the age of 85.

[[Lorenzo Chiarinelli]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Italian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops

Lorenzo Chiarinelli (16 March 1935 – 3 August 2020) was an Italian Roman Catholic prelate. He was born in Concerviano, Italy. He became a priest in 1957. He was made a bishop in 1983 by Pope John Paul II. 

He was the Bishop of Sora-Cassino-Aquino-Pontecorvo from 1983 to 1993, Aversa from 1993 to 1997 and Viterbo from 1997 to 2010.

Chiarinelli died on 3 August 2020 at the age of 85.

[[Shivajirao Patil Nilangekar]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians

Shivajirao Nilangekar Patil (1 September 1928 – 5 August 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a leader of Indian National Congress Party. He was born in Nilanga, Maharashtra. He was the Chief Minister of Maharashtra between 1985 to 1986. He was also a member of the Maharashtra Legislative Assembly between 1962 to 2014.

Nilangekar died on 5 August 2020 from COVID-19 at a hospital in Pune, aged 91.

[[Karam Ali Shah]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Pakistani politicians

Pir Karam Ali Shah (c. 1934 – 4 August 2020) was a Pakistani politician. He was governor of Gilgit-Baltistan. He was appointed governor on January 26, 2011 by President of Pakistan Asif Ali Zardari. He stepped down from the job on 16 February 2015. He was born in India.

Shah died on 4 August 2020 in Islamabad, Pakistan at the age of 86.

[[Jan Strelau]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Polish psychologists, Polish educators, People from Gdańsk

Jan Strelau (May 30, 1931 – August 3, 2020) was a Polish psychologist. He was born in Free City of Danzig, now Gdańsk, Poland. Strelau was best known for his studies on temperament. 

He was professor of psychology at Warsaw University from 1968 to 2001. 

In 2001, he became a professor at Warsaw School of Social Sciences and Humanities, where he took the positions of Vice-rector for Research and International Affairs from 2002 to 2010 and Vice-rector for Research from 2010 to 2012. He was the Chairman of the Board of Trustees from 2012 to 2016.

Strelau died in Warsaw on August 3, 2020 at the age of 89.

[[Robert Prosky]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2008 deaths, Deaths from surgical complications, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Robert Prosky (born Robert Joseph Porzuczek, December 13, 1930 – December 8, 2008) was an American actor. 

His best known movie roles were in Thief (1981), Christine (1983), The Natural (1984), and Broadcast News (1987). 

He also appeared in Gremlins 2: The New Batch (1990), Hoffa (1992), Mrs. Doubtfire (1993), Last Action Hero (1993), Miracle on 34th Street (1994), Dead Man Walking (1995), and Mad City (1997).

Prosky died on December 8, 2008 at a hospital in Washington, D.C. at the age of 78. The cause of death was heart surgery-related problems.

[[William Petersen]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, American television producers, People from Evanston, Illinois, Actors from Illinois

William Louis Petersen (born February 21, 1953) is an American actor and producer. He is best known for his role as Gil Grissom in the CBS drama series CSI: Crime Scene Investigation (2000–2015).

[[The Natural (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 movies, 1980s sports movies, American sports movies, Movies set in Chicago, Illinois, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Barry Levinson

The Natural is a 1984 American sports movie. It is based on Bernard Malamud's 1952 novel of the same name. It is directed by Barry Levinson. It stars Robert Redford, Glenn Close, and Robert Duvall.

The movie was nominated for four Academy Awards. 

Many of the baseball scenes were filmed in 1983 at War Memorial Stadium in Buffalo, New York. The All-High Stadium, also in Buffalo, stood in for Chicago's Wrigley Field in a key scene.

Riverhead is a census-designated place (CDP) located in the town of Riverhead in Suffolk County, New York on Long Island. The CDP's population was 13,299 at the 2010 census.

The Village of East Hampton is a village in Suffolk County, New York, United States. It is located in the town of East Hampton. The population was 1,083 at the time of the 2010 census.

The Town of East Hampton is located in southeastern Suffolk County, New York. At the time of the United States 2010 Census, it had a total population of 21,457.

Brentwood is a  hamlet in the Town of Islip in Suffolk County, New York, United States. As of the 2010 Census, the population of Brentwood was 60,664.

[[Jake LaTurner]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, State legislators of the United States, United States representatives from Kansas, Kansas Republicans

Jacob LaTurner (born February 17, 1988) is an American politician. He is a member of the United States House of Representatives since 2021. He became the Kansas State Treasurer in 2017. 

He is a member of the Republican Party. He was in the Kansas State Senate from 2013 until 2017. When he became state treasurer, LaTurner became the youngest current statewide official in the United States. He was reelected to the job in 2018, becoming the youngest current elected statewide official in the United States. 

LaTurner briefly announced a campaign for the United States Senate in the 2020 election but quickly dropped out. He later decided to run for the United States House of Representatives seat representing KS. LaTurner beat incumbent U.S. Representative Steve Watkins in that primary election.

[[Michelle De La Isla]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, American mayors, Politicians from Kansas, People from Topeka, Kansas, Kansas Democrats, Politicians from New York City

Michelle De La Isla (born March 19, 1976) is an American politician. She is the Mayor of Topeka, Kansas since 2018. She was a member of the Topeka City Council from 2013 to 2018. De La Isla is the city's first Latina, first single mother, and second woman to serve as mayor. 

She is the Democratic nominee for Kansas' 2nd congressional district in the 2020 United States House of Representatives race. De La Isla was born in New York City.

[[Overeating]]

CATEGORIES: Nutrition, Health problems, Lifestyles

Overeating (or over-eating) is eating food more than the body needs. There is a relationship between the energy that an organism uses and the amount eaten. Eating more leads to weight gaining and often obesity. It may be regarded as an eating disorder.

One consequence of overeating is weight gain, and excess weight may cause blood pressure to rise. In turn this makes illness and even death more likely.

The problem is very difficult to reverse: losing weight is often attempted, but rarely succeeds. Weight lost is usually rapidly replaced. Diets are famously unsuccessful. Obesity is the end product of overeating.

Some difficult facts are known. Poorer families tend to eat worse food than better-off families. Children learn from the experiences in their families. Once established, habits are hard to break. In 2013, several medical societies, including the American Medical Association and the American Heart Association, classified obesity as a disease.

[[Galena, Kansas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Cherokee County, Kansas, 1877 establishments in Kansas

Galena is a city in Cherokee County, Kansas, United States.  As of the 2010 census, the city population was 3,085.

[[Barbara Bollier]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, American physicians, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Kansas, Politicians from Texas, People from Galveston, Texas, Kansas Democrats

Barbara Goolsbee Bollier (born January 13, 1958) is an American physician and politician. She is the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from Kansas in the 2020 election. 

She is a member of the Kansas Senate since January 2017. Bollier is a member of the Democratic Party, after having left the Republican Party in 2018.

If Bollier won the U.S. Senate race, she would have been the first woman physician elected to the U.S. Senate.

Bollier lost the election to Roger Marshall in the senate race in November 2020.

[[Tim Huelskamp]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, United States representatives from Kansas, Kansas Republicans

Timothy Alan Huelskamp (ˈ; born November 11, 1968) is an American politician. He was the U.S. Representative for KS from 2011 to 2017. Huelskamp, a member of the Republican Party, was rated the least bipartisan. 

He ran for re-election in 2016 but was defeated in the Republican primary on August 2, 2016, by Roger Marshall. His term in the House ended on January 3, 2017.

[[Tracey Mann]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, Businesspeople from Kansas, United States representatives from Kansas, Lieutenant Governors of Kansas, Kansas Republicans

Tracey Mann (born December 17, 1976) is an American businessman and politician. He is a member of the United States House of Representatives for Kansas's 1st congressional district since 2021.

Mann was the 50th Lieutenant Governor of Kansas from 2018 to 2019. He was appointed by Governor Jeff Colyer in February 2018.

In August 2020, he won the Republican nomination for the United States House of Representatives for Kansas's 1st congressional district. He won the general election in November 2020.

[[Cori Bush]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, American political activists, American progressives, United States representatives from Missouri, Politicians from St. Louis, Missouri, US Democratic Party politicians

Cori Bush (born Julynbsp21, 1976) is an American politician, registered nurse, pastor, and activist. Bush is a member of the United States House of Representatives from Missouri's 1st congressional district since 2021. She is a member of the Democratic Party. 

On August 4, 2020, she beat 10-term incumbent Lacy Clay in the 2020 U.S. House of Representatives primary election. She won the general election in November 2020.

[[Lacy Clay]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, United States representatives from Missouri, Politicians from St. Louis, Missouri, US Democratic Party politicians

William Lacy Clay Jr. (born July 27, 1956) is an American politician. He was the U.S. Representative from Missouri from 2001 to 2021. He is a member of the Democratic Party. 

On August 4, 2020, he lost the Democratic primary to serve for an 11th term to community activist and progressive Democrat Cori Bush.

[[Sergio Zavoli]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Italian journalists, Italian politicians, Politicians from Emilia-Romagna

Sergio Wolmar Zavoli (21 September 1923 – 4 August 2020) was an Italian politician and journalist. Zavoli was born in Ravenna, Italy. He was a member of both Democrats of the Left and the Democratic Party. Between 2001 until his retirement in 2018, he was a member of the Italian Senate for Emilia-Romagna.

Zavoli died on 4 August 2020 in Rome at the age of 96.

[[China Girl (1942 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 movies, 1940s war movies, 1940s drama movies, American drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Henry Hathaway

China Girl is a 1942 American drama movie directed by Henry Hathaway and starring Gene Tierney, George Montgomery, Lynn Bari, Victor McLaglen, Alan Baxter, Ann Pennington. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Spurred big-eyed tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The spurred big-eyed tree frog (Nyctimystes pulcher)  is a tree frog from New Guinea.  It lives on the lower sides of mountains at around 1500 meters above sea level.  It lives all through the middle of the island, in both Indonesia and Papua New Guinea.

The spurred big-eyed tree frog is one of the largest species in Nyctimystes. The Latin word pulchra means "pale" or "fair."

[[Ram Temple, Ayodhya]]

CATEGORIES: Hindu temples

Lord Ram Temple is a Hindu temple that will be built at the holy pilgrimage site of Raam birthland in Ayodhya, Uttar Pradesh, India.

[[Sky Sport News]]

CATEGORIES: Television channels, German television, 2011 establishments in Europe

Sky Sport News (until August 4th 2020: Sky Sport News HD) is Germany and Austria's only 24-hour free-to-air sports news channel, owned by Sky Sport Deutschland.

The channel's format shows rolling news bulletins, updated every 15 minutes. It broadcasts live from 9am to midnight. There are three teams of presenters on air daily.

SSNHD launched on 1 December 2011, at midday. The first on-air presenters were Kate Abdo and Thomas Fleischmann. 

In 2016 Sky Deutschland announced that the channel would a become free-to-air channel and would be streamed in Germany. The first free-to-air broadcast was a match between Mainz and Bayern.

The channel now has more content. Alongside rolling news, it also broadcasts highlights, documentaries and magazine shows, all relating to sport. It is only allowed to broadcast 12 minutes of ads every hour.

In 2017, Sky reduced the channel's broadcast hours by three hours to fifteen hours.

On 12 March 2017 Sky Sport News HD started streaming.

On 5 August 2020 the station changed its name to Sky Sport News. 

[[Zopto]]

CATEGORIES: Software

Zopto is a British software company established in 2018 with an additional office located in Manhattan, USA.

It is a cloud-based set of software tools that is mainly used by B2B businesses to send automatic messages and information over the LinkedIn network.  It has been used by companies like Accenture, Zoom, IBM etc.

[[Ilse Uyttersprot]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian mayors, Christelijke Volkspartij politicians, Christen-Democratisch en Vlaams politicians, Deaths by beating, Flemish politicians, Murder victims, People from East Flanders, Women politicians

Ilse Uyttersprot (10 May 1967 – 4 August 2020) was a Belgian politician. She was a member of the  Chamber of Representatives from 2007 to 2010. From 2007 to 2013, she was mayor of Aalst, Belgium.

Uyttersprot was murdered by her boyfriend with a hammer on 4 August 2020 in Aalst, aged 53.

[[Billy Goldenberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, American composers, American songwriters, Writers from New York City

William Leon Goldenberg (February 10, 1936 – August 3, 2020) was an American composer and songwriter. He was best known for his work on television and movie. He was born in New York City. He was known for composing the scores of Kojak, Rhoda and Play It Again, Sam.

Goldenberg died on August 3, 2020 in New York City from heart failure at the age of 84.

[[Andre Spencer]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, Atlanta Hawks players, Golden State Warriors players, Sacramento Kings players, Sportspeople from California

Andre Devell Spencer (July 20, 1964 – August 4, 2020) was an American professional basketball player. He played for three teams in the NBA. From 1992 to 1994 Spencer played for the Atlanta Hawks, Golden State Warriors and Sacramento Kings during his brief NBA career. Spencer was born in Stockton, California.

Spencer died on August 4, 2020 at the age of 56.

[[Eric Bentley]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2020 deaths, American centenarians, British centenarians, British playwrights, American playwrights, Editors, Translators, American critics, British critics, Writers from Lancashire, Writers from New York City, British educators, American educators, Naturalized citizens of the United States

Eric Russell Bentley (September 14, 1916 – August 5, 2020) was a British-born American theater critic, playwright, singer, editor, and translator. In 1998, he was added into the American Theatre Hall of Fame. He was born in Bolton, Lancashire. Beginning in 1953, he taught at Columbia University and was a theatre critic for The New Republic. He was sued by Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller because he gave them negative reviews on their plays.

Bentley was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1969. 

Bentley died at his home in New York City on August 5, 2020, at the age of 103.

[[Sadia Dehlvi]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from breast cancer, Indian activists, Indian writers, Indian journalists, Columnists, People from New Delhi

Sadia Dehlvi (1957 – 5 August 2020) was an Indian activist, writer and columnist. She worked with the daily newspaper, the Hindustan Times, and published in Frontline and Urdu, Hindi and English newspapers and magazines. She criticised radical versions of Islam and called for a united understanding of Islam. 

Dehlvi died on 5 August 2020 at a hospital in New Delhi from breast cancer, aged 63.

[[Pete Hamill]]

CATEGORIES: Grammy Award winners, 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from fractured hip, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, American novelists, American educators, American editors, American essayists, Journalists from New York City

Pete Hamill (ˈ; June 24, 1935 – August 5, 2020) was an American journalist, novelist, essayist, editor and educator. He won the Grammy Award for Best Album Notes in 1976.

[[Agathonas Iakovidis]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Greek singers, Folk singers, Folk musicians, Guitarists, Eurovision Song Contest entrants

Agathonas Iakovidis (Αγάθωνας Ιακωβίδης; 2 January 1955 – 5 August 2020) was a Greek folk singer and musician. He represented Greece in the Eurovision Song Contest 2013 with Koza Mostra and the song "Alcohol Is Free". He was born in Langadas, Thessaloniki. His career began in 1971.

On 5 August 2020, Iakovidis died from a heart attack at his Athens home, aged 65.

[[National Park Service ranger]]

CATEGORIES: Law enforcement in the United States

National Park Service rangers are uniformed employees whose jobs are to protect and preserve areas in the National Park System by the United States Congress and the President of the United States. 

While all employees of the agency work on the National Park Service mission of preserving the natural and cultural resources, the term "park ranger" is traditionally used to describe all National Park Service employees who wear the uniform.

[[Toni Erdmann]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 comedy-drama movies, German drama movies, Austrian movies

Toni Erdmann is a 2016 German-Austrian comedy-drama movie directed, written and co-produced by Maren Ade. It stars Peter Simonischek and Sandra Hüller.

The movie was named the best movie of 2016 by Sight & Sound.

It won five awards at the 29th European Film Awards. It also won the European Parliament LUX Prize. 

It was nominated for the Best Foreign Language Film at the 89th Academy Awards, but lost to Iran's The Salesman.

[[Maren Ade]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, German movie directors, German movie producers, German screenwriters

Maren Ade (ˈmaːʁən ˈʔaːdə; born 12 December 1976) is a German movie director, screenwriter and producer. She teaches screenwriting at the Film Academy Baden-Württemberg in Ludwigsburg. She is known for directing and writing the Academy Award-nominated movie Toni Erdmann.

[[Sandra Hüller]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, German movie actors, German television actors, German stage actors, German voice actors

Sandra Hüller (born 30 April 1978) is a German actress. She is known for her roles Anneliese Michel in Hans-Christian Schmid's drama Requiem, and as the starring role in Maren Ade's comedy Toni Erdmann.

[[Film Academy Baden-Württemberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Germany, 1991 establishments in Europe, Colleges and universities in Germany, Baden-Württemberg

The Filmakademie Baden-Wuerttemberg (German: Filmakademie Baden-Württemberg) is a movie school in Ludwigsburg, Baden-Württemberg, Germany, founded in 1991. It is funded by the government, making it a public university.

[[Doris Buffett]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, American philanthropists, Writers from Omaha, Nebraska, Businesspeople from Omaha, Nebraska

Doris Eleanor Buffett (February 12, 1928 – August 4, 2020) was an American philanthropist. She was also known as the 'retail' philanthropist. She was the founder of The Sunshine Lady Foundation, The Learning By Giving Foundation, and The Letters Foundation who she co-founded alongside her younger brother, billionaire Warren Buffett.

She was also the daughter of U.S. politician and stockbroker Howard Homan Buffett. She planned to give all of her money away before her death. She was born in Omaha, Nebraska.

Buffett was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease in 2018. She died on August 4, 2020 at her home in Rockport, Maine at the age of 92.

[[Daisy Coleman]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, 2020 deaths, Suicides in the United States, American activists, American crime victims

[[Audrie & Daisy]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 movies, American documentary movies, Netflix movies

Audrie & Daisy is an American 2016 documentary movie about three cases of rape of teenage American girls, in 2011 and 2012. 

The documentary shares the stories of two American high school students, Audrie Pott and Daisy Coleman.  At the time of the sexual assaults, Pott was 15 and Coleman was 14 years old. After the assaults, the victims and their families were abused and cyberbullied.

Audrie Pott died by suicide in 2012, ten days after the sexual assault.

On August 4, 2020, Daisy Coleman also died by suicide after years of fighting depression and trauma. She was 23 years of age.

Audrie & Daisy had its world premiere at the 2016 Sundance Film Festival on January 25, 2016. The movie was bought by Netflix for streaming, and was released on September 23, 2016.

[[Suicide of Audrie Pott]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, 2012 deaths, Suicides by hanging in the United States, American crime victims, People from California

Audrie Taylor Pott (May 27, 1997 – September 12, 2012) was a 15-year-old student at Saratoga High School in Saratoga, California, who died by suicide.  She had been sexually assaulted at a party eight days earlier by three 16-year-old boys she knew and nude pictures of her were posted online. She was also bullied.  

On September 3, 2020 while at a party, Pott was dragged sexually assaulted after she passed out because she was drunk. Markers were also used to draw and write on her body, and photographs were taken and shared on social network.

On September 12, 2012, she killed herself by hanging.

On September 30, 2014, California Governor Jerry Brown signed Audrie's Law, "a bill that increases penalties and decreases privacy protections for teens convicted of sex acts on someone who is passed out from drugs or alcohol".

[[Rex Barnett]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Missouri, US Republican Party politicians

Rex Barnett (born October 22, 1938) is an American politician. He was an officer of the Missouri State Highway Patrol for 32 years in Troop H. He was a member of the Republican Party. Between 1994 to 2002, he was a member of the Missouri House of Representatives. He was born in Laredo, Missouri.

In 2012, Barnett's grandson, Matthew Barnett, was arrested for the rape of the then fourteen-year-old Daisy Coleman. However prosecutors declined to pursue charges and the records were sealed. Many people believed the case was closed because of Barnett's connection.

[[Martelli's cat]]

CATEGORIES: Felines, Extinct species

Martelli's cat (Felis lunensis) is a small wild cat in the Felinae subfamily. It used to live in Europe.  It is extinct now.  That means there are no Martelli's cats alive now.

Martelli's cat first lived about 12 million years ago.  This was during the Pliocene era.  It was bigger than most wildcats.  It hunted birds and small mammals.

Some scientists think that the modern wildcat (Felis silvestris) evolved from Martelli's cat.

[[Venezuelan Football Federation]]

CATEGORIES: Sport in Venezuela

The Venezuelan Football Federation (Federación Venezolana de Fútbol or FVF) is the governing body of football in Venezuela. It was founded in 1926 and affiliated in 1952. It is a member of CONMEBOL as well as FIFA, and is in charge of the Venezuela national football team.

[[Tootie Robbins]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American football offensive tackles, St. Louis Cardinals players, Green Bay Packers players, Sportspeople from North Carolina

James Elbert "Tootie" Robbins  (June 2, 1958 – August 2, 2020) was an American professional football player. He was an offensive tackle for 12 seasons in the National Football League (NFL) for the St. Louis/Phoenix Cardinals and the Green Bay Packers. Robbins was born in Windsor, North Carolina.

Robbins died on August 2, 2020 from COVID-19 at the age of 62.

[[Windsor, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in North Carolina, County seats in North Carolina

Windsor is a town in Bertie County, North Carolina, United States. The population was 3,630 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Bertie County, North Carolina.  Windsor is located in North Carolina's Inner Banks region. 

[[Cecil Leonard]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, New York Jets players, Sportspeople from Alabama

Cecil Leonard (July 20, 1946 – August 5, 2020) was an American football defensive back. He played two seasons with the New York Jets of the American Football League (AFL) and National Football League (NFL). He played college football at Tuskegee University. Leonard was born in Sylacauga, Alabama. Leonard was also a member of the Birmingham Americans of the World Football League (WFL).

Leonard died on August 5, 2020 in Statesboro, Georgia at the age of 74. His family and close friends will hold a memorial service in his hometown on August 23rd in Sylacauga, Alabama.

[[You Were Never Lovelier]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s musical movies, 1940s comedy movies, American musical movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by William A. Seiter

You Were Never Lovelier is a 1942 American romantic musical comedy movie directed by William A. Seiter and is a remake of the 1941 Argentine movie Los martes, orquídeas. It stars Fred Astaire, Rita Hayworth, Adolphe Menjou, Isobel Elsom, Leslie Brooks and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for 3 Academy Awards in 1943.
