[[Hanauma Bay]]

CATEGORIES: Volcanoes of Hawaii

Hanauma Bay is a tuff cone in Honolulu, Hawaii. It sits near another volcano called Koko Crater.

It was created 32,000 years ago as a vent of the Koʻolau Volcano. It is a popular tourist attraction due to the beach in its crater and at one point had 3 million visitors a year. The bay holds many types of marine wildlife.

The origin of the name “Hanauma” is not well known. The “hana” part means “bay” while the meaning behind “uma” is debated.

[[List of volcanoes in Hawaii]]

CATEGORIES: Volcanoes of Hawaii

The islands of Hawaii were made by volcanoes. Most of them are extinct but the Big Island and Maui have active ones. The volcanoes of Hawaii are fueled by a hotspot rather than a tectonic plate.

[[Hannah Ama Nyarko]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Ghanaian people, Ambassadors to Israel

Hannah Ama Nyarko (born 25 July 1964) is a Ghanaian diplomat. She is the ambassador of Ghana to Israel.

She studied at the University of Ghana gaining a first and masters degree. In January 1992, she joined the foreign service. She promoted trade between Ghana and Israel.

[[Ense petit placidam sub libertate quietem]]

CATEGORIES: Massachusetts, Latin state mottos of the United States

Ense petit placidam sub libertate quietem is a Latin phrase meaning "By the sword we seek peace, but peace only under liberty". It is the motto of both Massachusetts and the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

It was written around 1660 by Algernon Sidney, a member of the British "long parliament". He was an opponent of Charles II, who had him  executed for treason.

[[Peru, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Peru is a town in Clinton County in the U.S. state of New York. The population was 6,998 at the 2010 census.

[[Litoria sauroni]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Litoria sauroni  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists have only seen it in the Kikori Integrate Conservation and Development Project area.  Different scientists disagree about whether this frog should be in the genus Litoria or Nyctimystes.

This frog has red-and-black eyes and pads, called nuptual pads, on its front feet.

[[The Satin Slipper]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 drama movies, French drama movies, Portuguese movies, German drama movies, Swiss movies, Movies directed by Manoel de Oliveira

The Satin Slipper (Le soulier de satin) is a 1985 French Portuguese German Swiss drama movie directed by Manoel de Oliveira and based on the play of the same name by Paul Claudel. It stars Isabelle Weingarten, Luís Miguel Cintra, Patricia Barzyk, Anne Consigny, Bernard Alane, Jean-Pierre Bernard.

[[John Okell]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, British educators, Linguists

John William Alan Okell OBE (oʊ; 1934 – 3 August 2020) was a British linguist. He was known for his studies related to Burma. Okell was born in Brighton, England. 

He retired from SOAS in 1999, although he remained a research associate in the Department of South East Asia.

In 2014, in the Queen's Birthday Honours, he was made an Officer of the Order of the British Empire for services to UK/Burma relations.

He died on 3 August 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Brent Carver]]

CATEGORIES: Tony Award winning actors, 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian movie actors, Canadian voice actors, Canadian stage actors, Canadian television actors, Actors from British Columbia

Brent Carver (November 17, 1951 – August 4, 2020) was a Canadian actor. He was best known for his roles on Broadway in Parade as Leo Frank and Kiss of the Spider Woman as Molina. He won the Tony Award for Best Leading Actor in a Musical in 1993.  

Carver was born in Cranbrook, British Columbia. He died on August 4, 2020 at the age of 68 at home in Cranbrook.

[[Murray Cheater]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Competitors in athletics, Male athletes, Olympians, Sportspeople from Auckland

Murray Cheater (26 January 1947 – 4 August 2020) was a New Zealand athlete. He competed in the men's hammer throw at the 1976 Summer Olympics. He was born in Auckland.

Cheater died on 4 August 2020 at the age of 73.

[[John Chang-yik]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, South Korean people

The Right Reverend John Chang-yik (November 20, 1933 – August 5, 2020) was a South Korean Roman Catholic prelate. He was Bishop of Diocese of Ch’unch’on, South Korea from 1994 to 2010. In 1963, he became a priest. 

Chang-yik died on August 5, 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Cassegrain telescope]]

CATEGORIES: Telescopes

Cassegrain telescopes are reflector telescopes that use two curved mirrors to make an image. The big primary mirror gathers and concentrates light. The small secondary mirror then reflects the light through the back of the mirror. The secondary mirror is also curved so that it the light path is longer than the tube.

A "true Cassegrain" uses a primary mirror with a parabola-shaped curve, and a secondary mirror with a hyperbola-shaped curve. This is hard to make. Sphere-shaped curves are easier to make, but the image would be blurry. Catadioptric (lens and mirror) telescopes fix this by putting a special lens in front of the telescope.

Cassegrains are useful both as amateur telescopes which normal people can buy, and for scientists for serious astronomy work.

[[Horace Clarke]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, New York Yankees players, San Diego Padres players, People from Laurel, Maryland

Horace Meredith Clarke (June 2, 1938 – August 5, 2020) was an American Major League Baseball player. He played for the New York Yankees and the San Diego Padres from 1965 to 1974. Clarke was born in Frederiksted, U.S. Virgin Islands.

Clarke and Joe Mauer are the only hitters to break up three no-hit bids in the ninth inning.

Clarke died on August 5, 2020 in Laurel, Maryland from Alzheimer's disease-related problems at the age of 82.

[[Gregorian telescope]]

CATEGORIES: Telescopes

A Gregorian telescope was the first telescope to be designed that uses mirrors instead of lenses. It was invented by the English astronomer John Gregory. Even though it was designed in 1663, it wasn't the first reflecting telescope to be built. Newton's telescope, a different design, was built in 1668. The Gregorian telescope was first built in 1673 by Robert Hooke.

The telescope uses two curved mirrors. The large primary gathers light, and the small secondary reflects the light out the back of the primary mirror. Both mirrors are concave (bowl-shaped).

It is very similar to the Cassegrain telescope, which uses a large concave primary mirror and a small convex secondary mirror.

[[Herschelian telescope]]

CATEGORIES: Telescopes

A Herschelian telescope was invented in the 1780s by William Herschel. It is similar to a Newtonian telescope, except using only one mirror. 

In the 1780s, telescopes used metal mirrors which were not very reflective. Each mirror would absorb light and make the image dimmer. So Herschel invented a telescope with a tilted mirror that put the eyepiece in the front.

When mirrors became more reflective, Herschelian telescopes stopped being useful.

[[Hawa Abdi]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Somali people, Human rights activists, Physicians

Hawa Abdi Dhiblawe (May 17, 1947 – August 5, 2020) was a Somali human rights activist and medical doctor. She was the founder and chairperson of the Dr. Hawa Abdi Foundation (DHAF), a non-profit organization. Abdi was born in Mogadishu, Somalia. In 2009, she was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.

Abdi died on August 5, 2020, at her home in Mogadishu at the age of 73.

[[Opéra Bastille]]

CATEGORIES: Opera houses, Buildings and structures in Paris

The Opéra Bastille (opeʁa bastij, "Bastille Opera House") is a modern opera house in the 12th arrondissement of Paris, France.

It was opened in 1989 as part of President François Mitterrand's Grands Travaux.

It became the main facility of the Paris National Opera.

[[Shyamal Chakraborty]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India

Shyamal Chakraborty (1944 – August 6, 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a member of the Rajya Sabha from 2008 to 2014. He was the transport minister of West Bengal from 1982 to 1996. He was also a member of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly from 1981 to 1996.

Chakraborty died on August 6, 2020 at a hospital in Kolkata from cardiac arrest caused by COVID-19, aged 76. 

[[Werner Düggelin]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss writers, Swiss theatre directors

Werner Düggelin (7 December 1929 – 6 August 2020) was a Swiss theatre director. He was born in Zurich and grew up in Siebnen, Switzerland. In 1987, he won the Hans-Reinhart-Ring.

Düggelin was known for her stage directions relating to The Importance of Being Earnest, Dom Juan, The Just Assassins, The Lesson and Le Bourgeois gentilhomme.

Düggelin died on 6 August 2020 in Basel, aged 90.

[[Mukund Lath]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Indian educators, Indian historians

Mukund Lath (9 October 1937 – 6 August 2020) was an Indian scholar and cultural historian. He was known for his writings on music, dance, aesthetics and culture of India. He was honored by the Government of India, in 2010, with the fourth highest Indian civilian award of Padma Shri. Lath was born in Kolkata.

Lath died on 6 August 2020 in Jaipur at the age of 82.

[[Run-DMC]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 establishments in New York (state), 2000s disestablishments in New York (state), 2002 disestablishments in the United States, African-American musical groups, Musical groups from New York City, Musicians from Queens, Hip hop bands, Musical groups established in 1981, Musical groups disestablished in 2002

Run-DMC was an American hip hop group from Queens, New York. The group was founded in 1983 by Joseph Simmons, Darryl McDaniels, and Jason Mizell. 

Run-DMC is thought to be one of the most important acts in the history of hip hop culture. The group was one of the most famous hip hop acts of the 1980s. 

Along with LL Cool J and Public Enemy, the group pioneered new school hip hop music. 

The group was among the first to highlight the importance of the MC and DJ relationship. 

[[Joseph Simmons]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, American rap musicians from New York, Television personalities from New York City, Musicians from New York City

Joseph Ward Simmons (born November 14, 1964), better known by the stage name Run,  Rev. Run or DJ Run, is an American rapper, producer, DJ and TV personality. Simmons is one of the founding members of the influential hip hop group Run–D.M.C.

[[Darryl McDaniels]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, American rap musicians from New York, Record producers, Musicians from New York City, American hip hop musicians

Darryl Matthews McDaniels (born May 31, 1964), better known by his stage name DMC, is an American musician and rapper. He is a founding member of the hip hop group Run–D.M.C.

[[Jam Master Jay]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, 2002 deaths, American hip hop musicians, Musicians from New York City, Murders by firearm in the United States

Jason William Mizell (January 21, 1965 – October 30, 2002), better known by his stage name Jam Master Jay, was an American musician and DJ. He was the DJ of the influential hip hop group Run-D.M.C. 

During the 1980s, Run-D.M.C. became one of the biggest hip hop groups.

On October 30, 2002, at 7:30 pm, an unknown person shot Mizell in New York City. 

[[It's Tricky]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 songs

"It's Tricky" is the fourth and final single released from Run-DMC's third album, Raising Hell. It was released early in 1987 through Profile Records and was co-produced by Rick Rubin and the group themselves. 

The song peaked at No. 57 on the Billboard Hot 100 and No. 21 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs.

[[Carmine Benincasa]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Italian historians, Italian philosophers, Italian journalists, Italian art critics, Editors, Italian educators

Carmine Benincasa (17 December 1947 – 3 August 2020) was an Italian art critic, philosopher and editor. He was an art historian professor. Benincasa was born in Eboli, Italy. 

He was a professor of art history at the Accademia di Belle Arti di Macerata, the Academy of Fine Arts in Florence and Professor of History of Art at the Faculty of Architecture of the University La Sapienza in Rome. 

From 1978 to 1982 he was a member of the Venice Biennale Visual Arts Committee. He was the chief editor of the Italian edition of Cahiers d'Art.

Benincasa died on 3 August 2020 at the age of 72.

[[Pierre Viot]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, French businesspeople

Pierre Viot (9 April 1925 – 6 August 2020) was a French executive. He was a Senior Advisor on the French Court of Audit. He was born in Bordeaux, France. Viot headed the Centre national du cinéma et de l'image animée from 1973 to 1984.

Viot was President of the Paris Opera between 1985 to 1987. Between 1985 to 1990, he was President of the Opéra Bastille. Between 1984 to 2000, he was President of the Cannes Film Festival.

Viot died on 6 August 2020 at the age of 95.

[[Bernard Stiegler]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, French philosophers, Writers from Paris

Bernard Stiegler (stiɡlɛʁ; 1 April 1952 – 6 August 2020) was a French philosopher. He was head of the Institut de recherche et d'innovation (IRI), which he founded in 2006 at the Centre Georges-Pompidou. His best known work was Technics and Time, 1: The Fault of Epimetheus and Echographies of Television. He was born in Seine-et-Oise, France.

Stiegler died on 6 August 2020 in Paris at the age of 68.

[[Cilia Flores]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, Venezuelan politicians, First Ladies

Cilia Adela Gavidia Flores de Maduro (born 15 October 1956) is a Venezuelan lawyer and politician. She is married to the President of Venezuela Nicolás Maduro. In 2013, she became the First Lady. In 2015, she became a deputy in the National Assembly of Venezuela. She was president from 2006 to 2011, for her home state of Cojedes.

[[Fabiana Rosales]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Living people, Venezuelan writers, Journalists, First Ladies

Fabiana Andreina Rosales Guerrero (born 22 April 1992), also known as Fabiana Rosales de Guaidó, is a Venezuelan journalist  and social media human rights activist. 

She is married to Juan Guaidó, president of the National Assembly. She is considered by the White House and the National Assembly of Venezuela as the first lady of Venezuela.

[[Magdi Yacoub]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, Egyptian scientists, British physicians, Surgeons, British educators

Sir Magdi Habib Yacoub GBR (د/مجدى حبيب يعقوب ˈmæɡdi ħæˈbiːb jæʕˈʔuːb) (born 16 November 1935), is an Egyptian-British surgeon and cardiologist. He was a professor of cardiothoracic surgery at Imperial College London.

Yacoub is best known for his early work in repairing heart valves and for helping create the Ross procedure. He performed the UK's first combined heart and lung transplant in 1983.

From 1986 to 2006, he held the position of British Heart Foundation Professor of Cardiothoracic Surgery at the National Heart and Lung Institute, Imperial College Faculty of Medicine. 

He is the founding editor of the journal Disease Models & Mechanisms. He was born in Bilbeis, El Sharqia, Egypt.

[[Freya Pausewang]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, German writers, German sociologists, German educators

Freya Pausewang (20 August 1932 – 6 July 2020) was a German author and sociology educator. She was a younger sister of Gudrun Pausewang. She was born in Mladkov, Czech Republic.

Pausewang was known for her works in Ziele suchen (1994), Dem Spielen Raum geben (1997), Ins Leben begleiten (2009), Macht mich stark für meine Zukunft! (2012), Zukunftsorientierte Pädagogik (2016), Sozialkompetenz. Themenkarten für Teamarbeit, Elternarbeit, Seminare (2017) and Pädagogik auf dem Weg in die Zukunft (2018).

Pausewang died on 6 July 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Wayne Fontana]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, English rock singers, English pop singers, People from Manchester, Singers from Lancashire, Cancer deaths in England

Wayne Fontana (born Glyn Geoffrey Ellis, 28 October 1945 – 6 August 2020) was an English rock and pop singer. He was best known for the 1965 hit "Game of Love" with the Mindbenders. Fontana was born in Manchester.

Fontana died on 6 August 2020 from cancer in Stockport, Greater Manchester at the age of 74.

[[Cameo Kirby (1930 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 movies, 1930s drama movies, American drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Irving Cummings

Cameo Kirby is a 1930 American drama movie directed by Irving Cummings and based on the 1909 play of the same name by Booth Tarkington and Harry Leon Wilson. It stars J. Harold Murray, Norma Terris, Douglas Gilmore, Robert Edeson, Myrna Loy and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It is a lost movie.

[[Gokulathil Seethai (2019 TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: Zee Tamil Programming, Tamil-language television series, Indian television series

Gokulathil Seethai (கோகுலத்தில் சீதை) (Seetha in Home/Gokulam) is a 2019 Indian Tamil-language romance and family drama starring Nanda Gopal and Asha Gowda in the lead roles with actress Nalini, Gayathri and Dhakshayini plays a important role, while Madhumitha, Fouzil Hidhayah, Vaishali Thaniga and Vinitha Jaganathan plays female supporting role and  It was premiered on 4 November 2019. This series is an official remake of the Zee Telugu series Maate Manthramu.

This series started from 4 November 2019 on Everyday at 8.00PM (IST) time slot. The story is about Vasundhra (Vasu) - a young woman belonging to a middle-class family, tries to change the arrogant and rich Arjun into a responsible person.

[[ATRAC Audio Device]]

CATEGORIES: Sony

ATRAC Audio Device (also known as ATRAC AD or ATRAC HDD) a flash memory and harddisk on which audio data compressed in the ATRAC (Adaptive Transform Acoustic Coding) files recorded, (such as Network Walkman, VAIO Pocket, Xplod car audio series) same as iPod, iPod Mini, iPod Nano and iPod Shuffle.

[[Steptoe and Son]]

CATEGORIES: British comedy television series, English-language television programs

Steptoe and Son is a British comedy series that was first aired on UK TV between 1962 and 1965 and then again between 1970 and 1974. There are 57 episodes. It was made into 8 series or seasons. The programme revolves around the intergenerational relationship between a rag and bone father and son. 

[[Olivia Santana]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, Brazilian activists, Brazilian politicians

Maria Olivia Santana (born 25 March 1967) is a Brazilian activist. She is the founder of the Black Union For Equality (UNEGRO).

She was born in Salvador, Bahia. At the age of 14, she started to work as a cleaner in a private school. She studied at the Federal University of Bahia (UFBA). 

She was a city councilor in Salvador, Bahia. In 2012, she was a candidate for vice mayor of Salvador. She supported extending childcare.

Since 2019, she has been a member of the Bahia Legislative Assembly for the Communist Party of Brazil.

[[Kyōhei Tsutsumi]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 deaths, 2020 deaths, Musicians from Tokyo, Japanese composers, Japanese songwriters, Japanese pianists, Deaths from pneumonia

Kyōhei Tsutsumi (筒美京平) (May 28, 1940 – October 7, 2020) was a well-known songwriter and pianist in Japan. He was born on May 28, 1940 in Tokyo. He made many hits such as "Blue Light Yokohama" (ブルー・ライト・ヨコハマ), "Mata Au Hi Made" (また逢う日まで), "Watashi no Kare wa Hidari-kiki" (わたしの彼は左きき), Sentimental (センチメンタル) and so on. He was awarded for his works by an official renowned medal "紫綬褒章" from Japanese government in 2003. The number of works he wrote are more than 3,000, and he has sold over 74 million copies in total. 

Tsutsumi died of pneumonia on October 7, 2020 at the age of 80.

[[The Swarm (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 horror movies, 1970s science fiction movies, American science fiction horror movies, Movies directed by Irwin Allen, Warner Bros. movies

The Swarm is a 1978 American science fiction horror movie directed by Irwin Allen and stars Michael Caine, Katharine Ross, Richard Widmark, Richard Chamberlain, Olivia de Havilland, Ben Johnson, Lee Grant, José Ferrer, Patty Duke, Slim Pickens, Bradford Dillman, Fred MacMurray, Henry Fonda. It was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Maximus Inc.]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s establishments in Virginia, 1975 establishments in the United States, Companies of the United States, Virginia

Maximus Inc., trademarked as MAXIMUS, is an American outsourcing company. It gives services about processing business. These services are for government health and human services agencies in the United States, Australia, Canada, Saudi Arabia, and the United Kingdom. Maximus focuses on government programs, such as Medicaid, the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), health care reform, welfare-to-work, Medicare, child support, and other government programs. The company is in Reston, Virginia. It has more than 34,000 employees. It has a reported yearly revenue of $2.39 billion in fiscal year 2018.

[[Shooting of Leonard Deadwyler]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 1966 deaths, People shot dead by law enforcement officers in the United States

Leonard Deadwyler (February 19, 1941 – May 7, 1966) was an African-American man who was shot and killed by LAPD officer Jerold M. Bova after allegedly speeding and running red lights while driving his wife, who was in labor, to the hospital. His wife later sued Los Angeles for wrongful death, and was represented by Johnnie Cochran, but lost the case. However, Deadwyler's death inspired the building of Martin Luther King, Jr. Community Hospital in South Central.

[[Litoria pallidofemora]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Litoria pallidofemora  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists disagree about whether this frog is really in the genus Nyctimystes or the genus Litoria.

This frog has green coloring on the inside of its mouth.  Scientists say it is related to the northern New Guinea tree frog, Litoria graminea.

[[Dolma]]

CATEGORIES: Azerbaijani food, Greek food, Turkish food, Iranian food, Middle Eastern foods

Dolma meaning "filling" in Turkish or Dolmades in Greek, is the name for a number of dishes which are common in eastern Mediterranean and Caucasian cuisines. Usually, a kind of vegetable is filled with rice and chopped or ground meat. Instead of a vegetable, vine leaves are sometimes used.

In 2017, dolma making in Azerbaijan was included in the UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists. The tradition is present throughout the Republic of Azerbaijan, and is perceived as a central culinary practice in all of its regions.

[[Spiraea]]

CATEGORIES: Amygdaloideae

Spiraea is a genus of plants in the Rosaceae family. They are often grown for their beauty. There are about 80 to 100 species. One species of Spiraea, Spiraea betulifolia, was eaten by Native Americans.

[[De Havilland Mosquito]]

CATEGORIES: Aircraft, British Army equipment

The De Havilland Mosquito is a British aircraft from the World War II. The Mosquito was a successful design. Originally intended to be a bomber, the type was very fast, could fly a long way and carry heavy loads. Therefore, it was and it was adapted to a number of other roles such as fighter, night fighter, night intruder, attack, reconnaissance and pathfinder.

[[Kohala]]

CATEGORIES: Volcanoes of Hawaii

Kohala is an extinct shield volcano in Hawaii. It is the oldest of five volcanoes on the Big Island, forming its northwestern part.

[[Katsunari Miyai]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Tokyo, Baseball coaches, Deaths from lung cancer

Katsunari Miyai was a Japanese baseball manager. He was the manager of the baseball clubs of Waseda Jitsugyo and Chuo University. He was the only person to manage the winning teams of a Kōshien tournament and the Meiji Jingu Baseball Tournament.

[[Urtica]]

CATEGORIES: Urticaceae

Urtica is a genus of plants commonly known as the nettles. They can produce an itching sensation when they touch skin. The most well-known species is Urtica dioica, the common stinging nettle.

[[Call Her Savage]]

[[Tess of the Storm Country (1932 movie)]]

[[The Return of the Living Dead]]

The Return of the Living Dead is a 1985 American zombie comedy movie directed by Dan O'Bannon and starring Clu Gulager, James Karen, Thom Matthews, Don Calfa. It is set as a sequel to the 1968 movie Night of the Living Dead and was distributed by Orion Pictures. It was nominated for four Saturn Awards in 1986.

[[Calicut International Airport]]

CATEGORIES: Airports in Asia, Buildings and structures in India, Kerala

Calicut International Airport CCJ is an international airport located in Karipur, Malappuram district of Kerala, India. The airport opened on 13 April 1988. 

The airport is an operating base for Air India Express and operates Hajj Pilgrimage services to Medina and Jeddah from Kerala. 

It was the eleventh-busiest airport in India in terms of overall passenger traffic. It is the third-busiest airport in Kerala after Kochi and Thiruvananthapuram.

[[Air India Express Flight 1344]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in India, August 2020 events, Aviation disasters in Asia, Disasters in the 21st century, Kerala

Air India Express Flight 1344 was a scheduled flight from Dubai, United Arab Emirates to Kozhikode in Kerala, India. On 7 August 2020, the Boeing 737-800 skidded off the end of the runway into a gorge, where it broke into two pieces.

Of the 191 people on board - including both pilots - were killed in the crash.

[[Ralph Klassen]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, California Golden Seals players, Canadian ice hockey forwards, Cleveland Barons (NHL) players, Colorado Rockies (NHL) players, Ice hockey people from Saskatchewan, St. Louis Blues players, Saskatoon Blades players

Ralph L. Klassen (September 15, 1955 – August 3, 2020) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player. He played 497 games in the National Hockey League. 

In Klassen's ten-year career, he played for the California Golden Seals, Cleveland Barons, Colorado Rockies, and St. Louis Blues. He was born in Humboldt, Saskatchewan.

Klassen died on August 3, 2020 at the age of 64.

[[Lindsay Brown (accountant)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s births, 2020 deaths, New Zealand educators

Lindsay John Brown NZL (76 – 6 August 2020) was a New Zealand accountant. He was chancellor of the University of Otago from 2004 to 2008. 

Brown died in Dunedin, New Zealand on 6 August 2020, aged 76.

[[Muslim Evloev]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths by firearm, Russian sportspeople, Kyrgyzstani people, Wrestlers

Muslim Evloev (11 June 1995 – 6 August 2020) was a Russian-Kyrgyzstani freestyle wrestler. He won a gold medal in his event at the Asian Wrestling Championships and at the Islamic Solidarity Games. Evloev was born in Malgobek, Russia. 

He was killed in August 2020 during a shoot out in a counter-terrorism operation in Nazran, Russia at the age of 25.

[[Gunther Kaschlun]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, German Olympians, Rowers

Gunther Kaschlun (9 February 1935 – 20 July 2020) was a West German rower. He represented the United Team of Germany. He competed at the 1956 Summer Olympics in Melbourne with the men's coxless four where they were eliminated in the semi-final.

He died in July 2020 at the age of 85.

[[Nikolai van der Heyde]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch movie directors, Dutch screenwriters, People from Leeuwarden, Writers from Friesland

Nikolai van der Heyde (23 January 1936 – 6 August 2020) was a Dutch movie director and screenwriter. He directed seven movies between 1966 and 1987. He was born in Leeuwarden, Netherlands.

His 1968 movie To Grab the Ring was entered into the 18th Berlin International Film Festival. Five years later, his movie Love Comes Quietly was entered into the 23rd Berlin International Film Festival.

Heyde died on 6 August 2020 in Laren, Netherlands at the age of 84.

[[Nandi Yellaiah]]

CATEGORIES: Indian politicians, 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India

Nandi Yellaiah (1 July 1942 – 8 August 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a member of the Indian National Congress party. From 2014 to 2019, he was member of Parliament of India from Nagarkurnool in the Lok Sabha. He was born in Hyderabad, India.

Yellaiah died on 8 August 2020 at a Hyderabad hospital from COVID-19, aged 78.

[[Michael Ojo]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, African-American basketball players, Nigerian sportspeople, Sportspeople from Florida, People from Lagos

Michael Olalekan Ojo (January 5, 1993 – August 7, 2020) was a Nigerian-American professional basketball player. At 7 tall and 310, he was one of the tallest and heaviest players ever to play in Serbia and Europe. 

After competing in college basketball for Florida State, he played professionally for three seasons with Serbian clubs FMP and Crvena zvezda. He was born in Lagos, Nigeria.

Ojo died of a heart attack while training in Belgrade, Serbia at age of 27.

[[Judit Reigl]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Painters, Hungarian people

Judit Reigl (born Judit Némedy; 1 May 1923 – 7 August 2020) was a Hungarian painter. Her career was based in Paris. Her works are primarily found in the collections of French museums, including the Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris, Musée National d'Art Moderne and Musée de Grenoble.

Reigl died on 7 August 2020 at the age of 97.

[[Adin Steinsaltz]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Israeli writers, Israeli Jews, Israeli rabbis, Philosophers, Israeli educators, Critics, Publishers, People from Jerusalem

Rabbi Adin Even-Israel Steinsaltz (11 July 1937 – 7 August 2020) was an Israeli Chabad Chasidic rabbi, teacher, philosopher, social critic, and publisher. He was born in Jerusalem.

His edition of the Talmud was originally published in modern Hebrew and was translated into English, French, Russian, and Spanish. 

Beginning in 1989, Steinsaltz published several writings in Hebrew and English of the Babylonian (Bavli) Talmud in an English-Hebrew edition. and has since been brought to completion.

Steinsaltz was honored with the Israel Prize for Jewish Studies (1988), the President's Medal (2012), and the Yakir Yerushalayim prize (2017).

Steinsaltz died in Jerusalem on August 7, 2020, from acute pneumonia at the age of 83.

[[Précy-Saint-Martin]]

Précy-Saint-Martin is a commune of the Aube département in the north-central part of France.

[[Gennadi Touretski]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Russian sportspeople, Deaths from stroke

Gennadi Gennadiyevich Touretski (Геннадий Геннадьевич Турецкий, 17 July 1949 – 7 August 2020) was a Russian swimming coach. He was best known for training multiple Olympic gold medalists Alexander Popov and Michael Klim through the 1990s to early 2000s at the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS).

In 2011 he trained Ian Thorpe in Switzerland.

[[Kuranosuke Hamaguchi]]

CATEGORIES: Japanese songwriters, Japanese composers

Kuranosuke Hamaguchi (born: 浜口庫之助 on July 22, 1917 in Kobe, Japan - died: December 2, 1990 ) was a Japanese songwriter and jazz musician. His songs were a mixture of Japanese lyrics and American popular melody. In this way, he became popular in song making. It is said that he made around 4,000 songs during his lifetime.

[[Brum (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: British television series, English-language television programs

''Brum, also known as The Adventures of Brum, is a'' British television series. It is made for viewers aged 3 to 9 years old. Each episode runs for about 10 minutes. There were 66 episodes were produced. 

The show is set in Birmingham, England and produced by Ragdoll Productions. It was first broadcast in 1991 up until 2002.

[[Carrick-on-Shannon]]

CATEGORIES: County towns in Ireland, County Leitrim

Carrick-on-Shannon (Cora Droma Rúisc) is the county town of County Leitrim in Ireland. It is the largest town in the County Leitrim whilst it is the smallest county town in the entire country. According to the 2016 census, there are people 4,062 living there. It is strategically located in the crossing point of the River Shannon.

[[Five Megillot]]

CATEGORIES: Books of the Hebrew Bible, Judaism, Old Testament books

Five Megillot are five books found in the Hebrew Bible (also called Tanakh) under Ketuvim, which are read out during Holy Days of Judaism. They are:

Song of Songs used during Passover,

Ruth used on Shavuot,

Lamentations used on the 9th of Av,

Ecclesiastes used during Sukkot,

Esther for the holiday of Purim.

Turkish Delight (Turks fruit) is a 1973 Dutch romantic drama movie directed by Paul Verhoeven and  is based on the 1969 novel Turks fruit by Jan Wolkers. It stars Rutger Hauer in his movie debut, Monique van de Ven and was nominated for 1 Oscar in 1974.

[[70th Anniversary Grand Prix]]

The 70th Anniversary Grand Prix is a Formula One motor race. It is scheduled to be held on August 9, 2020 at the Silverstone Circuit in Silverstone, United Kingdom after British Grand Prix.

[[Maria Rosaria Capobianchi]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Italian biologists

Maria Rosaria Capobianchi (born 1953 Procida) is an Italian biologist. She is the laboratory director of virology at the National Institute for Infectious Diseases "Lazzaro Spallanzani" (INMI). In 2020, she isolated coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic.

She graduated from the Federico II University of Naples, and in Microbiology from the Sapienza University of Rome.

Her research focused on the mechanism of production and action of interferon, emerging viruses, persistent viral infections, and HIV infection. She was part of the World Health Organization Collaborating Center "Treatment, Diagnosis, Response and Training in Highly Infectious Diseases", established at INMI in 2009. She is a consultant of the National Transplant Center for viral infections in transplants.

In February 2020, her research group isolated SARS-CoV-2 , with Francesca Colavita and Concetta Castilletti.

[[Dateline NBC]]

CATEGORIES: NBC network shows, 1992 television series debuts, 1990s television series, 2000s television series, 2010s television series, American magazines

Dateline NBC is an American news magazine. It looks at true crime, though occasionally it looks at other topics. The program began on March 31, 1992 on NBC.

The show has been nominated for five Emmy Awards. 

Dateline NBC has also been the focus of some controversy. On November 17, 1992, the show aired an hour-long report titled Waiting to Explode. That was about certain pickup trucks from General Motors, particularly Chevrolet, blowing up on impact in truck crashes due to poor design. This especially applied to pickups between 1973 and 1987.

Past correspondents and anchors are Maria Shriver, Ann Curry and Jane Pauley.

[[Rhamnaceae]]

CATEGORIES: Rhamnaceae

The Rhamnaceae is a family of plants in the order Rosales, with around 55 genera and 950 species. Well-known plants in this family include Ziziphus and Hovenia dulcis.

[[Underclass]]

CATEGORIES: Social classes

The underclass is the segment of the population that occupies the lowest possible position in a class hierarchy, below the core body of the working class.

Whitney is an American sitcom that was on :NBC from 2011 to 2013.

[[Rhamnus]]

CATEGORIES: Rhamnaceae

Rhamnus is a genus of plants in the Rhamnaceae family. They are commonly known as buckthorns. There are around 110 species, and their height can be anywhere from 1 to 15 meters. Rhamnus species are called buckthorns because they have spines on their twigs. One common species is Rhamnus cathartica, the common buckthorn.

[[News magazine]]

CATEGORIES: News, Magazines

A news magazine is a printed, published and typed magazine, radio or television program. It has articles about current events. News magazines discuss stories in greater depth than newspapers and newscasts.

Radio news magazines are similar to television news magazines. Unlike radio newscasts, radio news magazines often run between thirty minutes and several hours.

[[Mespilus]]

CATEGORIES: Amygdaloideae

Mespilus is a genus of plants in the Rosaceae family. It contains two species, Mespilus germanica and Mespilus canescens, though M. canescens is a hybrid between M. germanica and a Crataegus species, and is properly called × Crataemespilus canescens. 

[[Bal Gangadhar Tilak]]

CATEGORIES: 1856 births, 1920 deaths, Hindus, Indian politicians, Indian revolutionaries, Nonviolence advocates

Bal Gangadhar Tilak (बाल गंगाधर तिलक; बाळ केशव गंगाधर टिळक;  born Keshav Gangadhar Tilak on 23 July 1856 – died 1 August 1920) was a leader of nationalism, teacher, and an Independence activist in British-ruled India. He was also conferred with the title of "Lokmanya", which means "accepted by the people (as their leader)". Mahatma Gandhi called him "The Maker of Modern India". 

A militant member of the 'extremist' wing within the Indian National Congress (and a member of the famous 'Lal, Pal and Bal' trio), he was twice imprisoned by the British for his nationalist activities. He helped to found the Home Rule League in 1914.

[[Si quaeris peninsulam amoenam circumspice]]

CATEGORIES: Latin state mottos of the United States, Michigan

In Latin, Si quaeris peninsulam amoenam circumspice means "If you seek a pleasant peninsula, look about you. It is the state motto of Michigan.

[[Excelsior!]]

CATEGORIES: Latin state mottos of the United States, New York

Excelsior! is a Latin phrase that can mean either "Ever upward", or can mean wood shavings used to pack items, though it usually means "Ever upward". It is the state motto of New York.

[[Lake Nakki]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of India, Rajasthan

Nakki Lake (नक्की झील) is an important tourist attraction and a scared lake in the Republic of India. It is also the national lake of the nation. It is a Hill station, Mahatma Gandhi's ashes were immersed in this Holy Lake on 12 February 1948 and Gandhi Ghat was constructed.

Nakki Lake lies in the state of Rajasthan.

[[Binary neural network]]

CATEGORIES: Computing

Binary neural network is an artificial neural network, where commonly used floating-point weights are replaced with binary ones. 

It saves storage and computation, and serves as a technique for deep models on resource-limited devices. Using binary values can bring up to 58 times speedup. Accuracy and information capacity of binary neural network can be manually controlled. Binary neural networks do not achieve the same accuracy as their full-precision counterparts, but improvements are being made to close this gap.

[[Kainar Academy]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 establishments in Asia, Colleges and universities in Asia, Kazakhstan

Kainar Academy (Қайнар Академиясы) is a private university in Almaty, Kazakhstan. The university was founded in 1991 as Kainar University (ҚАЙНАР университеті). In 2014, Kainar changed its name to Kainar Academy. It is accredited by the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan.

In 1999, Kainar College was created by the university.

[[Ksingmul people]]

The Ksingmul (also known as Xinh Mun, Con Pua, Puộc, and Pụa) are an ethnic group that live in Vietnam and Laos.

[[Lenticel]]

CATEGORIES: Trees, Plant physiology

A lenticel is  porous tissue in the bark of trees. Its cells make large intercellular spaces in the periderm of the bark. They are found in the woody stems and roots of dicotyledonous flowering plants. 

Lenticels are also found in other woody plants, starting in the Carboniferous period. The development and increase in these primitive lenticels gave a system  for aeration and gas exchange in these plants.

Lenticels work as pores for the direct exchange of gases. Otherwise the bark is impermeable to gases. The name 'lenticel' comes from its lenticular (lens-like) shape. The shape of lenticels is one of the characteristics used for tree identification.

[[Stowaway (1936 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 movies, 1930s musical movies, American musical movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by William A. Seiter

Stowaway is a 1936 American musical movie directed by William A. Seiter and starring Shirley Temple, Robert Young, Alice Faye, Helen Westley, Allan Lane, Astrid Allwyn, Eugene Pallette, Philip Ahn. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Story of Louis Pasteur]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 movies, 1930s drama movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by William Dieterle

The Story of Louis Pasteur is a 1936 American biographical drama movie directed by William Dieterle and starring Paul Muni, Josephine Hutchinson, Anita Louise, Donald Woods, Fritz Leiber, Henry O'Neill, Porter Hall. It was distributed by Warner Bros. and was nominated for 4 Oscars and won 3 Academy Awards in 1937.

[[Pedro Casaldáliga]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from respiratory tract infection, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Brazilian people, Human rights activists, Humanitarians, Spanish people, Roman Catholic bishops

Pedro Casaldáliga CMF, born Pere Casaldàliga i Pla (16 February 1928 – 8 August 2020), was a Catalan-born Brazilian prelate of the Catholic Church.

He led the Territorial Prelature of São Félix, Brazil, from 1970 to 2005. In 1971, he became a bishop. He was a well known humanitarian and human rights activist.

Casaldáliga was one of the best known experts of liberation theology. He was born in Balsareny, Catalonia. 

On 4 August 2020, Casaldáliga was hospitalized in Batatais, Brazil for a respiratory infection caused by his Parkinson's disease. He died four days later on 8 August, aged 92.

[[Chica Xavier]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian movie actors, Brazilian television actors, Brazilian stage actors, Deaths from lung cancer

 Francisca Xavier Queiroz de Jesus, known professionally as Chica Xavier (January 22, 1932 – August 8, 2020), was a Brazilian actress. Xavier was born in Salvador, Bahia. 

Her best known movie roles were in Sinhá Moça (1986), O Rei do Gado (1996), Força de um Desejo (1999), Esperança (2002), Um Só Coração (2004) and Duas Caras (2007).

Xavier died of lung cancer on August 8, 2020 in Rio de Janeiro at the age of 88.

[[Buruji Kashamu]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria, Nigerian politicians

Buruji Kashamu (19 May 1958 – 8 August 2020) was a Nigerian politician. He was a member of the People's Democratic Party. From 2015 to 2019, he was a member of the Nigerian Senate. He was born in Ogun State, Nigeria.

Kashamu died in Lagos on 8 August 2020 from COVID-19, aged 62.

[[Gabriel Ochoa Uribe]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Colombian footballers, Football managers

Gabriel Ochoa Uribe (November 20, 1929 – August 8, 2020) was a Colombian football player and manager. He won four league titles and the Copa Colombia with Millonarios. He managed the national team for a short time in 1985.

In 1979, he became manager of América de Cali, he led them to 7 league championships, they were runners-up in the Copa Libertadores three times consecutively (1985, 1986, 1987). He retired in 1991.

Ochoa Uribe died on August 8, 2020 in Cali, Colombia at the age of 90.

[[David Bishop (American politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, American lawyers, Politicians from New York, Politicians from Minnesota, People from Syracuse, New York, US Republican Party politicians, People from Rochester, Minnesota

David Tyre Bishop (March 9, 1929 – August 3, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician. Bishop was born in Syracuse, New York. He was a member of the Minnesota House of Representatives from 1983 to 1992 and 1993 to 2002. He was a Republican.

Bishop died on August 3, 2020 in Rochester, Minnesota at the age of 91.

[[Millonarios F.C.]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Colombia, 1940s establishments in South America, 1946 establishments, Colombian football clubs, Bogotá

Millonarios Fútbol Club is a professional Colombian football team based in Bogotá. They currently play in the Categoría Primera A. They play their home games at the El Campín stadium.

The team was initially created in 1937.

Millonarios has won the Colombian league 15 times. They are also the third Colombian team to achieve a major international title, the Copa Merconorte in 2001. Since the beginning of the Colombian professional football league, Millonarios has won many domestic tournaments, the last one in 2017.

Millonarios is also one of only three teams that have played every first division tournament in the country, along with their traditional rivals Santa Fe and Atlético Nacional.

[[Wilbert McClure]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, American Olympic gold medalists, American boxers, Sportspeople from Ohio, People from Toledo, Ohio

Wilbert McClure (October 29, 1938 – August 6, 2020) was an American boxer. He was an amateur. He won gold medals in the light middleweight division at the 1959 Pan American Games and the 1960 Olympics. As a professional he competed from 1961 to 1970.

McClure was born in Toledo, Ohio. He died on August 6, 2020 at the age of 81. 

[[Louis Meznarie]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, French engineers

Louis Meznarie (14 January 1930 – 6 August 2020) was a French engine expert. He was a team owner entrant to 24 Hours of Le Mans. He was born in Saintry-sur-Seine (Essonne), France. 

From 1959 to 1971 he was an official dealer of NSU for motorcycles and motorcars and engine preparation expert for French races. In 1968, he opened a large workshop in Le Plessis-Chenet (Le Coudray-Montceaux town) with the support of Shell Oil Company. 

From 1971 to 1983, he was the official engine preparation expert for Porsche, with many victories in 24 Hours of Le Mans, French Rally Championship and European Rally Championship. Notably in 1972, Assisted by Jürgen Barth, future winner in a Porsche 936 in 1977, by Sylvain Garant, then Mike Keizer. The 911 with a 2.5-liter engine, flanked by the No. 41 finished in 13th place in the general classification while winning its category.

At the Salon Moto Légende 2017, in Paris, Louis Meznarie, had sold these last motorcycles in number of 4 NSU by the Osenat auction house. In recent years, he traveled less and less but we always enjoyed finding him and exchanging many memories.

Meznarie died on 6 August 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Apisai Tora]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Fijian politicians, Trade unionists

Mohammad Apisai Vuniyayawa Tora (January 5, 1934 – August 6, 2020) was a Fijian politician, soldier, and trade unionist. He was a Senator from 2001 to 2006. He was elected to the House of Representatives for the first time in 1972 as a member of the National Federation Party. In 1977 when he lost his seat.

On 27 September 2005, he was sentenced to eight months in jail for offenses related to the coup of 2000.

Tora died on August 6, 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Adam Comrie]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths in the United States, Ice hockey people from Ontario

Adam Comrie (July 31, 1990 – August 7, 2020) was a Canadian professional ice hockey defenceman. Comrie was selected by the Florida Panthers in the 3rd round (80th overall) of the 2008 NHL Entry Draft. He was born in Kanata, Ontario. His career lasted from 2010 to 2020. 

Comrie was killed in a motorcycle crash on August 7, 2020 near Virginia while visiting his mother in the United States, aged 30.  

[[Lorenzo Soria]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine writers, Argentine businesspeople, Italian journalists, Italian businesspeople, Writers from Buenos Aires, Deaths from lung cancer, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles

Lorenzo Soria (27 November 1951 – 7 August 2020) was an Argentine-born Italian journalist and executive. He was President of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association for three terms between 2003 to 2005, 2015 to 2017 and again from 2019 until his death. He worked as a journalist for La Stampa and L'espresso. Soria was born in Buenos Aires.

Soria died on 7 August 2020 in Los Angeles from lung cancer, aged 68.

[[Jean Stewart]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, New Zealand sportspeople, Swimmers, Olympic bronze medalists

Jean Hurring (née Stewart, 23 December 1930 – 8 August 2020) was a New Zealand swimmer. She won a bronze medal in the 100 m backstroke at the 1952 Summer Olympics. Stewart was born in Dunedin, New Zealand.

Stewart died on 8 August 2020 in Auckland at the age of 89.

[[Mark Wirtz]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, French artists, French singers, French composers, French musicians, French comedians, French writers, French businesspeople, Record producers, Deaths from frontotemporal dementia

Mark Philipp Wirtz (3 September 1943spnd7 August 2020) was a French pop music record producer, composer, singer, musician, author, and comedian. Wirtz was best known for the never-completed A Teenage Opera concept album. The first single from the planned album, "Excerpt from A Teenage Opera" by Keith West, was a number 2 hit on the UK Singles Chart in September 1967. He was born in Strasbourg, France.

Wirtz died of frontotemporal dementia on 7 August 2020, aged 76.

[[Stephen F. Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from New York City, US Republican Party politicians

Stephen Fain Williams (September 23, 1936 – August 7, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was the Senior United States Circuit Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit between 1986 until his death. He was nominated to the position by President Ronald Reagan. Williams was born in New York City.

Williams was hospitalized in Washington, D.C. in June 2020 with COVID-19. He died from the infection two months later on August 7, 2020 at the age of 83.

[[Durham Castle]]

CATEGORIES: Castles in England, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom, Durham

Durham Castle is a Norman castle in the city of Durham, England. It is the former residence of the Bishop of Durham.  University College, Durham is there since 1837. 

Together with Durham Cathedral, the castle is a World Heritage Site in England since 1986. It is open to the general public to visit through guided tours.

[[Studley Royal Park]]

CATEGORIES: Parks in the United Kingdom, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom, North Yorkshire

Studley Royal Park (including the Ruins of Fountains Abbey) is a UNESCO-designated World Heritage Site in North Yorkshire, England. It has an area of 323 hectares (800 acres) and features an 18th-century landscaped garden, some of the largest Cistercian ruins in Europe, a Jacobean mansion, and a Victorian church designed by William Burges.

[[Waltheof, Earl of Northumbria]]

CATEGORIES: 1050 births, 1076 deaths, Earls and countesses, English royalty

October 2019Waltheof, Earl of Northumbria (died 31 May 1076) was the last Anglo-Saxon earl. He was the only English aristocrat to be executed during the reign of William I.

Lake County is a county in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 census, 11,539 people live here. The county seat is Baldwin.

[[Date honey]]

CATEGORIES: Middle Eastern foods, Libya, Iraq, Palestinian culture, Israeli culture, Date dishes, Spreads, Natural resources

Date honey or Date syrup (in Arabic: Rub, in Hebrew: Silan) is a sweet syrup made from dates. It is very popular in North Africa and Middle East cuisines. In the Iranian cuisine and the Arab cuisine, it is also used to sweet Tahini.

[[Grape honey]]

CATEGORIES: Spreads, Natural resources

Grape honey (in Arabic: Dabas) is a sweet syrup made from grapes. It is very popular in and the Middle East, Georgian, Mediterranean cuisines. 

[[Halva]]

CATEGORIES: Desserts

Halva (also known as halvah, halwa) is a solid candy based on vegetable fat and sugar.  There are many types of halva. In Israel, crude sesame base is popular. In Russia, halva made out of Sunflower seeds is popular.  

Halva has a number of geographical sources: from Iraq, Lebanon, Pakistan, Iran, India, Uzbekistan, Russia, Belarus, and Ukraine. It is considered a national dish in Turkey.

[[Camellia sasanqua]]

CATEGORIES: Camellia

Camellia sasanqua (often called the sasanqua camellia) is a species of plant in the genus Camellia. It is native to China and Japan. It can be found growing at a height of 900 meters. It grows up to 5 meters tall and is related to the tea plant, Camellia sinensis.

[[Sapodilla]]

CATEGORIES: Sapotaceae

Manilkara zapota is a fruit tree in the Sapotaceae family. It is commonly known as the Sapodilla or Sapota. It is from southern Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean. It is often grown for its fruit, which has a very malty and sweet flavor, and tastes like a pear.

[[Castles and Town Walls of King Edward in Gwynedd]]

CATEGORIES: Castles in Wales, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

53The Castles and Town Walls of King Edward in Gwynedd is a World Heritage Site recognised by UNESCO. It is located in Gwynedd, Wales. The site includes the castles of Beaumaris and Harlech. It also includes the castles and town walls of Caernarfon and Conwy. It is considered to be the "finest examples of late 13th century and early 14th century military architecture in Europe".

[[Fountains Abbey]]

CATEGORIES: Monasteries, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

July 2013Fountains Abbey  is one of the largest and best preserved ruined Cistercian monasteries in England. It is sits approximately 3 south-west of Ripon in North Yorkshire. It was founded in 1132 and operated for 407 years. It one of the wealthiest monasteries in England until it was dissolved in 1539, under the order of Henry VIII.

It is a Grade I listed building owned by the National Trust. It is part of the designated Studley Royal Park including the Ruins of Fountains Abbey. It is one of the recognised World Heritage Site by UNESCO.

[[Hurricane Isaac]]

Hurricane Isaac was a storm in 2012.

A tropical wave formed off the coast of Africa and it was named Tropical Depression Nine-L. A few hours later, it became a tropical storm and it was was named "Isaac."  Hurricane Isaac hit the Florida Straits, Gulf of Mexico and Louisiana.

[[Pontcysyllte Aqueduct]]

CATEGORIES: Wales, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

The Pontcysyllte Aqueduct (Traphont Ddŵr Pontcysyllte) is a canal aqueduct in north east Wales. It took 10 years to design and build. It was completed in 1805. It is the longest aqueduct in Great Britain, and is the highest canal aqueduct in the world. The 18-arched stone and cast iron structure is designed for narrowboats.

The aqueduct was part of a grand plan which was never completed. It was part of the proposed Ellesmere Canal. It would have been an industrial waterway which made a  link between the River Severn at Shrewsbury and the port of Liverpool on the River Mersey. 

The westerly high-ground route across the Vale of Llangollen was chosen. A less expensive route was surveyed to the east, but the route chosen would have taken the canal through a mineral-rich area. It would have taken the canal through the coalfields of North-East Wales. However, only parts of the canal route were completed. The plan fell through because the money ran out. The capitalist system at the time was primitive and unreliable. Most major work on the canal stopped after the completion of the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct in 1805.

The structure is a Grade I listed building. It is recognised as a  UNESCO World Heritage Site.

[[2020 Belarusian presidential election]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 elections, August 2020 events, Politics of Belarus

The Presidential elections were held in Belarus on 9 August 2020. 

[[Blaenavon]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Wales

Blaenavon (Blaenafon) is a town in southeastern Wales. It is on the south of Afon Lwyd and north of Pontypool. Parts of the town and surrounding country form the Blaenavon Industrial Landscape became part of the World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 2000. There are about 6,057 people living there.

[[Four Jills in a Jeep]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 movies, 1940s musical movies, 1940s comedy movies, American musical comedy movies, World War II movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by William A. Seiter

Four Jills in a Jeep is a 1944 American musical comedy movie directed by William A. Seiter and starring Kay Francis, Carole Landis, Martha Raye, Mitzi Mayfair, Jimmy Dorsey, Alice Faye. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Princess Ingrid Alexandra of Norway]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 births, Norwegian royalty, Living people, People from Oslo

Princess Ingrid Alexandra of Norway (born 21 January 2004) is the elder child of Crown Prince Haakon and Crown Princess Mette-Marit. She is second in line to succeed her grandfather King Harald V. She is a member of the House of Glücksburg; and she is expected to become the country's second female monarch, after the 15th-century Queen Margaret.

[[Lottie Louise Riekehof]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, German writers, American educators, Writers from Virginia, People from Arlington, Virginia

Lottie Louise Riekehof (August 13, 1920 – August 6, 2020) was an American Sign Language interpreter and author. She was born in Germany. She was an important person in the field of professional sign language interpreting.

She wrote one of the first classes for interpreter educators, and trained interpreters and interpreter educators all over the world.28

[[Alauddin Ali]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Composers, Bangladeshi writers

Alauddin Ali (24 December 1952 – 9 August 2020) was a Bangladeshi music composer. He won the Bangladesh National Film Award for Best Music Director five times for the movies Golapi Ekhon Traine (1978), Sundori (1979), Koshai (1980), Jogajog (1988) and Lakhe Ekta (1990). 

He won the Best Music Composer award for the movie Laal Doriya (2002) and the Best Lyrics award for Premik (1985).

Ali died on 9 August 2020 at a private hospital in Dhaka from lung cancer, aged 67.

[[Rachid Belhout]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths, Algerian footballers, Algerian football managers

Rachid Belhout (رشيد بلحوت; June 14, 1944 – August 9, 2020) was an Algerian football manager and player. He managed Al-Ahly Benghazi in the Libyan Premier League.

[[Salome Bey]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Naturalized citizens of Canada, American singer-songwriters, American composers, American jazz singers, American soul singers, American gospel singers, Canadian singer-songwriters, Canadian composers, Singers from Newark, New Jersey, Writers from Newark, New Jersey, Singers from Toronto, Writers from Toronto

Salome Bey CAN (October 10, 1939 – August 9, 2020) was an American-born Canadian singer-songwriter, composer, and actress. She was born in Newark, New Jersey.

Bey recorded two albums with Horace Silver, and released live albums of her performances with the Montreal Jubilation Gospel Choir and at the Montreux Jazz Festival. 

In 2005, she was made an honorary Member of the Order of Canada.

Bey was a member of the Canadian charity Artists Against Racism.

Bey died on August 9, 2020 in Toronto, Ontario from dementia-related problems, at the age of 80.

[[Martin Birch]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Record producers, British engineers, British businesspeople, People from Woking

Martin Birch (27 December 1948 – 9 August 2020) was a British music producer and sound engineer. He was well known for engineering and producing albums by British rock bands including Deep Purple, Rainbow, Fleetwood Mac, Whitesnake, Black Sabbath, Blue Öyster Cult, and Iron Maiden. He was born in Woking, Surrey.

Birch died on 9 August 2020, at age 71.

[[Brendan Halligan]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Irish businesspeople, Economists, Former MEPs, Irish politicians, People from Dublin

Brendan Halligan (5 July 1936 – 9 August 2020) was an Irish economist and politician. He was founder and president of the Institute of International and European Affairs (IIEA). He was president of the Ireland China Institute.

He was also a Board Member of Mainstream Renewable Power. He was General Secretary of the Labour Party, a Teachta Dála (TD), a Senator, and a Member of the European Parliament (MEP). He was born in Dublin.

He died on 9 August 2020, aged 84.

[[Carroll Hardy]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Boston Red Sox players, Cleveland Indians players, Minnesota Twins players, San Francisco 49ers players, Houston Astros players, Sportspeople from South Dakota, Deaths from dementia

Carroll William Hardy (May 18, 1933 – August 9, 2020) was an American professional athlete. He played in the National Football League for the San Francisco 49ers (1955) and in Major League Baseball for the Cleveland Indians (1958–1960), Boston Red Sox (1960–1962), Houston Colt .45s (1963–1964) and Minnesota Twins (1967). 

He was born in Sturgis, South Dakota. He batted and threw right-handed and was listed as 6 tall and 185.

Hardy died on August 9, 2020 in Highlands Ranch, Colorado from dementia-related problems at the age of 87.

[[Kurt Luedtke]]

CATEGORIES: Academy Award winning writers, 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Disease-related deaths in Michigan, American journalists, Screenwriters from Michigan, Writers from Detroit, Michigan, Writers from Grand Rapids, Michigan

Kurt Luedtke (September 28, 1939spndAugust 9, 2020) was an American screenwriter and executive editor. He was born in Grand Rapids, Michigan. He was known for working with Sydney Pollack on many movies.

He worked for the Detroit Free Press.  He wrote Out of Africa (1985), for which he won the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay.  He also wrote Absence of Malice (1981) and Random Hearts (1999).  

Luedtke died on August 9, 2020 at a hospital in Royal Oak, Michigan from multiple organ failure, aged 80.

[[Out of Africa (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 romance movies, 1985 drama movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, Academy Award winning movies, American romantic drama movies, American epic movies, British romantic drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies set in Africa, Movies directed by Sydney Pollack

Out of Africa is a 1985 American epic romantic drama movie directed and produced by Sydney Pollack. It stars Meryl Streep and Robert Redford. The movie is based on the 1937 autobiographical book Out of Africa written by Isak Dinesen, about her life in Kenya.

The movie also stars Michael Kitchen as Berkeley Cole, Malick Bowens as Farah, Stephen Kinyanjui as the Chief, Michael Gough as Lord Delamere, Suzanna Hamilton as Felicity, and the model and actress Iman as Mariammo. 

The movie had mixed reviews from critics. However, Out of Africa won seven Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Director for Pollack.

[[Klaus Maria Brandauer]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, Actors who played Bond villains, Austrian movie actors, Austrian stage actors, Austrian television actors, Austrian voice actors, Austrian movie directors, Austrian educators, Golden Globe Award winning actors

Klaus Maria Brandauer (klaʊ̯s maˈʀiːa ˈbʀandaʊ̯ɐ; born Klaus Georg Steng; 22 June 1943) is an Austrian actor and director. He is also a professor at the Max Reinhardt Seminar. 

Brandauer is known for his roles in Mephisto (1981), Never Say Never Again (1983), Out of Africa (1985), Hanussen (1988), Burning Secret (1988), and Introducing Dorothy Dandridge (1999). 

Brandauer was nominated for an Academy Award and won a Golden Globe Award.

[[Zaōnishiki Toshimasa]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Japanese professional wrestlers, Deaths from multiple myeloma

Zaōnishiki Toshimasa (born Toshimasa Adachi; 3 September 1952 – 9 August 2020) was a sumo wrestler. He was born in Yamagata, Japan. 

He made his professional debut in September 1970, and reached the top division in November 1976. His highest rank was maegashira 1. He retired in January 1983. He became an elder in the Japan Sumo Association. He reached the retirement age for elders of 65 in September 2017.

Zaōnishiki revealed in 2014 that he was diagnosed with multiple myeloma. He died on 9 August 2020 from the disease at the age of 67.

[[Banjarbaru]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Indonesia

Banjarbaru is a city in the province of South Kalimantan in Indonesia. It is located 35 southeast of Banjarmasin. The city had a population of 199,627 as of the 2010 Census.

[[Litoria purpureolata]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Litoria purpureolata   is a tree frog from the island of New Guinea.  Scientists have only found it in Papua Province in Indonesia and West Sepak Province in Papua New Guinea.

The adult male frog is 5.6–6.8 cm long, which is large for a frog in Nyctimystes or Litoria.  Unlike many tree frogs, it has only a small stripe down its side or no stripe at all.  It has green skin with some white on its front legs and rear legs.  It has a light brown arc on its ear.  Some of the webbing between its toes is purple in color.

[[Francisco A. Cárdenas]]

CATEGORIES: 1879 births, 1943 deaths, Mexican politicians

August 2020

Francisco Atenógenes Cárdenas Garza (born on July 16, 1879 in Abasolo, Nuevo León - died: July 3, 1943 in San Antonio, Texas) was a Mexican engineer and politician. He was Governor of Nuevo León. He later resigned before the end of his term. 

[[Quorn, Leicestershire]]

CATEGORIES: Civil parishes in Leicestershire, Villages in Leicestershire

Quorn is a village in Leicestershire, a county in the East Midlands region of England. It is situated near to the university town of Loughborough. The village's population in 2011 was 5,177.

The village was named Quorndon until 1899. The name was shortened to Quorn to avoid confusion in posting as the name was similar to the village of Quarndon in nearby Derbyshire.

Quorn is built around the old A6 road, it runs through the centre of the village. On 28 October 1991, a dual carriageway bypass opened. The building of this road took the A6 away to the north-east of the village.

Quorn, the famous meat substitute company, takes its name from the village. It began production in 1985.

The village has a heritage railway station, Quorn and Woodhouse, on the Great Central Steam Railway, a preserved railway that runs between Loughborough and Leicester. The station also serves the hamlet of Woodhouse.

Gordon Banks, former England international football goalkeeper, lived in Quorn for many years of his life.

[[ParaHoxozoa]]

CATEGORIES: Taxonomy

ParaHoxozoa is a proposed group within taxonomy.  It would be a clade, above phylum but below a kingdom.  

It would include the Bilateria, the Placozoa and the Cnidarians.

[[Enskede gård]]

CATEGORIES: Districts, Stockholm

Enskede gård is a district in Söderort, Stockholm. It shares borders with Johanneshov, Gamla Enskede, Enskedefältet and Årsta. Its name came from the former manor and estate, Enskede farm. The farm was mentioned as early as 1392.

[[Local Bubble]]

CATEGORIES: Milky Way

The Local Bubble, or Local Cavity, is where we are in our galaxy. It is a relative cavity in the interstellar medium (ISM) of  the Orion Arm in the Milky Way. It contains among others, the Local Interstellar Cloud, which contains the Solar System, and the G-Cloud. It is at least 300 light years across. It has a neutral-hydrogen density of about 0.05 atoms/cm3, or about one tenth of the average for the ISM in the Milky Way (0.5 atoms/cm3)

The exceptionally sparse gas of the Local Bubble is the result of supernovae that exploded within the past ten to twenty million years.  The gas is still in an excited state, emitting in the X-ray band.

[[Bælum]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Europe, Denmark

Bælum is a village in Denmark. It is 31 km from Aalborg. According to January 2020 census, there are 733 people living there. It is a part of Rebild Municipality.

It is 5 km northeast of Terndrup and 16 km north of Hadsund. There is a Bælum Church and Bælum Mill. There is a wind turbine and the motor house. They have been fully restored and are maintained by Bælum Møllelaug.

[[DNA barcoding]]

CATEGORIES: DNA, Evolutionary biology

DNA barcoding is a form of genetic analysis.  It is part of molecular biology.  Scientists use DNA barcoding to tell different species apart from each other.  Scientists use DNA barcoding to tell which species are related to each other or evolved from the same older species.

[[Actinidia]]

CATEGORIES: Actinidiaceae

Actinidia is a genus of woody vines in the family Actinidiaceae. It is commercially important as many plants in this genus produce kiwifruits, which are eaten in many parts of the world. The most well-known species is Actinidia deliciosa, the common kiwifruit.

[[Alquézar]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Spain, Municipalities in Aragon, Settlements in Huesca

Alquézar (Aragonese: Alquezra) is a town in the province of Huesca. It is located in the autonomous community of Aragon, Spain. As of 2012, its population was 301. 

[[Lehigh University]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Pennsylvania, 1865 establishments in the United States, Colleges and universities in Pennsylvania

Lehigh University is an American private research university in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. It was founded in 1865 by businessman Asa Packer.

In 2020, U.S. News & World Report ranked Lehigh as the 50th best university in the nation.

[[The New School]]

CATEGORIES: 1910s establishments in New York (state), 1919 establishments in the United States, Colleges and universities in New York City

The New School is an American private research university in New York City. It was founded in 1919 with an original mission as a home for progressive thinkers.

It is home to the Parsons School of Design, which is internationally recognized as one of the best schools for visual arts such as fashion, architecture, illustration, and photography. In 2020, QS World University Rankings listed Parsons as the 3rd best Art & Design program in the world.

[[A10 road (England)]]

CATEGORIES: Roads in England

The A10 is an important road in eastern England. It goes between London and King's Lynn. It follows the old route of the Roman road Ermine Street for much of its route. The road is about 90 long in total.

[[Actinidiaceae]]

CATEGORIES: Actinidiaceae

The Actinidiaceae are a family of around 360 species of plants in the Ericales order. The most important genus is Actinidia, the kiwifruits.

[[Jorge Rodriguez-Chomat]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, American judges, American lawyers, State legislators of the United States, Cuban politicians, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Politicians from Miami, Florida, People from Havana, US Republican Party politicians

Jorge Rodriguez-Chomat (June 28, 1945 – August 19, 2017) was a Cuban-American politician and judge. He was a one-term member of the Florida House of Representatives for the Republican Party from 1994 until his defeat in 1998. 

He was a Judge of the Criminal and Family Divisions of the Eleventh Judicial Circuit Court of Florida from 2011 until his retirement in 2017.

Rodriguez-Chomat died on August 19, 2017 from prostate cancer in Miami, Florida at age 72.

[[Senate of the Czech Republic]]

CATEGORIES: Czech Republic

The Senate of the Parliament of the Czech Republic (Senát Parlamentu České republiky), usually referred to as Senate, is the upper chamber of the Parliament of the Czech Republic. The seat of the Senate is Wallenstein Palace in Prague.

The Senate has 81 members, chosen in one-seat constituencies through the two-round system. If no candidate receives a majority of votes in the first round, there is a second round between the two highest-placed candidates. The term of office for Senators is six years.

The office was created in December 1992.

[[Parliament of the Czech Republic]]

CATEGORIES: Czech Republic

The Parliament of the Czech Republic (Parlament České republiky) or just Parliament (Parlament) is the legislative body of the Czech Republic.

It is made up of two chambers, both elected in direct elections:

[[Erich Gruenberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Austrian violinists, British violinists, British educators, Musicians from Vienna

Erich Gruenberg GBR (12 October 1924 – 7 August 2020) was an Austrian-born British violinist and teacher. He was a principal violinist of major orchestras in Stockholm and London. He taught at the Royal Academy of Music. He was born in Vienna.

Gruenberg died on 7 August 2020 at the Hampstead Garden Suburb in London at age 95.

[[P. J. Sheehan]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Irish politicians

Patrick Joseph Sheehan (1 March 1933 – 10 August 2020) was an Irish Fine Gael politician. He was a Teachta Dála (TD) for the Cork South-West constituency from 1981 to 2002 and 2007 to 2011. He was a member of the Fine Gael.

He retired from politics at the 2011 general election.

He died on 10 August 2020, aged 87.

[[Melinda Dillon]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Actors from Arkansas, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Living people, People from Hope, Arkansas

Melinda Ruth Dillon (born October 13, 1939) is an American actress. 

She received a 1963 Tony Award nomination for her Broadway debut in the original production of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?. She was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her roles as Jillian Guiler in Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977) and Teresa in Absence of Malice (1981).

Her other movie roles include Bound for Glory (1976), F.I.S.T. (1978), A Christmas Story (1983), Harry and the Hendersons (1987), The Prince of Tides (1991) and Magnolia (1999).

[[Hamilton (2020 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 movies, American musical movies, Disney+ movies

Hamilton is a 2020 American musical movie which is a live recording of  the 2015 Broadway musical. It was directed and produced by Thomas Kail and produced, written, and composed by Lin-Manuel Miranda.

Miranda also stars as first Treasury Secretary and Founding Father Alexander Hamilton, along with the musical's original principal Broadway cast.

Hamilton was originally planned for theatrical release on October 15, 2021; however, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the movie had a digital worldwide release on Disney+ on July 3, 2020. The movie received strong critical reviews.
