Okieriete "Oak" Onaodowan (oʊ oh; born August 16, 1987) is an American actor. He is known for his roles as Hercules Mulligan and James Madison in the 2015 musical Hamilton, and the role of Dean Miller in the ABC drama and Grey's Anatomy spin-off series Station 19. He was born in Newark, New Jersey.

[[Barrow-upon-Soar]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Leicestershire

Barrow-upon-Soar, also known as Barrow-on-Soar or simply Barrow, is a large village in the north of Leicestershire in England. It is in the Borough of Charnwood. It is between Loughborough and the city of Leicester. In 2011, the village had a population of 5,856 people.

[[Dariusz Baliszewski]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Polish historians, Polish journalists, Polish screenwriters, Writers from Warsaw

Dariusz Baliszewski (14 April 1946 – 10 August 2020) was a Polish historian, journalist and writer. He wrote the screenplay for Rewizja nadzwyczajna. He wrote many historical articles to one of the biggest Polish magazines, Wprost. 

In 1999, for his television creativity and professionalism in work, President Aleksander Kwaśniewski awarded him the Silver Cross of Merit.

Baliszewski was born in Warsaw. He died on 10 August 2020 in Warsaw, aged 74.

[[Kartika Liotard]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, 2020 deaths, Anti-pornography activists, Dutch activists, Dutch civil servants, Dutch jurists, Dutch women politicians, Feminists, Former MEPs, Independent politicians in the Netherlands, MEPs for the Netherlands, Politicians from South Holland, Socialist Party (Netherlands) politicians

Kartika Tamara Liotard (26 June 1971 – 1 August 2020) was a Dutch politician, anti-pornography feminist, and civil servant. She was a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from 2004 to 2014. She was formerly a member of the Socialist Party. Liotard was vice-chair of the EUL–NGL group. She was born in Voorburg, South Holland, and studied law at Maastricht University.

Liotard died on 1 August 2020, aged 49.

[[Alpine, Alaska]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in the United States, Settlements in Alaska

Alpine is an unincorporated community in northern Alaska. It is located in the North Slope Borough, along the Arctic Ocean. This city in Alaska had a population of 4 but was so remote that when they (the people of Alpine) got sick they could not get medicine in time. 

[[Isabelle Weingarten]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors, French photographers, French models, Actors from Paris

Isabelle Weingarten (18 April 1950 – 3 August 2020) was a French actress, model, and photographer. She was born in Paris. Her first movie role was in Four Nights of a Dreamer. 

She also starred in The Mother and the Whore in 1973. She began working for Cahiers du Cinéma in 1986. In 2008, she began studying the works of her father, Romain Weingarten, poet and playwright.

Wiengarten was married to Benjamin Baltimore from 1968 to 1978. She then married Wim Wenders, who she divorced in 1983. Lastly, she was married to Olivier Assayas until their divorce in 1996. 

Weingarten died on 3 August 2020 at the age of 70.

[[Olivier Assayas]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, French screenwriters, French movie critics, Movie directors from Paris, Writers from Paris

Olivier Assayas (born 25 January 1955) is a French movie director, screenwriter, and movie critic.

He made his debut in 1986, after directing some short movies and writing for the influential movie magazine Cahiers du cinéma.

Assayas's movie Cold Water was screened in the Un Certain Regard section at the 1994 Cannes Film Festival.

[[Maggie Cheung]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Models, Actors from Hong Kong

Maggie Cheung Man-yuk (張曼玉; born 20 September 1964) is a Hong Kong actress. 

She is known for her roles in As Tears Go By, Center Stage, Comrades: Almost a Love Story, Green Snake, The Soong Sisters, In the Mood for Love, and Clean.

In 1983, Cheung entered the Miss Hong Kong pageant and won the first runner-up and the Miss Photogenic award as well. She was a semi-finalist in the Miss World pageant the same year.

[[Mia Hansen-Løve]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, French screenwriters, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors, French voice actors, Actors from Paris, Writers from Paris, Movie directors from Paris

Mia Hansen-Løve (born 5 February 1981) is a French movie director, screenwriter, and former actress. 

Her first feature movie, All Is Forgiven, won the Louis Delluc Prize for Best First Film in 2007 along with Céline Sciamma's Water Lilies. 

Hansen-Løve's movie Father of My Children won the Special Jury Prize in the Un Certain Regard section at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival. 

In 2014, Hansen-Løve was awarded the status of Chevalier in the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. 

In 2016, she won the Silver Bear for Best Director for her movie Things to Come at the 66th Berlin International Film Festival, as well as becoming a member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

[[Sixto Brillantes]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines, Filipino lawyers, Filipino politicians, People from Manila

Sixto Serrano Brillantes, Jr. (August 14, 1939 – August 11, 2020) was a Filipino election lawyer. He was the chairman of the Commission on Elections from 2011 to 2015. He was appointed by President Benigno Aquino III on January 16, 2011. He was born in Manila.

On July 25, 2020 he was diagnosed with COVID-19 and was hospitalized in Manila. He died from the infection on August 11, 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Vladica Popović]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Serbian footballers, Serbian football managers

Vladimir "Vladica" Popović (Bладимиp "Bлaдицa" Пoпoвић; 17 March 1935 – 10 August 2020) was a Serbian footballer and manager. He won the Intercontinental Cup with Red Star Belgrade in 1991. He played for the Yugoslavia national football team from 1956 to 1965. 

Popović died in Belgrade on 10 August 2020, aged 85.

[[Dakelh]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in Canada, British Columbia

The Dakelh or Carrier are an Indigenous group who live in British Columbia.

[[Mike Tindall (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: English footballers, 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Sportspeople from Birmingham

Michael Tindall (5 April 1941 – 11 August 2020) was an English former professional footballer. He was best known for his career with Aston Villa. His playing position was wing-half.

Tindall started his career at South Birmingham Boys. He moved to Walsall for a short time before dropping into the non-League to play for Tamworth.

Tindall played for the England youth team but never represented the senior side.

Tindall died on 11 August 2020 from dementia-related problems, aged 79. 

[[Jose Melo]]

CATEGORIES: Filipino politicians, Filipino judges, 1932 births, 2020 deaths, People from Manila

Jose Armando R. Melo (May 30, 1932 – October 18, 2020) was a Filipino lawyer and jurist. He was an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines from 1992 to 2002. He is a former Chairman of the Commission on Elections (COMELEC).

[[Benjamin Abalos]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, Filipino politicians

Benjamin Santos Abalos, Sr. (born September 21, 1935) is a Filipino politician. He was a chairman of the Commission on Elections. He was also a former chairman of the  MMDA and mayor of Mandaluyong City. 

On June 5, 2002 President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo appointed Abalos to replace Alfredo Benipayo.

On October 1, 2007, Abalos resigned during a press conference after complaining for lack of rules to create an impeachment case against Filipino governors. The Commission on Elections appointed Resurreccion Borra as Acting Chairman.

[[Christian Monsod]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, Filipino politicians, Filipino lawyers, Political activists

Christian S. Monsod (born July 16, 1936) is a Filipino lawyer. He was Chairman of the Commission on Elections (COMELEC). He was one of the creators of the 1987 Constitution of the Philippines. 

He is the founder and honorary chairman of the Legal Network for Truthful Elections (LENTE) and key activist of the National Citizens' Movement for Free Elections (NAMFREL).

[[Canadian Aboriginal syllabics]]

CATEGORIES: Writing systems, Canada

Canadian syllabic writing, or simply syllabics, is an abugida and brahmic script created by a Christian missionary to write down the languages of some of the First Nations of Canada. This one alphabet later became many alphabets.

Each letter represents a syllable. The letters look like triangles and curves. Different languages have some different letters to represent the sounds in their own language best.

By the late 19th century the Cree had achieved what may have been one of the highest literacy rates in the world.

[[Bernardo P. Pardo]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Filipino judges, Filipino politicians, People from Manila

Bernardo P. Pardo (born February 11, 1932) is a Filipino politician and lawyer. Between 1995 to 1998, he was Chairman of the Commission on Elections. In 1998, President Joseph Estrada nominated him to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines. He retired in 2002.

Pardo was born in Manila. He studied at the University of Texas. 

[[Wymeswold]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Leicestershire, Civil parishes in Leicestershire

Wymeswold is a village and civil parish in the north of Leicestershire, a county in England. The 2011 census saw that around 1,296 people live there.

It is located north-east of Loughborough, a university town, and is very close to the border with Nottinghamshire. Nearby villages include Barrow-upon-Soar, Prestwold, Burton on the Wolds and Rempstone.

The village was formerly the location of RAF Wymeswold which has since closed. There is a memorial plaque on the wall of Wymeswold Pharmacy that pays tribute to when a Wellington Bomber crashed into a nearby hill while on a night training course.

The village has a greengrocer, a general convenience store, a pine furniture store, a gift shop, a restaurant and two public houses (The Three Crowns and The Windmill). There is also a village cricket club which also includes a football pitch.

[[Regino C. Hermosisima Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: Filipino politicians, Filipino judges, Living people, 1927 births

Regino Campos Hermosisima Jr. (born October 18, 1927) is a Filipino politician and lawyer. He was born in Cebu. He became a member of the Supreme Court as an Associate Justice on July 10, 1995. He retired on October 18, 1997. He was nominated by President Fidel Ramos.

[[Jose Vitug]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Filipino politicians, Filipino judges, Living people

Jose C. Vitug (born 15 July 1934) is a Filipino lawyer and jurist. He was an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines. He was appointed to the Court on June 28, 1993 by President Fidel Ramos and retired on July 15, 2004. Vitug was the Founding Dean of the Angeles University Foundation College of Law in Manila.

[[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of the Philippines

An Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines is one of 15 members of the Philippine Supreme Court, the highest court in the Philippines. 

The Chief Justice is in charge over the High Court, but carries only one of the 15 votes in the court. 

Until 1973, only men were appointed as Associate Justices to the Court. Cecilia Muñoz-Palma, an appointee of President Ferdinand Marcos, was the first woman to sit on the Court. 

Since then, 15 other women have been appointed as Associate Justices of the Supreme Court. 

[[Port of Beirut]]

CATEGORIES: Ports and harbours, Beirut

The Port of Beirut (مرفأ بيروت) is the main port in Lebanon on the eastern part of the Saint George Bay on Beirut's northern Mediterranean coast. It is west of the Beirut River. It is one of the largest and busiest ports on the Eastern Mediterranean. 

On 4 August 2020, two large explosions happened at the port, killing at least 220 people, and injuring more than 5,000 others. 

[[Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, Political activists, Belarusian politicians

Sviatlana Hyeorhiyeuna Tsikhanouskaya (Святла́на Гео́ргіеўна Ціхано́ўская, née Pilipchuk, Піліпчук, also trans. Svetlana Georgiyevna Tikhanovskaya, Светла́на Гео́ргиевна Тихано́вская; born 11 September 1982) is a Belarusian activist and politician. She was a presidential candidate in the 2020 Belarusian presidential election. She was born in Mikashevichy.

[[2020 Belarusian protests]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in Europe, August 2020 events, History of Belarus, July 2020 events, June 2020 events, May 2020 events, Politics of Belarus, September 2020 events

The 2020 Belarusian protests, nicknamed the Slipper Revolution, and the Anti-Cockroach Revolution are a series of street protests against Belarus's president Alexander Lukashenko. They began on 24 March 2020.

The protests are part of the Belarusian democracy movement. They are upset over the 2020 Belarusian presidential election, in which Lukashenko was controversially re-elected. Many believed the election was rigged and unfair.

Support from Russian President Vladimir Putin helped Alexander Lukashenko hold on, and the security forces started attacking people from the opposite side.

There were more than 600 political prisoners as of August 2021. These numbers came from the Viasna Human Rights Centre. Tens of thousands of people have been arrested and thousands have left the country.

[[The Naked and the Dead]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 books

The Naked and the Dead is a novel written by an American author named Norman Mailer. It was published in 1948. The novel was based on Mailer's experience as a cook while he was stationed in the Philippines. It is about the experiences about one platoon during World War II as they fight in the South Pacific.

It became very popular. It was turned into a film in 1958.

[[Oliviu Gherman]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Romanian politicians, Physicists, Romanian educators, Ambassadors to France

Oliviu Gherman (26 April 1930 – 11 August 2020) was a Romanian physicist, politician, university professor and diplomat. He was a member of the Romanian Senate between 1990 through 2004. He was the Senate President between 1992 to 1996. Between 2001 to 2004, he was the Romanian Ambassador to France.

Gherman died on 11 August 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Elaine Devry]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California, People from Compton, California

Elaine Devry (born Thelma Elaine Mahnken; January 10, 1930) is an American actress.

Her first movie was The Atomic Kid, in which she and her husband Mickey Rooney co-starred. Devry made three guest appearances on Perry Mason, including the title role of defendant Janice Wainwright in the 1962 episode "The Case of the Shapely Shadow." 

She also appeared in many other popular television series, including Death Valley Days, Bonanza, 77 Sunset Strip, Burke's Law, Family Affair, I Dream of Jeannie, Marcus Welby, M.D., Dragnet, and Tales of Wells Fargo. 

[[Martha Vickers]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 1971 deaths, Deaths from esophageal cancer, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, Actors from Michigan, People from Ann Arbor, Michigan, Models from Michigan

Martha Vickers (May 28, 1925 – November 2, 1971) was an American model and actress.

She played minor roles in many movies during the early 1940s. She played the drug-addicted younger sister of Lauren Bacall's character in The Big Sleep (1946). She also starred in a musical, The Time, the Place and the Girl (also 1946). She also starred in Love and Learn and That Way with Women (both 1947).

Vickers died of esophageal cancer at a hospital in Los Angeles on November 2, 1971 at the age of 46. 

[[Lorenzo Lamas]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Santa Monica, California

Lorenzo Fernando Lamas (born January 20, 1958) is an American actor. He is best known for his role of Lance Cumson in the soap opera Falcon Crest (1981–1990).

Lamas is also known for his roles as Reno Raines in the crime drama series Renegade (1992–1997), and Hector Ramirez in the soap opera The Bold and the Beautiful (2004–2006).

[[Fernando Lamas]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 1982 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Argentine movie actors, Argentine television actors, Argentine stage actors, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, People from Buenos Aires, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Argentine movie directors, Movie directors from Los Angeles, California, American television directors

Fernando Álvaro Lamas y de Santos (January 9, 1916spaced ndashOctober 8, 1982) was an Argentine-American actor and director. He was known for playing the "Latin Lover" in many movies during the 1940s and 1950s.

In 1951, Lamas starred as Paul Sarnac in the musical, Rich, Young and Pretty with Jane Powell. He also starred in The Law and the Lady (1952) which was very unpopular.

He also starred alongside Elizabeth Taylor in The Girl Who Had Everything (1952).

He is the father of actor Lorenzo Lamas. He was married to Arlene Dahl between 1954 to 1960. He was also married to Esther Williams between 1969 until his death.

[[Female Go players]]

This is an article about the history of Female Go players.

[[Rahat Indori]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian composers, Indian poets, Indian educators, Indian artists, Urdu poets

Rahat Indori (1 January 1950 – 11 August 2020) was an Indian Bollywood lyricist and Urdu poet. He was also a former professor of Urdu language and a painter. He was a language professor at Devi Ahilya University, Indore. As a movie score composer, his best known works were Khuddar, Mission Kashmir and Meenaxi: A Tale of Three Cities. Indori was born in Indore, Madhya Pradesh.

Indori died on 11 August 2020 at a hospital in Indore from COVID-19, aged 70. He was tested positive for the infection the night before.

[[Mohammad Javad Zarif]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Iranian politicians

Mohammad Javad Zarif (Mohammad-Javād Zarīf; mohæmːædd͡ʒæˌvɒːde zæˌɾiːf; born c. 7 January 1960) is an Iranian politician. He has been foreign minister of Iran since 2013. He helped end the economic sanctions against Iran from many countries on 16 January 2016. 

On 25 February 2019, Zarif resigned from his post as foreign minister. His resignation was rejected by President Hassan Rouhani.

[[A16 autoroute]]

CATEGORIES: Autoroutes in France

The A16, also called L'Européenne (The European) in French, is an autoroute (motorway) in France. It goes between Paris and the border with Belgium near Ghyvelde. It goes through Amiens, Calais and Dunkirk. It is part of the European route E40. The autoroute is about 319 long in total.

[[Isabelle Fuhrman]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Washington, D.C., American child actors

Isabelle Fuhrman (born February 25, 1997) is an American actress. She is best known for her roles as Esther in the 2009 horror movie Orphan and Clove in the 2012 dystopian adventure movie The Hunger Games.

[[Shakuntala Devi]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2013 deaths, Indian writers, Child prodigies, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Shakuntala Devi (4 November 1929 – 21 April 2013) was an Indian writer and mental calculator. She was popularly known as the "Human Computer". Devi wanted to make mathematics easier for students. 

Her talent earned her a place in the 1982 edition of The Guinness Book of World Records. However, the certificate for the record was given posthumously on 30 July 2020, despite Devi achieving her world record on 18 June 1980. In 2019, a movie was made in memory of her. The name of the movie was Shakuntala Devi.

[[Vidya Balan]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, Indian movie actors, Indian television actors, Indian stage actors

Vidya Balan (pronounced ʋɪd̪jaː baːlən; born 1 January 1979) is an Indian actress. 

She was awarded the Padma Shri by the Government of India in 2014.

Vidya is known for her roles in Paa (2009), the black comedy Ishqiya (2010), the thrillers No One Killed Jessica and Kahaani (2012), and the biopic The Dirty Picture (2011).

[[Cheraw, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in South Carolina

Cheraw (tʃ chə, local shə) is a town on the Pee Dee River in Chesterfield County South Carolina, United States. The population was 5,851 at the 2010 census. It has been nicknamed "The Prettiest Town in Dixie". 

[[Jodrell Bank Observatory]]

CATEGORIES: Establishments in the United Kingdom, Observatories, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom, Radio receivers

The Jodrell Bank Observatory a radio telescope in Cheshire. It picks up radio waves from outer space. Jodrell Bank is mainly used for investigating radio waves from the planets and stars.

It was the idea of its first director, Bernard Lovell, to use radio signals to investigate cosmic rays. Lovell, Professor of Astronomy at Manchester University, had worked on radar in World War II. The observatory was set up in 1945.  

It has been used to research meteoroids, quasars, pulsars, masers and gravitational lenses. It was heavily involved in tracking space probes.

The main telescope at the observatory is the Lovell Telescope. It has diameter of 250, and is the third largest steerable radio telescope in the world. There are three other active telescopes at the observatory. 

The Jodrell Bank Observatory is the base of the Multi-Element Radio Linked Interferometer Network (MERLIN), a "National Facility" run by the University of Manchester. What this means is that radio telescopes can work together to form a long baseline to better collect data from an important phenomenon. There are three other active telescopes at the observatory; the Mark II, and 42 and 7 m diameter radio telescopes. 

The telescope discovered radio noise from the Great Nebula in Andromeda—the first definite detection of an extragalactic radio source—and the remains of Tycho's Supernova in the radio frequency. At that time, Tycho's Supervova had not been discovered by regular light telescopes.

[[New Town, Edinburgh]]

CATEGORIES: Edinburgh, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

The New Town is in the central area in Edinburgh, Scotland. Together with the Old Town, it became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1995.  

It was built in stages between 1767 and around 1850. It kept much of its original neoclassical and Georgian period architecture. It is most famous for Princes Street. It faces the Edinburgh Castle and the Old Town. 

[[Tycho's Supernova]]

CATEGORIES: Supernovae, Astronomical objects, 1572

Tycho's Supernova  also called SN 1572 or B Cassiopeiae (B Cas) – was a supernova of Type Ia in the constellation Cassiopeia. It is one of eight supernovae visible to the naked eye in historical records. It appeared in early November 1572 and was independently discovered by many people. It is called Tycho's because Tycho Brahe published a book the next year about what he and other astronomers saw.

The remains of the supernova was first detected by radio telescopes. It was often known as 3C 10, which is a radio-source designation, but now people call it Tycho's supernova remnant. It can be seen by light telescope.

[[Liverpool Maritime Mercantile City]]

CATEGORIES: Liverpool, Merseyside, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

Liverpool Maritime Mercantile City is a former UNESCO World Heritage Site in Liverpool, England. The six sites included the Pier Head, Albert Dock,  William Brown Street,  and other famous landmarks in the city. They are considered the 'supreme example of a commercial port at a time of Britain's greatest global influence'.

The sites were nominated to UNESCO in January 2003. By March 2004, ICOMOS recommended the Liverpool Maritime Mercantile City as a World Heritage Site. It was accepted under cultural bases: ii, iii and iv. 

In 2012, the proposed construction of Liverpool Waters project caused the sites to be included in the List of World Heritage in Danger. In July 2017, UNESCO warned it might lose its status because of the development plans. 

English Heritage argued against the Liverpool Waters development. It thought some of Liverpool's most significant historic buildings would be “severely compromised”.

In July 2021, UNESCO announced that the site had been stripped of its World Heritage status.

[[Theaceae]]

CATEGORIES: Ericales

The Theaceae is a family of plants in the order Ericales. They contain the genus Camellia, used to make tea. They have around 7 to 40 genera.

[[Supinfo]]

CATEGORIES: Technical colleges and universities in Paris, 1965 establishments in Europe, 1960s establishments in France

Supinfo is a renowned graduate engineering school in France. It is in a campus of IONIS Education Group. It has been created in 1965. The school is recognized by the French State since 1972.

It offers a 5-year course in IT.

[[Sabang tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The Sabang tree frog (Nyctimystes sanguinolenta)  is a tree frog from New Guinea.  Scientists have seen it in the Baliem Valley and other places not high above sea level in Indonesia.

[[Old Town, Edinburgh]]

CATEGORIES: World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom, Edinburgh

The Old Town (Auld Toun) is oldest part of Edinburgh. It preserved much of its medieval street plan and buildings. Together with New Town, it forms a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

[[Lantz, Navarre]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Navarre

Lantz is a village in Navarre, Spain. It still maintains its old tradition of rural carnival.

[[Balsaminaceae]]

CATEGORIES: Ericales

The Balsaminaceae is a family of two genera and around 850 to 1,000 species, mostly in the genus Impatiens. The two genera in this family are Impatiens and Hydrocera.

[[Vyacheslav Volodin]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Russian politicians, Living people

Vyacheslav Viktorovich Volodin (Вячесла́в Ви́кторович Воло́дин; born 4 February 1964) is a Russian politician. He is the 10th Chairman of the State Duma since 5 October 2016.

[[NGC 4754]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 4754 is a barred lenticular galaxy in the Virgo constellation. It was discovered on on March 15, 1784 by astronomer William Herschel.

[[Hiroe Nakai]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Japanese sportspeople, Sportswomen, Living people

Hiroe Nakai (born June 24, 1969 in Hokkaido) is a Japanese Professional shogi player ranked 6-dan since 2002. She was one of the rivals of Ichiyo Shimizu.

[[St Martin's Church, Canterbury]]

CATEGORIES: Canterbury, Churches in the United Kingdom, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

The Church of St Martin is an old Church of England church in Canterbury, England. It is best known as having the longest continuous history as a parish church in the English-speaking world. It is often known as "The first church founded in England". Although there were already Roman and Celtic churches had existed for centuries. Together with the Canterbury Cathedral and St Augustine's Abbey, they are part of a World Heritage Site.

Since 1668 the church has been part of the benefice of St Martin and St Paul Canterbury. Both St Martin's and nearby St Paul's churches are used for weekly services. The current rector of the parish is the Reverend Mark Richard Griffin.

[[Euronews]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 establishments in Europe, Television channels, Censorship in Belarus

Three EBU members also used to own a share in the channel, but do not anymore today. These are:

On 4 June 2008, Euronews got a new circle logo and a new slogan: "pure". This was meant to market itself as "pure news" distancing from other competing channels (BBC, CNN, etc.) in the 24-hour news market.

In February 2015, Media Globe Networks got a 53% share of Euronews SA in a deal with the company. In January 2016, the channel started a sister network called Africanews, which is aimed at an African news market, with a pan-African view. Euronews got a new logo on 17 May 2016.

[[Fips Asmussen]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, German comedians, People from Hamburg

Fips Asmussen (born Rainer Pries; 30 April 1938 – 9 August 2020) was a German comedian and entertainer. He was known for his quick delivery of puns and bad jokes. Asmussen was born in Hamburg. His later comedy performances became known for unfunny and mostly politically incorrect. 

Asmussen died on 9 August 2020 in Querfurt, Saxony-Anhalt at the age of 82.

[[Rose of Washington Square]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 movies, 1930s musical movies, 1930s drama movies, American musical movies, American drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Gregory Ratoff

Rose of Washington Square is a 1939 American musical drama movie directed by Gregory Ratoff and stars Tyrone Power, Alice Faye, Al Jolson, Moroni Olsen, Winifred Harris, Joyce Compton, William Frawley, Ralph Dunn, Louis Prima. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Vinka Lucas]]

CATEGORIES: 1930s births, 2020 deaths, New Zealand businesspeople, Fashion designers, Croatian people, Deaths from stroke

Vinka Dragica Lucas NZL (née Ravlich/Ravlić; 1931/1932 – 10 August 2020) was a Croatian-born New Zealand fashion and bridalwear designer and business owner. She was co-founder of New Zealand Bride magazine. In 1959 Lucas and her husband David Lucas bought a fashion and dressmaking business in Hamilton. In 1963, the couple published a booklet of bridal designs, which later grew into the magazine New Zealand Bride.

In 2009, Lucas suffered a stroke.

In the 2019 New Year Honours, Lucas was appointed a Member of the New Zealand Order of Merit.

She died in Auckland on 10 August 2020, aged 88.

[[Trini Lopez]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American guitarists, American movie actors, American television actors, American pop singers, American pop musicians, Musicians from Dallas, Texas, Singers from Dallas, Texas, Actors from Dallas, Texas

Trinidad "Trini" López III (May 13, 1937spndAugust 11, 2020) was an American singer, guitarist, and actor.

His first album included a version of "If I Had a Hammer", which earned a Golden Disc for him. His other hits included "Lemon Tree", "I'm Comin' Home, Cindy" and "Sally Was a Good Old Girl". 

He designed two guitars for the Gibson Guitar Corporation.

He starred as Pedro Jimenez in the 1967 war movie The Dirty Dozen.

Lopez never married and had no children.

Lopez died on August 11, 2020 at a hospital in Palm Springs, California from COVID-19, aged 83.

[[Juan Pastor Marco]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish politicians

Juan Pastor Marco (24 November 1951 – 11 August 2020) was a Spanish politician. He was a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE). In 1977, he was elected to the Spanish Congress of Deputies representing Valencia Province.

He then was Secretary General of the PSOE in the Valencian Community from 1978 to 1979. He retired in 1982. He was born in Orba, Alicante.

Pastor Marco died on 11 August 2020, aged 68.

[[The Dirty Dozen]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 movies, 1960s war movies, American war movies, Movies directed by Robert Aldrich

The Dirty Dozen is a 1967 war movie starring Lee Marvin and featuring an ensemble supporting cast including Ernest Borgnine, Charles Bronson, Jim Brown, John Cassavetes, George Kennedy, Robert Ryan, Telly Savalas, Robert Webber and Donald Sutherland with Trini Lopez. It was directed by Robert Aldrich. 

The screenplay is based on the 1965 bestseller by E. M. Nathanson.

[[Robert Ryan]]

CATEGORIES: 1909 births, 1973 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American radio actors, American political activists, Actors from Chicago

Robert Bushnell Ryan (November 11, 1909spaced ndashJuly 11, 1973) was an American actor and activist. He was known for playing tough cops and ruthless villains. He worked in theater and movies. Ryan was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his rolein Crossfire (1947)''.

Ryan died of lung cancer in New York City on July 11, 1973 at the age of 63.

[[Robert Webber]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 1989 deaths, Deaths from motor neurone disease, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Santa Ana, California

Robert Laman Webber (October 14, 1924 – May 19, 1989) was an American actor. He was known for his role as Juror No. 12 in the classic 1957 movie  12 Angry Men. He also starred as General Denton in the 1967 war movie The Dirty Dozen.

Webber died from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis at the age of 64 in Malibu, California on May 19, 1989.

[[List of A2 roads]]

CATEGORIES: Roads, Transport lists

This is a list of roads with the name A2. Roads entries are sorted alphabetically by country.

[[A2 road (England)]]

CATEGORIES: Roads in England

The A2 is an important road in South East England. It goes between London and Dover. In Dover, it connects to the port to France. The road follows tracks used by the Celts and the Romans over a thousand years ago. It once linked to the three main Roman ports: Rutupiae (now Richborough), Dubris (now Dover) and Portus Lemanis (in modern Lympne). It was given the name "A2" in the 1920s. Now, the road is about 72 long.

[[The Hunters (1996 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 thriller movies, Swedish movies, Movies directed by Kjell Sundvall

The Hunters (Jägarna) is a 1996 Swedish thriller movie directed by Kjell Sundvall and starring Rolf Lassgård, Lennart Jähkel, Jarmo Mäkinen, Tomas Norström, Göran Forsmark, and Rolf Degerlund. The sequel was followed in 2011.

[[HUMINT]]

CATEGORIES: Intelligence agencies, Government agencies, Human communication

HUMINT (an abbreviation of Human Intelligence) is intelligence information got from personal contacts. It is a term used in the spy community of the NATO countries.

[[About Us (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 drama movies, Costa Rican movies, American drama movies

About Us (Entonces Nosotros) is a 2016 Costa Rican American drama movie directed by Hernán Jiménez (who also stars) and starring Noelia Castaño, Marina Glezer.

[[Shyamala Gopalan]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2009 deaths, American activists

Shyamala Gopalan (December 7, 1938 – February 11, 2009) was an India-born Tamil American civil rights activist and cancer researcher. She is the mother of Kamala Harris. Gopalan conducted research in the Cancer Research Lab in UC Berkeley's Department of Zoology. Her research led to advancements in the knowledge of breast cancer hormones. Her work changed the progress on the research of the hormone-responsiveness of breast tissue. 

[[Elephant Island]]

CATEGORIES: Uninhabited islands, Geography of Antarctica

Elephant Island is an ice-covered, mountainous island off the coast of Antarctica. It is at the edge of the South Shetland Islands, in the Southern Ocean. It has an area of 558 km², and its highest elevation is 973 metres.

[[Nyctimystes traunae]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Nyctimystes traunae  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  It lives on mountains in the middle of the island.  Scientists saw it about 800 meters above sea level.

[[Katherine Swynford]]

CATEGORIES: 1350s births, 1400s deaths, English nobility

Katherine Swynford, Duchess of Lancaster (born Katherine de Roet, c. 1350 – 10 May 1403), was the third wife of John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster, a son of King Edward III of England. She was the daughter of Paon de Roet, a knight.

[[Sonic X-treme]]

CATEGORIES: Sonic the Hedgehog, Video games

Sonic X-treme was a platform game developed by Sega Technical Institute. It was being created from 1994 until Sega cancelled it in 1997. It was meant to be the first 3D Sonic the Hedgehog game. It was also meant to be the first new Sonic game for the Sega Saturn. It built on past Sonic games. However, it had new things to take Sonic into the 3D era of video games. The story followed Sonic on his journey to stop Dr. Robotnik; Robotnik was trying to steal six magic rings from Tiara Boobowski and her father.

[[Lorna Beal]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Australian cricketers, Sportspeople from Melbourne, Sportswomen

Lorna Beal (née Larter; 28 November 1923 – 10 August 2020) was an Australian cricketer. She played seven Test matches for the Australian women's cricket team between 1948 and 1951.

Beal was born in Hawthorn, Victoria. She died in 2020 at the age of 96.

[[Virtute et armis]]

CATEGORIES: Mississippi, Latin state mottos of the United States

Virtute et armis is a Latin phrase meaning "By valor and arms". It is the state motto of Mississippi. It may have come from the motto of Lord Gray De Wilton, "virtute non armis fido" ("I trust in virtue, not in arms"). 

[[Tetum language]]

CATEGORIES: Languages of Asia, East Timor, Indonesia, Austronesian languages

The Tetum language (Tetum or Tetun) is a language spoken in East Timor. It has a lot of influence from Portuguese.

[[Christopher Knights]]

CATEGORIES: American voice actors

Christopher Knights is an English voice actor, film editor, and cinematographer. He is best known for providing the voice of Private the Penguin in Madagascar. He also worked on several DreamWorks movies such as Shrek, Shrek 2, Shrek the Third and Shrek 4-D. 

He started his filming career at Amblimation studios. He worked on We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story and Balto. He started his editing and acting career at DreamWorks. He worked on the Shrek series as an associate editor. He was also voice of the Three Blind Mice and Thelonious, Lord Farquaad's Henchman.

CATEGORIES: Animators

Tom McGrath is a animator.

Don't Forget the Lyrics! is a sing-along game show that aired from 2007 to 2011.

[[Innu]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in Canada, Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador, Native American

The Innu (or Montagnais) are an Indigenous people group who live in Quebec and Newfoundland.

They lived as hunter-gatherers. Then the Canadian government moved them away from their homeland and forced them to practice Western lifestyles.

The Unit is an American television series that aired on CBS from March 7, 2006, to May 10, 2009.

The Tour of Gymnastics Superstars was a nationwide concert tour of gymnasts from the United States.

Thérèse Raquin is a book by the French author Émile Zola.

[[Stonehaven derailment]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in Europe, 2020s in the United Kingdom, 21st century in Scotland, August 2020 events, Disasters in the 21st century, Railway accidents in Europe, Aberdeenshire

The Stonehaven derailment was a railway accident. It happened at around 09:40 BST on 12 August 2020. It happened near Carmont. Carmont is west of Stonehaven. They are in Aberdeenshire, in Scotland. 

At least three people died. Six others were injured. It was the first train derailment in the United Kingdom to kill people since the Grayrigg derailment in February 2007.

It was the worst crash involving an InterCity 125 train since the Ufton Nervet collision. That was in 2004.

The accident was caused by a landslide. Mud slid onto the tracks.

[[Le Robert]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Martinique

Le Robert is a town and the third-largest commune in the French overseas department of Martinique. It is located in the northeastern (Atlantic) side of the island of Martinique.

[[Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, Caliphs, Iraqi politicians, Islamic State people

Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi (born October 1976, أبو إبراهيم الهاشمي القرشي; alternative transliterations al-Qurayshi and al-Quraishi) is the second and current leader of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant. 

In January 2020, media reported his true identity is Amir Mohammed Abdul Rahman al-Mawli al-Salbi (أمير محمد عبد الرحمن المولى الصلبي). His appointment by a shura council was announced by ISIL media on 31 October 2019, less than a week after the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. 

The U.S. Rewards for Justice Program offers up to $10 million reward to information that brings him to justice.

[[Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape]]

CATEGORIES: Mining, Cornwall, Devon, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

The Cornwall and West Devon Mining Landscape is a World Heritage site. It includes select mining landscapes in Cornwall and West Devon. The site was added to the on July 2006. Plans to restart mining at South Crofty, and to build a supermarket at Hayle Harbour, caused its status to be questioned.

The World Heritage Committee considered placing the site on the List of World Heritage in Danger in 2014. This proposal was rejected. Instead, they agreed on a follow-up "Reactive Monitoring Mission".

[[Gordon J. Brand]]

CATEGORIES: People from Cambridge, English sportspeople, Golfers, 1955 births, 2020 deaths

Gordon John Brand (6 August 1955 – 11 August 2020) was an English professional golfer.

Brand turned professional in 1976 and enjoyed full playing privileges on the European Tour for 20 years. 

During his time on tour, he finished inside the top 30 on the Order of Merit seven times and inside the top 100 16 times. 

His highest ranking came in 1986, fifth place, in which year he finished as runner-up to Greg Norman in the Open Championship at Turnberry. In 1981, he won the Tooting Bec Cup after posting a round of 65. 

Brand died on 11 August 2020 at the age of 65, following a short illness.

[[Walter Carrington]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Ambassadors of the United States, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Walter C. Carrington (July 24, 1930 – August 11, 2020) was an American diplomat. He was the United States Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to Senegal and Nigeria. He worked during the presidencies of Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton. He was ambassador to Senegal between 1980 to 1981 and to Nigeria between 1993 to 1997. He was born in New York City.

Carrington died on August 11, 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Blaublitz Akita]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s establishments in Japan, 1965 establishments in Asia, Japanese football clubs, Akita Prefecture

Blaublitz Akita  is a Japanese professional football club in Akita Prefecture.

[[Belle du Berry]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in France, French movie actors, French singers, French songwriters

Belle du Berry (1966 – 11 August 2020) was a French singer-songwriter, and actress. She was born in Bourges, France. In 1992, she worked with Philippe Decouflé to choreograph the ballets for the opening of the 1992 Winter Olympics. She was known for being a member of the Paris Combo.

In 2009, du Berry wrote a collection of new songs with David Lewis as the trumpeter and pianist. 

Du Berry died of cancer in Le Kremlin-Bicêtre on 11 August 2020.

[[François-Mathurin Gourvès]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, French Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops

François-Mathurin Gourvès (17 June 1929 – 12 August 2020) was a French Roman Catholic bishop. He was Bishop of Vannes from 1991 to 2005, and was Bishop Emeritus from 2005 to 2020. He was born in Plougastel-Daoulas, France.

Gourvès died on 12 August 2020 in Saint-Anne-d'Auray, France at the age of 91.

[[Geoffrey Nunberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from glioblastoma, American educators, Writers from California

Geoffrey Nunberg (June 1, 1945nbsp– August 11, 2020) was an American semantician and author. 

In 2001 he received the Linguistics, Language, and the Public Interest Award from the Linguistic Society of America for his works to National Public Radio's Fresh Air.

He published many popular press books including Going Nucular: Language, Politics and Culture in Controversial Times (2004). 

Nunberg began working as a postdoctoral scholar at the University of California Berkeley and visiting professor at Stanford University. In the mid-1980s he moved to the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center where he worked until 2001.

Nunberg died August 11, 2020 from glioblastoma at his home in San Francisco at the age of 75.

[[Francisco José Cox]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Archbishops, People from Santiago

Francisco José Cox Huneeus (18 December 1933 – 12 August 2020) was a Chilean archbishop of the Catholic Church. He was a member of Schoenstatt Movement. He was Bishop of Chillán from 1975 to 1981 and Coadjutor Archbishop of La Serena from 1985 to 1990 and Archbishop there from 1990 to 1997. He resigned following accusations that he had sexual abused young boys. He was born in Santiago de Chile.

Cox died on 12 August 2020 in Santiago de Chile, aged 86.

[[Mónica Miguel]]

CATEGORIES: Mexican movie directors, Television directors, Mexican voice actors, Mexican stage actors, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Cancer deaths in Mexico, 1936 births, 2020 deaths

Mónica Luiza Miguel (13 March 1936 – 12 August 2020) was a Mexican actress, telenovela director and singer. She was born in Tepic, Nayarit. She was known for her acting roles in I Dream in Another Language, Más allá del puente and Under Fire. She directed episodes of Teresa.

Miguel died on 12 August 2020 in Mexico City from cancer-related problems, aged 84.

[[Howard Mudd]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths in the United States, American football offensive guards, Chicago Bears players, San Francisco 49ers players, National Football League coaches, Sportspeople from Michigan, People from Midland, Michigan

Howard Edward Mudd (February 10, 1942 – August 12, 2020) was an American football offensive lineman and coach. He was born in Midland, Michigan. Mudd played football for Hillsdale College from 1960 to 1963. 

He then played seven seasons in the National Football League (NFL) for the San Francisco 49ers and Chicago Bears from 1964 to 1970. Mudd was a three-time Pro Bowler, in 1966, 1967, and 1968. He retired in 1971. He began his coaching career at the University of California the following year. 

From 1998 to 2009, he was the offensive line coach for the Indianapolis Colts.

Mudd was killed in a motorcycle crash in Seattle, Washington on August 12, 2020 at the age of 78.

[[Bill Yeoman]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Deaths from renal failure, American basketball players, Sportspeople from Indiana

William Frank Yeoman (December 26, 1927 – August 12, 2020) was an American college football player and coach. His career began in 1962. He was the University of Houston's head coach, holding the position through 1986. In his tenure, he became the most successfull coach in school history, with an overall record of 160–108–8. 

He was also helped racial integration of collegiate athletics in the South by being the first coach at a white school in the State of Texas to sign a black player.

Yeoman was born in Elnora, Indiana. He died on August 12, 2020 at the age of 92 from kidney failure and pneumonia in Houston, Texas.

[[Elnora, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Indiana

Elnora is a town in Elmore Township, Daviess County, Indiana, United States. The population was 640 at the 2010 census.

[[Elmore Township, Daviess County, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in the United States, Settlements in Indiana

Elmore Township is one of ten townships in Daviess County, Indiana, United States. As of the 2010 census, its population was 1,113.

[[Can't Help Falling in Love]]

CATEGORIES: Elvis Presley songs, 1961 songs

"Can't Help Falling in Love" is a 1961 song recorded by American singer Elvis Presley for the album Blue Hawaii (1961). It was written by Hugo Peretti, Luigi Creatore, and George David Weiss. It was published by Gladys Music, Inc.

The melody is based on "Plaisir d'amour". 

The song was initially written for a woman as "Can't Help Falling in Love with Him", which explains the first and third line ending on "in" and "sin" rather than words rhyming with "you".

"Can't Help Falling in Love" was used in Presley's 1961 movie Blue Hawaii.

[[Haley Reinhart]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, American pop singers, American rock singers, American jazz singers, American blues singers, American soul singers, American R&B singers, American funk singers, American voice actors, American movie actors, Actors from Chicago, Singer-songwriters from Chicago

Haley Elizabeth Reinhart (born September 9, 1990) is an American singer-songwriter and actress. 

She is known for placing third in the tenth season of American Idol. In July 2011, Reinhart signed a recording deal with Interscope Records. 

Her debut album Listen Up! was released on May 22, 2012. She became the first American Idol alumna to perform at Lollapalooza.

[[Bob Moore]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2021 deaths, Musicians from Nashville, Tennessee, American bandleaders, American guitarists, American country musicians

Bob Loyce Moore (November 30, 1932 – September 22, 2021) was an American session musician, orchestra leader, and bassist. He was a member of the Nashville A-Team during the 1950s and 1960s. 

He performed on over 17,000 documented recording sessions with many popular singers such as with Elvis Presley and Roy Orbison. He is also the father of multi-instrumentalist R. Stevie Moore.

He died on September 22, 2021, at the age of 88.

[[Ray Walker (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, American gospel singers, American gospel musicians, Musicians from Missouri, Singers from Missouri, People from Springfield, Missouri

Ray Walker (born March 16, 1934) is an American singer and musician. He is a member of the singing group The Jordanaires. Walker has been the bass singer for the group since 1958. During his tenure with The Jordanaires, the group was added into the Country Music Hall of Fame. 

[[The Jordanaires]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Missouri, 1948 establishments in the United States, 2013 disestablishments in the United States, Musical groups disestablished in 2013, Musical groups from Missouri, People from Springfield, Missouri, Elvis Presley

The Jordanaires were an American vocal quartet that formed as a gospel group in 1948. They are known for providing background vocals for Elvis Presley, in live appearances and recordings from 1956 to 1972. 

The group has also worked in the recording studio, on stage, and on television with many other country and rock and roll artists.

[[Spring Valley, New York]]

Spring Valley is a suburb of New York City. It is a village in the towns of Ramapo and Clarkstown in Rockland County, New York, United States.

[[Ramapo, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York, 1791 establishments in New York (state)

Ramapo is a town in Rockland County, New York, United States.  It was originally formed as New Hampstead, in 1791. It shares its name with the Ramapo River. As of the 2010 census, Ramapo had a total population of 126,595.

[[Tamannaah]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, Indian movie actors, Indian television actors, Indian models, Actors from Mumbai

Tamanna Bhatia (born 21 December 1989), known professionally as Tamannaah, is an Indian actress and model. She was born in Mumbai. She appears in Tamil and Telugu movies.

Her best known movies were Ayan (2009), Paiyaa (2010), Siruthai (2011), Veeram (2014), Dharma Durai (2016), Devi (2016) and Sketch (2018).

She also appeared in 100% Love (2011), Oosaravelli (2011), Racha (2012), Thadaka (2013), Baahubali: The Beginning (2015), Bengal Tiger (2015), Oopiri (2016), Baahubali 2: The Conclusion (2017), F2: Fun and Frustration (2019),  and  Sye Raa Narasimha Reddy (2019).

She received the "Dayawati Modi" Award in 2017.

[[Spanish naming customs]]

CATEGORIES: Spanish culture, Names

Spanish naming customs are traditions for naming children as used in Spain. 

A person's name consists of a given name (simple or composite) followed by two surnames. Historically, the first surname was the father's first surname, and the second the mother's first surname. 

In recent years, the order of the surnames in a family is done when registering the first child. However, the traditional order is still largely the choice. Often, the practice is to use one given name and the first surname most of the time (e.g. "Miguel de Unamuno" for Miguel de Unamuno y Jugo). The complete name being usually reserved for legal, formal, and documentary matters. 

Both surnames are sometimes used when the first surname is very common (e.g., Federico García Lorca, Pablo Ruiz Picasso or José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero) to get a more customized name. In these cases, it is even common to use only the second surname, as in "Lorca", "Picasso" or "Zapatero". This does not affect alphabetization: "Lorca", the Spanish poet, must be alphabetized in an index under "García Lorca" and not "Lorca".

[[Carlo Rolandi]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Italian Olympians, Sailors, People from Naples

Carlo Rolandi (2 July 1926 – 8 August 2020) was an Italian sailor. With Agostino Straulino, he finished 4th in the Star competition at the 1960 Summer Olympics. He was born in Naples. Rolandi was the president of the Italian Sailing Federation from 1981 to 1988.

Rolandi died on 8 August 2020, aged 94.

[[Jefferson (proposed Pacific state)]]

CATEGORIES: California, Thomas Jefferson, Oregon

The State of Jefferson is a proposed U.S. state that would span mostly rural area of southern Oregon and northern California.

This region on the Pacific Coast is the most famous of several that have sought to adopt the name of Thomas Jefferson, the third President of the United States. 

This region makes up most of Northern California's land but does not include San Francisco or other Bay Area counties that account for the majority of Northern California's population.

If the proposal were ever approved, the new state's capital city would have to be determined by a constitutional convention. Yreka, California, was named the provisional capital in the original 1941 proposal. Port Orford, Oregon and Redding, California are some other possible capital city ideas.

[[Port Orford, Oregon]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Oregon

Port Orford (Tolowa: tr’ee-ghi~’- ’an’ ) is a city in Curry County on the southern coast of Oregon, United States. The population was 1,133 at the 2010 census.

[[Stan Statham]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Cardiovascular disease deaths in California, American television news anchors, American political activists, American conservatives, State legislators of the United States, Television personalities from California, Politicians from California, US Republican Party politicians

Stan Statham (April 7, 1939 – August 1, 2020) was an American television news anchor, activist and politician. He was born in Chico, California. He was elected as a Republican to the California State Assembly in 1976. He retired in 1994. Statham was known as a supporter of the State of Jefferson.

Statham died on August 1, 2020 in Oroville, California from a heart attack, aged 81.

[[Twentieth Century (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 movies, 1930s romance movies, 1930s comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by Howard Hawks

Twentieth Century is a 1934 American romantic comedy movie directed by Howard Hawks and starring John Barrymore, Carole Lombard, Walter Connolly, Roscoe Karns, Charles Lane, Etienne Girardot, Edgar Kennedy. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Treaty of Lambeth (1212)]]

CATEGORIES: 1212, Treaties, 13th century in England, History of France

The Treaty of Lambeth was signed on 4 May 1212 by King John of England and several French counts. The Treaty of Lambeth of 1212 should not be confused with the Treaty of Lambeth of 1217, also known as the Treaty of Kingston.

By 1212 John had lost his Angevin possessions in France. Renaud lands had also been seized by King Philip II of France. Renaud brought other continental nobles, including Ferdinand, into a coalition against Philip. In return he was given several fiefs in England and an annuity. In the treaty agreed on 4 May 1212, each prince promised not to make a separate peace with France.

This treaty was part of England's retreat from France, and the collecting of all France under the rule of its king. Previously, under the conquering English kings from Normandy, the Norman kings had ruled over large parts of what is now France.

[[Zweifel's big-eyed tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

Zweifel's big-eyed tree frog (Litoria zweifeli)  is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  It lives in forests and wetlands not near the ocean.

Some scientists, for example Paul Menzies, say this frog is closely related to Grant's big-eyed tree frog.

This frog was named after the scientist Richard George Zweifel.  Zweifel described, or wrote the first formal papers about, many other frogs and wrote many studies about frogs and other amphibians.

[[T'Pau]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s establishments in England, 1986 establishments in the United Kingdom, English rock bands, Shropshire, Musical groups established in 1986

T'Pau are an English pop-rock band. They formed in Shrewsbury, England in 1986. Carol Decker is the lead singer for the band. They had a number of top 40 hits around the United Kingdom and United States. They were "Heart and Soul", "China in Your Hand" and "Valentine".

Their first hit was the 1987 pop-rock ballad "Heart and Soul". It was did badly at first in the UK charts. It became a hit on the United States Billboard Hot 100. It hit #4 after being shown in a Pepe Jeans advertisement. It repeated the upswing on the UK Singles Chart. 

Their first album, Bridge of Spies (called TPau in the USA) hit #1 in the UK and went quadruple platinum.

[[Martika]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, American child actors, Singers from Los Angeles County, California, Actors from Los Angeles County, California, People from Whittier, California, Living people

Marta Merrero (born May 18, 1969), also known as Martika is an American singer and actress. She had an uncredited role in the movie Annie. Later, she acted as Gloria on the television program ''Kids Incorporated.

In 1988, Martika had a self-tited studio album. From the album was her United States #1 hit pop ballad, "Toy Soldiers", in 1989. It was certified Gold. The song also hit #5 in the United Kingdom, Ireland, Germany and Australia.

Martika was born in Whittier, California under Cuban parents.

[[Sugar apple]]

CATEGORIES: Annona

The sugar apple (Annona squamosa) is a species of fruit in the Annonaceae family. It is a relative of the custard apple. It grows better in tropical lowland climates better than the custard apple or Annona reticulata.

[[Annona]]

CATEGORIES: Annona

Annona is a genus of plants in the Annonaceae family. It contains species like the custard apple and sugar apple. It is the second-largest genus in its family after Guatteria. It has about 166 species of shrubs and trees. Its name comes from from anón, a Hispaniolan Taíno word for it.

[[Inaccessible Island]]

CATEGORIES: Uninhabited islands, Volcanoes, Islands of the United Kingdom, Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

Island in Tristan da Cunha archipelago

Inaccessible Island is an extinct volcano. It was last active six million years ago. Together with Gough Island, Inaccessible Island is a protected wildlife reserve, both make up the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Gough and Inaccessible Islands. Inaccessible Island is home to the endemic Inaccessible Island rail, the world's smallest extant flightless bird.

Inaccessible Island is part of the archipelago of Tristan da Cunha. It is part of the overseas territory of the United Kingdom known as Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha. Tristan da Cunha itself is accessible only by sea via a seven-day sail from Cape Town, South Africa, by landing during the 60 days of the year that the harbor allows for access to the island.

[[Small Maracanazo]]

CATEGORIES: Sport in Venezuela

The Small Maracanazo was an historical football match, played in 1971 between the Champion teams of Venezuela and Brazil in Rio de Janeiro.

[[Parliament of Egypt]]

CATEGORIES: Egypt

The Parliament of Egypt, officially the House of Representatives (مجلس النواب arz) is currently a unicameral legislature (though the approval of the 2019 Egyptian constitutional referendum will create a second chamber, called the Senate).

[[Harvey D. Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, American military personnel of the Korean War, American military personnel of the Vietnam War, American generals, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, People from North Carolina

Harvey Dean Williams Sr. (July 30, 1930 – August 7, 2020) was a United States Army major general. He was the first African-American post commander of Fort Myer. 

He was the Deputy Inspector General of the U.S. Army in 1980. He was a commander in the Korean War and Vietnam War. He was born in Whiteville, North Carolina.

Williams died from Parkinson's disease on August 7, 2020 in Germantown, Maryland at the age of 90.

[[Germantown, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Maryland, Montgomery County, Maryland

Germantown is an urbanized census-designated place in Montgomery County, Maryland, United States. With a population of 90,494 as of 2016 U.S. Census Bureau. Germantown is the third most populous place in Maryland, after the city of Baltimore, and the census-designated place of Columbia.

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Maryland

Columbia is a census-designated place in Howard County, Maryland, United States.

[[Hahoe Folk Village]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Asia, Buildings and structures in South Korea, World Heritage Sites in South Korea

Hahoe Folk Village is a village in South Korea.  It has buildings and other things that were built in the Joseon Dynasty or that have been rebuilt in the same style.  Hahoe Village hosts cultural events, including traditional mask dances.  It is in the city of Andong, in North Gyeongsang Province.  It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

The people who built the town used Confucian philosophy and the clan system to decide where to put each building and road.  The clan system was very important in Korea during the Joseon Dynasty.  Some of the houses are made of wood and some are made of mud.  Some of the houses have tile roofs and some have thatched roofs.  Some of the buildings are made of traditional materials and some have been rebuilt with modern materials.  There is a 600 year old zelkova tree in the village.  People have named the tree "Samsindang," and there is a shrine next to it.  Unlike many homes in South Korea, which face south, the houses in Hahoe Village face the tree.  The Byeongsanseowon Confucian Academy is 4 km east of the village.

People still live in Hahoe Folk Village.  Many of them are members of the Ryu clan who have lived there since the 1400s. There are about 127 households in Hahoe Folk Village.  Some of them still have a jongga or head of the family and practice ancestor worship in the Confucian way.

Hahoe Folk Village is known for its traditional outdoor mask performances.  Most traditional masks in Korea are made out of calabash and are used only once.  Masks in Hahoe are made from wood, usually alder wood, and are reused many times.

Hahoe Folk Village also hosts Seonyu Julbul Nori.  On the birthday of the spiritual leader Buddha, people ride down the Nakdong River in boats.  People read poetry.  There is also a display called line fire. This is a special way of lighting fireworks.  Mulberry tree charcoal is put in long pouches that are tied every few centimeters on their length.  The pouches are attached to a rope made of straw, one pouch every five meters.  The rope is long enough to go between two trees.  One end of one charcoal pouch is lit, and it takes a long time for all the charcoal to burn down the whole length of the rope.

The name "Hahoe" comes from "ha" for "river" and "hoe" for "turn around" in Korean.  The village is built right where the Nakdong River turns around.  

In 2020, the village added a traditional brushwood bridge near Hahoe Folk Village.

Queen Elizabeth II visited Hahoe Folk village in 2019.

[[Limes (Roman Empire)]]

CATEGORIES: World Heritage Sites, Buildings and structures in Germany, Great Britain, Listed buildings, World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom

Limes (plural limites) is a modern term used for the Roman border defence in Germany. It marks the borders of the Roman Empire, though it was not used by the Romans for this purpose. 

The term has been extended to refer to the frontier defences in other parts of the empire, such as in the east and in Africa. It is used by the World Heritage site bureaucracy to include the two walls in Britain, the Antonine Wall and Hadrian's Wall.

The Limes is often associated with Roman forts, but it could apply to any area near the walls where the Romans exercised loose control with military forces.

[[Little Gandhi]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 movies, Documentary movies, Syrian movies, Turkish movies

Little Gandhi is a 2016 Syrian Turkish documentary movie directed by Sam Kadi and based on the life of activist Ghiath Matar.

[[Tecate Municipality]]
