Idle No More is a movement in support of Indigenous rights. It was started in 2012 by 4 women, 3 of whom were First Nations.

[[Chittur, Palakkad]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in India

Chittur Taluk is a village in the east of Palakkad district. In 2001 Census, there were 31,884 people living there.  It shares the eastern border with Tamil Nadu state. It is where Parambikulam wildlife sanctuary and Nelliyampathy hills are.  

Government College, Chittur and Government Arts and Science College, Kozhinjampara are major government colleges in the area.

Chetopa is a city in Labette County, Kansas, United States. In 2010, 1,125 people lived there.  Chetopa was named after Chief Chetopah, an Osage Indian chief. Later, the community name was shortened.

[[4th Dimension roller coaster]]

CATEGORIES: Roller coasters

A 4th Dimension roller coaster is a type of steel roller coaster whereby riders are rotated independently of the orientation of the track, generally about a horizontal axis that is perpendicular to the track.

[[Royal Tombs of the Joseon Dynasty]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Seoul, World Heritage Sites in South Korea

The Royal Tombs of the Joseon Dynasty are a group of burial sites in Seoul, South Korea.  Some of them are in other parts of WHICH Province.  They were built for the rulers of the Joseon Dynasty and their families.  They were named a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2009.

The tombs show Confucian philosophy.  The location of each tomb was chosen carefully.  Most tombs have a hillside behind them and face a body of water.  Many of them have mountains visible in the background.  Many of the tombs have statues, burial mounds, shrines for ancestor worship and buildings for guards and groundskeepers.

The oldest tomb was built in 1408 and the newest in 1966.

[[Boy Story]]

CATEGORIES: C-pop, Musical groups

Boy Story (男孩的故事) is a Chinese hip-hop group launched by JYP Entertainment and Tencent Music Entertainment Group (TME). The group is composed of six members: Hanyu, Zihao, Xinlong, Zeyu, Ming Rui, and Shuyang. On September 1, 2017 Boy Story released their first single "How Old R U". In September 21 2018, Boy Story made an official debut with their first mini album Enough.

[[Treble (association football)]]

CATEGORIES: Association football terminology, Association football records and statistics

A treble in association football is when a club team wins three trophies in a single season. A continental treble is when a clubs wins the national league competition, the main national cup competition and the main continental trophy. A domestic treble is when a clubs wins three national competitions. Usually this means the league title, the main cup competition and one secondary competition.

The following people are all converts to Buddhism, sorted alphabetically by family name.

[[Deloitte Football Money League]]

CATEGORIES: Association football rankings, Association football records and statistics

The Deloitte Football Money League is a ranking of football clubs by revenue made from football operations. The accountancy firm Deloitte makes this list every year. It publishes it in early February of each year. It is about the season most recently finished.

[[Joel Glazer]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, American billionaires, Businesspeople from New York, Jewish American sportspeople, Jewish billionaires, Jewish businesspeople, Glazer family, People from Rochester, New York, Sportspeople from New York

Joel Glazer (born 1967) is part of the Glazer family. The family controls First Allied Corporation and HRG Group, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers of the NFL, and England's Manchester United Football Club. The family is based in Florida.

[[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New South Wales

Port Macquarie is a coastal town in New South Wales, Australia. The town is well known for its Koala Hospital, and it is the host of the annual IRONMAN Australia triathlon.

[[Nahanni National Park Reserve]]

CATEGORIES: World Heritage Sites in Canada, National parks in Canada, Northwest Territories, 1972 establishments in Canada

Nahanni National Park Reserve is a national park reserve in Northwest Territories, Canada. It is about 500 west of Yellowknife. It has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1978. The park has an area of about 30050.

[[23rd century]]

CATEGORIES: 3rd millennium, Centuries

The 23rd century will begin on January 1, 2201 and will end on December 31, 2300.

[[24th century]]

CATEGORIES: 3rd millennium, Centuries

The 24th century will begin on January 1, 2301 and will end on December 31, 2400.  Unlike most end-of-century years, the year 2400 will be a leap year, and the next century leap year after 2000.

[[Dennis Bovell]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, British record producers, Black British musicians, British bass guitarists, Barbadian musicians, Reggae musicians

Dennis Bovell (born 22 May 1953) is a Barbados-born reggae guitarist, bass player and record producer. He is based in England. He was a member of the British reggae band Matumbi. He also released dub-reggae records under his own name as well as the pseudonym Blackbeard. He is most widely known for his decades-spanning collaborations with Linton Kwesi Johnson.

[[Thoracic vertebrae]]

CATEGORIES: Bones

The thoracic vertebrae are 12 vertebrae, or bones of the spine. They are situated between the cervical (neck) vertebrae and the lumbar vertebrae. The thoracic vertebrae are represented by the symbols T1 through T12.

The thoracic vertebrae provide attachment for the ribs and make up part of the back of the thorax (the chest).

[[Peter T. King]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, United States representatives from New York, Politicians from New York City, US Republican Party politicians

Peter Thomas King (born April 5, 1944) is an American politician. He was the U.S. Representative from New York between 1993 to 2021. He is a member of the Republican Party.

[[Susan Molinari]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, United States representatives from New York, Lobbyists, Journalists from New York City, Businesspeople from New York City, Politicians from New York City, Google people

Susan Molinari (born March 27, 1958) is an American politician, journalist, and lobbyist. She was a member of the U.S. House of Representatives, representing Staten Island for three terms. She is a Republican.

She gave the keynote address at the 1996 Republican National Convention. However, the next year, she resigned from Congress to become a TV journalist for CBS News. She was in 2008 a Washington lobbyist with clients including Russia.

Later she became a vice president for public policy at Google from 2012 to 2018.

[[Korra]]

CATEGORIES: Characters of Avatar: The Last Airbender, Fictional bisexual females, Fictional characters introduced in 2012

Avatar Korra is the title lead character in Nickelodeon's animated television series The Legend of Korra (a sequel to Avatar: The Last Airbender). She is the current incarnation of Raava's Avatar and Avatar Aang.

The character was created by Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko and is voiced by Janet Varney.

The series' final scene, indicating the beginning of a romantic relationship between Korra and Asami Sato. This was rare in its LGBT representation in western children's television.

[[Tenzin (The Legend of Korra)]]

CATEGORIES: Characters of Avatar: The Last Airbender, Fictional characters introduced in 2012

Tenzin is a major character in Nickelodeon's animated television series The Legend of Korra, which aired from 2012 to 2014. 

The character and the series, a sequel to Avatar: The Last Airbender, were created by Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko. He is voiced by J. K. Simmons. 

Tenzin's father, Aang, was the Avatar before Korra and kept world peace by preventing the Fire Nation from destroying the Earth Kingdom during the 100-year war. Tenzin’s mother is Katara. Tenzin is the youngest of the three children of Aang and Katara.

[[Asami Sato]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional bisexual females, Characters of Avatar: The Last Airbender

Asami Sato is a major character in the Nickelodeon animated television series The Legend of Korra, which aired from 2012 to 2014. The character and the series, a sequel to Avatar: The Last Airbender, were created by Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko. She is voiced by Seychelle Gabriel. 

The series' final scene, showed the beginning of a romantic relationship between Asami and the female lead character, Korra. It was a rare move in its representation of LGBT persons in western children's television.

[[Lin Beifong]]

CATEGORIES: Characters of Avatar: The Last Airbender

Lin Beifong is a major character in Nickelodeon's animated television series The Legend of Korra. The voice was by actress Mindy Sterling. It was aired from 2012 to 2014. 

The character and the series, a sequel to Avatar: The Last Airbender, were made by Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko. 

Lin's mother, Toph Beifong. Lin is the older of Toph's two children. 

She has the same abilities like her mother such as sensing movement based on her feet.

[[Mindy Sterling]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, American movie actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American television actors, Actors from New Jersey, People from Paterson, New Jersey

Farm (2011–13) and Miss Francine Briggs on the Nickelodeon series iCarly (2007–12), The Powerpuff Girls, Nutri Ventures and for Frau Farbissina in the Austin Powers movie series (1997–2002).

[[Bolin (The Legend of Korra)]]

CATEGORIES: Characters of Avatar: The Last Airbender, Fictional characters introduced in 2012

Bolin is a major fictional character in Nickelodeon's animated television series The Legend of Korra, which aired from 2012 to 2014. The character and the series, a sequel to Avatar: The Last Airbender, were created by Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko. He is voiced by P. J. Byrne. 

Bolin is able to bend the classical element of earth, which is known as earthbending. It is revealed in the third season that he is also able to create and control lava, which is a very rare sub-ability called lavabending.

[[Mako (The Legend of Korra)]]

CATEGORIES: Characters of Avatar: The Last Airbender

Mako (Mǎ Gāo) is a major character in Nickelodeon's animated television series The Legend of Korra, which aired from 2012 to 2014. The character and the series, a sequel to Avatar: The Last Airbender, were created by Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko. 

He is voiced by David Faustino. Because he is a firebender, Mako is able to create and manipulate the classical element of fire. Mako also has the ability to both create and redirect lightning. 

The character was named in honor of the late Mako Iwamatsu who voiced Iroh, a major supporting character, in the first two seasons of Avatar: The Last Airbender.

[[Sehore district]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Madhya Pradesh

Sehore District is a district of Madhya Pradesh state in central India. The town of Sehore is the district headquarters. The district is part of Bhopal Division. It has 8 Tehsils and 6526 villages.

[[David Faustino]]

[[Daniel Dae Kim]]

He is the producer of the television drama The Good Doctor.

[[Hurricane Fay]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 disasters, Category 1 Atlantic hurricanes, Hurricanes in Bermuda, Tropical cyclones

Hurricane Fay was a 2014 hurricane in the Atlantic Ocean. It was the first hurricane to make landfall on Bermuda since Emily in 1987. The sixth named storm and fifth hurricane of the 2014 Atlantic hurricane season, Fay formed several hundred miles northeast of the Lesser Antilles on October 10. Initially a large subtropical cyclone, the storm gradually turned into a tropical cyclone on October 11 as it turned north. Despite being disrupted by wind shear for most of its duration, Fay steadily intensified. Turning east, Fay briefly achieved Category 1 hurricane status on October. Fay made landfall on Bermuda early on October 12 as a hurricane. Wind shear finally caused Fay to weaken to a tropical storm later that day. Fay weakened into an open trough early on October 13.

A few tropical cyclone warnings and watches were issued due to Fay on Bermuda. Despite its low strength, Fay caused much damage on Bermuda. Wind gusts over 100 mph (155 km/h) blocked roads with downed trees and poles. The winds also left a majority of the island's electric customers without power. The terminal building at L.F. Wade International Airport was flooded due to damage to its roof. Along the coast, the storm destroyed numerous boats and unmoored many others. Immediately after the hurricane, 200 Bermuda Regiment soldiers were called for cleanup and to help in damage repairs. These occurred at the same time as preparations for the stronger Hurricane Gonzalo, which struck the island less than six days later and increased the damage. Fay and Gonzalo were the first pair of hurricanes to make landfall in Bermuda in the same season.

[[Jim Meskimen]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Comedians from Los Angeles, California

James Ross Meskimen (born September 10, 1959) is an American stand-up comedian and actor. He is also known for his voice-over work in video games.

Meskimen played the father of Mary-Kate Olsen and Ashley Olsen's characters in Our Lips Are Sealed and as Officer Wholihan in How the Grinch Stole Christmas.

He was the voice of the Genie in the Aladdin franchise, sometimes replacing Robin Williams.

[[Attica Prison riot]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 in the United States

The Attica Prison uprising, also known as the Attica Prison rebellion or Attica Prison riot, happened at the Attica Correctional Facility in Attica, New York, United States, in 1971. 

It was a form of protest for demands of better living conditions and political rights. The uprising was one of the best-known and most significant flashpoints of the Prisoners' Rights Movement.  

On September 9, 1971, two weeks after the killing of George Jackson at San Quentin State Prison, 1,281 of the Attica prison's about 2,200 inmates rioted and took control of the prison, taking 42 staff hostage.

During the following four days of negotiations, authorities agreed to most of the prisoners' 28 demands, but would not agree to demands for complete amnesty from criminal prosecution for the prison takeover.

By the order of Governor Nelson Rockefeller, state police took back control of the prison. When the uprising was over, at least 43 people were dead, including ten correctional officers and civilian employees, and 33 inmates.

[[Bar Harbor, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine

Bar Harbor is a town on Mount Desert Island in Hancock County, Maine, United States. As of the 2010 census, its population is 5,235. 

[[Attica (town), New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Attica is a town in Wyoming County, New York. The population was 7,702 as of 2010. The town is named after a region in Greece.

The Town of Attica is on the north boundary of the county and contains part of a village also named Attica.

[[Warsaw (village), New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York, County seats in New York

Warsaw is a village in Wyoming County, New York. It is the county seat of Wyoming County and lies inside the Town of Warsaw. The village of Warsaw is near the center of the town in a valley. The population was 3,473 at the 2010 census.

[[Warsaw, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Warsaw is a town in Wyoming County, in the U.S. state of New York. The population was 5,064 at the 2010 census. The town may have been named after Warsaw, Poland.

[[Attica (village), New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York

Attica is a village in Wyoming County and Genesee County, New York. The population was 2,547 at the 2010 census.

[[Batavia, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New York, County seats in New York

Batavia is a city in and the county seat of Genesee County, New York, United States. It is near the center of the county, surrounded by the Town of Batavia. Its population as of the 2010 census was 15,465. The name Batavia is Latin for the Betuwe region of the Netherlands, and honors early Dutch land developers.

[[Batavia (town), New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Batavia is a town in Genesee County, New York, United States. The population was 6,809 at the 2010 census.

[[Alexander, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Alexander is a town in Genesee County, New York, United States. The population was 2,534 at the 2010 census. The town is named after Alexander Rea, an early settler. It includes a village also named Alexander.

[[Alexander (village), New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York

Alexander is a village in Genesee County, New York, United States. The population was 509 at the 2010 census. The village is named after early settler, Alexander Rea.

[[John Cazale]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 1978 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Massachusetts, Actors from New York City

John Holland Cazale (k, kadˈdzaːle) (August 12, 1935 – March 13, 1978) was an American actor. He appeared in five movies over six years, all of which were nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture: The Godfather (1972), The Conversation (1974), The Godfather Part II (1974), Dog Day Afternoon (1975), and The Deer Hunter (1978)

[[The Conversation]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 mystery movies, 1974 thriller movies, American mystery movies, American thriller movies, Movies directed by Francis Ford Coppola, English-language movies

The Conversation is a 1974 American mystery thriller movie. It was written, produced and directed by Francis Ford Coppola and starring Gene Hackman with supporting roles by John Cazale, Allen Garfield, Cindy Williams, Frederic Forrest, Harrison Ford, Teri Garr and Robert Duvall.

It was nominated for three Academy Awards in 1974 and lost Best Picture to The Godfather Part II, another Francis Ford Coppola movie. 

In 1995, it was selected for preservation in the National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".

[[National Film Registry]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 establishments in the United States, Entertainment in the United States, Movie industry, United States National Film Registry movies

The National Film Registry (NFR) is the United States National Film Preservation Board's (NFPB) selection of movies that are believed in need to be preserved because they are very good. The NFPB, created by the National Film Preservation Act of 1988, was reauthorized by acts of Congress in 1992, 1996, 2005, and again in October 2008. The mission is to keep the American cinema heritage alive and safe.

[[Joseph Papp]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 1991 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, American theatre directors, Theatre producers, Businesspeople from New York City

Joseph Papp (born Joseph Papirofsky; June 22, 1921 – October 31, 1991) was an American theatrical producer and director. He created The Public Theater in what had been the Astor Library Building in lower Manhattan.

He produced David Rabe, Ntozake Shange's For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow Is Enuf, Charles Gordone's No Place to Be Somebody, and Michael Bennett's Pulitzer Prize–winning musical, A Chorus Line.

Papp also founded Shakespeare in the Park, helped to develop other off-Broadway theatres and worked to preserve the historic Broadway Theatre District. He was born in New York City.

Papp died on October 31, 1991 in New York City from prostate cancer, aged 70.

[[Ted Lerner]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, Living people, Real estate developers, Businesspeople from Washington, D.C., Businesspeople from Maryland

Theodore N. Lerner (born October 15, 1925) is an American real estate developer. He was the managing principal owner of the Washington Nationals baseball team.

He is the founder of the real estate company Lerner Enterprises, the largest private landowner in the Washington metropolitan area as well as Chelsea Piers in New York City.

In 2015, Forbes magazine named him the richest person in Maryland.

[[Frank Barnaby]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, English physicists

Frank Charles Barnaby (27 September 1927 – 1 August 2020) was an English nuclear physicist. He worked at the Nuclear Issues Consultant to the Oxford Research Group.

Barnaby was Director of the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) from 1971 to 1981. In 1981, Barnaby became a founding member of the World Cultural Council.

[[Bob Calhoun]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, State legislators of the United States, American lawyers, Politicians from Illinois, Politicians from Virginia, People from Oak Park, Illinois, US Republican Party politicians

Robert Lathan Calhoun (July 22, 1937 – August 6, 2020) was an American attorney and politician. He was a Republican member of the Alexandria City Council and the Senate of Virginia between 1988 and 1996. He was born in Oak Park, Illinois.

Calhoun died of prostate cancer on August 6, 2020, in Berryville, Virginia, at age 83.

[[Steve Grossman]]

CATEGORIES: American jazz musicians, American saxophonists, American composers, Musicians from New York City, Deaths from cardiac arrest, 1951 births, 2020 deaths

Steven Mark Grossman (January 18, 1951sndAugust 13, 2020) was an American jazz fusion and hard bop saxophonist.

Grossman was Wayne Shorter's replacement in Miles Davis' jazz-fusion band. Then, from 1971 to 1973, he was in Elvin Jones' band.

Grossman died on August 13, 2020 in Glen Cove, New York from cardiac arrest, aged 69.

[[Elvin Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2004 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, American jazz musicians, American drummers, Musicians from Michigan, People from Pontiac, Michigan

Elvin Ray Jones (September 9, 1927 – May 18, 2004) was an American jazz drummer of the post-bop era. 

From 1960 to 1966, he was a member of the John Coltrane quartet. His brothers Hank Jones and Thad Jones were also jazz musicians with whom he recorded. He was added into the Modern Drummer Hall of Fame in 1995.

[[Angela Buxton]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, British tennis players, Sportspeople from Liverpool, Writers from Liverpool

Angela Buxton (16 August 1934 – 15 August 2020) was a British tennis player. She won the women's doubles title at both the French Championships and Wimbledon in 1956 with her playing partner, Althea Gibson. She was born in Liverpool.

Buxton wrote the tennis books Tackle Tennis This Way, Starting Tennis, and Winning Tennis and Doubles Tactics.

Buxton died on 15 August 2020 in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, at the age of 85.

[[Kenneth Kunen]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, American mathematicians, Scientists from California, Scientists from Wisconsin, People from Madison, Wisconsin

Herbert Kenneth Kunen (August 2, 1943sndAugust 14, 2020) was an American professor of mathematics at the University of Wisconsin–Madison. 

He worked in set theory. He also worked on non-associative algebraic systems, such as loops, and used computer software, such as the Otter theorem prover, to derive theorems in these areas.

[[Bill Bowman (American politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Businesspeople from Montana, Businesspeople from North Dakota, Politicians from Montana, Politicians from North Dakota, US Republican Party politicians

Bill Bowman (May 26, 1946 – August 15, 2020) was an American politician and businessman. He was a member of the North Dakota State Senate from 1990 until 2018. Bowman was born in Baker, Montana. He was a member of the Republican Party.

Bowman died on August 15, 2020 in Bowman, North Dakota at the age of 74.

[[Bowman, North Dakota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in North Dakota, County seats in North Dakota

Bowman is a city and county seat of Bowman County, North Dakota, United States.  Its population was 1,650 at the 2010 census.

[[Amidon, North Dakota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in North Dakota, County seats in North Dakota

Amidon (ˈ AM) is a city in, and the county seat of Slope County, North Dakota, United States.

Amidon was the smallest incorporated county seat in the 2000 census. When the 2010 census reported its population as 20.

[[Stuart Christie]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Scottish writers, People from Glasgow

Stuart Christie (10 July 1946 – 15 August 2020) was a Scottish anarchist writer and publisher. 

When aged 18, Christie was arrested  while carrying explosives to assassinate the Spanish caudillo, General  Francisco Franco. He was later alleged to be a member of the Angry Brigade, but was acquitted of related charges. 

He went on to found the Cienfuegos Press publishing house and in 2008 the online Anarchist Film Channel, which hosts movies and documentaries with anarchist and libertarian socialist themes. He was born in Glasgow.

Christie died aged 74, from cancer, on 15 August 2020.

[[Ruth Gavison]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Israeli educators, Israeli lawyers, People from Jerusalem

Ruth Gavison (רות גביזון; March 28, 1945 – August 15, 2020) was an Israeli Law professor. She was born in Jerusalem. She worked at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. She was a member of the Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities. In 2011, she won the Israel Prize.

Gavison was nominated for a position on Israel's Supreme Court in 2005 but failed to secure a majority for the appointment.

Gavison died on August 15, 2020 in Jerusalem at the age of 75.

[[Richard Gwyn]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Canadian journalists, Canadian historians, Canadian radio personalities, Political commentators

Richard John Philip Jermy Gwyn, CAN (May 26, 1934 – August 15, 2020) was a Canadian journalist, author, historian, and civil servant.

From 1957 to 1959, Gwyn was the parliamentary correspondent for United Press International, in Ottawa. Later in 1959 to 1960, he worked for Thomson Newspapers. 

From 1960 to 1962, he was the Ottawa editor for Maclean-Hunter Business Publications. From 1962 to 1968, he worked for Time Canada as a parliamentary correspondent and contributing editor. From 1968 to 1970, he was the executive assistant to the Minister of Communications, Eric Kierans. 

From 1970 to 1973, he was the director-general, socio-economic planning in the Department of Communications.

Gwyn died from Alzheimer's disease on August 15, 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Chilla Porter]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Australian Olympic silver medalists, Politicians from Brisbane, Cancer deaths in Australia

Charles Michael "Chilla" Porter (11 January 1936 – 15 August 2020) was an Australian athlete and political figure. He won a silver medal in the high jump at the 1956 Summer Olympics in Melbourne. He later was general secretary of the Liberal Party of Australia (Western Australian Division) from 1978 to 1987. He was born in Brisbane.

Porter died on 15 August 2020, after a long battle with cancer near Perth. He was aged 84.

[[Henryk Wujec]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Polish politicians

Henryk Wujec (25 December 1940 – 15 August 2020) was a Polish politician. He was a member of the Sejm from 1989 to 2001.

Wujec was born in Podlesie, Biłgoraj County. Wujec was an activist in the Solidarity movement of the 1980s. In 1984, he was imprisoned at Białołęka for his political activities.

[[Henk Wullems]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch footballers, Dutch football managers, Deaths from cerebral infarction, Sportspeople from The Hague

Henk Wullems (January 21, 1936 – August 15, 2020) was a Dutch association football manager.

[[Mário de Araújo Cabral]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Portuguese sportspeople, Formula One drivers

Mário Veloso de Araújo Cabral (ˈmaɾiu vɨˈlozu dɨ ɐɾɐˈuʒu kaˈβɾaɫ; 15 January 1934 – 17 August 2020), commonly known by the nickname "Nicha" Cabral (kaˈβɾaɫ), was a Portuguese racing driver. He participated in five Formula One World Championship Grands Prix (four starts), debuting on 23 August 1959.  He did not score any championship points. He was born in Cedofeita, Portugal.

Araújo Cabral died in Lisbon on 17 August 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Elsimar M. Coutinho]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian scientists, Brazilian writers, Brazilian educators

Elsimar Metzker Coutinho (May 18, 1930 – August 17, 2020) was a Brazilian scientist. He was a professor, gynecologist, and television personality. He was born in Pojuca, Bahia. His works helped create the first injectable contraceptive ciclofem.

Coutinho died on August 17, 2020 from COVID-19 at the age of 90.

[[Jasraj]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Indian singers, Indian educators

Pandit Jasraj (28 January 1930   – 17 August 2020) was an Indian classical vocalist. His songs were related to Mewati gharana. His musical career lasted for 75 years. He was born in present-day Fatehabad, Haryana.

He was also the founder of schools for Indian classical music in Atlanta, Tampa, Vancouver, Toronto, New York, New Jersey, Pittsburgh, Mumbai, and Kerala. At age 90, he was teaching some of his international students through Skype.

Jasraj died of cardiac arrest on 17 August 2020 while visiting family in the United States in New Jersey, aged 90.

[[Nishikant Kamat]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cirrhosis, Indian movie directors, Indian movie producers, Indian screenwriters, Indian movie actors, People from Mumbai

Nishikant Kamat (17 June 1970 – 17 August 2020) was an Indian filmmaker and actor. His first movie was Dombivali Fast. His best known movie was Evano Oruvan. An actor, he starred in Saatchya Aat Gharat and Rocky Handsome. He was born in Mumbai.

Kamat died of cirrhosis on 17 August 2020 in Hyderabad at the age of 50.

[[Nina Kraft]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Lower Saxony

Nina Kraft (December 31, 1968 – August 17, 2020) was a German professional triathlete. She was born in Braunschweig, Lower Saxony. Kraft was banned by the German Triathlon Federation (DTU) for one year, after a positive drug test.

Following her win at Ironman Germany in July 2004 Kraft crossed the finish line in first place a few months later in October at the Ironman World Championship as the apparent Ironman World Champion.

Kraft died from an illness in Germany on August 17, 2020 at the age of 51.

[[Michael Diven]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, US Democratic Party politicians

Michael B. Diven (March 27, 1970 – August 18, 2020) was an American politician. He was a member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives for the 22nd District between 2001 to 2006. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Diven died on August 18, 2020 in Pittsburgh, aged 50.

[[Madhav Prasad Ghimire]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2020 deaths, Nepalese people, Poets, Educators, Deaths from respiratory failure, Centenarians

Madhav Prasad Ghimire (माधव प्रसाद घिमिरे) (23 September 1919 – 18 August 2020) was a Nepali poet and scholar. He was honored as the Rashtra Kavi (National Poet) by the Government of Nepal in 2003. Some of his best known works include Gauri, Malati Mangale, Shakuntala, and Himalwaari Himalpaari.

Ghimire died on 18 August 2020 of respiratory failure in Nepal at the age of 100.

[[Dale Hawerchuk]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stomach cancer, Buffalo Sabres players, Calder Trophy winners, Canadian ice hockey centres, Hockey Hall of Fame inductees, Ice hockey people from Ontario, Memorial Cup winners, Philadelphia Flyers players, St. Louis Blues players, Sportspeople from Toronto, Winnipeg Jets players

Dale Hawerchuk (April 4, 1963 – August 18, 2020) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player and coach. 

Hawerchuk played in the National Hockey League (NHL) for 16 seasons as a member of the Winnipeg Jets, Buffalo Sabres, St. Louis Blues and Philadelphia Flyers. He won the NHL's Calder Memorial Trophy as the league's Rookie of the Year in 1982 and was elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame in 2001. 

Hawerchuk was the head coach of the Barrie Colts of the Ontario Hockey League from 2010 to 2019.

Hawerchuk was diagnosed with stomach cancer in September 2019. He died from the disease on August 18, 2020 in Barrie, Ontario at the age of 57.

[[Barrie]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ontario

Barrie is a city and manifesting regional centre in Ontario, Canada, located on the shores of Kempenfelt Bay, the western arm of Lake Simcoe. 

Barrie is located 85 north of Toronto, 355 northeast of Detroit and 335 west of Ottawa.

[[Sayeeda Khanam]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from kidney disease, Bangladeshi people, Photographers

Sayeeda Khanam (29 December 1937 – 18 August 2020) was a Bangladeshi photographer. She was the first female professional photographer of Bangladesh. She covered many important events of Liberation War of Bangladesh in 1971 through her photography.

She also did portraits of figures such as Queen Elizabeth, Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, Mother Teresa, Indira Gandhi and Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.

Khanam died on 18 August 2020 in Dhaka from kidney disease, aged 82.

[[Cesare Romiti]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Italian businesspeople, Italian economists, People from Rome

Cesare Romiti (24 June 1923spnd18 August 2020) was an Italian economist and businessman. He was born in Rome. He was best known as an executive of both state-owned firms and private companies, including Fiat and Alitalia.

In April 1997, Romiti was convicted tax fraud, and making illegal payments to political parties. In 2000, the Supreme Court commuted the sentence to eleven months and ten days, for the same charges. In December 2003, the Court of Appeal in Turin, revoked the sentence for false accounting.

Romiti died on 18 August 2020, aged 97.

[[Mohammad-Ali Taskhiri]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Iraqi politicians, Iranian politicians, Asian diplomats

Mohammad-Ali Taskhiri (19 October 1944 – 18 August 2020) was an Iraqi-born Iranian cleric and diplomat. During the 1980s Taskhiri served as the Iranian representative to the Organisation of the Islamic Conference. He was a member of the Assembly of Experts between 1999 to 2007 and again from 2016 until his death. He was born in Najif, Iraq.

Taskhiri died on 18 August 2020 in Tehran from a heart attack, aged 75.

[[Hans Cavalli-Björkman]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish businesspeople, Bankers, Swedish lawyers

Hans Cavalli-Björkman (29 June 1928 – 18 August 2020) was a Swedish lawyer and banker. He was the chairman of the Swedish Association football club Malmö FF, a post he held between 1975 and 1998. During Cavalli-Björkmans years at the club they won four Swedish championships. He was also CEO of Swedish bank SEB in the late 1980s.

Cavalli-Björkman was born in Jönköping, Sweden. He died on 18 August 2020 in Malmö, Sweden at the age of 92.

[[Robert R. Shahan]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Bishops, Episcopalians, People from Kansas

Robert Reed "Bob" Shahan (October 18, 1939 – August 14, 2020) was an American Anglican prelate. He was the bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Arizona from 1992 to 2004. He was born in Elkhart, Kansas. He was made bishop by Edmond L. Browning.

Shahan died on August 14, 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Edmond L. Browning]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2016 deaths, Presiding Bishops of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America, People from Corpus Christi, Texas

Edmond Lee Browning (March 11, 1929 - July 11, 2016) was an American bishop. He was the 24th Presiding Bishop and Primate of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America from 1985 through 1997.

[[Katharine Jefferts Schori]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, Presiding Bishops of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America, People from Oregon, People from Pensacola, Florida

Katharine Jefferts Schori (born March 26, 1954) is the former Presiding Bishop and Primate of the Episcopal Church of the United States. 

She was the 9th Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Nevada. She was the first woman elected as a primate in the Anglican Communion. Jefferts Schori was elected at the 75th General Convention on June 18, 2006. She retired on November 1, 2015.

She took part in her first General Convention of the Episcopal Church as Presiding Bishop of The Episcopal Church in July 2009.

Jefferts Schori was born in Pensacola, Florida.

[[Ones]]

Ones can refer to:

[[Michael Curry (bishop)]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Presiding Bishops of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America, Writers from Chicago

Michael Bruce Curry (born March 13, 1953) is an American bishop. He is the 27th and current presiding bishop and primate of The Episcopal Church. He was elected in 2015.

He is the first African American to be presiding bishop in The Episcopal Church. He was previously bishop of the Diocese of North Carolina. He was born in Chicago.

[[Episcopal Church (United States)]]

CATEGORIES: Churches in the United States

The Episcopal Church (TEC) is a member church of the worldwide Anglican Communion. It is based in the United States with additional dioceses elsewhere. 

It is a mainline Christian denomination divided into nine provinces. The presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church is Michael Bruce Curry, the first African-American bishop to serve in that position.

2018 the Episcopal Church had 1,835,931 baptized members, of whom 1,676,349 were in the United States. 2011 it was the nation's 14th largest denomination. 

[[Chetan Chauhan]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian cricketers, Indian politicians

Chetan Pratap Singh Chauhan Chetan_Chauhan.ogg (21 July 1947 – 16 August 2020) was an Indian cricketer and Bharatiya Janata Party politician. He played 40 Test matches for India. He played Ranji Trophy for Maharashtra and Delhi. He played most of his international cricket in the late 1970s.

He was also twice elected to the Lok Sabha from  Amroha in Uttar Pradesh, in 1991 and 1998. From 2018 to 2020, he was minister for youth and sports in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India.

On 12 July 2020, he was hospitalized after testing positive for COVID-19 in Haryana. He died from multiple organ failure caused by the infection on 16 August 2020 at the age of 73.

[[Barbara Doherty]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American theologians, American educators, American Roman Catholics, Writers from Chicago

Barbara Doherty (December 2, 1931 – August 17, 2020) was an American educator and theologian. 

She was a Roman Catholic religious sister. She was a member of the Sisters of Providence of Saint Mary-of-the-Woods. She was president of Saint Mary-of-the-Woods College in Indiana from 1984 to 1998. She was director of the Institute of Religious Formation at Catholic Theological Union in Chicago.

She died on August 17, 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Indiana

Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, often called St. Mary's, is an unincorporated community in Sugar Creek Township in northwestern Vigo County, in the U.S. state of Indiana. It had a population of 797 at the 2010 census.

[[Sugar Creek Township, Vigo County, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in the United States, Settlements in Indiana

Sugar Creek Township is one of twelve townships in Vigo County, Indiana, United States. As of the 2010 census, its population was 7,153.

[[Arthur Docters van Leeuwen]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Politicians from The Hague

Arthur Docters van Leeuwen (8 May 1945 – 14 August 2020) was a Dutch politician, jurist and civil servant. He was member of the liberal political party VVD. Between 1999 and 2007 he was chairman of the Netherlands Authority for the Financial Markets. He was born in The Hague.

Docters van Leeuwen died from a heart attack on 14 August 2020 from a heart attack, aged 75.

[[Nikolai Gubenko]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Russian movie actors, Russian movie directors, Russian movie producers, Russian screenwriters, Russian theatre directors, Russian politicians, Deaths from cardiac arrest

Nikolai Nikolaevich Gubenko (Николай Николаевич Губенко; 17 August 1941 – 16 August 2020) was a Soviet and Russian actor, film and theatre director and screenwriter. He was the founder of the Community of Taganka Actors theatre. His movie Wounded Game was entered into the 1977 Cannes Film Festival. 

He was named People's Artist of the RSFSR in 1985.

Gubenko was also active in politics. He was the last Minister of Culture of the USSR (1989—1991) and as the Russian State Duma deputy between 1995 and 2003. From 2005 on he acted as the Moscow City Duma deputy.

He died of cardiac arrest on 16 August 2020 in Moscow, one day before his 79th birthday.

[[Valentin Pavlov]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2003 deaths, People from Moscow, Heads of government of the Soviet Union, Russian businesspeople

Valentin Sergeyevich Pavlov (Валéнтин Серге́евич Па́влов; 27 September 1937 – 30 March 2003) was a Soviet official who became a Russian banker following the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

He was the Premier of the Soviet Union between January 1991 to August 1991.

[[Palashi]]

CATEGORIES: West Bengal, Villages in India

Palashi pəˈlaːsi, anglicised as Plassey, is a village on the east bank of Bhagirathi River, located 50 kilometres north of the city of Krishnanagar  in Kaliganj CD Block in the Nadia District of West Bengal, India. 

[[Nikolai Tikhonov]]

CATEGORIES: 1905 births, 1997 deaths, Heads of government of the Soviet Union

Nikolai Aleksandrovich Tikhonov (Николай Александрович Тихонов; 14 May – 1 June 1997) was a Soviet politician during the Cold War. He was Chairman of the Council of Ministers from 1980 to 1985.

[[Bahman Mofid]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Iranian actors, Iranian singers, Deaths from lung cancer, People from Tehran

Bahman Mofid (بهمن مفید; 15 August 1942 – 16 August 2020) was an Iranian actor and singer. He was born in Tehran. He was known for his roles in Qeysar, Reza Motorcyclist and Wood Pigeon.

Mofid died of lung cancer in Tehran on 16 August 2020, one day after his 78th birthday.

[[Sharon Lee (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Queens borough presidents, US Democratic Party politicians

Sharon Lee is an American Democratic politician.

In January 2020, she became the acting borough president of Queens. 

Lee was appointed deputy borough president in November 2018. Lee took over as borough president from Melinda Katz in January 2020, who was elected Queens District Attorney in 2019. 

[[Rubén Díaz Sr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Rubén Díaz Sr. (born April 22, 1943) is a Puerto Rican politician and an ordained Pentecostal minister. He has represented the 18th Council District in the New York City Council since January 2018. 

He is a member of the Democratic Party. Díaz represented the 32nd district in the New York State Senate from 2003 to 2017.

He is a socially conservative Democrat. Díaz is known for his criticisms to abortion and same-sex marriage.

[[Meningoencephalitis]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Meningoencephalitis (m; from Greek μῆνιγξ meninx, "membrane", ἐγκέφαλος, enképhalos "brain", and the medical suffix -itis, "inflammation"), also known as herpes meningoencephalitis, is a medical condition. It is like meningitis, which is an infection or inflammation of the meninges, and encephalitis, which is an infection or inflammation of the brain.

[[Caio Narcio]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, Brazilian politicians, Deaths from brain disease

Caio Narcio Rodrigues da Silveira (21 August 1986 – 16 August 2020) often simply known as Caio Narcio was a Brazilian politician and a social scientist. He was born in Uberlândia, Minas Gerais. He was a Federal Deputy from 2015 to 2019.

In 2018, Narcio was diagnosed with meningoencephalitis. In July 2020, he was hospitalized in São Paulo with COVID-19. He died from the infection and meningoencephalitis on 16 August 2020, less than a week before his 34th birthday.

[[Jean-Michel Savéant]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, French chemists

Jean-Michel Savéant (September 19, 1933  – August 16, 2020) was a French chemist. His works focused in electrochemistry. He was elected member of the French Academy of Sciences in 2000. He was foreign associate of the National Academy of Sciences in 2001.  

[[Gershon Shafat]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of Israel, Israeli politicians, Politicians from Vienna, Political activists

Gershon Shafat (גרשון שפט, 6 December 1927 – 16 August 2020) was an Austrian-born Israeli politician. He was a member of the Knesset for Tehiya from 1984 to 1992. He was born in Vienna.

He became a member of the Bnei Akiva youth movement, and later joined the National Religious Party. In 1946 he was amongst the founders of kibbutz Ein Tzurim.

Shafat died on 16 August 2020 in Tel Aviv, aged 92.

[[Pierre-Yves Trémois]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, French sculptors, Artists from Paris

Pierre-Yves Trémois (8 January 1921 – 16 August 2020) was a French visual artist and sculptor. He was known for working on drawing in equal proportions on surrealism and science illustration. He was born in Paris.

He held seat #2 in the engraving section at the Académie des Beaux-Arts.

In 2015, he was honored with the Commander of the Order of Arts and Letters.

[[Georg Volkert]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, German footballers, Sportspeople from Bavaria

Georg Volkert (28 November 1945 – 16 August 2020) was a German football player.

He played in 410 games in Bundesliga and scored 125 goals.

He won 12 caps for West Germany between 1968 and 1977. He scored 2 goals in his debut.

Volkert died on 16 August 2020 in Erlangen, Germany from a heart attack, aged 74.

[[Xavier (wrestler)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, 2020 deaths, American professional wrestlers, Sportspeople from New York City, Sportspeople from Hartford, Connecticut

John Jairo Bedoya Jr. (December 28, 1977 – August 16, 2020) was an American professional wrestler, better known by his ring name, Xavier. He was best known for his appearances with Ring of Honor between 2002 and 2004, where he was the second ROH Champion.

Bedoya died on August 16, 2020 at the age of 42.

[[Ali Chaouch]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Tunisian politicians

Ali Chaouch (26 June 1948 – 17 August 2020) was a Tunisian politician and government minister. He was the Tunisian Minister of the Interior between 1997 to 1999.

Chaouch died on 17 August 2020, aged 72.

[[Mariolina De Fano]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors, Italian voice actors, People from Bari

Mariolina De Fano (14 October 1940 – 18 August 2020) was an Italian actress. She was born in Bari, Italy. She was known for her roles as Zia in Tutto l'amore che c'è (2000), Mrs. Lo Turco in The Cézanne Affair (2009) and as Mrs. Bandiera in Make a Fake (2011). She was born in Bari, Italy. Her career lasted from 1981 to 2017.

De Fano died on 18 August 2020 in Bari from a short-illness at the age of 79.

[[Allan Fotheringham]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian journalists, Canadian television presenters, Columnists, People from Saskatchewan

Allan Fotheringham (August 31, 1932 — August 19, 2020) was a Canadian newspaper and magazine journalist, columnist and television presenter. He was known for his many columns that appeared in Vancouver Sun, Toronto Sun, The Globe and Mail and National Post. He was also a panelist on Front Page Challenge between 1984 to 1995.

He died on August 19, 2020 in Quebec at the age of 87.

[[Pierre Berton]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2004 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, Canadian historians, Canadian television presenters, Canadian journalists

Pierre Francis de Marigny Berton CAN (July 12, 1920 – November 30, 2004) was a Canadian author of non-fiction, especially Canadiana and Canadian history. He was a television personality and journalist.  He won many honours and awards for his books. He was born in Whitehorse, Yukon. Between 1957 to 1995, he was a panelist for Front Page Challenge.

Beron died on November 30, 2004 at a hospital in Toronto of congestive heart failure, aged 84.

[[Gianni Agnelli]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2003 deaths, Italian businesspeople, Deaths from prostate cancer, People from Turin

Giovanni "Gianni" Agnelli, OMRI, OML, OMCA, CGVM, CMG (ˈdʒanni aɲˈɲɛlli; 12 March 1921spaced ndash24 January 2003), also known as L'Avvocato ("The Lawyer"), was an Italian businessman. He was known for his business career with Fiat. As the head of Fiat, he controlled 4.4% of Italy's GDP. He was the richest man in modern Italian history.

[[Andrej Andreevich Zolotov]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Russian screenwriters, Critics, Television writers, Writers from Moscow, Editors

Andrej Andreevich Zolotov (born 13 December 1937) is a Russian screenwriter and music and art critic. He has written over 30 documentaries about Russian musicians, composers and conductors. He is the vice president of the Russian Academy of Arts. 

He was born in Moscow. He wrote the scripts for Komsomolskaya Pravda and the TV series Vremya. He was Assistant Minister of Culture between 1990 and 1992. He became the chief editor of RIA Novosti in 1994.

[[Lorraine Thomson]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Dancers, Canadian television presenters, Canadian television producers, People from Regina, Saskatchewan

Lorraine Thomson (12 July 1931 – 13 August 2020) was a Canadian dancer, television host, television producer and one of the co-founders, with Pierre Berton, of the ACTRA Awards. 

She was the first dancer hired by the CBC for their first televised variety show, The Big Revue.

She turned to radio hosting the 1960s, and then television hosting in the 1970s for CBC's The Naked Mind, The Weaker(?) Sex and V.I.P. 

She was the one of the first women to produce variety shows on CBC.

For 18 years, she was the program coordinator for Front Page Challenge. She was nominated for several national awards for her work both in front of and behind the camera.

[[Bob Sykes (American football)]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Oakland, California, American football fullbacks, Washington Redskins players, Sportspeople from New Orleans, Louisiana

Robert Eugene Sykes (March 15, 1927 – August 4, 2020) was an American football fullback in the National Football League for the Washington Redskins in 1952.  He played college football at San Jose State. He was born in Oakland, California. 

Sykes died on August 4, 2020 in Laguna Niguel, California at the age of 93.

[[Douglas Wiseman]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian businesspeople, Politicians from Ontario

Douglas Jack Wiseman (July 21, 1930 – August 1, 2020) was a Canadian politician and businessman.  He was in the Legislative Assembly of Ontario as a Progressive Conservative from 1971 to 1990, and was a cabinet minister in the government of Bill Davis. He was born in Smiths Falls, Ontario.

Wiseman died on August 1, 2020 at a hospital in Perth, Ontario at the age of 90.

[[Wendy Blunsden]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Australian cricketers, Sportspeople from South Australia, People from Adelaide

Wendy Blunsden (9 February 1942 – 1 August 2020) was an Australian cricketer. She captained the Australia national women's cricket team in one Test match and played a total of seven tests. She was born in Adelaide. She made her Test debut against New Zealand in 1972.

Blunsden died on 1 August 2020, aged 78.

[[Nando Angelini]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors, Italian voice actors

Nando Angelini (17 August 1933 – 7 August 2020) was an Italian actor. He appeared in more than eighty movies between 1957 until his death. He was born in San Benedetto del Tronto, Italy. His best known roles were in Il Sorpasso, Barabbas and Bloody Pit of Horror.

Angelini died on 7 August 2020 in Pescara, Italy at the age of 87.

[[Garhajis]]

CATEGORIES: Somalia

Garhajis is a clan made up of Habr Yunis and Eidagale who live in northern Somalia. They border the habar Awal tribe to the west, the Warsangeli to the East and the reer darawiish to the southeast.

[[Tibetan Mastiff]]

The Tibetan Mastiff is a big breed dog. It originated in Tibet. It has long black fur. It is like the Tibetan spaniel dog, but its fur is different.

[[Bruno Fernandes]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Portuguese footballers, Association football midfielders, Manchester United F.C. players, Premier League players, Footballers at the 2016 Summer Olympics, 2018 FIFA World Cup players

Bruno Miguel Borges Fernandes (born 8 September 1994 in Maia, Porto) is a Portuguese professional footballer. He plays as a midfielder for ManchesU club Manchester United and for the Portugal national team.

He has previously played in Italy for Novara, Udinese, and Sampdoria, as well as in Portugal with Sporting CP. He was named Primeira Liga Player of the Year in both 2018 and 2019. In January 2020, Manchester United signed him for an initial fee of €55 million (£47 million).

Fernandes made his senior debut for Portugal in November 2017. He had previously played for Portugal's under-19s, under-20s and under-21s. He also played for Portugal at the 2016 Summer Olympics.

[[Ranoidea (genus)]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Animals of Oceania, Frogs, Taxonomy

Ranoidea is a genus of frogs in the subfamily Pelodryadinae. They live in Australia, New Guinea, the Maluku Islands, and the Louisiade Archipelago. Scientists still disagree with each other about whether Ranoidea should be its own genus or not and which frogs should be in it.  Many of the frogs in Ranoidea used to be in Litoria, Dryopsophus, or Hyla.  In 2016, one team of scientists wrote a paper saying Litoria should be divided up into other genuses. Many other amphibian scientists read it and agreed, but some did not. One reason for this was that not all of the frogs in Litoria had been studied on the DNA level.

[[Ranoidea (superfamily)]]

CATEGORIES: Ranoidea, Frogs, Taxonomy

The Ranoidea are a superfamily of frogs in the order Anura. These frogs have a fused pectoral girdle bone in their chests, no ribs, and the males hold on to the female with an axillary grip during mating. The tadpoles have a single spiracle on the left side and complex mouthparts. Some species do not have tadpoles, and small frogs grow straight from eggs. Scientists disagree about exactly which frogs should be placed in which family and on exactly where Ranoidea belongs among groups of amphibians.  Amphibian scientists often change their minds about exactly which frogs are related to each other and how closely, usually when someone finds new information (Glaw,Vences, 2001).

This superfamily contains seventeen different families, each containing at least 2 species (some contain over 300 different species).

[[NGC 77]]

CATEGORIES: Lenticular galaxies

NGC 77 is a lenticular galaxy in the Cetus constellation. It is located about 780 million light-years away.

[[Shut up]]

CATEGORIES: English language, Slang, Idioms, Bullying

"Shut up" is a command meaning to "be quiet". However, it is more forceful, likely used to tell someone to stop making noise or talking nonsense. It is also a short form of "shut your mouth up". This use is sometimes rude and disrespectful.

[[Dipper]]

CATEGORIES: Occupations

A dipper was the operator of a bathing machine used by women bathers. The dipper pushed the machine into and out of the water and helped the bather into and out of the water. A dipper had to be large and strong to carry out this work.

[[Hexene]]

CATEGORIES: Alkenes

Hexene is an alkene with a molecular formula C6H12. The prefix "hex" is derived from the fact that there are 6 carbon atoms in the molecule, while the "-ene" suffix denotes that there is an alkene present—two carbon atoms are connected via a double bond.

[[Dick Tooth]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Australian rugby union players, Sportspeople from New South Wales

Dick Tooth (21 September 1929 – 5 August 2020) was a Australian rugby union footballer. He was born in New South Wales. He represented for the Wallabies in ten Test matches and nineteen total appearances and was Australian captain on two occasions.

His club rugby was played with the Sydney University Football Club and later with Randwick in the Shute Shield. He practised as an orthopaedic surgeon.

Tooth died on 5 August 2020 in Sydney at the age of 90.

[[Kalevi Oikarainen]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Finnish Olympic bronze medalists, Skiers

Kalevi Oikarainen (27 April 1936 – 14 August 2020) was a Finnish cross-country skier. He competed between the 1950s and the 1970s. Oikarainen was born in Kuusamo. He won a bronze medal in the 4 × 10 km relay at the 1968 Winter Olympics in Grenoble.

He died on 14 August 2020 at the age of 84.

[[Gary Cowling]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Virginia

Gary Cowling (November 4, 1961 – August 17, 2020) was an American actor. He was born in Newport News, Virginia. He appeared in What's Your Sign?, Waldo Walker, Celebrity, Judgment Call, Analyze This, The Namesake and The Accidental Husband (2007).

Cowling died on August 17, 2020 at the age of 58.

[[Randall Rollins]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American billionaires, Businesspeople from Georgia (U.S. state)

Richard Randall Rollins (November 5, 1931 – August 17, 2020) was an American billionaire businessman. He was the chairman of Rollins Inc., the US's largest pest control company. He was born in Ringgold, Georgia.

He was also chairman of Marine Products Corporation, and RPC, Inc and a director of Dover Downs Gaming and Entertainment, Inc, and Dover Motorsports.

As of August 2020, Forbes his net worth at US$5.1 billion.

Rollins died on August 17, 2020, aged 88.

Savvas Theodoridis (18 February 1935 – 17 August 2020) was a Greek footballer. He played as a goalkeeper for Olympiacos between 1955 to 1963 and the Greek national team from 1957 to 1960. He was born in Athens.

Theodoridis died on 17 August 2020 in Athens, aged 85.

[[Todd Nance]]

Nance died on August 19, 2020 at the age of 57.

[[Borys Paton]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2020 deaths, Centenarians, Ukrainian scientists

Borys Yevhenovych Paton HOU (Пато́н Бори́с Євге́нович; 27 November 1918 – 19 August 2020) was a Ukrainian scientist. He was the chairman of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine. He was appointed to this post in 1962. He was known for his works in electric welding. He was born in Kyiv.

Paton died on 19 August 2020 in Kyiv at the age of 101.

[[Warren Magnuson]]

Warren Grant "Maggie" Magnuson (April 12, 1905 – May 20, 1989) was an American lawyer and politician. He was a member of the Democratic Party. He was a U.S. Representative (1937–1944) and a U.S. Senator (1944–1981) from Washington. 

[[Bill Cash]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Conservative MPs (UK), Political writers, Writers from London, Politicians from London, People from Staffordshire, UK MPs 1983–1987, UK MPs 1987–1992, UK MPs 1992–1997, UK MPs 1997–2001, UK MPs 2001–2005, UK MPs 2005–2010, UK MPs 2010–2015, UK MPs 2015–2017, UK MPs 2017–2019, UK MPs 2019–

Sir William Nigel Paul Cash (born 10 May 1940) is a British Conservative politician. He was a Member of Parliament (MP) since 1984. He was first elected for Stafford and then for Stone in Staffordshire in 1997. 

After his tenth election victory in the 2019 general election, aged 79, Cash became the oldest sitting member of the House of Commons.

He was appointed a Knight Bachelor in the 2014 Birthday Honours for political services. He is a known critic of the European Union.

[[Hell or High Water (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 drama movies, 2010s western movies, American western movies, American heist movies, American drama movies, Lionsgate movies

Hell or High Water is a 2016 American neo-Western heist drama movie directed by David Mackenzie and written by Taylor Sheridan. The movie is about two brothers (Chris Pine and Ben Foster) who carry out a series of bank robberies to save their family ranch, while being pursued by two Texas Rangers (Jeff Bridges and Gil Birmingham).

The movie was theatrically released in the United States on August 12, 2016. It made $37 million. It had many positive reviews. It was nominated for four Oscars.

[[Galle]]

CATEGORIES: World Heritage Sites in Asia, Cities in Asia, Settlements in Sri Lanka

Galle (formerly Point de Galle) is a city on the southwest coast of Sri Lanka. It is also known as Galle Fort, the fortified old city founded by Portuguese colonists in the 16th century. Its stone sea walls were expanded by the Dutch. Its building designs shows Portuguese, Dutch and British influences. Some of the notable buildings include the 18th-century Dutch Reformed Church. Galle Lighthouse stands on the fort’s southeast tip. It is part of UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

Sandusky died on August 11, 2020 in Louisville, Kentucky just one week before his 88th birthday.

[[Raymond Allen (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, American television actors, Actors from Kansas City, Missouri

Raymond Gilmore Allen (March 5, 1929 – August 10, 2020) was an American television actor. He was known for his appearances on television during the 1970s. He had roles as Ned the Wino on Good Times, as Woodrow "Woody" Anderson on the NBC sitcom Sanford and Son, and as mechanic Merle the Earl on Starsky and Hutch. He was born in Kansas City, Missouri.

Allen died on August 10, 2020 from respiratory failure in California, aged 91.

[[Christopher Guy Harrison]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Businesspeople from London

Christopher Guy Harrison (3 September 1960 – 19 August 2020) was a British luxury furniture designer. He was the founder and head designer of the international furnishings brand Christopher Guy. His company designs upholstery, chairs, dining tables, sofas, headboards and office furniture.

In 2017, Christopher Guy partnered with rug manufacturer Nourison to create a new line of luxury area rugs. He was born in London. Some of his furniture was inspired by those used on the set of Gone with the Wind.

Some of his furniture had been used in many movies such as Stardust, Casino Royale, The Devil Wears Prada and The Interview.

Harrison died on 19 August 2020 in London of lung cancer, aged 59.

[[The Devil Wears Prada (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2006 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies based on books

The Devil Wears Prada is a 2006 American comedy-drama movie directed by David Frankel and produced by Wendy Finerman. The screenplay, written by Aline Brosh McKenna, is based on Lauren Weisberger's 2003 novel of the same name.

The movie stars Meryl Streep as Miranda Priestly and Anne Hathaway as Andrea "Andy" Sachs. Emily Blunt and Stanley Tucci co-star as co-assistant Emily Charlton and art director Nigel Kipling, respectively. Adrian Grenier, Simon Baker, and Tracie Thoms play key supporting roles.

[[Lauren Weisberger]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, American novelists, Writers from Pennsylvania, People from Scranton, Pennsylvania

Lauren Weisberger (born March 28, 1977) is an American novelist. She was the author of the 2003 bestseller The Devil Wears Prada, which is based on her experience as an assistant to Vogue editor-in-chief Anna Wintour.

[[John Michael Higgins]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Comedians from Massachusetts, Actors from Boston, Massachusetts

John Michael Higgins (born February 12, 1963) is an American actor and comedian. He is known for appearing on many of Christopher Guest's mockumentaries.

He also played Peter Lovett in the TV Land original sitcom Happily Divorced and provided the voice of Iknik Blackstone Varrick in The Legend of Korra. He also starred in the NBC sitcom Great News as Chuck Pierce.

[[Agnes Simon]]

CATEGORIES: Sportspeople from Budapest, Tennis players, 1935 births, 2020 deaths

Agnes Simon (née Almási; 21 June 1935 – 19 August 2020) was a Hungarian international table tennis player. She was born in Budapest. 

From 1953 to 1976, she won several medals in singles, doubles, and team events in the Table Tennis European Championships and in the World Table Tennis Championships.

Her three World Championship medals. She also won three English Open titles.

Simon died on 19 August 2020, aged 85.

[[The Late Late Show with James Corden]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 American television series debuts, 2010s American television series, American comedy television series, American television talk shows, CBS network shows, English-language television programs

The Late Late Show with James Corden (also known as Late Late) is an American late-night talk show hosted by James Corden on CBS. It is the fourth and current version of The Late Late Show.

Corden was announced as the show's new host on September 8, 2014, replacing Craig Ferguson. The show premiered on March 23, 2015.

On April 4, 2017, it was confirmed that Corden would bring The Late Late Show to England for three special episodes. It was the third time in the show's history that it aired from another country, with Ferguson taking his incarnation to Paris, France, in 2011 and Scotland in 2012. Corden returned to London to film a week of shows June 18–21, 2018, and June 17–20, 2019.

In July 2019, CBS announced that Corden's contract to run the show had been extended until August 2023.

[[Eclectus parrot]]

CATEGORIES: Parrots

The eclectus parrot (Eclectus roratus)  is a parrot that lives in the Solomon Islands, Sumba, New Guinea and nearby islands, northeastern Australia, and the Maluku Islands (Moluccas). The parrot is about 35 cm (14 in) long. 

[[Jamnagar]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in India, Settlements in Gujarat

Jamnagar is a city in the state of Gujarat, India. Reliance Industries, India's largest privately-held company, has set up the largest oil refining and petrochemicals hub near the village of Moti Khavdi in Jamnagar district. 

[[Toothpick]]

CATEGORIES: Hygiene, Food utensils

A toothpick is a small thin stick of wood, plastic, bamboo, metal, bone or other material. It has at least one and sometimes two pointed ends. The first mention and patent for it was in February 1872. A person can push a toothpick between their teeth to remove very small pieces of food, after a meal. Toothpicks are also used for celebrations to hold or stick small appetizers (like cheese cubes or olives). 

Toothpicks sometimes have plastic frills or look like small paper umbrellas or flags.

[[Adhesive bandage]]

CATEGORIES: Medical equipment

An adhesive bandage is a small medical dressing. It used for wounds that are not serious. The adhesive bandage protects the wound from bacteria, further damage, and dirt. It helps the body to heal itself. Some of the dressings have antiseptic properties. It also holds the cut together so that the body can heal itself. It can, however, sometimes cause allergies.

[[Royal Library of the Netherlands]]

CATEGORIES: 1790s establishments in Europe, 1798 establishments, Dutch culture, Government of the Netherlands, National libraries in Europe, The Hague

The Royal Library of the Netherlands (Dutch: Koninklijke Bibliotheek or KB; Royal Library) is the national library  of the Netherlands. It is based in The Hague. It was founded in 1798. The KB collects everything that is published in the Netherlands. It also collection everything about the Netherlands. This includes anything from medieval literature to today's publications (books, newspapers, etc.). There are about 7 million publications in the stockrooms of the library. This includes books, newspapers, magazines and maps. The KB also offers many digital services. The main service is the national online Library. It has e-books and audiobooks. Other digital services include Delpher (millions of digitised pages) and The Memory. Since 2015, the KB has helped to bring together many institutions to make a large digital library.

[[Striped burrowing frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The striped burrowing frog, greenstripe frog, or Australian striped treefrog (Ranoidea alboguttata)  is a tree frog from Australia.  It lives in Queensland, New South Wales and the Northern Territory.

This frog lives in forests and in grasslands that are covered in water for part of the year.  They spend a lot of time aboveground when it there is a lot of rain or water around, and they spend more time underground near ponds when the weather is dry. This frog can stay underground for years waiting for rainy weather.

Scientists believe this frog lays eggs in bodies of water and the tadpoles grow into frogs before these bodies of water dry up.

[[Tomori Kusunoki]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from Tokyo, 1999 births, Japanese voice actors, Japanese singers

Tomori Kusunoki is a voice actress of anime characters. She is also an actress and a singer. She is the voices for Llenn in Sword Art Online Alternative Gun Gale Online and Hazuki Kagimura in Märchen Mädchen.

[[NGC 5]]

NGC 5 is an elliptical galaxy in the Andromeda constellation.

[[R Stewart (Randy) Thompson (February 11, 1965 Vancouver, BC Canada)]]

CATEGORIES: English Football League

R. Stewart (Randy) Thompson - born February 11, 1965 (Vancouver, B.C.) - is a Calgary, Canada-based, globally-focused business builder, angel investor, venture capitalist, and entrepreneur. Thompson studied at The University of British Columbia and The University of Alberta and holds a Bachelors of Arts (Political Science) degree from the University of Alberta.

[[President of the Presidency of Yugoslavia]]

The office of the President of the Presidency of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia existed from the death of the President of the Republic for life Josip Broz Tito on 4 May 1980 until the dissolution of the country by 1992.

[[Branko Kostić]]

Branko Kostić (Serbian Cyrillic: Бранко Костић, 28 August 1939 – 20 August 2020) was a Yugoslav politician, businessman, university professor. 

[[Frank Cullotta]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Deaths from diabetes, Deaths from COPD, Chicago Outfit mobsters, Businesspeople from Chicago, Businesspeople from Las Vegas, Nevada

Frank Cullotta (December 14, 1938 – August 20, 2020) was an American mobster for the Chicago Outfit. He was a member of the "Hole in the Wall Gang" in Las Vegas with friend and mobster Tony Spilotro. 

After his arrest in 1982, he became a government witness, and entered the witness protection program. Cullotta later became an author and a tour guide. He worked as a movie consultant for mobster/mafia movies such as for Casino.

On August 20, 2020, Cullotta died at the age of 81 in a Las Vegas hospital from complications related to COVID-19 and other medical issues.

[[Hasil Bizenjo]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Pakistani politicians

Mir Hasil Khan Bizenjo (3 February 1958 – 20 August 2020; Urdu: میر حاصل خان بزنجو) was a Pakistani politician. He was Minister for Maritime Affairs from August 2017 to May 2018. He was a member of the National Party of Pakistan. Bizenjo was a member of the Senate of Pakistan from 2009 until his death.

Bizenjo was diagnosed with lung cancer in 2019. He died in Karachi on 20 August 2020, at the age of 62.

[[Helmut Hubacher]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss politicians

Helmut Hubacher (15 April 1926 – 19 August 2020) was a Swiss politician. He was a member of the Social Democratic Party of Switzerland. From 1963 to 1997, he was a member of the National Council. He was born in Krauchthal, Switzerland.

Hubacher died on 19 August 2020 in Porrentruy, Switzerland at the age of 94.

[[Hal Singer]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2020 deaths, Musicians from Tulsa, Oklahoma, American bandleaders, American R&B musicians, American jazz musicians, American saxophonists, American centenarians

Harold Joseph Singer (October 8, 1919 – August 18, 2020), also known as Hal "Cornbread" Singer, was an American R&B and jazz bandleader and saxophonist. He was the last surviving male survivor of the Tulsa race riot.

Singer became a centenarian on 8 October 2019.  He died on August 18, 2020.

[[Wojciech Karpiński]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Polish historians, Critics, Researchers, Writers from Warsaw

Wojciech Karpiński (11 May 1943 – 18 August 2020) was a Polish writer, historian of ideas and literary critic. He was born in Warsaw. 

Karpiński made his writing debut in 1964 with an essay on François de La Rochefoucauld. He went on to publish in Kultura, Res Publica, Tygodnik Powszechny, Znak, Zeszyty Literackie and Gazeta Wyborcza.

Between 1982 and 2008 he worked as a researcher of the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique in Paris. He has taught at the University of Texas in Austin (1990) and New York University (1994–95, invited by Tony Judt).

Karpiński died on 18 August 2020 in Paris at the age of 77.

[[Howie Judson]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Illinois, Chicago White Sox players, Cincinnati Reds

Howard Kolls Judson (February 16, 1926 – August 8, 2020) was an American professional baseball player. He was a right-handed pitcher in the Major Leagues from 1948 to 1954. He played for the Chicago White Sox and Cincinnati Redlegs. He was born in Hebron, Illinois.

Judson died on August 8, 2020 in Winter Haven, Florida at the age of 95.

[[Hebron, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois

Hebron is a village in McHenry County, Illinois, United States. It is located about 3 miles south of the Illinois/Wisconsin border. As of the 2010 census the village population was 1,216.

[[Dai Davies]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2021 deaths, Welsh footballers, Deaths from pancreatic cancer

William David Davies, better known as Dai Davies (1 April 1948 – 10 February 2021) was a Welsh professional footballer. He  played in goal between 1969 and 1987.  He made 52 appearances for the Wales national football team, and played for Everton, Wrexham (twice), Tranmere Rovers and three spells at Swansea City. 

Davies was born in Glanaman, Wales.

In August 2020, Davies was diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer. He died from the disease on 10 February 2021, aged 72.

Choi Bo-min (born August 24, 2000), professionally known by the mononym Bomin, is a South Korean singer, actor and host.

[[Candy Desk]]

CATEGORIES: United States Senate

The candy desk has been a tradition of the United States Senate since 1968, where a United States senator sits at a specific desk near a busy entrance keeps a drawer full of candy for members of the body. The current occupant of the candy desk is Pennsylvania Senator Pat Toomey.

[[Shin Yeeun]]

Shin Ye-eun (신예은, born January 18, 1998) is a South Korean actress. She is being managed by JYP Entertainment.

[[Steve Symms]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, United States senators from Idaho, United States representatives from Idaho, US Republican Party politicians

Steven Douglas Symms (born April 23, 1938) is an American retired Republican politician. He was a four-term congressman from 1973 to 1981 and a two-term U.S. Senator from 1981 to 1993, representing Idaho. 

[[Shirley Walker]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2006 deaths, Deaths from stroke, American composers, American conductors, Musicians from California

Shirley Anne Walker (née Rogers, April 10, 1945 – November 30, 2006) was an American movie and television composer and conductor. She was one of the few female movie score composers working in Hollywood. 

Walker was one of the first female composers to earn a solo score credit on a major Hollywood motion picture. She was born in Napa, California.

She wrote her movie scores entirely by hand. She always orchestrated and conducted her own scores by herself.

Walker died on November 30, 2006 from stroke-related problems in Reno, Nevada at the age of 61.

[[Federal Bureau of Prisons]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 establishments in the United States

The Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) is a United States federal law enforcement agency under the Department of Justice responsible for the care, custody, and control of incarcerated individuals.

[[Norman Carlson]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lymphoma, Businesspeople from Iowa, Businesspeople from Florida, Politicians from Iowa, Politicians from Florida

Norman Albert Carlson (August 10, 1933 – August 9, 2020) was an American correctional officer and politician. He was born in Sioux City, Iowa. He was made Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons in 1970 by President Richard Nixon. He retired from the office in 1987. He was Director Emeritus of GEO Group.

Carlson died on August 9, 2020 at a hospital in Phoenix, Arizona from lymphoma, one day before his 87th birthday.

[[András Arató]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Models, Hungarian scientists, Hungarian engineers, Photographers, Internet celebrities, Internet memes

András István Arató (born 11 July 1945) is a retired Hungarian electrical engineer and model. He is best known for becoming an internet meme known as "Hide the Pain Harold".

András has been in and out of the stock photo and advertisement industry as a model. He is known for his overall facial expression and fake smile.

While vacationing in Turkey, András Arató decided to upload personal vacation photos onto social media site iWiW, which were noticed by a photographer.
