Centerville is an unincorporated community in Yell County, Arkansas, United States. Centerville has a post office with ZIP code 72829.

[[Adrienne Bailon]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, Living people, American R&B singers, American pop singers, American gospel singers, American hip hop musicians, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Internet celebrities, Television personalities from New York City, Singers from New York City, Businesspeople from New York City, Actors from New York City, Musicians from New York City

Adrienne Eliza Houghton (née Bailon; born October 24, 1983) is an American singer, actress, television personality, Youtuber, and businesswoman. She is a former member of girl groups 3LW and the Cheetah Girls.

Bailon appeared in The Cheetah Girls movies, Coach Carter and All You've Got.

[[Political spectrum]]

CATEGORIES: Elections

A political spectrum is a way to classify different political positions in relation to others. These positions sit upon one or more geometric axes that represent independent political dimensions.

[[Viktor Mykolayovych Tikhonov]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Ukrainian politicians, Deaths from pneumonia

Viktor Mykolayovych Tikhonov (5 March 1949 – 29 August 2020) was a Ukrainian politician. He was born in the Antratsyt Raion, Ukraine. During the Mykola Azarov cabinet, he was the First Vice Prime Minister between 11 March 2010 through 1 June 2011. He was a member of the Verkhovna Rada between 1994 through 2014.

Tikhonov died of pneumonia on 29 August 2020 in Simferopol, Ukraine at the age of 71.

[[Fig wasp]]

CATEGORIES: Wasps, Symbiosis

Fig wasps are wasps of the superfamily Chalcidoidea which spend their larval stage inside figs. Most pollinate the figs, but others simply feed on the plant. 

The non-pollinators belong to several groups in the superfamily Chalcidoidea. So, the fig wasps are a polyphyletic group: they include several unrelated lineages whose similarities are based upon their shared association with figs. 

The pollinators are all in the family Agaonidae. They make galls. The other types either make their own galls or use the galls of other fig wasps.

[[Eastern mountains tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The eastern mountains tree frog (Ranoidea dorsivena) is a frog from New Guinea. Scientists saw it about 1500 meters above sea level in the higher parts of the Fly River and Sepak River, and in the Arfak Mountains.

[[Dr. Jekyll and Sister Hyde]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 science fiction movies, 1971 horror movies, British science fiction movies, British horror movies, Science fiction horror movies, Movies directed by Roy Ward Baker, Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde movies

Dr. Jekyll and Sister Hyde is a 1971 British science fiction horror movie directed by Roy Ward Baker and is based on the 1886 novella Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde by Robert Louis Stevenson. It stars Ralph Bates, Martine Beswick, Gerald Sim, Lewis Fiander and was distributed by Hammer Film Productions.

[[Zoom]]

zoomZoom may refer to:

[[Zoom (software)]]

CATEGORIES: Video chat

Zoom is a video chat software program made by Zoom Video Communications. Its unpaid service allows up to 100 people to video chat for no more than 40 minutes. Its paid service allows up to 1,000 people to video chat with no time limit.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, Zoom has become very popular for working from home, attending school from home, and online social relationships. It has also been criticized by people concerned about privacy and surveillance.

[[Patrick W. Skehan]]

CATEGORIES: 1909 births, 1980 deaths

Patrick William Skehan (30 September 1909 - 9 September 1980) was an American Old Testament semitic scholar.

[[Society of Saint Pius X]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 establishments, Christian organizations

The Society of Saint Pius X is a Catholic fraternity of priests with  traditionalist views. Marcel Lefebvre, a French priest founded it in the 1970s, because he thought that the Second Vatican Council had given up many of the these traditions. It is against many of the changes the Second Vatican Council introduced, namely the dialogue with leaders of other religions and the communal relation of different Christian groups. Since 1975, the Society of Saint Pius X  no longer has canonical mandate. In 1988, the society consecrated new bishops, which by canonical law, led to the excommunication of those consecrating, and those consecrated. Pope Benedict XVI annulled the excommunications in the 2000s, after all involved affirmed that the Pope was the head of the Catholic Church. As of 2020, the society has 680 priests and 217 seminarians.

[[Least weasel]]

CATEGORIES: IUCN Red List least concern species, Mustelids, Mammals of Asia, Mammals of Europe, Mammals of North America

The least weasel (Mustela nivalis) is the world's smallest mammalian carnivore. It is the smallest member of the genus Mustela, the smallest member of the family Mustelidae and the  order Carnivora. 

It is also called the little weasel or common weasel. 

The weasel is native to Eurasia, North America and North Africa. It has been introduced to New Zealand, Malta, Crete, Bermuda, Madeira Island, the Azores, the Canary Islands, São Tomé, the Falkland Islands, Argentina and Chile. It is a least concern species.

[[The Simpsons (season 4)]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons seasons, 1990s television seasons

The 4th season of The Simpsons first started showing on television on September 24, 1992. The season started with the episode "Kamp Krusty". The season ended with the episode "Krusty Gets Kancelled" on May 13, 1993. The season was first released to DVD for Region 1 on June 15, 2004, Region 2 on August 2, 2004, and Region 4 on August 25, 2004.

Many of the show's staff left after the season ended. Jay Kogen, Wallace Wolodarsky, and Jeff Martin stopped writing episodes when the season ended. David M. Stern and Jon Vitti left, but they came back years later to write more episodes. Al Jean, Mike Reiss, and Rich Moore left to make The Critic. Jean and Reiss came back to The Simpsons around the 10th and 13th seasons. Rich Moore came back to help with animation for The Simpsons Movie. This was the first season to have animation done by Film Roman instead of Klasky Csupo.

Dan Castellaneta won an Emmy Award for "Outstanding Voice-Over Performance". He won for his voice acting of Homer Simpson in the episode "Mr. Plow".

[[Ashanti (1979 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 movies, 1970s action movies, 1970s adventure movies, Swiss movies, American action movies, American adventure movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Richard Fleischer

Ashanti (also called Ashanti, Land of No Mercy) is a 1979 Swiss American action adventure movie directed by Richard Fleischer and was based the 1977 novel Ébano by Alberto Vázquez-Figueroa. It stars Michael Caine, Peter Ustinov, Kabir Bedi, Beverly Johnson, Omar Sharif, Rex Harrison, William Holden, Zia Mohyeddin, Jean-Luc Bideau, Tariq Yunus and was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Abraj Al Bait]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Saudi Arabia, Towers in Asia, Mecca, 2004 establishments in Asia, Establishments in Saudi Arabia

Abraj Al Bait (Arabic: أبراج البيت‎) is a  building in Saudi Arabia. It was considered the world's tallest building  from 2004 to 2011. It is used as a clock tower and is 601 tall.

[[Seether]]

Seether is a South African rock band formed in Pretoria in 1999.

[[Joke Kersten]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch mayors, Dutch women politicians, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Labour Party (Netherlands) politicians, Politicians from North Brabant

Johanna Wilhelmina "Joke" Kersten (11 April 1944 – 6 August 2020) was a Dutch politician. She was member of the House of Representatives for the Labour Party from 4 September 1990 to 17 May 1994. She was mayor of Grubbenvorst and Broekhoven between 1995 and 2001. 

Later Kersten was acting mayor of Arcen en Velden, Bergeijk and Asten. She served as mayor of Uden between 2004 and 2009.

Kersten was born in Beugen (municipality of Boxmeer) and died in Grubbenvorst (municipality of Horst aan de Maas), aged 76.

[[Edward Wilson Merrill]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Engineers from Massachusetts, American chemists, American biologists, American educators, Scientists from Massachusetts, Writers from Massachusetts

Edward Wilson Merrill (August 31, 1923 – August 6, 2020) was an American biomaterials scientist. He was one of the founders of bioengineering. His work focused on the biomedical engineering field as it developed from chemical engineering. 

[[Lonely are the Brave]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 drama movies, 1960s western movies, American western movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by David Miller

Lonely are the Brave is a 1962 American western drama movie directed by David Miller and was based on the 1956 novel The Brave Cowboy by Edward Abbey. It stars Kirk Douglas, Walter Matthau, Gena Rowlands, George Kennedy, Bill Bixby, Carroll O'Connor and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Edward Bruner]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, American anthropologists, American educators, Scientists from Illinois, Writers from Illinois, People from Urbana, Illinois, Scientists from New York City, Writers from New York City

Edward M. Bruner (September 28, 1924 – August 7, 2020) was an American anthropologist and educator. He was born in New York City. He worked at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. His book Culture on Tour: Ethnographies of Travel was his best-known book. His works focused on Toba Batak migrants in Indonesia in the 1960s.

Bruner died on August 7, 2020 in Urbana, Illinois at the age of 95.

[[Mike Yaschuk]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Ice hockey people from Saskatchewan

Mike Yaschuk (November 5, 1922 – August 7, 2020) was a Canadian ice hockey player and coach. He played professionally in senior leagues in Canada and in the English League. Yaschuk was born in Ituna, Saskatchewan. 

He played junior with the St. Boniface Athletics and was the MJHL leading scorer in 1942–43. Yaschuk played senior ice hockey with the Winnipeg Reo Flyers from 1946-48. He played one season with the Saskatoon Quakers of the Western Canada Senior Hockey League in 1948-49, then moved to England. 

Yaschuk died on August 7, 2020, aged 97.

[[Bernd Fischer]]

CATEGORIES: German mathematicians, 1936 births, 2020 deaths

Bernd Fischer (18 December 1936 – 13 August 2020) was a German mathematician.

He was best known to his works to the classification of simple groups, and he discovered several of the sporadic groups. He helped discover 3-transposition groups and created the three Fischer groups.

[[Ary de Sá]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian Olympians, Long jumpers

Ary Façanha de Sá (1 April 1928 – 16 August 2020) was a Brazilian long jumper. At the 1952 Summer Olympics he finished fourth in the long jump. He also competed at the 1956 Summer Olympics. 

He became South American long jump champion in 1952, won silver medals in 1956 and 1958 and a bronze medal in 1954. 

Sa died on 16 August 2020 at the age of 92.

[[Fred Clarke (Australian footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Australian rules footballers, Sportspeople from Victoria (Australia)

Fred Clarke (1 December 1932 – 17 August 2020) was an Australian rules footballer. He played with Richmond in the Victorian Football League (VFL). During his career he wore the number 17 guernsey. 

In the 1953 season, Clarke played four early games before suffering a thigh injury from which he was unable to recover well enough to make any more appearances. 

[[Durham, New Hampshire]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New Hampshire

Durham is a town in Strafford County, New Hampshire, United States. The population was 14,638 at the 2010 census. Durham is home to the University of New Hampshire.

[[Jan D. Achenbach]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, American academics, American editors, American engineers, Dutch scientists, Naturalized citizens of the United States, People from Leeuwarden

Jan Drewes Achenbach (20 August 1935 – 22 August 2020) was a Dutch-American engineer, editor and educator. He was professor emeritus (Walter P. Murphy Professor and Distinguished McCormick School Professor) at Northwestern University. 

Achenbach was born in the northern region of the Netherlands, in Leeuwarden. 

He worked as a preceptor at Columbia University, he was then appointed as assistant professor at Northwestern University.

Achenbach is the founding editor-in-chief of Wave Motion. 

He was honored with the National Medal of Science from President George W. Bush in 2005.

Achenbach died on 22 August 2020 at the age of 85.

[[Fujio Matsuda]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, American engineers, American educators, Scientists from Hawaii

Fujio "Fudge" Matsuda 松田 富士男 (October 18, 1924 – August 23, 2020) was the first Japanese American president of the University of Hawaii. This made him the first Asian American to become president of a major university in the United States.

After retiring, Matsuda was on the boards of several non-profit organizations, including for the Japanese Cultural Center of Hawaii just after its near-closure in 2003.

Matsuda died at his home on August 23, 2020, at the age of 95.

[[Zuray Marcano]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Venezuelan sportspeople, Venezuelan people

Zuray Marcano Fuenmayor (26 May 1954 – 23 August 2020) was a Venezuelan teacher and Paralympic powerlifter. In 2016, she was a competitor at the Rio Paralympics at the age of 62. She was born in El Tigre, Venezuela.

She was paralyzed at an early age due to polio.

Marcano died on 23 August 2020 in Maracay, Venezuela, aged 66.

[[Augusto Caminito]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie producers, Italian movie directors, Italian screenwriters, People from Naples

Augusto Caminito (1 July 1939 – 23 August 2020) was an Italian movie director, screenwriter, and producer. He was born in Naples. As a director, he was known for his works Grandi cacciatori (1988) and Vampire in Venice (1988). He produced Ne parliamo Lunedì (1990). He also wrote the screenplay for Halleluja for Django (1967).

Caminito died on 23 August 2020 in Rome, aged 81.

[[Carl Garrett]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, New England Patriots players, Chicago Bears players, New York Jets players, Oakland Raiders players, Sportspeople from Texas, People from Denton, Texas

Carl L. Garrett (August 31, 1947 – August 24, 2020) was an American football halfback. He began his professional career with the American Football League's Boston Patriots. He also played for the Chicago Bears, New York Jets, and Oakland Raiders. His career began 1969 and he retired in 1977. 

Garrett was born in Denton, Texas. He studied at New Mexico Highlands University. Garrett died on August 24, 2020 in Denton at the age of 72.

[[Daejeon Station]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in South Korea, 1900s establishments in Asia, 1905 establishments, Railway stations in South Korea, 1900s establishments in South Korea

Daejeon Station is on South Korea's KTX railway network, 166.6 km south of Seoul Station.

[[Alien TV]]

CATEGORIES: Australian television series, Canadian television series, Comedy television series, Children's television series, Netflix original shows, English-language television programs

Alien TV is a 2020 hybrid animated series produced by Entertainment One and Pop Family Entertainment for Netflix. The series focuses on a television news crew made up of the extra-terrestrials Ixbee, Pixbee and Squee, who are sent to learn about the planet Earth.

[[Jorge Sanjinez Lenz]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Centenarians, Peruvian people, World War II people

Jorge Sanjinez Lenz (January 24, 1917 – August 24, 2020) was a Peruvian military veteran. He participated as a military volunteer in World War II, on the side of the Allies for the liberation of Europe from the Axis Powers. 

He was part of the foreign troops of the Piron Brigade. He was born in Moquegua, Peru.

He was the last Latin American soldier to die who participated in D Day.

Sanjinez died of lung cancer in Lima on August 24, 2020 at the age of 103.

[[Francisco Belaúnde]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Peruvian politicians

Francisco Belaúnde Terry (3 October 1923 – 25 August 2020) was a Peruvian politician. He was a member of Congress between 1980 to 1990. He also was President of the Congress between 1980 to 1981. His brother Fernando Belaúnde Terry was President of Peru.

Belaúnde died on 25 August 2020 in Lima, aged 96.

[[Fernando Belaúnde Terry]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 2002 deaths, Presidents of Peru, People from Lima

Fernando Belaúnde Terry (October 7, 1912 – June 4, 2002) was a Peruvian politician. He was President of Peru (1963–1968 and 1980–1985).

[[Don Parkinson (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Legislative speakers, State legislators of the United States, American lawyers, Guam, US Democratic Party politicians

William D. "Don" Parkinson (1942 – August 31, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was the Speaker of the Guam Legislature from 1995 to 1997 and as Majority Leader from 1989 to 1995. He was a member of the Democratic Party of Guam. He was a member of the legislature from 1983 to 1997.

Parkinson died on August 31, 2020, aged 77–78.

[[Jürgen Schadeberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, South African people, German photographers

Jürgen Schadeberg (18 March 1931 – 29 August 2020) was a German-born South African photographer and artist. He also used the name Jurgen Schademann. He photographed key moments in South African history, including iconic photographs such as Nelson Mandela as an inmate at Robben Island. He was born in Berlin.

Schadeberg died on 29 August 2020 from a stroke at the age of 89.

[[S. I. Padmavati]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2020 deaths, Centenarians, People from New Delhi, Indian scientists, Physicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Burmese people

Dr. Padmavati Sivaramakrishna Iyer (20 June 1917 – 29 August 2020), commonly known as Dr. S. I. Padmavati or Dr. S. Padmavati, was a Burmese-born Indian cardiologist.

She was director of the National Heart Institute, Delhi and the founder president of the All India Heart Foundation.

Padmavati was awarded India's second highest civilian honour, the Padma Vibhushan in 1992.

Padmavati was an elected fellow of the National Academy of Medical Sciences. She was the first woman cardiologist in India in 1954.

Padmavati died on 29 August 2020 from COVID-19 in New Delhi at the age of 103.

[[André-Paul Duchâteau]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian writers

André-Paul Duchâteau (8 May 1925 – 26 August 2020) was a Belgian comics writer and mystery novelist. He was born in Tournai, Belgium. He worked with Tibet on the detective comics series Ric Hochet and the more humoristic western comic Chick Bill. He also wrote under the pseudonym Michel Vasseur. 

Duchâteau died on 26 August 2020 in Uccle, Belgium at the age of 95.

[[Adrien Gouteyron]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, French mayors

Adrien Gouteyron (13 May 1933 – 26 August 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the Senate of France between 1978 to 2011. He represented the Haute-Loire department. He was a member of the Union for a Popular Movement Party. Gouteyron was born in Rosières, France.

Gouteyron died on 26 August 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Victor Hugo Martínez Contreras]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung disease, Roman Catholic bishops, Guatemalan people

Víctor Hugo Martínez Contreras (29 March 1930 – 26 August 2020) was a Guatemalan Roman Catholic archbishop. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1956. He was auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Huehuetenango, Guatemala, from 1970 to 1975 and as bishop of the diocese from 1975 to 1987. 

He was bishop from 1987 to 1996, and then the archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Altos, Quetzaltenango-Totonicapán, Guatemala from 1996 to 2007.

Martínez Contreras died on 26 August 2020 in Guatemala City from problems caused by lung disease, aged 90.

[[Don Kidd]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Texas, Politicians from New Mexico, US Republican Party politicians

Don Kidd (October 10, 1937 – August 27, 2020) was an American politician. He was a Republican member of the New Mexico State Senate from 1993 to 2005. He was born in Crowell, Texas.

Kidd died on August 27, 2020 at his home in Carlsbad, New Mexico from pancreatic cancer at the age of 82.

[[Cristian Castro]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, Pop singers, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican voice actors, Actors from Mexico City, Singers from Mexico City

Christian Sáinz Valdés Castro (born 8 December 1974), known professionally as Cristian Castro  or Cristian, is a Mexican pop singer and actor.

He is the son of actors Veronica Castro and Manuel "El Loco" Valdés.

He is known for his slight tenor vocal singing. Castro is known as one of the most well known Hispanic pop singers of the last three decades. 

Juan Gabriel described Castro as "the man with the most faculties to sing in Mexico".

[[H. Vasanthakumar]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian politicians, Indian businesspeople

Harikrishnan Vasanthakumar (14 April 1950spnd28 August 2020) was an Indian businessman and politician. He was the founder and chairman of Vasanth & Co. He was also the founder and managing director of the Tamil satellite TV channel Vasanth TV.

He was elected as the member of parliament to the 17th Lok Sabha from Kanyakumari constituency in the 2019 Indian general election. He was also elected as member of the Tamil Nadu Legislative Assembly from Nanguneri constituency in the 2006 and 2016 elections.

He was born in Travancore-Cochin, Tamil Nadu. Tamilisai Soundararajan, the Governor of Telangana, is his niece.

Vasanthakumar died on 28 August 2020 at a hospital in Chennai, Tamil Nadu from COVID-19, aged 70.

[[Don Bacon (microbiologist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, New Zealand academics, New Zealand scientists, Microbiologists

Donald Frederick Bacon (6 April 1926 – 28 August 2020) was a New Zealand microbiologist. In 1966, he was appointed the inaugural professor of microbiology at Massey University, where he remained until his retirement in 1989. Bacon was born in Gisborne, New Zealand. He was known for his works relating to the genetics of E. coli and associated bacteriophages. He retired in 1989.

Bacon died in Palmerston North, New Zealand on 28 August 2020 at the age of 94.

[[Get on Up (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s biographical movies, 2010s musical movies, 2014 drama movies, American biographical movies, American musical movies, American drama movies, Universal Pictures movies

Get on Up is a 2014 American biographical musical drama movie about the life of singer James Brown and directed by Tate Taylor and written by Jez and John-Henry Butterworth.

The movie stars Chadwick Boseman as Brown, Nelsan Ellis as Bobby Byrd, Dan Aykroyd as Ben Bart, Viola Davis as Susie Brown, Craig Robinson as Maceo Parker, and Octavia Spencer as Aunt Honey.

The movie was released on August 1, 2014, received positive reviews.

[[Randall Kenan]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2020 deaths, LGBT writers, Gay men, LGBT people from New York City, Writers from New York City

Randall Kenan (March 12, 1963 – August 28, 2020) was an American author. He was born in Brooklyn, New York. 

His works focused around what it means to be black and gay in the southern United States. Some of Kenan's most notable works include the collection of short stories Let the Dead Bury Their Dead, named a New York Times Notable Book in 1992, A Visitation of Spirits, and The Fire This Time. 

Kenan was the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Whiting Award, and the John Dos Passos Prize.

Kenan died on August 28, 2020 at the age of 57.

[[Rahat Khan]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Bangladeshi journalists, Novelists

Rahat Khan (19 December 1940 – 28 August 2020) was a Bangladeshi journalist and novelist. He wrote more than 32 novels. He was an editor for The Daily Ittefaq.

He won Bangla Academy Literary Award in 1973 and Ekushey Padak in 1996 by the Government of Bangladesh.

Khan died on 28 August 2020 in Dhaka at the age of 79.

[[Assar Lindbeck]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish writers, Swedish economists, Swedish academics

Carl Assar Eugén Lindbeck (26 January 1930 – 28 August 2020) was a Swedish professor of economics at Stockholm University and at the Research Institute of Industrial Economics (IFN). Lindbeck was a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.

Lindbeck's work focused in research on unemployment (e.g. the insider-outsider theory of employment), the welfare state (including the effect of changing social norms), and China's reformed economy.

Lindbeck died on 28 August 2020 in Stockholm, aged 90.

[[Antoinette Spaak]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian politicians, People from Brussels

Antoinette Spaak (27 June 1928 – 28 August 2020) was a Belgian politician. She was active in the Democratic Front of Francophones (Front Démocratique des Francophones, FDF). She was president of the party between 1977 to 1982. She was born in Brussels. 

She died at her home in Brussels, Belgium on 28 August 2020, aged 92.

[[Bill Paterson]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Actors from Glasgow, Scottish movie actors, Scottish stage actors, Scottish television actors, Scottish voice actors

William Tulloch Paterson (born 3 June 1945) is a Scottish actor and commentator. 

He has appeared in many movies and television projects including Comfort and Joy (1984), Truly, Madly, Deeply (1990), Wives and Daughters (1999), Sea of Souls (2004–2007), Amazing Grace (2006), Miss Potter (2006), and PBS's Little Dorrit (2008). 

[[Michael B. Jordan]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people, African American actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American video game actors, American child actors, American television producers, Movie producers from California, Movie producers from New Jersey, Actors from California, Actors from Newark, New Jersey, People from Santa Ana, California

Michael Bakari Jordan (b; born February 9, 1987) is an American actor and producer. He is known for his movie roles as shooting victim Oscar Grant in the drama Fruitvale Station (2013), boxer Adonis "Donnie" Creed in the Rocky sequel movie Creed (2015), and Erik Killmonger in Black Panther (2018).

[[Donna Murphy]]

CATEGORIES: Tony Award winning actors, Emmy Award winning actors, Drama Desk Award winners, 1959 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from New York City, Singers from New York City

Donna Murphy (born March 7, 1959) is an American actress and singer. She is known for her work in musical theater. 

She won the Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical twice for her role as Fosca in Passion (1994–95) and as Anna Leonowens in The King and I (1996–97).

[[Kikoriki]]

CATEGORIES: Animated television series

Kikoriki, known in the United States as GoGoRiki and in Russia as Smeshariki (Смеша́рики), is a Russian animated television series made up of 209 episodes of 6 minutes and 30 seconds each, aimed at children of 3 to 8 years. 

The first episode premiered in Russia on May 17, 2004. 

The series is aired in 60 countries, is translated to 15 languages.

[[Eileen Davidson]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Writers from Los Angeles, California, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Models from Los Angeles, California, Television personalities from Los Angeles, California, Emmy Award winning actors

Eileen Marie Davidson (born June 15, 1959) is an American actress, author, television personality and former model. Davidson is best known for her roles in soap operas as Kristen DiMera on NBC's Days of Our Lives, as well as Ashley Abbott on CBS's The Young and the Restless and The Bold and the Beautiful.

[[Artesia, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in Los Angeles County, California

Artesia is a city in southeast Los Angeles County, California.  

[[Ceres, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in Stanislaus County, California

Ceres is a city in Stanislaus County, California. The population was 45,417 at the 2010 U.S. Census.

[[Black Panther (Marvel Comics)]]

CATEGORIES: Characters created by Stan Lee, Fictional characters introduced in the 1960s, Marvel Comics adapted into movies, Marvel Comics mutates, Marvel Comics superheroes, Marvel vs. Capcom fighters

Black Panther is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics. The character was created by writer-editor Stan Lee and writer-artist Jack Kirby, first appearing in Fantastic Four #52 (cover-dated July 1966) in the Silver Age of Comic Books. 

Black Panther's real name is T'Challa. He is the king and protector of the fictional African nation of Wakanda. 

Black Panther is the first superhero of African descent in mainstream American comics.

Chadwick Boseman played the character in the Marvel Cinematic Universe movies Captain America: Civil War (2016), Black Panther (2018), Avengers: Infinity War (2018), and Avengers: Endgame (2019).

In 2011, Black Panther was ranked 51st overall on IGN's "Top 100 Comic Books Heroes" list.

[[2020 Jolo bombings]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 crimes in Asia, 2020s explosions in Asia, 2020s murders in Asia, 21st century in the Philippines, August 2020 events, Explosions in 2020, Islamic State, Islamic terrorist incidents in Asia, Islamic terrorist incidents in the 2020s, Mass murder in 2020, Mass murder in Asia, Suicide bombings in Asia, Suicide bombings in the 2020s, Terrorist incidents in 2020, Terrorist incidents in Asia in the 2020s

The 2020 Jolo bombings occurred on August 24, 2020, when suicide bombers of Abu Sayyaf jihadists attacked Jolo, Sulu, Philippines, killing 14 people and wounding 75 others.

The first attack happened as army personnel were assisting in carrying out COVID-19 humanitarian efforts. The second, a suicide bombing, was carried out near the Our Lady of Mount Carmel Cathedral.

[[Jolo, Sulu]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Philippines

Jolo is a city which is the capital of the Sulu province of the Philippines. In 2015, 125,564 people lived there. That same year, 40% of people living there were poor.

Islamist bombers attacked Jolo in 2019 and 2020.

[[Sulu]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of the Philippines

Sulu (sʊˈlu; Tausūg: Wilāya sin Lupa' Sūg; Lalawigan ng Sulu) is a province of the Philippines in the Sulu Archipelago and part of the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM).

Its capital is Jolo on the island of the same name.

[[Ric Drasin]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from renal failure, American educators, American movie actors, American professional wrestlers, Stuntmen, Actors from California, Writers from California, Sportspeople from California, People from Bakersfield, California

Richard Alan "Ric" Drasin (July 12, 1944 – August 30, 2020) was an American bodybuilder, personal trainer, actor, stuntman, author,  and former professional wrestler. He wrestled professionally for 36 years between 1965 and 2001.

He was also known for designing both the original Gold's Gym logo — a cartoon sketch of a bald weightlifter, and the World Gym gorilla logo.

Drasin was born in Bakersfield, California. He began his fitness career in 1962. He taught classes in nutrition and exercise at the YMCA. He trained with the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) champion Mae Young.

Drasin died of kidney failure in Van Nuys, California on August 30, 2020 at the age of 76.

[[Hamilton (1998 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 action movies, Swedish movies, Norwegian movies, Movies directed by Harald Zwart

Hamilton is a 1998 Swedish Norwegian action movie directed by Harald Zwart and starring Peter Stormare, Lena Olin, Mark Hamill, Mats Långbacka, Terry Carter.

[[Iran men's national handball team]]

CATEGORIES: National handball teams, Sport in Iran

The Iran national handball team is the national handball team of Iran and is controlled by the IR Iran Handball Federation.

[[Asian Men's Handball Championship]]

CATEGORIES: Asian Handball Championships, Asian championships

The Asian Handball Nations Championship is the official competition for senior national handball teams of Asia (since 2018, also includes teams from Oceania), and takes place every two years. In addition to crowning the Asian champions, the tournament also serves as a qualifying tournament for the World Championship.

[[Asian Handball Federation]]

CATEGORIES: Sports organizations, Handball, 1974 establishments in Asia

The Asian Handball Federation (AHF) (الاتحاد الآسيوي لكرة اليد) is the governing body of handball and beach handball in Asia. It has 44 member countries, mostly located on the Asian continent, but excludes the transcontinental countries with territory in both Europe and Asia – Azerbaijan, Georgia, Russian Federation and Turkey – which are instead members of European Handball Federation (EHF). Three other states located along the western fringe of Asia – Cyprus, Armenia and Israel – are also EHF members. Hong Kong China and Macau, although not independent countries (both are Special regions of China), are also members of the AHF.

One of IHF's six continental confederations, the AHF was formed officially on 26 August 1974 in Tehran (Imperial State of Iran), on the sidelines of the 7th Asian Games 1974. The AHF headquarters is located in Kuwait City (Kuwait). Its current President is Sheikh Ahmed Al-Fahad Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah from Kuwait who is a member of House of Sabah, the ruling family of Kuwait.

[[Asian Women's Handball Championship]]

CATEGORIES: Asian Handball Championships, Asian championships

The Asian Handball Nations Championship is the official competition for senior national handball teams of Asia (since 2018, also includes teams from Oceania) and takes place every two years. In addition to crowning the Asian champions, the tournament also serves as a qualifying tournament for the World Championship.

[[Handball at the Asian Games]]

CATEGORIES: Handball, Asian Games

Handball has been an Asian Games event since 1982 when the sport was first played in New Delhi, India.

[[Black List (1995 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 thriller movies, Canadian thriller movies, Movies directed by Jean-Marc Vallée

Black List (Liste noire) is a 1995 Canadian thriller movie directed by Jean-Marc Vallée and starring Michel Côté, Geneviève Brouillette, Sylvie Bourque, Jacques Galipeau.

[[The Harvest Month]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 drama movies, Finnish movies, Movies directed by Matti Kassila

The Harvest Month (Elokuu) is a 1956 Finnish drama movie directed by Matti Kassila and starring Toivo Mäkelä, Emma Väänänen, Rauni Luoma, Aino-Maija Tikkanen, Rauni Ikäheimo, Senni Nieminen, Heikki Savolainen, Sylvi Salonen, Olavi Ahonen.

[[The Magnificent Dope]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 movies, 1940s comedy movies, American comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Walter Lang

The Magnificent Dope is a 1942 American comedy movie directed by Walter Lang and starring Don Ameche, Henry Fonda, Lynn Bari, Edward Everett Horton, Frank Orth, Hobart Cavanaugh. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[John Thompson (basketball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Boston Celtics players, College basketball coaches, American sports commentators, Sportspeople from Washington, D.C.

John Robert Thompson Jr. (September 2, 1941 – August 30, 2020) was an American college basketball coach, player and sports commentator. He coached for the Georgetown Hoyas between 1972 to 1999.

In 1984, he became the first African-American head coach to win a major collegiate championship. During his basketball playing career, he played for the Boston Celtics. He was born in Washington, D.C..

Thompson was honored into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame on October 1, 1999.

Thompson died on August 30, 2020 in Arlington, Virginia at the age of 78.

[[21 Bridges]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 movies, American action thriller movies, Movies set in the United States

21 Bridges is a 2019 American action thriller movie directed by Brian Kirk. The movie stars Chadwick Boseman as an NYPD detective who shuts down the 21 bridges of Manhattan to find two suspected cop killers (Stephan James and Taylor Kitsch).

Sienna Miller, Keith David, and J. K. Simmons also star. Brothers Joe and Anthony Russo produce the movie.

21 Bridges was theatrically released in the United States on November 22, 2019 by STXfilms. It received mixed reviews from critics.

[[Russo brothers]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 1971 births, Living people, Duos, American movie actors, Movie directors from Ohio, Movie producers from Ohio, Screenwriters from Ohio, Actors from Cleveland, Ohio

Anthony Russo (born February 3, 1970) and Joseph Russo (born July 18, 1971) are American directors, producers, screenwriters, and actors. They direct most of their work together.

They are best known for directing four movies in the Marvel Cinematic Universe: Captain America: The Winter Soldier (2014), Captain America: Civil War (2016), Avengers: Infinity War (2018), and Avengers: Endgame (2019).

[[Amazon weasel]]

CATEGORIES: Mustelids, Mammals of South America

The Amazon weasel (Mustela africana), is a type of weasel. It is native to South America. It is also called the tropical weasel. It was first identified from a museum example that was not labeled well. The museum label said it was from Africa. That is why the scientific name is Mustela africana.

[[Stephan James]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Actors from Toronto

Stephan James (born December 16, 1993) is a Canadian actor. He is known for playing track and field sprinter Jesse Owens in the 2016 movie Race. He also played John Lewis in the 2014 drama Selma.

He also stars as Walter Cruz in the Amazon series Homecoming, for which he received a Golden Globe Award nomination. He also played Julian Williams on the Canadian teen drama Degrassi: The Next Generation.

[[Special functions]]

CATEGORIES: Functions and mappings

Special functions are some mathematical functions used in mathematical analysis or physics. Most of them appear in higher education. Some experts are studying numerical methods for them.

[[Ava DuVernay]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winners, 1972 births, Living people, Movie directors from California, Movie producers from California, Screenwriters from California, People from Long Beach, California

Ava Marie DuVernay (ˌ; born August 24, 1972) is an American filmmaker. 

For her work on Selma (2014), DuVernay became the first black woman to be nominated for a Golden Globe Award for Best Director, and also the first black female director to have her movie nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture. 

In 2017, she was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature for her movie 13th (2016).

DuVernay's 2018 Disney children's fantasy movie A Wrinkle in Time made her the first black woman to direct a live-action movie earning $100 million at U.S. box office.

[[Selma (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 drama movies, American drama movies, Martin Luther King Jr.

Selma is a 2014 historical drama movie directed by Ava DuVernay and written by Paul Webb. It is based on the 1965 Selma to Montgomery voting rights marches. 

The movie stars actors David Oyelowo as Martin Luther King Jr., Tom Wilkinson as President Lyndon B. Johnson, Tim Roth as George Wallace, Carmen Ejogo as Coretta Scott King, and Common as James Bevel.

It was released worldwide on January 9, 2015.

[[The Milk of Sorrow]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 drama movies, Peruvian movies, Spanish movies

The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada, The frightened teat) is a 2009 Peruvian Spanish drama movie directed by Claudia Llosa and starring Magaly Solier, Susi Sánchez, Efrain Solís. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 2010.

[[Lea Gottlieb]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 deaths, 1918 births

Lea Gottlieb ( Lea Gottlieb   Lea Gottlieb ; September 17, 1918 - November 17, 2012 ) is the founder of beach fashion. Lea Gottlieb was an Israeli fashion designer and businesswoman. Made a swimsuit, once a purely functional thing, a high fashion item.    

[[Mustapha Adib]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Ambassadors of Lebanon, Lebanese politicians

Mustapha Adib Abdul Wahed (مصطفى أديب) (born 30 August 1972) is a Lebanese diplomat, politician, researcher and academic. He has been the ambassador of Lebanon to Germany since 2013.

On 31 August 2020, he became Prime Minister-designate of Lebanon after being asked by President Michel Aoun to form a new government. Nearly a month later, on 26 September 2020, he stepped down from the role after failing to form a government.

[[Achaguas Municipality]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities, Venezuela

The Achaguas Municipality is one of the seven municipalities (municipios) that makes up the Venezuelan state of Apure has an area of 15,754 km². It has a population of 58,516. The town of Achaguas is the municipal seat of the Achaguas Municipality.

[[Gupabal station]]

Gupabal Station is on South Korea's Seoul metro line 3 railway service station. Some trains are finish driving at this station.

[[Jama Garad Ali]]

CATEGORIES: Somalia

Jama Garad Ali is the supreme garaad of the reer darawiish tribe. His crowning happened in the year 2006 in the town of Sahdheer. It was attended by elders of the reer darawiish tribe as well as well as others. When the supreme garaad of the reer darawiish is crowned, milk is poured over his head.

[[Lorentz National Park]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Indonesia, National parks in Asia

Lorentz National Park is a national park in Papua, Indonesia. It has an area of about 25056. It has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1999. The park is named after the Dutch explorer Hendrikus Albertus Lorentz. There are many ecosystems in the park with many types of animals and plants.

[[Arsenal W.F.C.]]

CATEGORIES: English football clubs

Arsenal Women Football Club is an English professional women's football club based in Islington, London, England that is affiliated with Arsenal. The club plays in the Women's Super League, the top flight of English women's football.

[[Manchester City W.F.C.]]

CATEGORIES: English football clubs

Manchester City Women's Football Club (formerly Manchester City Ladies F.C.) is an English women's football club based in Manchester who play in the FA Women's Super League. It is affiliated with Manchester City F.C. who play in the Premier League.

[[FA Women's Super League]]

CATEGORIES: Football in England, Women's football

The Football Association Women's Super League (FA WSL, or currently known as the Barclays FA Women's Super League for sponsorship reasons) is the highest league of women's football in England. Established in 2010, it is run by the Football Association and currently features 12 fully professional teams.

[[Liverpool F.C. Women]]

CATEGORIES: English football clubs

Liverpool Football Club Women is an English women's football club.

[[Ranoidea elkeae]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

Ranoidea elkeae is a tree frog from Indonesia. Scientists saw it near the Kalibum River.

[[Ranoidea eschata]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Australia

Ranoidea eschata is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  Scientists saw this frog on Rossel Island and Sudest Island, which are part of the Louisiade Archipelago.

[[Ecosia]]

CATEGORIES: Search engines

Ecosia is a search engine based in Berlin, Germany. Its profits are mainly given to nonprofit organizations for replanting trees. 

The description of the company show it is a social business. It keeps information about users safe. In April 2021, the company claims to have fully planted 124 million trees around the world.

[[Bad Mojo]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 video games, Adventure games

Bad Mojo is a computer game by Pulse Entertainment and Drew Pictures.  It was made in 1996.  In this game, an insect scientist named Roger is turned into a cockroach and must move through an old house back to his human body.  On the way, he learns his landlord Eddie's big secret. It was released on CD-ROM. Vincent Carrella and Phill Simon made the game.

[[Penelope Pussycat]]

CATEGORIES: Looney Tunes characters, Fictional cats, Fictional characters introduced in the 1940s

Penelope Pussycat is an animated cartoon cat shown in the Warner Bros. classic Looney Tunes. She is usually a non-speaker, though she meows and purrs. She was often called Penelope, Fifi, Fabrette and Le Cat. The name Penelope Pussycat was created under Warner Bros. for marketing.

Penelope first appeared in the 1949 animated short Scent-imental Reasons. That movie got an Academy Award.

Her first speaking role was Carrotblanca, a 1995 animated short movie.

[[Inka Bause]]

Inka Bause (born 21 November 1968 in Leipzig) is a German schlager singer, TV presenter and actress.

[[Converse]]

CATEGORIES: 1900s establishments in Massachusetts, 1908 establishments in the United States, American clothing companies, Footwear, Companies based in Massachusetts, Boston, Massachusetts

Converse is an American shoe company that sneakers, skating shoes, lifestyle brand footwear, apparel, and accessories.

[[Stephen A. Smith]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, American sports commentators, People from the Bronx, People from Queens

Stephen Anthony Smith (born October 14, 1967) is an American sports television personality, radio host and journalist. He works for ESPN. He is a commentator on ESPN's First Take. He is also an analyst for EPSN's SportsCenter and NBA Countdown.

Smith was born in the Bronx, New York City. He grew up in Hollis, Queens. His parents were from Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands.

[[Grana]]

CATEGORIES: Botany

Grana (Gra-nuh) are the thylakoid cell stacks in a chloroplast cell. Its singular name is "Granum". It is located in the stroma of the chloroplast.

[[Steppe polecat]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of Asia, Mammals of Europe, Mustelids

The steppe polecat (Mustela eversmanii), is a type of mustelid. It is also called the white or masked polecat. It is native to Central Europe, Eastern Europe and Central Asia. It is a Least Concern species. It is generally light yellowish, with dark limbs and a dark mask across the face.

[[Polynesian languages]]

CATEGORIES: Languages, Polynesia

The Polynesian languages are a group of languages spoken in Oceania. They all belong in the Malayo-Polynesian branch of the Austronesian languages. They are mostly spoken in Polynesia, but some are spoken in nearby Melanesia and Micronesia.

There are around 30-40 Polynesian languages, with Samoan having the most speakers. Other well-known Polynesian languages include Māori, Tongan, Hawaiian and Tahitian.

[[Donald Trump (disambiguation)]]

CATEGORIES: Human name disambiguation pages

Donald Trump (born June 14, 1946) is the 45th president of the United States, as well as an American businessman and television personality.

Donald Trump may also refer to:

[[R/The Donald]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 establishments in the United States, Donald Trump, 2020 disestablishments

r/The_Donald was a subreddit on Reddit where users created discussions and memes about U.S. president Donald Trump. It was first created in June 2015 following the announcement of Trump's presidential campaign, the group grew to over 790,000 people who call themselves as "Patriots." The group was banned in June 2020 for violating Reddit rules on harassment and targeting. It was one of the most active groups on Reddit.

[[GirlsDoPorn]]

CATEGORIES: Pornography, 2009 establishments in California, 2020 disestablishments, Sexual abuse, American websites, San Diego, California

GirlsDoPorn was an American pornographic website active between 2009 and 2020. It was based in San Diego, California. It shut down because six people from the site were charged with sex trafficking, fraud, and coercion in November 2019. Two more people were charged with preventing police from stopping sex trafficking in December 2019.  The website shut down in January 2020.  The United States Department of Justice said that the website and its sister website, GirlsDoToys, had earned over $17 million.

[[Hector the Bulldog]]

CATEGORIES: Looney Tunes characters, Fictional dogs, Fictional characters introduced in the 1940s

Hector the Bulldog is an animated cartoon character in Warner Bros. Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies series of cartoons. Hector is a muscular bulldog and walks pigeon-toed. He often wears a black collar with silver studs.

Hector first appeared in Peck up Your Troubles (1945). In this movie, he stops Sylvester the Cat from getting a woodpecker. In A Hare Grows in Manhattan, he leads a street gang of dogs. However, his usual role is protecting Tweety Bird from Sylvester and other danger. Granny is the owner of Hector.

[[Norm Spencer]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Actors from Vancouver, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors, Canadian movie actors

Norman Spencer (February 23, 1958 – August 31, 2020) was a Canadian actor and voice actor best known for his portrayal of the Marvel Comics character Cyclops in X-Men: The Animated Series and the Marvel vs. Capcom video games.

[[Bukit Kutu]]

CATEGORIES: Ghost towns, Towns in Asia, Settlements in Malaysia

Bukit Kutu or Treacher Hill is a ghost town located on a mountain in Selangor, Malaysia. It is a town no one lives anymore. It was classified as secondary hill station by Aiken due to no growth happens in this town.

The place name Treacher Hill comes from the former British Resident of Selangor, William Hood Treacher, while other name Bukit Kutu comes from Orang Asli people who say that the road is too long until say "Kutu". "Kutu" in Malay language means flea and "Bukit" means hill, hence it is called as "flea hill".

The town was opened in 1893 and this town only have two bungalows. It is damaged by Japanese army with bomb during World War II. After that, no one live in this town anymore. Chimney is the only thing that still standing in this town. The chimney is used to be a bungalow owned by Tom Sargent, construction engineer for Federated Malay States Railway. The town has now very popular for hikers to walk in the route.

[[Filiz Aker]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2017 deaths, Turkish movie actors, Actors from Istanbul

Filiz Aker (20 August 1963 - 27 August 2017) was a Turkish movie actress.

Aker died on 27 August 2017, aged 54. Three day later, she was buried at Tuzla Cemetery in Istanbul.

[[Robert J. Sunell]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, American generals, People from Oregon

Robert John Sunell  (5 June 1929 – 8 August 2020) was a major general in the United States Army. He was Program Manager of Tank Systems for the United States Army Tank-Automotive Command. Sunell was born in Astoria, Oregon. He served on the U.S. Army between 1953 to 1988.

Sunell died on 8 August 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Robert Williams (psychologist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, American educators, American psychologists, Scientists from Arkansas, People from Little Rock, Arkansas

Robert Lee Williams II (February 20, 1930 – August 12, 2020) was an American professor emeritus of psychology and African and Afro-American studies at the Washington University in St. Louis. He was born in Little Rock, Arkansas.

He was a well known person in the history of African-American Psychology.  He was well known as a critic of racial and cultural biases in IQ testing. He created the Black Intelligence Test of Cultural Homogeneity. He was a founding member of the Association of Black Psychologists, and served as its second president.

Williams died on August 12, 2020 in St. Louis, Missouri at the age of 90.

[[Ralph Ferguson]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Ontario

Ralph Ferguson, CAN (September 13, 1929sndAugust 30, 2020) was a Canadian farmer and politician. He was born in Ontario. He was first elected to the House of Commons of Canada in the 1980 federal election as the Liberal Member of Parliament (MP) for Lambton--Middlesex.

He lost his MP re-election in 1984 and was re-elected in 1988 and retired in 1993. During the John Turner cabinet, he was Minister of Agriculture.

Ferguson died on August 30, 2020, at age 90.

[[Ángel Faus Belau]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish journalists, Spanish educators

Angel Faus Belau (9 February 1936 – 30 August 2020) was a Spanish journalist and educator. He was born in Villarreal, Province of Castellón. He was a communications professor at the University of Navarra. He was a well known expert of European radio communication. He was a member of the Academia Española de la Radio.

Faus Belau died on 30 August 2020 in Castellón de la Plana at the age of 84.

[[Jacques Galipeau]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Canadian comedians, Actors from Montreal

Jacques Galipeau (22 September 1923 – 30 August 2020) was a Canadian actor and comedian. He was born in Montreal. 

Galipeau was known for his roles in Beau temps, mauvais temps (1955), Les Belles Histoires des pays d'en haut (1969), The Pyx (1973), La Petite Patrie (1974), Bingo (1974), Duplessis (1977), He Shoots, He Scores (1991), Black List (1995), Set Me Free (1999) and Chaos and Desire (2002).

Galipeau died on 30 August 2020, aged 96.

[[Nina Bocharova]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Soviet Olympic gold medalists, Soviet Olympic silver medalists, Ukrainian sportspeople

Nina Antonovna Bocharova (Ніна Антонівна Бочарова, September 24, 1924 – August 31, 2020) was a Soviet-Ukrainian gymnast. He won four medals at the 1952 Summer Olympics, two gold and silver. She was born in Suprunivka, Poltava Oblast, Ukrainian SSR, Soviet Union.

Bocharova died on August 31, 2020 in Rome, aged 95.

[[Motorcycle speedway]]

CATEGORIES: Motorcycles

Motorcycle speedway, usually referred to as speedway, is a motorcycle sport involving four and sometimes up to six riders competing over four anti-clockwise laps of an oval circuit.

[[A Twelve-Year Night]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 drama movies, Uruguayan movies, Spanish movies, Argentine movies, French drama movies, German drama movies, Movies directed by Álvaro Brechner

A Twelve-Year Night (La noche de 12 años) is a 2018 Uruguayan Spanish Argentine French German drama movie directed by Álvaro Brechner and starring Antonio de la Torre, Chino Darín, Alfonso Tort, César Troncoso, Soledad Villamil.

[[Jerzy Szczakiel]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Polish sportspeople

Jerzy Szczakiel (28 January 1949 – 1 September 2020) was a Polish Speedway rider. He was one of three Polish nationals to win the Speedway World Championship. He won the championship in 1973. He was born in Grudzice, Poland.

Szczakiel died on 1 September 2020 in Paris, aged 71.

[[Jack Danzey]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Australian rugby league players, Sportspeople from Sydney

Jack Danzey Jr. (14 February 1941 – 31 August 2020) was an Australian professional rugby league footballer, referee and administrator. He played in the NSWRFL Premiership for the Newtown, Balmain and Cronulla-Sutherland clubs during the 1960s. His career lasted from 1960 to 1968. He was born in Sydney.

Danzey died on 31 August 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Vladislav Krapivin]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Russian novelists, Children's writers, Russian journalists, Deaths from pneumonia

Vladislav Petrovich Krapivin (Владислав Петрович Крапивин; 14 October 1938 – 1 September 2020) was a Russian children's books writer. He was born in Tyumen, then-Soviet Union. He began working for Ural Pathfinder newspapers. Many of his books were published by Sverdlovsk Publishing House. His best known books were Meet My Brother (1968) and August: The Month of the Winds (1975).

Krapivin was hospitalized for pneumonia on 10 August 2020 in Yekaterinburg, Russia. He died on 1 September 2020, aged 81.

[[Tomomi Inada]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, Japanese politicians

Tomomi Inada is a Japanese lawyer and politician. She has been a member of the Japanese House of Representatives, representing the 1st Fukui Prefecture since September 2005.  

She was the 14th Japanese Minister of Defense from August 2016 to July 2017. She spent time as the Chairwoman of the Policy Research Council of the Liberal Democratic Party in her fourth term as a member of the House of Representatives in the Diet.

[[Shigeru Ishiba]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, Japanese politicians

Shigeru Ishiba is a Japanese politician. Ishiba is a member of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and of Heisei-Kenkyukai (part of the party faction led by Fukushiro Nukaga) until 2011. 

Ishiba was Director General of the Japan Defense Agency under Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi from 2002 to 2004. 

He was Minister of Defense under Yasuo Fukuda from 2007 to 2008 and Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries under Tarō Asō from 2008 to 2009. The LDP lost government in 2009, entering Opposition. 

In August 2020, he announced his candidacy for the Liberal Democratic leadership election to replace Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. He lost the election on 14 September to Yoshihide Suga, coming in third place.

[[The Comey Rule]]

CATEGORIES: Donald Trump, American drama television series

The Comey Rule is an upcoming American miniseries based on the book A Higher Loyalty by former FBI director James Comey.

The show is about FBI director James Comey as he serves under the new president of the United States Donald Trump.

It was announced in October 2019 that Billy Ray was to write and direct a miniseries produced by CBS Television Studios. Jeff Daniels will play James Comey and Brendan Gleeson playing Donald Trump. Michael Kelly, Jennifer Ehle, Holly Hunter, Steven Pasquale, Oona Chaplin, Scoot McNairy, William Sadler and T. R. Knight will also star with Peter Coyote cast as Robert Mueller. 

In June 2020, the series was revealed to be named The Comey Rule and will consist of two episodes totalling four hours. 

It will premiere over two nights on September 27 and 28, 2020.

[[Douglas McIlroy]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Unix, Commons category link is on Wikidata

[[Colombian weasel]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of South America, Mustelids

The Colombian weasel (Mustela felipei), is a very rare type of weasel. It is also called the Don Felipe's weasel. It is only known from the departments of Huila and Cauca in Colombia and nearby northern Ecuador. The Colombian weasel is only known from one Colombian weasel.

It only lives in riparian habitats at an altitude of 1,100 to 2,700 m (3,600 to 8,900 ft). There is lots of deforestation in the riparian habitats in the northern Andes of Colombia and Ecuador. There is less than 10 known dead Colombian weasels that were studied. It is could be the rarest carnivore in South America. It is a vulnerable species.

It is the second-smallest living carnivore on average. The upperparts and tail are blackish-brown, while the underparts are orange-buff.

The first photo of a living Colombian weasel was taken in 2011 by an amateur naturalist who found one trapped in his parents' house; the weasel later escaped. The image was uploaded to iNaturalist in 2018. It gained widespread attention.

[[Long-tailed weasel]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of North America, Mammals of South America, Mustelids

The long-tailed weasel (Mustela frenata), is a type of mustelid. It is also called the bridled weasel or big stoat. It lives in southern Canada throughout all the United States and Mexico, through all of Central America and northern South America.

[[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Presidents of the United Arab Emirates, Current national leaders

Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan (born 25 January 1948) is the current President of the United Arab Emirates, Emir of Abu Dhabi, and commander of the UAE Armed Forces.

[[Tarun Gogoi]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Indian politicians

Tarun Gogoi  (11 October 1934 – 23 November 2020) was an Indian politician. He was the Chief Minister of Assam from 2001 to 2016. 

He was a member of the Indian National Congress and led the party to a record three consecutive electoral victories in Assam.

On 26 August 2020, Gogoi was hospitalized with COVID-19 and was given a blood plasma transplant in Guwahati, Assam. He died three months later on 23 November from problems caused by the infection, aged 86.

[[Garaad Abdiqani]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2006 deaths, Somali politicians

Garaad Abdiqani was the twentieth garaad guud of the reer darawiish tribe. This means he was the 20th supreme chieftain of the reer darawiish tribe. During his term, he promoted peace between the Hashi Faction, a Warsangeli and Dhulbahante alliance, and SNM, another Somali group. The line of succession returned to the Baharsame lineage after Diiriye Guure became garaad guud of Dhulbahante when Diiriye Guure became Sultan of both Dhulbahante and Darawiish.

[[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian musicians, Indian singers, Indian movie actors, Indian voice actors, Indian movie producers, Record producers, Indian businesspeople, Bollywood playback singers

Sripathi Panditaradhyula Balasubrahmanyam (4 June 1946 – 25 September 2020), also known as S. P. Bala, S. P. B., or Balu, was an Indian musician, playback singer, music director, actor, and movie producer. His works were in Telugu, Tamil, Kannada, Hindi and Malayalam. He has recorded over 40,000 songs in 16 Indian languages.

He held the Guinness World Record for recording the highest number of songs by a singer with over 40,000 songs. He was born in Nellore, Madras Presidency, British India.

He was honored with the Padma Shri (2001) and Padma Bhushan (2011) from the Government of India.

On 5 August 2020, Balasubrahmanyam tested positive for COVID-19 and was hospitalized in Chennai. A week later, he was in critical condition and put on life-support. He tested negative for COVID-19 on September 7, but still remained on life support. However, on September 24, his condition became critical again and he was put on maximum life support again. He died the following day from the post-COVID complications on 25 September, aged 74.

[[Miloš Říha]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Czech ice hockey players, Ice hockey coaches

Miloš Říha (6 December 1958 – 31 August 2020) was a Czech ice hockey player and coach. He coached the Czech national team at the 2019 IIHF World Championship. He was born in Přerov, Czechoslovakia. He played as a Forward left.

His played career lasted from 1976 to 1991. He was the 196th overall pick for the Minnesota North Stars. During his career, he played for the Czech teams HC ZUBR Přerov, HC Dukla Jihlava, HC Vítkovice Ridera, PSG Berani Zlín, HC Kometa Brno and SHK Hodonin.

Říha died on 31 August 2020 at a hospital in Prague, aged 61.

[[Barbara Judge]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Cancer deaths in London, American lawyers, American chief executives, British lawyers, Bankers, Businesspeople from New York City, Businesspeople from London

Barbara Thomas Judge, Lady Judge, CBE (née Singer; 28 December 1946 – 31 August 2020), previously known as Barbara Singer Thomas, was an American-British lawyer and businesswoman. She was the first female chairman of the Institute of Directors. She was made chair in 2015.

In 2018, she was suspended from the Institute of Directors after people accused her of being sexist and racist.

Judge was born in New York City. She studied at the University of Pennsylvania and at New York University. She was married to Sir Paul Judge between 2002 until his death in 2017.

Judge died on 31 August 2020 from pancreatic cancer in London, aged 73.

[[Campino (candy)]]

CATEGORIES: Candy

Campino is a brand of hard candy made by August Storck KG. It is made using a mix of yogurt and fruits that has varied since the product was released in 1966. Until 2007, only two versions were available: strawberry and summer fruits (a mixed bag of raspberry, blackcurrant and peach). In 2007, a strawberry, cherry, and peach version was released. Campino candies are no longer available in the United Kingdom, but are available in the United States and Canada.

[[Toffifee]]

CATEGORIES: Candy

Toffifee (known in the United States as Toffifay) is a German brand of caramel candies owned by the Berlin-based German company August Storck KG. Toffifee are caramel cups with nougat, caramel and a hazelnut inside, and a chocolate button on top. They are sold in boxes containing 4, 12, 15, 24, 30, 48 or 96 Toffifee candies. 

The product was first sold in West Germany in 1973, and was marketed as a product "for the whole family". By 2016, Toffifee was being sold in over 100 countries. In the United States, Toffifee is spelt "Toffifay" and uses a different package design. Elsewhere in the world, including in Canada and Europe, the brand uses its original spelling and orange box design.

[[Institute of Directors]]

CATEGORIES: 1903 establishments in the United Kingdom

The Institute of Directors (IoD) is a business organisation for company directors, senior business leaders and entrepreneurs. It is the UK’s longest running organisation for professional leaders. It was founded in 1903. The IoD's goal is to create "free enterprise, entrepreneurialism, wealth creation and good corporate governance".

The current chair of the IoD is Charlotte Valeur.

[[Spaghetti Junction]]

CATEGORIES: Motorways in the United Kingdom, Birmingham

Spaghetti Junction is a motorway interchange in Birmingham, England. It is junction 6 of the M6 motorway. 

The junction's official name is Gravelly Hill Interchange, but this name is not used very often. The junction links the M6 with the A38(M) motorway which passes through Birmingham. The interchange was opened in 24 May 1972, and was given its popular name by local journalists.

The junction covers 30 acres, serves 18 routes and includes 4 km (2.5 miles) of slip roads. There are five levels, and it flies over two railway lines, three canals and two rivers. It took nearly four years to build it, against an estimated three years. It cost £8 million, which is a deceptively small amount. It can only be understood by realising the extent of monetary inflation during the past half century.

The junction has had a lot of repair work done a number of times since it was built. There is very heavy traffic through the junction, and there were some alleged cost-saving measures during its construction.
